HEADLINE: The Vanishing Economists

 BODY:
Re "A Doctorate Too Dry for Its Own Good" (Economic View, April 11), about students' declining interest in becoming Ph.D. economists:
One reason for the decline is a sharp drop in the value that many corporations attach to the degree. In the early 1980's, armed with a master's in economics, I entered a typical corporate economists' shop. Seeing my company's (and other companies') declining interest in economics as a profession and facing the need for a Ph.D. to further my economics career, I chose instead to take another opportunity in the company, in marketing. Since then, the five-person department in which I worked has been dissolved. 
 A combination of 60's-bred hubris about economists' abilities and an overemphasis on highly technical, impractical training has put the corporate economist to pasture in too many places. While I have been happy with my marketing path, I am saddened that a discipline with so much to offer is so poorly received in most boardrooms.
 
PATRICK J. CASEY
Jacksonville, Fla., April 11

HEADLINE: DATABANK: MAY 3-7;
Investors Ask: Where to Go From Here?

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE 

 BODY:
Markets around the world have been on pins and needles awaiting guidance from the United States. As overseas investors watched the week's divergent paths, they might have thought they had come upon a one-way sign with arrows pointing in opposite directions.
First, the Dow Jones industrial average crossed 11,000 on Monday, sending shares higher overseas. 
 Then, on Thursday, the Dow, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index and the Nasdaq fell on revived fears of tighter credit. Investors in the United States and in Europe and Asia reacted to a warning by Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, that inflationary pressures could re-emerge.
 A report on Friday that unemployment in the United States had edged higher assuaged those inflationary concerns for the moment, causing an uptick in American and European markets. This economy is still in the sweet spot, Robert Freedman, executive vice president for the John Hancock Funds in Boston, told The Associated Press on Friday.
 In the end, the Dow set a new record, closing up 2.2 percent for the week, at 11,031.59. The S.& P. rose frac-tionally, and the Nasdaq fell 1.5 percent, to 2,503.62. Stocks overseas were mixed. MICKEY MEECE

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: MONTENEGRO;
Air War Hurts Stability Of a Yugoslav Republic

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA 

DATELINE: CETINJE, Montenegro, May 7

 BODY:
It was a beguiling promise, "To Live Better," that helped Montenegro's governing coalition win power last year. But few people in this ancient city would say their lives are better now than before.
The sprawling OBOD electronics plant here, which employs 2,500 people, has been shut down completely since NATO's bombardment of Serbia cut off the market where 90 percent of the plant's air-conditioners, washing machines and refrigerators were sold. 
 The last time workers were paid was in February, and what they received then was December's salary. With no money circulating, small shopkeepers like Marko Stevov Kaludjerovic have had to extend credit to so many people that they too are in danger of going under. "Then they can count me as another casualty of the war," Mr. Kaludjerovic said.
The economy of Montenegro -- which is joined with Serbia in the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia -- was already severely weakened before the bombardment began. And although Montenegro has never recognized Belgrade's declaration that a state of war now exists, it has suffered several NATO bombardments that have shocked and angered residents who thought they would be protected because of Montenegro's fledgling connections to the West.
Add to that volatile mix the economic disruptions and problems sure to be caused by the recently imposed embargo on oil for Serbia coming through Montenegro's Adriatic ports, and the stress fractures challenging the tiny republic's stability threaten to break wide open.
Government officials here acknowledge the danger. They believe civil authority is already being undermined by aggressive moves of the Yugoslav Army in Montenegro and the agitation of opposition forces loyal to President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia.
While it struggles to check the army's moves, the Government of Montenegro's President, Milo Djukanovic, fears an economic collapse could undermine whatever support it retains. Unemployment has soared to as much as 50 percent, and more than 60 percent of all 635,000 residents of Montenegro may be eligible to receive some Government payment of social assistance -- if the Government has the money to pay.
Things will only get worse. The important tourism season has been wiped out with the NATO assaults, and the closing of the major Adriatic seaport of Bar by the Yugoslav Navy means shortages are likely.
The Government has appealed to the West for help. The United States provided $10 million in aid last month to help the Government meet some salary and pension obligations, and the European Union has promised $13.86 million to cover some of the cost of caring for the thousands of Kosovo Albanians who have sought refuge here.
But the Government fears the West does not understand the urgency of Montenegro's problems.
"Unless we have more help," Vojin Djukanovic, Minister of the Economy, said in an interview in the capital, Podgorica, "there will be a civil war here."
The minister, no relation to President Djukanovic, a former Deputy Prime Minister of the federal Government in Belgrade until he was dismissed by Mr. Milosevic last May, said that pro-Milosevic forces were using Montenegro's economic problems to foment dissent and lay the ground work for a coup. He estimates it would take $100 million in loans and credits to enable Montenegro to survive the current crisis without forfeiting the democratic advances it has made since President Djukanovic was elected in 1997, and his coalition won parliamentary elections last summer.
"The tragedy of our day is that the West has been opening the port of Bar, and now the Yugoslav Army is closing it," Vojin Djukanovic said, referring to Montenegro's main Adriatic port.
The Government's hope is that the people of Montenegro will be patient, and not catch war fever.
"People in Montenegro are not living better, that's quite correct," said Bozidar Jaredic, the Government's Minister of Information. "But the majority of people in Montenegro can understand the current circumstances and they can see the Government and Parliament are doing all they can."
While the people of Montenegro may not yet have reached their breaking point, they are showing strains. Radojica Radosevic, a jeweler in downtown Podgorica, said business has dropped by 70 percent since the NATO attacks began and the shop he has owned for 25 years is now empty most of the time.
"No one has been receiving their salaries on time so people just don't have enough money," Mr. Radosevic said as workmen installed a new folding metal security gate over the front window of his shop. He said it was a precautionary measure, against increasingly desperate times. "To be honest, I don't know much longer it can go on," he said.
Montenegrins joke that with the port blocked, the airports closed and border crossings often slammed shut, their country -- long known for the stunning beauty of its mountains and seaside -- has become "the world's most beautiful prison."
Few places though may be under as much pressure as Cetinje, where practically every family has suffered because of the closing of the giant OBOD factory.
"Since January, I've worked only 20 days," said Kice Pejovic, a mother of two sons who has been employed at the assembly plant for 12 years. She said the family survived on the food it grows in a small garden, and the milk it gets from a cow it keeps nearby. They cannot remember the last time any one of them bought clothes. "It's very hard, and every day it seems to get worse," she said.
No one is suggesting that the NATO assaults caused all of Montenegro's economic problems. The OBOD plant is 45 years old and has never been modernized. Productivity is still measured on Communist-era scales, and the product line has not been updated for years.
But Branislav Basovic, the general manager, said things would have been much better if the West had not failed to take full account of Montenegro's democratic opening.
For instance, he said, the sanctions imposed on Yugoslavia earlier this decade dried up the small, but important, export market OBOD had developed with Western Europe and the United States. Now, he said, practically all exports -- which constitute 90 percent of the factory's output when it is operating -- go to Serbia.

LENGTH: 492 words

HEADLINE: Study Finds Some Strategies That Help Poor Students Learn

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
Low-income students are making significant academic gains in schools with educational strategies that include higher standards and more personal instruction, parent involvement and teacher accountability, according to reports made public this week.
Education Trust, a nonprofit organization in Washington that seeks to improve education for the poor, based its conclusions on a survey of 366 elementary and secondary schools, in 21 states, that had scored above average on standardized math and reading tests but had poverty levels of more than 50 percent -- that is, at least half of the students received free or reduced-price lunches. 
 After adopting new teaching approaches, Public School 72 in Buffalo displayed dramatic improvements in reading. Ninety-five percent scored at or above grade level in the 1996-1997 school year, compared with the New York State average of 86.1 percent. The previous school year, it had reported a score of 45 percent, against a state average of 83.1 percent.
In Gary, Ind., the Arthur Melton Elementary School stood out for its math and reading scores, with 78 percent of students reading at or above grade level, compared with the state average of 68 percent, and 91 percent in math, compared with 70 percent.
Shallow Water Elementary School in Shallow Water, Kan., saw its scores improve to 80 percent from 50 percent in math, compared with state averages of about 45 percent for 1996 and 1997.
The trust found that the schools that are doing well or have improved shared five characteristics: increased learning time for reading and math; money devoted to continuing education for teachers and staff members; systems to monitor student progress and provide extra help; efforts to involve parents in the day-to-day learning process, and state or district accountability requirements for teachers and the staff if students fail to show measurable improvement.
"Poor kids can achieve at high levels if we teach them at high levels," said Kati Haycock, the director of Education Trust. "What remains to be done is for more schools to do what these schools have proven can be done."
Another study, conducted by the Education Trust and the Kentucky Association of School Councils, found that several schools in Kentucky with a high level of poor students achieved the highest scores on the state's standardized tests in 1998. The study found that as a result of new teaching and administrative methods, 5 of the 20 elementary schools with the highest reading scores were low-income schools, as were 6 of the 20 with the highest math scores and 13 of the 20 with the highest writing scores.
"Every child can learn," said Bob Sexton, the director of the Prichard Committee for Academic Excellence in Lexington, Ky., an advocacy group seeking education improvements in Kentucky. "The socio-economic barrier can be overcome with the pursuit of high standards for every child. But we have a long way to go."

HEADLINE: Many States Slow to Use Children's Insurance Fund

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
States are using less than 20 percent of the Federal money that Congress made available, with much fanfare, for a big new program to subsidize health insurance for children in low-income families.
Some states say they cannot find enough eligible uninsured children to use all the money they are entitled to receive. Critics say many states have been slow to reach out to eligible children and sign them up. 
 The program's slow start and the accumulation of unspent money are tempting Republicans in Congress to take back some of the money and use it for other purposes -- an idea vehemently opposed by Democrats, by advocates for children and by governors of both parties.
Senator John D. Rockefeller 4th, the West Virginia Democrat who helped create the Children's Health Insurance Program in 1997, said, "The Appropriations Committee is looking at the unused money for other projects." He objects to such a shift.
Elaina J. Fox, a spokeswoman for West Virginia's new child health program, said, "A majority of states will probably not be able to utilize their full allotments" of Federal money.
Governors are enthusiastic about the program, and tens of thousands of children have clearly benefited. But Representative Diana DeGette, Democrat of Colorado, said some states, including her own, had "an abysmal record" of finding uninsured children and enrolling them in the new program.
Congress provided $39 billion for the program over 10 years, including $4.2 billion a year in 1998 and 1999. Federal officials said states had used $260 million through December 1998 and $115 million in the first three months of this year. The Congressional Budget Office estimates that states will use a total of $800 million this year.
States say they have enrolled one million youngsters in the new program. But Federal officials and health policy experts say the numbers are somewhat misleading.
Nearly 30 percent of the million children are in New York State, and 176,000 of the New York children were already in a state-financed program, Child Health Plus, often described by Federal officials as a model for the nation.
Moreover, Frank C. Ullman, a health policy expert at the Urban Institute here, said, "The decrease in Medicaid enrollment in many states is greater than the increase in coverage through the new Children's Health Insurance Program." So it is unclear, he added, whether there has been a net reduction in the number of uninsured children -- one of the main goals for President Clinton and Congress.
The number of children without health insurance has been creeping up in recent years and is now at least 10.7 million, the Census Bureau says.
Under Federal law, children eligible for Medicaid may not be enrolled in the new Children's Health Insurance Program. Medicaid is intended for families with somewhat lower incomes. States are supposed to screen children and enroll them in Medicaid if they qualify for it.
But states have a strong financial incentive to put children into the new program, rather than in Medicaid, because the Federal Government pays a larger share of the costs -- 65 percent, rather than 50 percent, in high-income states like New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
The children's health plan was forged in a bipartisan agreement between the President and Congress. When he signed the legislation in August 1997, Mr. Clinton said it would extend insurance coverage "to up to five million children." He called it "the largest expansion in health care for children" in three decades.
Bruce D. Lesley, director of Congressional relations at the National Association of Children's Hospitals, said: "The results to date have been mixed. Some states like South Carolina have done an unbelievably good job of enrolling children in the new health insurance program. Other states like Virginia are not doing so well. In these states, parents who need to know about the new program have no idea that it exists."
South Carolina simplified its enrollment process, disseminated applications at drug stores, day care centers, schools, churches and Indian reservations and signed up 40,400 children for the new program. By reaching out to low-income families, the state also found 46,000 other children who were eligible for its pre-existing Medicaid program.
By contrast, Amy M. Atkinson, a spokeswoman for the Virginia Department of Medical Assistance Services, said her state had enrolled 8,599 children in the new insurance program, including only 71 in Richmond, through May 3.
Senator Charles S. Robb, Democrat of Virginia, said, "My state has not been as quick off the mark as others have."
Edward J. Rogan, a spokesman for the New Jersey Department of Human Services, said the state had enrolled 30,232 children in its new health program, known as Kid Care, and expected to spend $19 million of its $88 million Federal allotment this year.
Connecticut has enrolled 8,000 children and expects to spend $5.4 million of its $35 million Federal allotment this year, said David Dearborn, a spokesman for the Connecticut Department of Social Services. As a side benefit, he said, in reaching out to low-income families, the state has found several thousand children eligible for its Medicaid program.
Auditors in some states said some children enrolled in the new program were probably ineligible and should have been enrolled instead in the regular Medicaid program.
In welfare, a separate program, states have also allowed substantial amounts of Federal money to go unspent. They say they are keeping it for a rainy day, in case the economy sputters.
But that concern does not explain delays in spending money on health insurance for children. Officials in many states said they had only recently begun to enroll children because they first had to design new health programs, get Federal approval, prepare application forms, set up toll-free telephone lines, print posters and run advertising to publicize the availability of the new benefits.
Judith A. Arnold, deputy commissioner of the New York Health Department, said, "Congress should be patient with states that seem to be moving slowly."
The Federal Government has approved children's health plans for every state except Tennessee, Washington and Wyoming.
State officials told Congress in 1997 that they needed the maximum latitude to design their own programs because they knew best how to meet the health needs of uninsured children.
But in a curious way, the law penalized states that had already expanded Medicaid eligibility by increasing the permissible income for families seeking coverage. Such states included Minnesota, Vermont and Washington.
In Washington State, for example, Medicaid covers children whose family incomes are up to twice the official poverty level (up to $27,760 a year for a family of three). Since those children are eligible for Medicaid, they may not enroll in the new Children's Health Insurance Program.
Under Federal law, Washington may use its share of the new Federal money -- $46 million a year -- for children of families with incomes up to 2.5 times the poverty level.
But Thomas W. Bedell, acting director of the Medicaid program in Washington State, said: "We won't be able to spend our full allotment of Federal money. We have only 10,000 uninsured children with family incomes from 200 to 250 percent of the poverty level. We estimate that we can spend only $7.5 million of our Federal money in the next year and a half."
Likewise, Gov. Howard Dean of Vermont, a Democrat, said the law penalized "states like Vermont that have served as national leaders in expanding health care coverage."
Mr. Ullman of the Urban Institute said: "In theory, there's enough money to cover five million children a year in the initial years of the new Children's Health Insurance Program. But only 3.2 million uninsured children live in families with the proper income to qualify."
Other children might benefit, because they lack health insurance, but their family incomes are too low or too high to qualify for coverage under the new program, Mr. Ullman said.
Money earmarked for a particular year remains available in the two subsequent years. But Federal officials said some states were building up huge reserves because they would not come close to spending their allotments of Federal money in the early years of the program.

HEADLINE: City Seeks Private Development for Randalls Island

BYLINE: By DOUGLAS MARTIN 

 BODY:
New York City is asking private companies to suggest commercial development proposals for Randalls Island to help pay for a $200 million renovation of the park there.
"We want to see who's out there to invest," Deputy Mayor Randy L. Levine said. 
 The city's goal, according to a public notice to be published today, is the "creation of a dynamic urban park" on land that has been a scruffy, rather forgotten piece of the city -- despite its central location in the East River between Manhattan, Queens and the Bronx.
Mr. Levine said the idea was to work from a master plan developed over the last two years by the Randalls Island Sports Foundation, a seven-year-old private support group, modeled after the Central Park Conservancy, that has raised more than $2 million for the park.
Most of the group's focus has been on recreation and creating new ball fields in the 480-acre park. It hopes to get private developers to pay for building and operating costs in the same manner that Chelsea Piers contributes to the new Hudson River Park in Manhattan.
In essence, the city is trying to fulfill the dreams of Robert Moses, who, as City Parks Commissioner, filled in the gap between Randalls and Wards Islands and prepared a comprehensive development plan in the mid-1930's. Despite Mr. Moses' construction of Downing Stadium -- where Jesse Owens qualified for the 1936 Olympics, Pele played his first American soccer game and Jimi Hendrix and Pearl Jam have performed -- the area never achieved its potential. There was no way to water the 27 baseball fields, for example.
But under Mr. Moses the park did emerge from its role as the site of the city's cemetery for the indigent and an asylum for the poor and troubled.
Today, youth and adult softball and soccer leagues throng to the island, and a golf driving range and miniature golf course have been added in recent years. On a nice summer day, 50,000 people visit.
Many of the visitors come to picnic beneath a spectacular view of the Manhattan skyline, or walk on nature trails where they sometimes spot pheasants. Events held on the island range from the Lollapalooza music festival to the Black Rodeo.
The project envisioned in the master plan carries an estimated price of $200 million, but the foundation's chairman, Richard J. Davis, said the project would likely proceed in segments. Ideally, he said, the initial segment would cost about $70 million and include the big indoor athletic buildings envisioned. But he said entrepreneurs' specific ideas will determine priorities and timing.
Among other things, the foundation's plan calls for replacing Downing Stadium with an amphitheater and festival grounds; building or upgrading 32 softball fields and 23 soccer fields, and building a field house for indoor athletic events and a 400-meter outdoor track.
Also in the plan are a tennis and skating center, a water park and an area for such alternative sports as in-line skating and kayaking. Wetlands and other natural areas would be enhanced and protected; trails for walking, horse-back riding and bicycling would be laid, and new marinas, ferry terminals and restaurants would be built.
Mr. Levine said the specific ideas provided by entrepreneurs could re-shape the plan. "Instead of doing it piecemeal, we would like to come up with a comprehensive plan," he said. "This is an opportunity to put flesh on the bone."
The process is the same as the city is using for Governors Island, though Mr. Levine says the city has more control over Randalls Island because it owns it. President Clinton has agreed to give Governors Island to the city only if it can come up with an acceptable plan to use it.
Giuliani administration officials say that interest in Governors Island has come from universities, museums, hotel developers and amusement park operators, including Tivoli Gardens of Denmark (whose representatives have also visited Randalls Island). Gambling, once the favored option for Governors Island, has been ruled out, they said.
Park advocates say they support bringing private developers into the Randalls Island park in a way that would be unacceptable in a historical treasure such as Central Park. They also point out that almost everything in the remodeled park would remain free to all.
"They're not turning the park over to anybody," said Marcia Reiss, policy director for the Parks Council, a research and advocacy group. "They are very clear they want it to be open to everybody."
The request for ideas is being handled by the city's Economic Development Corporation. The corporation can legally negotiate deals directly with companies, rather than going through the longer and more formal request for proposals required of other city agencies, Mr. Davis said.
Mr. Davis said one of the park's biggest problems, inadequate bus service, may be solved as the grounds are spiffed up. He predicted that more buses would be assigned, just as they were to Riverbank State Park in Harlem.
"Randalls Island will become a destination," he said.

HEADLINE: May 2-8;
Beware the Scarf in Parliament

BYLINE: By STEPHEN KINZER

 BODY:
At its first meeting, Turkey's newly elected Parliament turned not to pressing problems like inflation, human rights or educational reform, but to the question of the Muslim head scarf. The chamber erupted in pandemonium as Merve Kavakci, an American-educated deputy from Istanbul, sought unsuccessfully to take her oath of office while wearing a scarf.
She was harshly denounced by the President, the Prime Minister and many others, and the press began a campaign portraying her as a militant fundamentalist bent on subverting the secular Republic. 
 The debate reflected conflict between Turkey's desire for fuller democracy and its fear of religious influence in politics.

HEADLINE: May 2-8;
European Insurers Agree To Settle Holocaust Claims

 BODY:
More than a half-century after the Holocaust, a group of European insurance companies has reached an agreement to pay claims on prewar policies under a formula that reflects present-day values.
The agreement was reached after two days of negotiations in London and its terms were not released. But the broad outlines were made public by the World Jewish Congress, which took part in the talks, and Lawrence S. Eagleburger, the former American Secretary of State, who led a committee conducting the negotiations. 
 The agreement is the latest in a series of efforts to secure compensation from Swiss banks, multinational corporations and other institutions that advocates for Holocaust victims say were unjustly enriched during Nazi Germany's persecution of Jews.
In this case, the agreement is different because it takes into account a half-century of interest, inflation and currency devaluations, and thus could lead to payments totaling billions of dollars.

HEADLINE: At Fort Dix, a New Ellis Island Embraces Kosovo's Refugees

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

DATELINE: FORT DIX, N.J., May 8

 BODY:
Selim Berisha sat in a barracks carefully made safe for old people and children, with pictures of murder running through his head.
On March 28, a holy day for Muslims, he recalled, the Serb police and paramilitaries spilled into his neighborhood in Pristina, the capital of Kosovo. They beat Albanians in the streets and fired in the air and at houses. As the bullets shattered his windows, Mr. Berisha, a 63-year-old taxi driver, hid in his cellar with his family and neighbors -- 50 people in all. 
 In the morning, they found a neighbor who had not made it to shelter. He lay dead in his yard, his remains set upon by dogs. "We buried him, and we escaped into the woods," Mr. Berisha said.
Mr. Berisha was among the first Albanians from Kosovo who came to Fort Dix to begin new lives, separated by thousands of miles, but little time, from the loss of their homes and their worlds.
In less than a week, Fort Dix has been transformed from an Army base into a kind of sprawling Ellis Island, gearing up to be the gateway to America for almost 20,000 Albanian refugees.
The military has named the relief operation Open Arms, and Government agencies have tailored it with a certain sensitivity to both the refugees and to public relations.
Almost overnight, swing sets and play houses sprouted on the base, and by Friday morning, the smiles of toddlers blossomed like so many daisies at the play-house windows. Signs in English and Albanian lined the walls, one bare room had been turned into a chapel, and officials made a point of not serving pork to the Albanians, most of whom are Muslim.
Soldiers speaking to reporters were ordered to say "dining facility" instead of "mess hall," and to call the place where the Immigration and Naturalization Service fingerprints and photographs refugees upon their arrival a "welcome center." Terry Wade, a staff sergeant from Fort Bragg, N.C., who helped prepare the base, observed: "We're kind of running this like a hotel system. Welcome to the HoJo."
But four-foot-tall wooden fences have also gone up over the last week at Fort Dix, for the heart of Ellis Island was always immigration screening. The fences are guarded by military police, and the final authority over the refugees lies with the immigration service.
While the children play gleefully, as if Fort Dix were a miniature Disneyland, their parents and older siblings remain shaken by all they have seen and lost.
Ilir Hoxha, a 45-year-old music producer, said he missed the home he built for his family, a four-room house with two bathrooms in Pristina.
A few weeks ago, he was standing by the open door of that house with his son, Arben, 20, when the Serbian police approached. They forced Mr. Hoxha's wife and teen-age daughters outside and put a gun to his throat, demanding German marks. Mr. Hoxha said he had none; indeed, he had been out of work for 10 years, since Serbs began choking the Albanian economy and culture.
The Serbian police gave his family "half a minute to get out," he said. Armed police officers stood on both sides of the road. The family marched 40 minutes to the train station, staring straight ahead. At the station, they met up with 7,000 other ethnic Albanians and waited five days for a train to take them to the border with Macedonia, where they were stripped of their documents and told never to come home. Asked what might have happened had she looked at the police as she was climbing onto the train, Mr. Hoxha's 17-year-old daughter, Arbreshe, said only, "If . . .," and burst into tears.
The family sat at a picnic table in Doughboy Field at Fort Dix, historically a place of transformation, where generations of boys were turned into soldiers. As Mr. Hoxha told the family's tale, his children and his wife, Hysnije, stared at the grass, as if transfixed. Mr. Hoxha worried about a sister who remained behind. "The situation there is very dangerous," he said. "They don't have anything to eat or drink."
Mr. Hoxha has no relatives in the United States, and said his family had no preference for living in one part of the country over another. "New York," Arbreshe whispered, and smiled. Her father said he wanted most to return home, if he could only raise his family in peace.
The soldiers here appeared genuinely touched by the refugees, charmed by the children and moved by the adults. Early Thursday morning, some 12 hours after they had completed their 13-hour journey from Skopje, Macedonia, the refugees were finally getting to bed after an initial screening by the immigration service and a greeting from Hillary Rodham Clinton.
A mother approached Specialist Kenneth Sollano, 22, of Opp, Ala. She laid her head on folded hands and tried to explain that her little daughter could not sleep. The soldier handed her a doll, which the toddler hugged as she finally dozed off.
Despite the uniforms and the lack of freedom to move, the compound at Fort Dix is far different from the overcrowded tent camps of Macedonia, where the threat of disease looms and resources are stretched. Perhaps afraid the scarcity might return, children at the base cafeteria on Friday afternoon piled trays tall with soup, heaps of spaghetti and meat, and many slices of bread.
Sergeant Wade said that some of the refugees did not know how to say "thank you" in English but expressed their gratitude in other ways. "I gave a little 2-year-old a stuffed toy, and he looked at me and put his hand over his heart," the sergeant said. Adults, eager to help, tried to pick up brooms and sweep.
"It put chills on me," Sergeant Wade said, "that I could do some good for these people."
Mehde Shehu, 39, an Albanian who came here from the Albanian Assistance Center in the Bronx, said the refugees, many of whom were farmers, valued self-reliance. He said immigration officials should allow them to work in the fields at Fort Dix. "They would make them beautiful," he said.
Mr. Shehu had come to Fort Dix to see if he could talk to the refugees, but was being kept at arm's length by officials after he tried to pass a newspaper to a refugee on Thursday.
Though the plight of the Kosovar Albanians has touched a chord in many people, so much that a phone line set up in New Jersey to channel offers of help jammed with calls on Thursday night, immigration officials are controlling access to the refugees.
On Thursday, a day after the first refugees arrived, a 14-year-old, Hassan Maliqi, ventured to the gate to greet reporters and photographers. But almost immediately, he was shooed back and surrounded by 13 soldiers in uniform, for although the compound is being called a "village," it is really a "containment area," one reserve officer blurted out.
The Mayor of nearby Wrightstown, Jozsef Farago, a refugee from the Soviet crackdown in Hungary in 1956, wanted to invite the refugees to a picnic on May 15 to celebrate the centennial of the Wrightstown Fire Department. He also encouraged residents to help the refugees however they could, perhaps just by inviting a family over for an afternoon barbecue to show they cared. But the refugees are not being allowed to leave Fort Dix, and for the moment, Mayor Farago said, he has been told not to be so helpful.
The refugees are being screened for medical problems, while the immigration service tries to do background and criminal records checks. For the refugees to be granted asylum, immigration officials must ascertain that they would face danger if they returned to their home country. In this instance, noted Carl Rusnok, an immigration service spokesman from the Philadelphia office, there is little doubt they will qualify.
Last night, another 102 refugees arrived at Kennedy International Airport, and they are to stay with relatives. Two flights scheduled for next week are to bring more refugees to Fort Dix, where they will join the 860 there now.
Officials said the refugees were expected to stay at Fort Dix for about two weeks, until resettlement agencies find apartments for them. The agencies are also to help them assimilate to the United States, enrolling the children in schools and helping the parents find work.

HEADLINE: Pay Raise for American Soldiers Is Long Overdue

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Re "Doubts Surface Over Raise Being Planned for Military" (news article, May 6): I write as a former naval officer who recently left active duty. As you note, the 1986 pension cut to 40 percent from 50 percent of base pay was intended not only as a money-saving device but also to increase retention among officers between the 20-year point and the 30-year point in their careers. Yet it had the effect of increasing the exodus of officers from the 8- to 12-year point. The new legislation is an attempt to redress this. It should be noted that base pay is only a portion of a military salary; in my case it was 50 percent to 60 percent. This is not an excessively generous pension. 
 Increasing pay and benefits will allow military personnel and their families to participate in the economic boom that the rest of society is experiencing. Thousands of servicemembers are eligible for food stamps. That those who defend us are unable to support their families on military pay should offend us all.
 
BRIAN ROEMER
Washington, May 7, 1999

HEADLINE: Nine-Tenths of the Law

BYLINE: By Charles R. Morris; Charles R. Morris's most recent books are "American Catholic" and the forthcoming "Money, Greed, and Risk."

 BODY:

Property and Freedom
 By Richard Pipes.
 328 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf. $30. 
 Richard Pipes, a longtime professor of Russian history at Harvard, has had the satisfaction, rare among academics, of seeing his once unpopular views adopted as American policy. During the early days of Soviet-American arms limitation talks, Pipes was one of a handful of academics who continued to insist on the criminal nature of the Soviet regime. His 1977 Commentary magazine article, "Why the Soviet Union Thinks It Can Fight and Win a Nuclear War," was one of the half-dozen or so most influential articles in the entire period of the cold war, and his many books on Soviet and Russian history are standards in the field.
Pipes is now retired from Harvard, and his latest book is his first not specifically in his discipline. "Property and Freedom" is a meditation on the close connection between property rights and the development of law and individual liberty throughout the history of civilization. Pipes is massively erudite -- his source notes contain references in at least six languages -- and he has assembled a vast amount of material. But aside from a fascinating chapter on the sources of the perverse attitudes toward property and liberty in modern Russia, the book is a considerable disappointment, especially the querulous broadside against the modern welfare state with which it concludes.
In Pipes's view, despite the vanquishing of Communism, "liberty's future . . . is still at peril, although from a different and novel source. The main threat to freedom today comes not from tyranny but from equality."
Pipes links the "modern habit of thinking in terms of group rights rather than individual rights" with "Stalin's program of 'liquidating,' i.e., murdering 'kulaks,' for example, and Hitler's genocide of Jews and gypsies," both of which "were justified by the notion that people are to be judged and treated on the basis not of their personal behavior but of their membership in a designated group." Affirmative action, it seems, is but a step toward the gulag. The modern threat to liberty, Pipes goes on, comes "from below, from one's fellow citizens who . . . care more about their personal security than about general freedom."
Does Pipes read newspapers? Raising a clamor that the Morlocks are taking over, in a country that has just severely limited public assistance and one in which economic inequality is increasing rapidly, seems like piling on, if not actually paranoid. The book's characteristic rhetorical device is to make an extreme statement, then immediately back off it, as if Pipes were afraid to stand up for how he really feels. So, "abolishing welfare with its sundry 'entitlements' and spurious 'rights' . . . would go a long way" toward resolving the social predicament, is immediately qualified by "but such a solution is not feasible."
More seriously, there are real holes in Pipes's argument. The proposition that property rights usually reinforce the development of a rule of law is so unexceptionable as to be platitudinous. But Pipes seems to be making a stronger argument, that absolute respect for property rights is a precondition for maintenance of liberty. He admits a number of exceptions to that rule, but does so grudgingly, as he must, for they add up to a rather different argument from the one he would like to make.
The Slavic rulers of medieval Russia, most notably Ivan the Terrible, held their positions by grace of their Mongol conquerors, but only so long as they ruthlessly collected huge amounts of tribute. Over three centuries, the institutionalization of the czar's role as surrogate Robber in Chief fatally retarded the development of a nobility as a countervailing economic interest group. Russia never had a class of powerful barons like the ones who wrung Magna Carta out of King John in 1215. The consequence was the Russian "patrimonial" state, in which the czar could, and actually did, dispose of anyone's property virtually at whim.
Catherine the Great finally granted her nobles legal rights in their property by a 1785 charter that Pipes extols as "a revolutionary measure in the fullest and most constructive sense of the word." Although Catherine's reforms benefited only a tiny minority of the population, Pipes says that minority privileges are "the most reliable way of implanting freedom and rights, because it gives rise to social groups interested in protecting their advantages."
In the Russian case, however, there was a catch. The "introduction of landed property," Pipes concedes, "was a mixed blessing" because it enslaved privately held serfs, or about one-third of the population. Before Catherine's reform, the serfs had accumulated real, if limited, traditional privileges, which were summarily swept away when they were made the personal property of their landlords. That seems a rather large qualification to Pipes's argument. Limited freedom for serfs was restored in the next century by reforming czars, but only by trampling on the property rights of the gentry.
Pipes also conveniently ignores the case of modern Western slavery. Dred Scott surely didn't feel liberated by the Supreme Court decision that upheld his master's property rights. Nor does Pipes make any mention of the latifundista tradition in Spanish America that kept the great mass of peasantry in a state of virtual serfdom, or the destruction of Ireland in the service of the property rights of absentee British landlords.
At the conclusion of an extended chapter on the development of property and freedom in England, Pipes speculates on why similar traditions did not arise throughout Europe, even though formal legal protections were roughly similar. Dutch burghers and Polish nobles, for example, enjoyed almost identical protections for property, but the Netherlands became a thriving middle-class republic, while Poland stayed sunk in the Dark Ages.
Pipes never entertains the possibility that the distribution of property may be a far more important condition of freedom than the protection of property per se. Absolute deference to the property rights of the few can create private despotisms as surely as attempts to enforce absolute equality from the top can create despotisms of the state. The challenge is to tease out the balance between insuring a broad distribution of economic stakes and limiting intrusive state power. "Property and Freedom," however, is an exercise in dyspepsia that is not interested in such difficult questions. 
http://www.nytimes.com

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Review

TITLE: PROPERTY AND FREEDOM (BOOK)

HEADLINE: Beyond Blond and Gorgeous: L.A.'s TV Image Is Changing;
New Approaches Try to Capture the City's Complexities

BYLINE: By BERNARD WEINRAUB 

DATELINE: HOLLYWOOD, May 9

 BODY:
Everyone in Los Angeles is blond, beautiful and, duh, has an I.Q. capable of absorbing only one Leonardo. DiCaprio, not da Vinci. The town stops dead in its tracks every week for a late afternoon freeway chase that is more entertaining than anything else on television. Everyone over 30 gets facial surgery, and that includes the women. And you can't find a good bagel either.
This small-screen perspective on Los Angeles, focusing on the banal, the superficial and the glitzy, has been beamed out in dozens of television shows over the decades, reflecting an image of Los Angeles that has acquired the undeniable patina of truth for many viewers. But the city's image, like television, is changing. Its odd trajectory can be traced in the departure of that archetypal L.A. show, "Melrose Place," on May 24 after seven years and 226 episodes on Fox, and the critical success of the new ABC comedy "It's Like, You Know . . . ," which makes fun of the kind of gorgeous, self-absorbed airheads who populate "Melrose Place." 
 "There's often been a kind of shallow view of L.A.," said Peter Mehlman, a former co-executive producer of "Seinfeld" who created "It's Like, You Know . . . ." The new show is about a group of wacky underachievers in a Los Angeles apartment house who do things like spend an entire episode watching a high-speed car chase.
"The perception of L.A. has always been that of surface glamour, and there's never been much of an attempt to get beneath the veneer," he said. "Actually, it's one of the saddest cities on earth because so many people come out here struggling for some kind of dream, and so few get there. And it's hard to see because it's so physically pretty."
In contrast to New York, which appeals to television executives precisely for its grittiness (though even shows like "N.Y.P.D. Blue" have their moments of unreality, too), Los Angeles is often presented as a sun-drenched pastel city with barely a trace of economic or social diversity. Even "Dragnet," which made its debut in 1952 and became one of the most successful police dramas ever by drawing on actual cases from the files of the Los Angeles Police Department, rarely focused on the violence, poverty and racial and immigration problems that were roiling the city in the postwar era.
Several new Los Angeles-based dramatic series (including one by the filmmaker David Lynch) that promise to deal with the complexities of life in the city may turn up on home screens in the fall. This more complex vision of Los Angeles is probably the next wave in television. (While movie studios have churned out film noir set in Los Angeles since the 1930's, television has shied away from these bleak mysteries in favor of the city's sun and light.)
Los Angeles's complexity goes only so far on television. Even David E. Kelley, the highly skilled and innovative creator of shows like "Ally McBeal," "The Practice" and "Picket Fences," has a new show, "Snoops," that by all accounts depicts the more glamorous side of the detective business. The show, tentatively set for ABC, features handsome private eyes who use high-tech means to catch the bad guys. One network executive described it as " 'Miami Vice' in L.A."
And some television shows perpetuate the banality of life in Los Angeles. Look at "Baywatch," with its cast of hunk lifeguards with perfectly chiseled features. Or the USA Network's successful "Pacific Blue," about seven young male and female police officers in tight clothes riding on motorbikes in Santa Monica. "It's cops on bikes," said Joan Swift, the publicity chief at the network. "They're in great shape."
In contrast, some of the successful shows involving New York, like "Seinfeld," "Mad About You," "Law and Order" and "N.Y.P.D. Blue," have been viewed by critics as more realistic and hard-edged. (The hit show "Friends," also set in New York, is another matter.)
Paradoxically, with the exception of "Law and Order," most of these New York-based series are actually shot in studios in Los Angeles. And it shows. Even on a series like "N.Y.P.D. Blue" there is a notable absence of people seen -- and accents heard -- on the streets of New York now: Koreans, Indians, Pakistanis, Africans, Latinos, Russians, Israelis and others.
And except for a handful of shows like "Cosby," with its star, Bill Cosby, who is black, the New York region is often represented in shows like "The King of Queens" and "Everyone Loves Raymond" as a place populated by Italian, Irish and Jewish types -- and stereotypes -- where everyone speaks with an extreme Noo Yawk accent like that of Fran Drescher in "The Nanny."
By contrast, the shows set in Los Angeles often depict the outlandish wealth of areas like Beverly Hills and Bel Air. This goes back to "fish out of water" comedies like the corny 1960's "Beverly Hillbillies," about a backwoods clan that strikes oil and moves to Beverly Hills. More recently, there was the somewhat more realistic "Fresh Prince of Bel Air," about a black rapper from a tough Philadelphia neighborhood (Will Smith) who moves in with wealthy Bel Air relatives.
Yet blondes at the beach still seem to predominate.
Aaron Spelling, whose company, Spelling Television, produced "Melrose Place," and whose Los Angeles-themed shows over the years like "Mod Squad," "Charlie's Angels," "Hart to Hart" and "Beverly Hills 90210" have, in some ways, shaped the kind of glitzy version of Los Angeles, said, essentially, that fantasy sells, not only around the nation but, more importantly, abroad.
"We do some of our L.A. shows for two crazy reasons," Mr. Spelling said. "When it's snowing in the East and Midwest, when it's freezing outside, people love to see the beaches and the sunshine. And in foreign countries they love L.A. Sunset Strip. Malibu. Rodeo Drive. The homes. It's the glamour. They love it."
Heather Locklear, who played the malevolent Amanda Woodward on "Melrose Place," said that the highly successful series, about a group of young people who live in a garden-apartment complex, initially floundered when it was tamely patterned as a sober "twentysomething" version of the hit show "Thirtysomething." Then the creators added some spice.
"It was a fantasy," she said. "The women became a little stronger than the men. It was sexy girls wearing tight clothes and no bras."
Ms. Locklear said with a laugh that she hoped she would now get more varied parts. "I'm a little typecast," she said. "People think of me as a nasty-type person who always wore short skirts. Hopefully, I'll be able to break that."
 
The City Becomes A Major Character
As a reaction to the fantasy version of Los Angeles, "It's Like, You Know . . ." is really the first show to take on the city with a vengeance. Ted Harbert, an executive producer of the show and former chairman of ABC Entertainment, said he could not recall a series that had turned a city like Los Angeles into a dominant character.
"Like Kramer in 'Seinfeld,' or Ted Baxter in 'Mary Tyler Moore,' and Norm and Cliff in 'Cheers,' L.A. is one of our crazy and loopy characters," said Mr. Harbert, who grew up in Pound Ridge, N.Y., and Stamford, Conn. "L.A. is a confusing place because it lures you with wonderful weather and great opportunity and then often frustrates with its inability to deal with complex emotions. It celebrates superficiality in many ways."
(ABC executives remain uneasy that the show, which has performed moderately well, may be too much of an inside joke for most of the country.)
The idea -- or at least the title -- for the show came when Mr. Mehlman, a onetime sportswriter for The Washington Post, visited Fred Segal, a trendy clothing store. "The woman who worked there used the term 'it's like, you know,' about five times in one minute, and I thought that was a great idea for a title. And if I was going to use that title it would have to be set in L.A."
The cast includes Chris Eigeman as a New York journalist visiting Los Angeles to write a book, "Living in Los Angeles: How Can You Stomach It?" Actually, Mr. Eigeman's personal view of Los Angeles is quite similar to the character he plays. "I do think L.A. is a little moral petri dish of degradation," said Mr. Eigeman, who lives in Brooklyn when he is not making the show in Los Angeles.
But the star is the actress Jennifer Grey ("Dirty Dancing"), who plays Jennifer Grey. Reality blurs. In the show, the self-deprecating Ms. Grey talks about some real-life boyfriends and her facial surgery.
"I'm not actually playing myself," Ms. Grey said. "I'm playing a character loosely based on certain facts of my life. It's also based on what the public might think I'm like, based on movies or rumors or tabloids."
Ms. Grey lived in Los Angeles for eight years, before moving back to New York two years ago.
 
The Illusion And the Reality
"The show is about the most demented city in the country, and how it dements the people who live here," Ms. Grey said of Los Angeles, admitting nonetheless that the yoga, the Pilates exercise, the weather and the health food were better there than in New York.
"Nothing's real in L.A.; it's all about illusion," Ms. Grey said. "It's about illusion of power, illusion of youth, illusion of wealth. Nothing is what it seems."
But this kind of L.A. bashing is anathema to other actors as well as filmmakers, who said it was too easy dismiss the city as superficial when it is, in fact, extraordinarily complex.
Mr. Lynch, whose films include "Blue Velvet" and "Lost Highway," as well as the cult serial drama "Twin Peaks," has just completed an ABC pilot for a dramatic series set in Los Angeles called "Mulholland Drive." He said he hoped to deal with numerous levels of life in the city.
"At first glance there's a big sprawling sameness to L.A.," Mr. Lynch said. "But every little section has its own mood. And I love the different moods in L.A. The Valley is so different from Santa Monica, which is so different from Pomona or Riverside. It sort of excites me to deal with the specific moods here."
And Mark Johnson, producer of the CBS drama "L.A. Doctors," said he and the show's creator, John Lee Hancock, were seeking to present a series as much about Los Angeles as it was about doctors.
"The reason we did this was that, like it or not, L.A. was at the cutting edge of what's going on in the country," Mr. Johnson said. "It's easy to make fun of superficiality and shallowness. But there are conflicts and temptations and dynamics that abound in L.A. that are much more harsh and extreme than anywhere else in the country. And that, we hope, makes good television."

HEADLINE: Treasury Offering 5- and 10-Year Notes

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financing this week offers today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and auctions of 5-year and 10-year notes on Wednesday.
By the close of the New York cash market on Friday, traders said, the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 4.47 percent and a six-month bill was 4.49 percent. In when-issued trading the 5-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.35 percent and the 10-year note at 5.46 percent. 
 The following taxable and tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week:

SECTION: Section C; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1721 words

HEADLINE: Disputes and Unknowns of Electronic Rights Roil the Book Industry

BYLINE: By DOREEN CARVAJAL 

 BODY:
When Peter Mayer felt the slim weight of an electronic book in the palm of his hand, he suffered instant pangs of dread.
There was no reassuring crackle of paper or the faint scent of ink that had been a constant in his career in publishing, for two decades as chief executive of Viking Penguin and now his own independent company, Overlook Press. 
 "I respect it," Mr. Mayer said of the electronic book that could change the dynamics of his business, "but I have an emotional and professional investment in what I know. And when I was young, I knew that I could conquer any change, and now I don't know what's ahead."
Such wariness is prompting Mr. Mayer, and some authors and agents, to shy away from books made of bytes until a clear view develops of the rapidly emerging market for electronic readers. The culture of technology has collided with the slower-moving book industry, which is engaged in a tense, early clash over how to divide up the spoils of an infant business that is still difficult to picture in scope and potential.
"This is a scramble over who controls what," said Laurence J. Kirshbaum, chief executive of Time Warner Trade publishing, a Time Warner unit that includes Warner Books and Little Brown & Company. He noted that "we're not being motivated by what's to come, but a fear of being left out as the train is pulling away from the station, with some exotic station in mind."
For the first time in five years, the New York-based Authors Guild mailed out contract warnings last month to some 7,500 members. The letter criticized current E-book contracts as bad deals. The guild said it considered distribution fees for electronic-book manufacturers a payment scheme that would deny publishers and authors the rewards of the information age.
Some prominent literary agencies are also advising authors to refuse electronic-book agreements unless the contracts promise to revise the deals if electronic editions rapidly gain popularity. But in turn, some publishers are refusing to make that concession, which means that many popular books are staying firmly on the bookshelves instead of a digital page.
In the last three years, start-up technology companies have pushed forward with plans to make electronic books as ubiquitous as mass-market paperbacks. This month, Nuvomedia will expand its sales of $500 versions to stores, while Librius is preparing to begin selling its slender 12-ounce pocketbook-sized model for $200 in July. Softbook Press has been lining up deals with corporations and school districts that are eager to eliminate lockers and reduce backpack strain on students laden with textbooks. Softbook's version, with note-taking and scribble functions, sells for $299.
The first E-books became available late last fall. Barnesandnoble.com, for example, has about 500 titles available for sale and downloading and has sold about 15,000 copies in this format. In general, the privately held manufacturers will not say how many of the electronic readers have been sold, but a Barnesandnoble.com spokesman, Ben Boyd, said the company had been "pleasantly surprised with the pace that customers have purchased these devices and titles."
The numbers may seem small now, says Chuck Verrill, a literary agent with Darhansoff & Verrill, but "the issues are profound in their long-term impact."
"And we want to see the market grow, but we want to make sure the terms are fair," he said. The agency's authors, including Arthur S. Golden and E. Annie Proulx, are avoiding the electronic format until they get better deals with publishers.
The devices that are inspiring all this anxiety weigh from 12 ounces to more than two pounds and carry brand names like Rocket eBook, Millennium E-Reader and the Softbook. They seem rather expensive now for leisure reading, but eventually the manufacturers expect the cost to fall below $100 or plunge to nothing as E-readers are given away like cellular phones to entice customers to buy and download books, newspapers and magazines.
With almost missionary zeal, the entrepreneurs developing the E-books from the West Coast, and a culture of technology, are talking of sweeping changes in a publishing industry centered in New York and steeped in tradition.
"I think they're going to be everywhere," said Devin P. McKinney, director of content services for Softbook Press. "I think that 50 percent of the books are going to be published in electronic form and not in paper."
Publishers say they do not feel threatened by the development of the electronic book because they do not think the form will replace conventional books for adult readers who will always want to savor the familiar touch of paper.
But a new generation of young readers may have different notions about what constitutes a good book. Some school districts are already negotiating to buy the Softbook for students to essentially create "textbook-free" schools where students can download books and packets of course information over phone lines.
For instance, the Davis Joint Unified School District in Davis, Calif., is expecting to learn this month whether it has received a $6 million Federal grant to subsidize the purchase of some 3,000 electronic books that will be shared among 7,700 students.
But if educators see immediate benefits, publishers are showing more caution as the first deals are struck for electronic rights that could set a pattern to last the life of a copyright. When authors try to make the case that paperless books will result in cost savings, Random House, the top-ranking publisher, expresses private misgivings.
In an internal memo, the company said that "a generally held misconception is that publishers will make greater profits on E-books since the costs of paper, printing, warehousing and delivery are saved."
"This ignores the different kinds of costs that are incurred in handling E-books," the memo said. It then listed the added expenses of formatting manuscripts for electronic books, protecting digital material from piracy and granting higher discounts to E-book distributors.
But the Authors Guild does indeed expect savings from lowered paper and printing costs and so, as the guild's director, Paul Aiken, put it, "the result seems clear: authors should receive a significantly higher royalty for E-books than they do for physical books."
The Authors Guild says that now, a writer might get a share as great as 15 percent of the list price of a book as a royalty. The structure for an electronic book is about the same, but can run as low as 4 percent. In a conventional contract for a hard-cover book, the publisher gets about 35 percent of the list price while the distributor gets 15 percent and the bookseller keeps 35 percent. With the new electronic rights agreements that E-book manufacturers are getting from publishers, this structure shifts, with publishers getting 25 to 40 percent, booksellers 35 to 40 percent and distributors 20 percent.
In particular, the guild has criticized the new cut for Nuvomedia, which it describes as a combined "whopping 60 percent distribution fee" to Nuvomedia and Barnesandnoble.com, which sells the electronic titles.
Not surprisingly, such sentiments anger E-book manufacturers like Martin F. Eberhard, the chief executive of Nuvomedia, based in Mountain View, Calif., even though the parent company of Random House, Bertelsmann A.G., has invested in his company and in Barnes & Noble.
At the annual Book Expo America in Los Angeles, which draws thousands of booksellers and publishers, Mr. Eberhard sat in his exhibit booth, fuming about Random House's arguments and the Authors Guild letter, which also contended that "profit margins for publishers and royalty rates for authors should soar with these sales."
"If the publishing industry doesn't let up on these squabbles, it will hurt them," he said, adding that the combined 60 percent share for the distributor and bookseller had since dropped to 55 percent of the list price of a book.
Mr. Eberhard contends that the costs of publishing an electronic version are lower than conventional formats and so authors can improve their shares. He complained, though, that Random House was taking credit for bearing the costs of encrypting digital material "because they're trying to get the best royalty rate that they can."
But Random House's general counsel, Harriette K. Dorsen, said: "Publishers do the formatting and each device needs to be individually done. Upgrades are required for new upgrades of the devices." In addition, she said, the costs of encryption are passed back to the publishers through higher discounts granted to E-book manufacturers.
Some literary agents contend that Random House has taken tough negotiating positions by refusing to allow contract revisions as the market grows. But Ms. Dorsen said: "This is emphatically not correct that we have refused to revisit the issue of royalties. In fact, we understand that in a changing environment, with a business in its infancy, there will be changes in the way this business is done."
The current tension is such that Nuvomedia is prevented from selling an electronic version of Arthur S. Golden's "Memoirs of a Geisha," one of the titles published by Random House's Knopf unit that was used to test eRocket books with customers. "We had it all ready to go, and it was pulled at the last minute because the author wasn't happy with the deal," Mr. Eberhard said. Barnesandnoble.com, which was offering it on its site, deleted it when a dispute emerged.
Mr. Golden's literary agent, Mr. Verrill, said he and his client chose not to permit an electronic version more out of concern about the uncertainties of the future. In general, he said, he thinks that publishers should allow contracts to be revised after a limited number of years to gauge the impact of electronic books on publishing economics.
"We're not ready to commit a book that was likely to sell for the next 20 years over terms that seemed so unthought-out," Mr. Verrill said.
At the same time, he is aware of the impact if authors continue to shy away from electronic versions.
"You bet it has an impact," Mr. Verrill said. "It affects the content that Nuvomedia can offer, and if they have nothing but books nobody wants, then they're likely to fail."

HEADLINE: Defining the On-Line Chief;
Ebay's Meg Whitman Explores Management, Web Style

BYLINE: By LAURA M. HOLSON 

 BODY:
In a Valley of unexpected millionaires, Meg Whitman is the unlikeliest of billionaires.
Ms. Whitman recalls the day in November 1997 that a headhunter urged her to leave her comfortable job promoting Teletubbies at Hasbro Inc. The proposition: to head up a no-name Silicon Valley start-up that needed a chief executive. Her answer was "no." 
 Like legions of graduates coming out of elite business schools in the late 1970's, Ms. Whitman had taken her Harvard M.B.A. and slipped quietly into a successful career at a blue-chip consulting firm. She later moved to corporate America, happy to work for the likes of Disney and Stride Rite.
So it would take more than Internet stock options in a company she had never heard of for Ms. Whitman to give up the peaceful life she enjoyed with her husband and two sons in Boston.
That was until Ms. Whitman visited the cramped San Jose, Calif., offices of Ebay Inc., the person-to-person Web auction community that was already attracting a following so devout it bordered on the cultish. After a few days of being wooed by venture capitalists and hearing the testimonials of users so addicted they slipped out of business meetings to monitor their auctions, Ms. Whitman was hooked.
"I thought something was very right here," she said. "They had touched a consumer nerve."
Ms. Whitman's "no" became "yes." And 14 months ago, she packed up her family and moved to California to begin preparing Ebay for the initial public stock offering that the company's founder, Pierre M. Omidyar, was already mulling.
Since its $735 million offering last September, the company's market capitalization has blossomed to $22.1 billion -- the stock price skyrocketing 1,019 percent. And the 42-year-old Ms. Whitman, along with a cadre of early investors, has become very rich -- at least on paper.
But more to the point, she is also one of the new generation of Internet executives who is bringing conventional corporate bona fides and consumer- product-style marketing to the Web. In the process, executives like Ms. Whitman are changing the way Web companies are run -- even as they develop a new management style suited to this emergent medium.
With no technology background to speak of, Ms. Whitman leaves the heavy lifting to the tech experts. But what she does seem to have are many of the skills that may be necessary if Ebay is to prove itself more than a hot stock or consumer fad and become an established brand.
In some ways, executives like Ms. Whitman are becoming to technology what Ray Kroc, the founder of McDonald's, was to fast food and consumer culture in the early 1960's. In those days, an executive did not need to understand the chemistry of ground beef to deliver a hamburger people wanted. Likewise, today's Internet executives do not have to be computer geniuses, but seasoned brand managers who immerse themselves in the culture they are trying to foster on line.
Robert Kagle, a partner at the venture firm Benchmark Capital, an early Ebay investor that hired Ms. Whitman, may put it best: "I was looking for a brand builder to help make Ebay a household name. Understanding technology was not the central ingredient. You have to get the emotional component of the customer experience in your gut."
Certainly, the Ebay brand is becoming synonymous with Ms. Whitman, something she is not entirely comfortable with. A man moving furniture at Ebay's headquarters last week pointed at her, a spark of recognition lighting up his face. "There she is," he shouted. "My wife said she's seen you on TV. Maybe 10 times. You're real popular."
Ms. Whitman smiled and waved at the man. But the grin faded as she turned away. "That's what I hate," she said. "I even have the furniture man noticing me."
The attention is not all that surprising, though. Ms. Whitman campaigns for Ebay as fervently as any candidate on the trail. In recent weeks she attended a press conference with the Governor of Utah; spoke to reporters at the National Press Club in Washington, where she also met with Congressional leaders to discuss on-line privacy, and was interviewed for a handful of coming profiles.
"Personally, I don't care," she said, commenting on the media swirl. "But it is the right thing to do for Ebay."
Ms. Whitman never planned on a Web career. After a summer selling advertising for her college magazine at Princeton University, she switched from pre-med studies and graduated with an economics degree in 1977. She got her M.B.A. from Harvard Business School two years later, and briefly worked at Procter & Gamble before moving to San Francisco in 1981 with her husband, Griffith R. Harsh 4th, who landed a neurosurgery residency at the University of California at San Francisco.
There, she was hired by the consulting firm Bain & Company, where she worked for eight years. But the demands of her husband's career (they moved to Boston in 1992 when he became director of the brain tumor program at Massachusetts General Hospital) and the fact that headhunters called every time a new job emerged, led to a number of jobs at several companies.
It was her two years as chief executive of Florists' Transworld Delivery in Michigan, though, that proved her biggest disappointment. Ms. Whitman had been hired by the florist-owned member association in 1995 -- better known as F.T.D. -- to help smooth its transition to a privately held company. But several key members opposed the idea, quick decisions were politically impossible and competition was eroding market share. Conceding defeat, Ms. Whitman quit in 1997, moved briefly to Hasbro and the next year found herself at Ebay.
As if to test the new chief's technical mettle, Ebay's Web site crashed during her first day on the job, crippling trading for eight hours. "The No. 1 job at Ebay is keeping the site up," she said, so she assembled a team of senior managers to assess the site's reliability. As a result, Ebay added enough backup software and computer servers to increase trading capacity.
But intermittent problems have persisted, and Ms. Whitman has not hesitated to tap powerful Silicon Valley connections to help her. "Last January, we were having short outages -- 10 to 15 minutes," she recalled. "It made everyone here crazy." So she called Scott G. McNealy, chairman of Sun Microsystems Inc., whom she has known for a decade. "I said, 'Scott, I need a nanny for this system until the baby gets better.' " Now Sun technicians are on call 24 hours. But the baby can still be fussy; just last Monday, trading was interrupted for four hours because of a computer glitch.
Much of Ms. Whitman's job is understanding who uses the auction service. About a year ago, Ms. Whitman set up a consumer insight and analysis group to find out. In contrast to the situation at traditional retailers, she said, "there is no one between us and the consumer." So twice monthly Ebay posts customer surveys on the site. Among the suggestions that were adopted is "Ebay Life," a newsletter full of feel-good stories -- like the woman who collects wedding cake decorations, 50 of which she found on Ebay, or the stay-at-home mother who is an avid Ebay trader at night.
Ebay, at times, can come off as a bit homespun, but that does not concern Ms. Whitman. "I didn't create this culture, but I want to maintain it," she said.
Mr. Kagle can attest to that. It was he who prodded her to set up a feature that customers had been requesting: notification by E-mail whenever favorite items are up for bid. And everyone is a source of feedback. Even the architects who redesigned their headquarters were asked to buy something and report back to Ms. Whitman.
Three times a week, Ms. Whitman meets with staff members to review what other auction sites have that Ebay does not. Ebay's recent $260 million acquisition of the auction house Butterfield & Butterfield was spurred, in part, by the threat of competition, she said. And Ebay is rushing to expand into untapped regional as well as foreign markets.
Whatever the sense of urgency that drives her, Ms. Whitman displays a calming, down-to-earth veneer -- perhaps a result of her upbringing as the youngest of three children in the comfortably affluent village of Cold Spring Harbor on Long Island's North Shore.
Her father was a businessman, her mother a full-time homemaker with a sense of adventure. Ms. Whitman recalls the summer she was 6 years old when her mother, the three Whitman children and a family friend with five children of her own, embarked on a three-month camping trip across Canada to Alaska. Driving for long stretches in a camper with canvas bunks in the back, the children would sometimes get antsy and start to squabble. So Ms. Whitman's mother came up with an unusual solution to tire them out.
She would stop the camper, order the children out on the deserted Alaskan highway and let them run ahead, creeping behind in the camper until they were weary. More than once, a passing trucker would stop to ask if something was wrong. "You could always hear the hiss of the air brakes," Ms. Whitman recalled. "We finally put up a sign on the back of the camper that said, 'We're O.K.' "
And one year, during the family's annual Christmas camping trip on the island of St. John in the Virgin Islands, her parents were too late to make a reservation at the usual campground. Undaunted, the family bivouacked in a toolshed.
That willingness to make do may help explain why Ms. Whitman was willing recently to move with her husband and children into a subdivision in Menlo Park that the locals refer to as "Woodside training houses," because executives there typically aspire eventually to the exclusive homes in that nearby town. "We didn't want to buy a statement house," she said (although not buying a statement house is a statement in itself). They do plan to move once they have finished remodeling a 3,800-square-foot home they bought in well-heeled Atherton.
Working for Ebay will be her last job, Ms. Whitman said. Her stock options -- worth about $1.3 billion as of Friday's closing price -- vest over four years, and she plans to stay at the company at least five years. But by then, if she has not delivered, her options could be worth significantly less or, depending on the capriciousness of the market, nothing at all.
For it is not yet certain whether the new brand-conscious executive is indeed the blueprint for the future, or simply an expensive experiment in Internet management. Yahoo and Amazon.com are already fast on the heels of Ebay hoping to grab the company's loyal customers for their own. And more are sure to come.
"There is this constant roar," Ms. Whitman said. "The challenge is to reorganize your business every three months." And being on the run makes missteps inevitable. "You will be wrong sometimes," she said. "That is just going to happen."
But uncertainty is a condition with which Ms. Whitman, and any investors in Internet stocks, for that matter, must learn to live with.
"She has done a great job so far with the stock," said Alberto Vilar, president of Amerindo Investment Advisors, and one of Ebay's largest shareholders. "Anyone who wants to pick her off as a second-rate manager is barking up the wrong tree."
But though a fan of Ms. Whitman, Mr. Vilar sounded the kind of warning that is an implicit part of being one of today's new Web chiefs: "Her board and shareholders are going to lynch her if she doesn't execute."

Chart: "Management.com"
 
With corporate bona fides that include a Harvard M.B.A. and executive stints at established consumer-product companies like Disney and Hasbro, Meg Whitman is bringing conventional management experience to Ebay. But as Ms. Whitman has found, running a Web company requires adapting some of the established methods to the emergent corporate management style:
 
THE OLD WAY
* Decisions must be made in a matter of months.
* The focus is on selling consumer products.
* The chief executive monitors the company image.
* The chief uses a hands-off management style.
* Company strategy sessions might be held once or twice a year.
 
THE WEB WAY
* Decisions must be made in a matter of days -- or even hours.
* The focus is on selling consumers an experience.
* The chief executive micro-manages the company image.
* The chief uses a more approachable management style.
* Strategy sessions might be needed several times a week. (pg. C8)
