HEADLINE: Tokyo Journal;
Vying for Korean Hearts: Kim Il Sung vs. Hip-Hop

BYLINE: By NICHOLAS D. KRISTOF 

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 10

 BODY:
On the walls of the classrooms are stern portraits of North Korea's late "Great Leader" and his son the "Dear Leader," and a huge banner on the gymnasium declares, "Great Leader Marshal Kim Il Sung Is With Us Forever."
But it is obvious that this high school is in Tokyo, not North Korea, when a cluster of giggly teeny-boppers bounce up and test their English by asking about something really important to 16-year-old hearts. 
 "Do you like the Backstreet Boys?" asked Yun Mi Hyang, a junior at the Korean High School in Tokyo, and she and her friends paused breathlessly. "You know, the Backstreet Boys. Kevin! Nick! Brian! Oh, they are so great! The best American band. I love their music."
Miss Yun and the other students at the Korean High School come across, in short, as the world's funkiest Stalinists. But the 137 North Korea-backed schools in Japan -- partly financed by North Korea and run by North Koreans who are long-term residents of Japan -- are caught in a crisis, for it is becoming ever more difficult to balance loyalties to Great Leaders and Backstreet Boys.
More broadly, the 650,000 ethnic Koreans in Japan -- by far Japan's largest minority -- seem to be at a crossroads and increasingly to be choosing the Japanese path rather than the Korean path. After half a century in which the Korean population in Japan bridled and fought constantly with its hosts, it is becoming more subdued, and every year more than 10,000 Koreans are taking Japanese citizenship.
"Intermarriage is increasing, and taking of Japanese nationality is increasing," Ku Dae Sok, the principal of the Korean High School, said glumly as he sat in a spacious office with memorabilia of Kim Il Sung on the shelves. "So I think the trend for Koreans here is headed downhill."
Today's Koreans in Japan are mostly grandchildren of those who were brought here to work as manual laborers when Korea was a Japanese colony early in this century.
Most were from what is now South Korea, but in the postwar era many were contemptuous of the American-backed Government in the South. Many Koreans felt that the true nationalistic credentials belonged to Kim Il Sung, who fought Japanese troops during World War II and who established a fervently nationalistic Government in the North.
The upshot was that most of Japan's Koreans initially inclined toward the North, not so much because of its Communist political system as because of patriotism.
Japan discriminated harshly against the Koreans, even after the war, and that cemented the nationalistic tendencies of the Korean minority. The discrimination continues today, for Japan's Education Ministry, which has traditionally been as prone to hard-line ideologies as North Korea itself, bars graduates of Korean schools from even applying to enter Japan's prestigious national universities.
Yet the broader reason for the crisis in the Korean schools has to do with changes among the Koreans themselves.
"The original purpose of the schools was to prepare Koreans so that they could go back to their homeland," said So Chung On, an official of the pro-North Korean Chosun Soren organization in Japan. "But now young people have no intention of going back to their homeland.
"Taking account of that reality, our organization has been trying to modify the contents of the education," Mr. So added. One result is that the North Korean schools in Japan now study much less politics and ideology, and the curriculum is fairly similar to that of Japanese schools, except that classes are all conducted in the Korean language.
This flexibility in the curriculum has helped preserve the support of some Korean parents, but even so, attendance of Korean schools has fallen to 17,000 today, compared with 35,000 in 1967. That reflects a significant waning of support for North Korea in recent years among Japan's Korean population.
Korean families in Japan used to send $100 million or more each year in hard currency to North Korea, but now the aid has fallen to a small fraction of that. One reason is the current recession in Japan, but more important is that some Koreans in Japan look to North Korea and now see not inspiration, but rather something closer to embarrassment.
In contrast, as South Korea has prospered and democratized and emerged from beneath the American thumb, it has steadily gained support. Now more Koreans in Japan are aligned with South Korea than with the North.
The South does not run full-fledged schools in Japan, so parents usually send their children to Japanese schools and then sometimes to Korean-language classes on the side.
What keeps the North Koreans here going, it seems, is not ideology or politics, but nationalism and loyalty. "Are people proud of their mothers only in good times and then ashamed of their mothers when they run into troubles?" asked Shin Te Jyun, the president of the student body at the Korean High School.
Perhaps the greater challenge to the Korean schools is not that pro-North Koreans will defect to the South, but rather that they will join the flood of Koreans signing up for Japanese nationality. Most Korean families in Japan now speak Japanese at home, and the surge of naturalizations alarms many Korean stalwarts who see it as a kind of cultural suicide.
"I could never think of becoming a Japanese citizen, because we were colonized by Japan," said Sok Kyong Suk, a Japanese teacher at the school. "To become Japanese would be a humiliation."

HEADLINE: WORLD NEWS BRIEFS

BYLINE: Compiled by Terence Neilan

 BODY:

MIDDLE EAST
 
ISRAEL: P.L.O. OFFICES ORDERED CLOSED -- The police served orders to close three offices in Orient House, the P.L.O. headquarters in East Jerusalem, but the action was delayed pending a petition to the Supreme Court by Israeli peace advocates. Palestinians called the order an election ploy by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyhau, who has made Jerusalem a centerpiece of his campaign. Faisal Husseini, left, the top Palestinian official in East Jerusalem, warned that a forcible closing could set off riots.
 Joel Greenberg (NYT)
 
IRAN: PARDON URGED FOR EX-MAYOR -- A majority of Iranian legislators have signed a petition calling for a pardon for the former Mayor of Teheran, Gholamhossein Karbaschi, a moderate who began serving a two-year prison term last week on corruption charges. (Agence France-Presse) 

IRAQ: U.S. ATTACKS NORTH AGAIN -- American jets attacked air-defense sites after being tracked by radar during patrols in the northern no-flight zone, the U.S. military said. Air Force F-15's and F-16's dropped laser-guided bombs on antiaircraft sites northwest of Mosul, according to a statement from Incirlik, in southern Turkey, where the jets are based. Iraq said one person was wounded. (AP)
 
ASIA
 
PAKISTAN: JOURNALIST CASE PRESSED -- Punjab state officials said in Lahore High Court that they do not know the whereabouts of Najam Sethi, editor of The Friday Times, although his wife says two Punjab police officers were among 10 men who took him from their home on Saturday. A Government spokesman has said Mr. Sethi was suspected of links to India's intelligence agency; his wife says he is being punished for speaking out against the Government. The court gave the Government two days to say where Mr. Sethi is being detained. Celia W. Dugger (NYT)
 
INDONESIA: EAST TIMOR CLASHES -- Supporters and opponents of independence for East Timor fought for a second day in Dili, the district capital, and officials said four people had been killed. Riot policemen circulated in trucks and shots could be heard from the main market, the university and a cemetery. A referendum on independence is scheduled Aug. 8. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
VIETNAM: CORRUPTION TRIAL -- A trial with 77 defendants, including 18 bank officials, opened in Ho Chi Minh City, drawing hundreds of spectators. The case involves a charge of collusion by private companies to acquire huge bank loans with exaggerated collateral. Some defendants risk a death penalty. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
CAMBODIA: LOOTED ARTWORKS RETURNED -- Under military escort, 61 sandstone statues and friezes looted by the Khmer Rouge have been returned for safekeeping to authorities at Siem Reap, the site of the huge temple complex of Angkor. The looted pieces, some dating from the 10th century, were recovered from Anlong Veng, the last stronghold of guerrilla holdouts from the Communist insurgency. Seth Mydans (NYT)
 
EUROPE
 
BRITAIN: BOMB SUSPECT REMANDED -- A 22-year-old man accused of killing 3 people and wounding more than 100 in three London nail bombings last month was ordered held in custody by a London court. The man, David Copeland, an unemployed subway engineer, was arrested a week ago and charged with the attacks, the first in a black neighborhood, the second in an Asian one and the last in a gay pub, where the three people died. Mr. Copeland is not known to be a member of any of the racist groups that claimed responsibility for the bombings. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
BRITAIN: A SUIT OVER VIAGRA -- A decision by the National Health Service to curb the prescribing by its doctors of the impotence drug Viagra was challenged in England's High Court by Pfizer Ltd. as "legally indefensible." The drug company, which makes Viagra, said it was considering suing the Government for damages in lost business. Health Secretary Frank Dobson took the action in September, saying unrestricted prescribing would be a "serious drain" on the service's finances. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
 NORTHERN IRELAND: SINN FEIN'S CHOICES -- Sinn Fein has picked its chief negotiator, Martin McGuinness, left, and another party official, Bairbre de Brun, as its nominees for the party's two positions in the executive of the new Northern Ireland Assembly. The province's largest party, the Ulster Unionists, is refusing to let Sinn Fein, the political wing of the I.R.A., take its seats unless guerrillas start to disarm. The Unionist leader, David Trimble, and Sinn Fein's leader, Gerry Adams, are deadlocked on the issue. Warren Hoge (NYT)
 
RUSSIA: YELTSIN CHARGES -- Leaders of Russia's moderate Yabloko Party told members to support one of the five impeachment charges against President Boris N. Yeltsin: that he exceeded his authority by waging a disastrous war against secessionists in Chechnya. The impeachment debate begins in the lower house on Wednesday. Yabloko's 46 members often hold the balance of power, but it is unclear whether the votes exist to impeach Mr. Yeltsin. Michael Wines (NYT)
 
GERMANY: 'RED ARMY' MEMBER SURRENDERS -- Barbara Meyer, one of the last members of the Red Army Faction terrorists of the 1970's and 80's, turned herself in, the federal prosecutors in Karlsruhe said. She is being held pending trial for murder and other charges. The prosecutor said she had been living in Lebanon. (NYT)
 
THE AMERICAS
 
COLOMBIA: JUSTICE MINISTER QUITS -- Minister of Justice Parmenio Cuellar, left, has resigned, saying reforms of the judicial system backed by the Government will contribute to human rights violations. The Interior Minister, Nestor Martinez, favors leaving untouched many features of special "faceless" courts that protect judges, lawyers and witnesses by allowing them to testify anonymously. That system is supposed to be dismantled by June 30, but Mr. Martinez favors laws that would allow many contentious practices to continue. Larry Rohter (NYT)
 
 MEXICO: SENATOR HURT BY GUNFIRE -- Senator Hector Sanchez Lopez, a former candidate for governor who continues to protest what he calls fraud in elections last August in Oaxaca state, was wounded during a confrontation with a crowd of governing-party activists in a Oaxaca village. Senator Sanchez blamed the governing party leaders in Oaxaca for the attack, a contention the state attorney general, who is from the governing party, called infantile. Sam Dillon (NYT)
 
ARGENTINA: PARAGUAY PLEA REJECTED -- A Federal judge rejected a Paraguayan request for the arrest of Gen. Lino Oviedo, a retired former army chief who is suspected of masterminding the assassination of Vice President Luis Maria Argana of Paraguay almost two months ago. The judge said the Paraguayan warrant was incomplete, lacking charges and the amount of jail time the general could face. General Oviedo has held political asylum in Argentina since he and his family fled to Buenos Aires on March 28.
 Clifford Krauss (NYT)
 
AFRICA
 
ANGOLA, ZAMBIA: MEETINGS PLANNED -- Hoping to ease growing tensions between Angola and Zambia, defense and security ministers from both countries have agreed to meet in Swaziland this week for talks. For months Angola has accused Zambia of allowing the Angolan rebel group Unita to resupply via Zambia. But Zambia denies such cooperation, saying the accusations emanate from its refusal to allow Angolan troops to use Zambian territory to attack the rebels.
 Suzanne Daley (NYT)
 
RWANDA: BELGIAN EXTRADITION DENIED -- Tanzania turned down Belgian requests for the extradition of a former Rwandan Army major accused of killing 10 Belgian peacekeepers during Rwanda's 1994 genocide, saying he should be tried in Rwanda. The officer, Bernard Ntuyahaga, is accused of ordering the slaying of Rwanda's Prime Minister and the soldiers deployed to protect her.
 (Reuters)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Making Brazilian Soccer a Bigger Deal

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 10

 BODY:
Luiz Carlos Faloppa loves rooting for his soccer team. Yet he has not attended a match in person for eight years, disgusted with the concrete slab seating and the irate fans who lob urine-filled plastic cups and brawl with supporters of rival clubs.
"I tired of getting urine tossed on my back," said Mr. Faloppa, a 39-year-old executive at a magazine publisher. Now he watches soccer only on television. 
 Years of mismanagement and neglect have left Brazilian soccer in disarray, with only diehard fans, mostly young males, mustering courage to attend matches live. The situation is not much better for players, who are subject to a punishing schedule of games, bound by an archaic system limiting their ability to negotiate lucrative contracts and often threatened with violence on and off the field.
Even so, foreign and Brazilian investment firms increasingly see opportunities to transform Brazilian soccer into a moneymaker. For example, Nationsbank -- now Bank of America -- purchased the licensing rights of the Vasco da Gama club of Rio de Janeiro. And in the most widely publicized transaction, Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst Inc., the Dallas-based buyout firm with investments throughout Latin America, announced a deal in April giving it the marketing and licensing rights for Corinthians, Sao Paulo's largest team.
"Soccer in Brazil is like baseball, basketball and football put together," said Charles Tate, the firm's president. The transaction gives Hicks, Muse all licensing rights of the club's name, enabling it to sell items like caps or T-shirts emblazoned with the Corinthians insignia as well as the opportunity to negotiate deals for the TV broadcast of games. Hicks, Muse has already entered into pay-TV ventures in Brazil and in neighboring Argentina that could facilitate such deals.
Mr. Tate said Hicks, Muse would use its knowledge from experiences in the United States, where it has interests in sports ranging from professional baseball and hockey to rodeo.
The entrance of American companies like Hicks, Muse into Brazilian soccer is the latest chapter of a wide-reaching transformation that began largely with efforts by the most famous soccer player in Brazil, Edson Arantes do Nascimento, better known as Pele. After retiring from the game, Pele was named Minister of Sports in 1994 by the newly elected President, Fernando Henrique Cardoso. He strongly encouraged clubs to treat players, many of whom came from poor backgrounds, with greater respect. He also sought to limit corruption in clubs by spurring them to make the leap from nonprofit organizations into for-profit companies.
Pele, now 58, convinced Congress last year to approve legislation that requires greater transparency of club finances and better accounting procedures. This change has paved the way for potential investors to consider deals with some of Brazil's larger teams. Another part of the legislation, known as the Pele Law, phases out an antiquated system in which players had little freedom to negotiate contracts.
"The Pele Law laid the groundwork that investors needed to start taking Brazilian football seriously," said John Michael Streithorst, the director of new business ventures at Banco Icatu, an investment bank based in Rio de Janeiro, which had negotiated with Corinthians before the club's deal with Hicks, Muse.
Mr. Streithorst likens the situation in Brazil to that in England in the 1980's, an era when English soccer was widely known for the violent clashes among rival fans. With the entry of private investors into the sport, however, and with lucrative pay-TV licensing contracts, soccer's image improved, and a broader array of fans began to attend games.
Another domestic authority on the Brazilian soccer business, the talk show host and newspaper columnist Juca Kfouri, has estimated that it may be possible for sports to generate 4 percent of Brazil's gross domestic product in a few years, up from 1.5 percent today. "Thank God capitalism is winning out against the feudal attitudes that have prevailed in this sport for too long," Mr. Kfouri said. "With the talent produced here, Brazil could have the N.B.A. of world soccer."
That potential, combined with the transformation of soccer in recent years in Europe, where some clubs have gone so far as to sell stock to the public, has not limited investors only to contracts with individual clubs. For instance, the Globo media group and several Rio de Janeiro investment banks have invested $30 million in Lance!, a daily sports newspaper founded in 1997 along the lines of France's L'Equipe and Italy's Gazzetta dello Sport. Although Lance! publishes some articles about other sports, including auto racing and volleyball, soccer dominates. And the newspaper unabashedly supports efforts to improve team management.
"Having more private capital in clubs should act like a benevolent virus, in which the good cells expel the bad cells," said Walter de Mattos, the newspaper's publisher.
One large problem facing those hoping to transform Brazilian soccer is the way games are scheduled. In Brazil, a club can play up to 90 games a year, compared with 60 or 70 in Europe. Players often complain of the effects of the grueling schedule. And there is an array of championships and other tournaments, making schedules confusing.
Regardless, soccer as a business is expanding even outside the two largest cities, Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo. In the northeastern state of Bahia, Opportunity, an investment group, formed a venture with the state's largest club. Even Pele is considering similar deals. He has left his post as Minister of Sports and now dedicates part of his time to Pele Sports and Marketing, which is searching for possible ventures.

HEADLINE: When the Dragon Awakes . . .;
. . . and Finds That It's Not 1999 Anymore

SERIES: COUNTING TO 2000: China's Computer Puzzle

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
When Zhang Qi, the state official who coordinates China's Year 2000 computer policy, began asking Government ministries last August for monthly reports on their readiness, most simply ignored her.
"I was not satisfied," said Ms. Zhang, a 53-year-old career bureaucrat whose flinty demeanor seems perfectly suited to her task. "We are here to offer them service and technical support. But quite a few did not send over information, and we had to call them to find out their situation." 
 She got action only after she reminded her colleagues that confronting the Year 2000, or Y2K, problem was a top priority of Prime Minister Zhu Rongji and other leaders. "It takes some time to make them realize and believe the problem," she said with ill-disguised impatience.
In contrast to the United States and Europe, where the public debate over the Year 2000 issue has gone through a full cycle -- from near-hysteria to having many people dismiss the whole thing as a minor annoyance -- China is just waking up to the idea that on Jan. 1, 2000, some of its computers may not work.
(In general, the problem results from the reliance of many programs on only the last two digits of a year. Unless updated, some computers and electronic machinery might misinterpret "00" as 1900 rather than 2000, substitute another year or simply freeze.)
Experts here warn that China could suffer everything from severe disruptions in power and water to lesser but still expensive glitches in telecommunications, banking, public health and transportation. And China's woes could spill over to Hong Kong, where banks, brokerage firms, and shipping companies with close ties to the mainland are worried about lost cargo and missing payments.
"China is very, very behind in Y2K contingency planning," said Joseph Sweeney, director of research at the Hong Kong office of Gartner Group, a research firm that specializes in the Year 2000 problem. "There's no way many of their organizations will come up to speed in time."
Yet so little is known about the nature of the problem here that the experts are often reduced to a digital-age version of reading tea leaves as they scrounge for clues about how and where China will be affected. The dearth of data is compounded by China's computer network -- a mix of 1960's-era mainframe machines and pirated copies of the latest Windows software running on a variety of personal computers.
Tim Shepheard-Walwyn, the chairman of the Global 2000 Coordinating Group, a consortium of 300 banks that monitors Year 2000 compliance, said he did not have enough information even to make a judgment about China. He visited Beijing in March to prod officials at the People's Bank of China for more details.
Part of the resistance is that China is not nearly as dependent on computers as the United States or other Asian countries. Seventy percent of people live in rural areas, where computers -- let alone computer bugs -- are barely known. Even in big cities, the prospect of computer failures is not frightening to a country that measures calamity on the scale of last year's Yangtze River floods.
"Food still comes in on people's backs, water comes from a dam upriver, and people don't use that much electricity anyway," said R. Mark Mecham, deputy director of the United States Information Technology Office in Beijing, a trade association that represents more than 50 computer makers.
At a minimum, though, the Year 2000 problem could cramp China's economy, which is growing despite the Asian slump. Gartner Group estimates that 66 percent of Chinese companies will experience some failure in their computers. That compares with 40 percent of companies worldwide.
Experts said China's Year 2000 problems were likely to be concentrated in just the kind of places where the Government wants to showcase its future as a technologically advanced economy: the Pudong district of Shanghai and Shenzhen, the special economic zone that borders Hong Kong.
In a recent survey, a Chinese research firm, Century Perspective Market Research, found that only 15 percent of commercial and governmental organizations had fixed Year 2000 flaws and tested their systems.
Numbers like these alarm foreign companies here, as well as companies outside China that deal with the mainland. Hong Kong's container port, for example, processes half of China's exports and 40 percent of its imports. Many of the invoices for those goods are settled by payments that flow electronically between banks in Hong Kong and their counterparts in mainland China.
If the Chinese banks suffer computer malfunctions, it would paralyze hundreds of millions of dollars of settlements within days. Alan Fung, an area manager at Standard Chartered Bank in Hong Kong, said the banks were already devising plans to channel transactions through larger Chinese banks. Failing that, they might resort to writing out transactions on paper.
"If the Chinese banks fail to process transactions for one or two days, that might not be a problem," Mr. Fung said. "But if the interruption is for four or five days, that's another issue."
Similarly, Hong Kong's major utility, CLP Power, buys some of its electricity from power plants in mainland China. Among those is the Daya Bay nuclear power station in neighboring Guangdong Province. A spokesman said 97 percent of CLP's Hong Kong systems were ready. But he acknowledged that the company had little control over Chinese suppliers like Daya Bay.
American computer companies have fears of a different sort. They sold China most of its 10 million computers. And although many have dispatched teams here to repair bugs, they are afraid of being dragged into Chinese courts if Year 2000-related glitches lead to costly interruptions in services.
"It's a very sensitive issue because relations with the Government are obviously very important," said Greg Shea, the director of communications and government affairs for Hewlett-Packard in Beijing.
Outsiders say they are impressed by the noise Ms. Zhang has generated since she became China's Year 2000 czar last August. With a propaganda campaign that includes advertising, newspaper articles and trips around the country, Ms. Zhang has introduced the term Y2K to the Chinese vocabulary.
China has also made splashy symbolic gestures -- such as requiring top officials of the Civil Aviation Administration to be aloft on New Year's Eve as a show of confidence in the air traffic control system.
But Ms. Zhang has been more successful as an evangelist than a trouble-shooter. That is because, in fixing Year 2000 problems, she must overcome a gantlet of technological, financial and institutional hurdles.
One big problem is that an estimated 96 percent of the software in China is pirated. Software manufacturers generally refuse to repair products not sold under a license. Faced with buying a license to become Year 2000 compliant, many Chinese companies simply opt to leave their equipment alone.
China's straitened finances are an even bigger hurdle. The central Government has given provincial and local governments a deadline to be compliant that is supposed to lead to repairing all identified problems by the end of September. But Beijing also says they must foot the bill.
China's banks alone have spent $600 million on Year 2000 fixes, according to Ms. Zhang, so selling the party bosses in China's unruly provinces on such a costly chore for public facilities and the many businesses still under government control is no small challenge.
"Officials who want to be promoted don't see this as an opportunity," said Chen Xinxiang, a gregarious engineer who is overseeing the Beijing municipal government's Year 2000 preparations.
Mr. Chen, who has a Ph.D. from Pennsylvania State University, took on the project as a sideline to his efforts to promote Internet use in Beijing. He said he was confident that China's capital would not suffer widespread breakdowns in transportation, telecommunications or electricity.
But Mr. Chen said there were potential trouble spots. The plant that supplies two-thirds of Beijing's water cannot be shut down for testing, and Mr. Chen said he did not know whether its computers were vulnerable. Water would still flow if the computers malfunctioned, but it might not be purified.
On April 9, Beijing had a kind of dry run for Jan. 1. Because it was the 99th day of 1999 -- many computers were programmed to read a string of 9's as the end of a file -- some experts said April 9 was the first of a series of dates that could cause electronic glitches. Mr. Chen said there were three computer crashes in the city: the reservations system of a luxury hotel, the network of a company, and the board that displays exchange rates at a bank.
"I've been telling people, 'This is a tiny version of the Y2K issue,' " Mr. Chen said. "It was like an alarm."
For all his jitters, Mr. Chen said he would happily fly on New Year's Eve. That reflects a growing view -- even among foreigners -- that China's skies will not be filled with dangerously wayward airplanes. Officials here contend they are only six months behind the Federal Aviation Administration in the testing and repair of the country's air traffic control system. (If so, that confidence could be overdone, since even the F.A.A. says it does not expect to finish until June.)
Yi Qun, the deputy director of the Civil Aviation Administration, said it was not hard to debug China's guidance and communications equipment because most of it was made by foreign suppliers.
With its top aviation officials at risk, China plans to adopt precautionary measures, such as spacing planes farther apart in the hours just before and after midnight on New Year's Eve, which falls on a Friday this year.
As the Year 2000 draws closer, the focus among computer companies here has shifted from how to get ready for Jan. 1 to how to deal with the fallout from inevitable failures afterward. I.B.M., Hewlett-Packard and other companies are bracing for a blizzard of lawsuits demanding compensation for Year 2000 losses.
"It's still far from clear that American companies will get a fair hearing in Chinese courts," Mr. Mecham said.
I.B.M. has played a central role in advising the Chinese Government on Year 2000 issues. But executives at rival companies said it was taking a low profile as the threat of lawsuits loomed. I.B.M. declined to discuss its efforts in China.
The companies may have reason to worry. Beijing initially ordered its ministries to demand free repairs. Suppliers that refused would no longer be allowed to sell products to the Government, according to a mid-1997 directive.
Ms. Zhang has since softened that line, saying China no longer expects companies to bear the entire cost of repairs. "The question is, how much should they pay?" she said. "Chinese users have already paid a lot. And as we know, big companies like I.B.M. never do anything free of charge."
In general, though, Ms. Zhang has cultivated close relations with the computer industry. It is easy to understand why: With 18 Government departments reporting to her on Year 2000 readiness, she needs a constant stream of advice from experts on where to channel her energies.
Of the Government departments, in fact, only the People's Liberation Army does not have to report to Ms. Zhang on the Year 2000 issue. "Maybe they are able to solve it themselves," she said with a faint smile.

HEADLINE: Edwin Dale Jr., 75, Reporter And an Expert in Economics

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
Edwin L. Dale Jr., a former economics reporter in the Washington bureau of The New York Times who later explained the intricacies of supply-side economics as a budget spokesman in the Reagan Administration, died today at the Washington Hospice.
He was 75 and was visiting in Washington when he died. He had homes in Delray Beach, Fla., and Osterville, Mass., on Cape Cod. 
 The cause was lung cancer, said his wife, Meredith.
Mr. Dale worked for The Times from 1955 to 1976. In his journalistic work, economists often found him as knowledgeable as they were. For example, Mr. Dale was credited by economists with being one of the first to establish that the roots of inflation lay as much in the service sector as in the pricing of goods. He came to this insight in the 1950's and helped bring it to public awareness.
Joseph Laitin, a spokesman for Government agencies including the Treasury Department, said, "One budget director commented to me after an interview that this man Dale was qualified to be budget director."
The economist Paul A. Volcker said, "It was pretty wild and woolly when I was Chairman of the Federal Reserve, and he was a voice of calm, common sense during that period."
Mr. Volcker said that when Mr. Dale became the spokesman for David A. Stockman, director of the Office of Management and Budget under President Ronald Reagan, "I thought that was a waste of a good journalist, going to the budget bureau."
Mr. Dale was born in Philadelphia and went to Yale University, where he was managing editor of The Yale Daily News and graduated in 1944, in time to serve as a naval officer in the Pacific in World War II.
His first newspaper job was with The Worcester Evening Gazette in Massachusetts in 1947 and he was an economics reporter for The New York Herald Tribune before joining The Times.
In 1968 Mr. Dale assisted on an important scoop on the escalation of the war in Vietnam.
Stanley Karnow, in his 1983 book "Vietnam: A History," wrote that Representative William Moorhead of Pennsylvania held a party at his home in Washington that was attended by Mr. Dale and Townsend Hoopes, the Under Secretary of the Air Force. Mr. Hoopes, Mr. Karnow said, had turned against the war and "hinted to Dale that a faction of the Pentagon was forming to resist a troop buildup in Vietnam."
Acting on Mr. Dale's hint, The Times was able to report on March 10 that President Lyndon B. Johnson was considering a Pentagon request to call up 206,000 more men at a time when the Administration was proclaiming that Communist forces had been crippled by losses suffered in their recent Tet offensive.
Mr. Dale was the author of "Conservatives in Power" (1960, Doubleday) and the principal author of "The People's Budget" (1995, Regency). He was co-editor, with his Times colleague Richard E. Mooney, of "Inflation and Recession?" (1958, Doubleday).
Mr. Dale was married to Mary Todd Hastings from 1950 until her death in 1983. In addition to Mrs. Dale, he is survived by a stepdaughter, Rosalind C. Dujardin of Bermuda; a stepson, Daniel C. Cross of Washington, and six step-grandchildren. 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Nasdaq Is Back in Favor, But Dow and S.& P. Slip

BYLINE: By The Associated Press 

 BODY:
Stock prices closed mixed yesterday after a choppy session that saw some profit taking in blue chips and renewed interest in technology shares.
The Dow Jones industrial average was off 24.34 points, to 11,007.25. The blue-chip index fluctuated between positive and negative territory throughout the session. 
 Broader stock indicators were mixed. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was down 4.70, to 1,340.30, but the Nasdaq composite index rose 22.77, to 2,526.39, largely on the strength of Internet stocks.
Blue-chip stocks fell in a reversal of last week's trading pattern, in which investors sold technology stocks and bought those of economically sensitive, or cyclical, companies. Yesterday, traders were unloading cyclicals like General Motors and Boeing.
"The market is a fickle mate, and on any given day, it's going to like the cyclicals and hate something else and on another day going to flip-flop and do just the opposite," said Charles Crane, chief market strategist at Key Asset Management.
One exception was aluminum stocks, which rose after Credit Suisse First Boston upgraded Kaiser Aluminum.
But while bond prices were stronger yesterday, consumer and financial services stocks declined amid concern about interest rates. Investors are concerned about the general upward movement in interest rates, particularly in light of two big auctions of Treasury securities this week, said Hugh Johnson, market strategist at the First Albany Corporation.
Rising interest rates typically prompt some selling in financial services stocks and also stocks trading at high prices relative to their earnings projections, Mr. Johnson said.
"Investors generally don't buy companies with high price-to-earnings ratios when interest rates are rising," he said, "and that generally hurts large companies, which tend to have the highest P/E ratios."
Big consumer stocks like Johnson & Johnson and Procter & Gamble, which depend on lower rates to keep consumers buying, were hit hard.
Meanwhile, merger news moved other stocks. HSBC Holdings is buying Republic National Bank of New York and an affiliated banking company for $10.3 billion in cash. Under the agreement, HSBC will pay $72 a share for the Republic New York Corporation and Safra Republic Holdings S.A. Republic's stock fell on the news, however.
Internet stocks were higher on reports USA Networks would abandon its bid to acquire Lycos after concluding it cannot win approval from Lycos shareholders. Lycos stock rose and USA Networks fell. Shares of CMGI Inc., a holding company that has about a 20 percent stake in Lycos, advanced.
In economic news, two manufacturing groups jointly reported that spending on machine tools in March rose 44 percent from February but declined 48 percent from a year earlier.
Analysts consider demand for machine tools a reliable indicator of the strength of the manufacturing sector and the overall economy. Don Carlson, president of the Association for Manufacturing Technology, said the group expected stronger results in the second half of this year.
 
Treasuries End Slide
 By Bloomberg News
 Treasury bond prices rose yesterday, snapping a two-day drop, as the highest 30-year Treasury yields in almost a year lured investors.
"It's a buying opportunity," said Alan Day, who helps oversee about $4 billion at Stratevest Group in Burlington, Vt. "There's an overreaction to the threat of inflation."
The price of the 30-year Treasury bond rose 9/32, to 92 13/32. The bond's yield, which moves in the opposite direction, fell to 5.79 percent, from 5.81 percent on Friday.

HEADLINE: Pataki Report Says Tax Cuts Helped Upstate

BYLINE: By LESLIE EATON 

 BODY:
As government officials in Albany remained deadlocked over the state budget, Gov. George E. Pataki released a report yesterday asserting that tax cuts enacted by his administration have prompted an economic revival in upstate New York.
The report, by Stephen Kagann, the Governor's chief economist, says that the number of nongovernmental jobs in the 52 counties north of the New York City metropolitan region has hit a record, and contends that manufacturers have started to add jobs in the Hudson Valley, the Mohawk Valley, and Syracuse. Manufacturing is particularly important upstate, employing almost 14 percent of private-sector workers, versus 10.5 percent of workers nationwide, according to the study. 
 The report puzzled some independent economists, who said that upstate shows few signs of an economic rebound. "If it's happening, you can't see it in the employment statistics," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Regional Financial Associates.
The economic problems in Asia have hit manufacturers across the country Mr. Kagann said. Nevertheless, some areas of the state were gaining manufacturing jobs while such jobs were declining nationwide, he said, "and that hasn't happened in New York State in 25 years."
The study was released as the Governor and State Legislature remain deadlocked over the state budget, which is more than a month overdue. The Governor has proposed further tax cuts and a very small increase in spending, and wants to use the state surplus to pay for future needs. The Democrat-controlled Assembly wants to skip the tax cuts and increase spending; the State Senate, which is controlled by Mr. Pataki's Republican Party, is somewhere in the middle.
Mr. Kagann's report asserts that for every $1 billion in tax revenues raised by state or local governments, upstate companies cut 45,000 jobs. The same amount of tax revenue does create government jobs -- but only 17,000, he said. "It's not a fair tradeoff," Mr. Kagann said.
Independent analysts agree that cutting taxes can have a positive effect on private-sector employment, especially in manufacturing.
But in addition to the tax burden, there are other factors that have dragged down the upstate economy, economists said, including the national decline in manufacturing, the mergers and sales of companies that have moved headquarters out of upstate, and Canada's weak economy.

HEADLINE: HSBC to Pay $10.3 Billion For Republic

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL 

DATELINE: LONDON, May 10

 BODY:
HSBC Holdings P.L.C. announced today that it would purchase the parent company of the Republic National Bank of New York for $10.3 billion cash, the biggest foreign takeover deal for an American banking company.
The purchase of the Republic New York Corporation and an affiliate by HSBC -- an international banking group based in London with antecedents in Hong Kong and Shanghai -- would double the size of HSBC's private-banking business. It would also give HSBC the third-biggest retail branch network in the New York region, serving lower- and middle-income customers with low-cost checking and free automated teller machine services. 
 Banking industry analysts said the deal largely reflected HSBC's efforts to expand its highly profitable private-banking operations, which serve very wealthy clients.
"Strategically it fits," said James Johnson, an analyst with Credit Lyonnais Securities. "It complements them in an area they have been pushing: wealth management."
The deal would likely result in layoffs at Republic's New York operations to eliminate duplication with HSBC Bank USA, the network of American branches formerly known as Marine Midland. Analysts also said that the effects of the deal on Republic's less affluent customers remained unclear, with the possibility of new services and higher fees. Page C6.
Republic's sale would mark the end of independence for a banking business founded more than three decades ago by Edmond Safra, a Lebanese-born Jewish businessman who is regarded as an enduring figure in the banking world.
Mr. Safra, 66, suffers these days from Parkinson's disease, a neurological disorder, and there had been growing speculation in recent days that he might sell. Republic's stock rose 14 percent on Friday, and HSBC's purchase plan was reported on Sunday evening by Bloomberg News.
Under the $72-a-share agreement, HSBC is buying the Republic New York Corporation and an affiliated company, Safra Republic Holdings S.A., the parent of banks that serve clients in havens like Switzerland, Luxembourg and Monaco.
HSBC has grown aggressively out of its roots in the colonial Hongkong and Shanghai Bank. It is now a major competitor in the business of managing money for the wealthy, a profitable business that helps offset the risks in such other operations as loans to emerging-market countries of Asia.
The deal would surpass the previous record for a foreign takeover of an American bank, the $10.1 billion purchase of Bankers Trust by Deutsche Bank announced late last year. It would also be HSBC's biggest purchase since it acquired Marine Midland Bank of Britain for $6.1 billion in 1992, which led to the relocation of its headquarters from Hong Kong to London.
The combined HSBC and Republic would have assets of $554.4 billion and currently employs 136,700 people. HSBC said that it would finance the purchase partly through through borrowing and a $3 billion stock sale, and that the deal would eventually result in $300 million annual savings.
Its spokesman, Adrian Russell, said the move would maintain the bank's stated intention to balance its holdings in the industrial world with investment in emerging markets. And, he said, "It gives us an extra million customers in the world's biggest economy."
The acquisition requires regulatory approval in Britain, the United States, Hong Kong and elsewhere, but Mr. Russell said HSBC hoped to complete it by the end of the year.
HSBC announced last year that it would list its shares for trading in the United States, and there has since been speculation that it planned a big American acquisition.
After rising Friday on takeover speculation, Republic shares fell $1.9375, to $68.0625, in New York today. Safra Republic shares, traded in Luxembourg, soared 17.5 euros to close at 66 euros. Both HSBC Holdings and HSBC's separate class A shares fell more than 2 percent here.
By purchasing Safra Republic Holdings, HSBC will acquire 30,000 international clients in high-margin private banking, a business that generally caters to people with $1 million and more to invest. The affiliate has 44 offices holding client funds that total $56.5 billion.
"What they want to capture is an ever-growing number of millionaires in Asia and, to some extent, in Latin America," said Simon Samuels, a banking analyst with Salomon Smith Barney here. Wealth management, he said, was also seen as "the flavor of the next century" on the assumption that with governments less able to provide pensions, there would be a corresponding boom in private investment by individuals.
John Bond, HSBC's chairman, said: "The acquisitions we have announced today will bring together two complementary private banking franchises. At the stroke of a pen, it doubles the size of our consumer-banking operations in the United States, and it doubles the size of our private-banking business around the world."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: TRADE;
Aides Fear Clinton's China Deal Has Become Collateral Damage

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
In the days just before NATO mistakenly bombed the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, Administration officials were already voicing fears that they might have missed their moment to strike a political deal to get China into the World Trade Organization.
Such a deal has been the centerpiece of President Clinton's much-debated effort to build a "web of engagement" with Beijing. Now the hopes of patching it together in a few months are fading, and White House officials doubt that they will have the political opportunity to get it through Congress after that. 
 The bombing has clearly fueled the nationalist sentiments that were forcing Prime Minister Zhu Rongji, China's leading economic reformer, to pull back some of the concessions he offered a month ago.
That, in turn, creates a backlash here. Lawmakers who were wavering about whether to support the deal that Mr. Clinton nearly had in hand seem virtually certain to reject any accord with lesser concessions.
But that is only the beginning of the problem. The images of Chinese tossing bricks at the American Embassy may harden the views of powerful figures including Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, who argue that the United States should not aid China's efforts to seek prestige through membership in the group that sets the rules of world trade.
Senator Lott has said he opposes China's entry because of Beijing's alleged espionage efforts and human rights abuses. For its part, the AFL-CIO has vowed to oppose the deal for fear that American jobs will be lost.
"Before the bombing of the Chinese Embassy, it was very optimistic for the Administration to think they could get this together before the summer," said Senator Max Baucus, a Montana Democrat who has been leading the effort in the Senate to get China into the trade group and whose constituents export farm products to Asia. Now, he said, "it's much harder."
"But to a great extent," he said, "this is now in the hands of the Chinese."
Senator Baucus is among many inside and outside the Administration who are critical of President Clinton's decision to walk away from the market-opening concessions that Mr. Zhu offered last month in everything from agriculture to foreign ownership of cellular phone concerns. Had a deal been initialed then, Mr. Baucus argues, it would probably be far less vulnerable today.
It is too early to tell, some Clinton aides say, whether the President himself harbors second thoughts about not having closed an agreement while Mr. Zhu was here.
By some accounts, Mr. Clinton castigated a few of his advisers after Mr. Zhu's visit, saying that while the President was focused on Kosovo, his aides should have been finding ways to quickly close the negotiating gap.
That outburst led to a last-minute effort to rescue a deal. Mr. Clinton's called Mr. Zhu in New York on April 13, offering to send negotiators to Beijing immediately to finish up the talks. They arrived days after Mr. Zhu's return but ran into obstacles.
Chinese negotiators, under attack at home for giving so much away, floated suggestions that the 14-page list of Chinese concessions that the Administration published during Mr. Zhu's visit was no longer on the table. The American team returned home empty-handed. In the aftermath of the Belgrade bombing, it is unclear whether they will return to Beijing next week as scheduled.
"What we're hoping," one official said, "is that the anti-American protests run their course and Zhu can proceed with his reforms." In that case, the reforms would include the kind of opening of markets that entry into the trade group would require.
But it is a chancy bet. And if it turns out that the embassy bombing was a turning point -- that the deal within Mr. Clinton's grasp a month ago has become part of the collateral damage of the Kosovo conflict -- then the effects could be serious and lasting. For the deal was less about trade than about gloabl strategy, accommodating China's rising economic power to a world system in which Beijing still feels treated as an outsider.
"This is a case where they probably could have gotten it through Congress," said Nicholas Lardy, a scholar at the Brookings Institution. "Whether they could get the same deal right now is highly uncertain."
But Mr. Lardy noted that while China suspended various talks with the United States today, it did not withdraw from the trade talks.

HEADLINE: Candidates Falling Into the Open Arms Of High Technology

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, May 10

 BODY:
Vice President Al Gore makes a point in his Seattle visits of stopping at Internet companies like Amazon.com, the on-line commerce pioneer. Other Presidential hopefuls, including Senator John McCain, Representative John R. Kasich and former Senator Bill Bradley, have recently toured Microsoft's campus here.
So far Gov. George W. Bush of Texas has not come near either Seattle or Silicon Valley in Northern California. But that did not stop a group of high-technology executives from taking out a newspaper advertisement in The San Jose Mercury News last month, calling Mr. Bush one of the "visionary leaders who understand the New Economy" and urging him to run for President. 
 The dance is on between Presidential candidates and high-technology executives, who were once regarded as bit players in campaign finance and whose industry in turn prided itself on its libertarian streak and almost dismissive attitude toward whatever was happening in Washington, D.C. Facing a host of tax and regulatory issues, and with the landmark Microsoft antitrust case serving as a powerful reminder that Federal officials can still sway the competitive landscape, many industry executives are clearly deciding that it pays to have friends in the White House and Capitol.
Mr. Gore, who has long sought to position himself as the Administration's champion of computer technology and the Internet, has extensive contacts in the industry and pulled in roughly $400,000 last month at a Silicon Valley fund-raiser given by John Doerr, a founder of Technology Network, widely known as Technet, the prime lobbying and fund-raising organization of the industry.
But Mr. Gore's competitor for the Democratic nomination, Mr. Bradley, who spent a year as a visiting professor at Stanford University in which he nursed his own Silicon Valley contacts, has also done well, taking in about $1 million at a large San Francisco fund-raiser last month that was well-populated with industry executives.
And Governor Bush, though pledged to stay in Texas until the end of the legislative session this spring, is planning big fund-raisers for San Francisco and Palo Alto in early summer. Among those who signed the recent pro-Bush newspaper advertisement, which praised the Republican Mr. Bush for "creating an environment that stresses personal responsibility over government intervention, and innovation over regulation," were James Barksdale, founder of Netscape; Bob Herbold, chief operating officer of the Microsoft Corporation; Jeff Henley, chief financial officer of the Oracle Corporation, and Steve Behm, a vice president of Cisco Systems.
It is still early in the campaign cycle, but it is already certain that computer-industry donations will be a bigger factor in the 2000 elections than they have previously been.
"Unless high-tech people unplug their telephones, sign off E-mail and leave the country in the next 18 months, they're going to give more than they've ever given before," said Larry Makinson, executive director of the Center for Responsive Politics, a nonpartisan group that tracks campaign finances. "They're certainly being hit up like never before."
Contributions to 1998 Congressional campaigns from the high-tech industry totaled about $8.1 million, more than twice as much as the total in the 1994 campaigns. Even as industry contributions will continue to grow in 2000, they will probably still be well below the dollars spent by other industries, like energy and banking, that have had large lobbying and campaign-donation operations in place for a long time.
Microsoft, whose total campaign contributions in 1998, $1 million, were more than triple its 1996 contributions, according to the Center for Responsive Politics, is planning to have a major presence in the 2000 campaign. (The contributions include individual giving by company employees, political action committee donations and so-called soft money, which is given to the political parties rather than the candidates.)
A Microsoft spokesman, Greg Shaw, said the company acknowledged it was "a little slow in recognizing the importance of being a more visible and more active participant in Washington," but was now intent on "sharing its views and experience" with policy leaders there.
For the Presidential aspirants, the booming industry is not just an obvious source of money. It is also the creator of technology that they are intent on understanding, since it could be vital to their campaigns.
The number of American households with Internet access has doubled to nearly 44 million since the last Presidential election, according to Forrester Research Inc., a company that monitors technology trends. Candidates are already trying to use the World Wide Web to attract voters, with sites that offer video clips, questionnaires and invitations for visitors to "get involved" by volunteering to work for the campaign, donating money or at least signing up for regular E-mail updates.
For the high-technology executives, there is a growing array of reasons to want good friends in Congress or the White House. They have already won legislation creating a moratorium on taxes for Internet commerce, special visas for skilled foreign workers and an extension of tax credits for research and development, though they have had only minor success so far in measures to limit lawsuits for problems related to the year 2000 computer glitch.
Still, while the more established interests in the relatively young computer industry, like Microsoft and America Online, are getting increasingly involved in the political process, many newer Internet companies and their top executives do not show significant signs of doing so, even as their stock prices have climbed so high that their market value has eclipsed that of huge companies in other industries.
"When you're Amazon.com," said Wade Randlett, Democratic political director of Technet, the industry group, "you're a new company and you're trying to grow at 50 percent a quarter and your competitors are trying to kill you -- that just doesn't allow you to devote a lot of time to anything else."
A spokesman for Amazon.com, Bill Curry, said the company had recently designated a person on the legal staff to monitor public-policy issues related to the Internet, and was evaluating whether the company needed to do a better job of establishing contact with public officials.
"We want to avoid the mistake of being so focused on building a business that some day we find out we need relationships in Washington and we don't have any," Mr. Curry said.
Calculating the precise impact the high-technology industry is having on the 2000 campaign is difficult. The most recent filings with the Federal Election Commission, for instance, show contributions by individuals through March 31 and do not reflect big fund-raisers held by both Mr. Gore and Mr. Bradley in the San Francisco Bay Area last month.
The commission reports show Mr. Gore with about $83,000 in direct contributions from executives at high-technology companies, but they do not show the roughly $400,000 he pulled in at the fund-raiser given by Mr. Doerr, a leading industry venture capitalist.
Many computer companies, which had little presence in Washington in the past, have set up political action committees for corporate giving that are expected to make major contributions to candidates or the national parties as the campaign heats up.
Moreover, while many computer companies applaud the Federal lawsuit against Microsoft, in which a ruling is expected this summer, and thus may have a reason to reward Mr. Gore, the case is also a reminder that the Government has the potential to wield enormous power in shaping the industry, all the more reason for computer executives to take an interest in campaigns.
The Microsoft antitrust battle is an obvious reason for anyone in the industry to pay more attention to Washington, even as the company says the case does not belong in a Federal courtroom.
"A few of our competitors decided that Washington, D.C., was a place where they could out-compete us on issues that in our view would have been better resolved in the marketplace," said Mr. Shaw, the Microsoft spokesman.
As Microsoft has become far more active in both making campaign contributions and deploying lobbyists, and tried to fend off a lawsuit pushed by a Democratic Administration, there is no question that the Republican Party has benefited.
About two-thirds of the company's total contributions last year went to Republicans. In 1992, just 20 percent of them did.
And Republican Presidential candidates, including Senator McCain of Arizona and Representative Kasich of Ohio, have traveled to Microsoft recently to meet with top officials.
Microsoft executives said that the company was "steadfastly bipartisan" and that increases on the Republican side were attributable to the party's having taken control of Congress in 1994. Across the industry in general, many executives are not particularly partisan, meaning that either party could make inroads.
"More than anything else, Silicon Valley is on the 50-yard-line of the political spectrum," Mr. Randlett of Technet said. "It's strongly free-market, free trade, pro-economic growth. And it's pro-choice, pro-public education and pro-environment, with the same if not greater fervor than the belief in free-market philosophy. Whichever candidate is most centrist is going to do best here."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: DIPLOMACY;
EMBASSY BOMBING MAY BADLY IMPEDE KOSOVO DIPLOMACY

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
NATO's bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade threatens to drag out a diplomatic solution in Kosovo and to inflict long-term damage on an already-troubled relationship between the United States and China, officials said today.
Although Clinton Administration officials were confident at first that the crisis would soon blow over, they now see signs that the Chinese Government may delay a United Nations Security Council resolution requiring an international security force in Kosovo, a senior Administration official said. That resolution is at the heart of a proposed diplomatic settlement of the conflict. 
 The Chinese signaled today that they would try to obstruct the Administration's diplomatic strategy by demanding that NATO first halt its bombing against Yugoslavia before the Security Council could consider any other action on Kosovo.
Yugoslavia's President, Slobodan Milosevic, announced a partial withdrawal of his forces from Kosovo, a move that may be intended to take advantage of the turmoil caused by the Chinese incident and to splinter support within NATO for the American-led bombing campaign.
He did not specify the number of troops involved, and NATO and Pentagon officials said they saw no signs of a pullout. Page A10. President Clinton insisted that Mr. Milosevic had to meet all of NATO's conditions.
At the United Nations today, the Chinese representative, Qin Huasun, said suspending the air strikes was an essential precondition for any discussion by the Security Council on Kosovo. "Anything short of that is impossible for the Security Council to discuss any plan to solve the problem,' he said.
China also announced today that it was suspending high-level military ties and a number of ongoing talks about issues the Administration sees at the heart of the American-Chinese relationship, including human rights.
The bombing may also imperil an important overture, the possible entry of China into the World Trade Organization. Page A11.
Anti-Western officials in Beijing are using the embassy bombing to make their case against economic concessions that Prime Minister Zhu Rongji offered during his trip to Washington last month.
The Administration has based much of its strategy for improved relations with China on extending economic ties. Administration officials had hoped to finish negotiations in the next few months, when they believed that the Senate would be more amenable. Congress's indirect approval would be necessary for China to enter the trade organization.
But just as anti-Americanism is riding high in Beijing, anti-Chinese anger is simmering in Congress, with Senators angry over reports of Chinese efforts to steal American satellite and nuclear technology.
To try to calm China, which contends that the bombing was not a mistake, President Clinton apologized for the third time today. He sent a letter to the President, Jiang Zemin, on Sunday and publicly expressed regrets on Saturday.
"I want to say to the Chinese people and to the leaders of China, I apologize, I regret this," Mr. Clinton said in remarks before a ceremony on youth and violence at the White House.
Mr. Milosevic's announcement of a troop pullback did not say how many of his estimated 40,000 troops in Kosovo would be removed, and NATO was dismissive of the offer. Indeed, Jamie P. Shea, the NATO spokesman, suggested that the announcement could be a cover for a rotation of troops.
Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright dismissed the announcement as a "half measure."
Mr. Clinton said, "I'm encouraged by any good word." But he, like other NATO officials who were cautious in their reaction, insisted that other terms must be met to reach a settlement. "I think that the conditions that we set out are the minimal ones," the President added.
As the Administration worked at holding its Kosovo policy together, the Russian envoy, Viktor S. Chernomyrdin, arrived in Beijing to talk to Chinese officials about Kosovo.
Mr. Chernomyrdin changed his travel plans and headed for Beijing.
Administration officials said they assumed that because the Russians were eager to play a predominant role in finding a solution in Kosovo, Mr. Chernomyrdin would encourage the Chinese to be amenable.
Even so, the image of senior officials of two anti-NATO countries, China and Russia, meeting over Kosovo, the place where NATO's future hangs in the balance, was unsettling for Administration officials.
But in the end, the officials said, they were confident that Mr. Chernomyrdin would ask the Chinese not to block a Security Council resolution on the international security force.
"For the Russians, the United Nations is an important venue, and it's important for them to argue back home that they've brought this issue back to the United Nations and out of the hands of NATO," a Russia expert in the Administration said. "I think their position to the Chinese is going to be: 'Don't screw up the possibility of a Security Council resolution. Let's try and get it closer to our terms.' "
After his visit to Beijing, Mr. Chernomyrdin was expected to meet in Moscow with Deputy Secretary of State Strobe Talbott on Wednesday to discuss details on the planned international security force.
Among the questions that need to be addressed are which countries would be represented in the force and the rules of engagement for the soldiers, State Department officials said. Just as crucial was the issue of how far Mr. Milosevic had to pull back his forces and over what period of time, so that NATO could consider a pause in the bombing.
On all these matters, there are considerable differences between the Russians and NATO. The Russians, for instance, would like a bombing pause first, before a troop withdrawal by Mr. Milosevic.
And as the allies and the Russians negotiated among themselves, Mr. Milosevic has still to be formally approached with a cohesive plan.
The aftermath of the bombing of the embassy was sure to affect the talks in Moscow, the State Department officials said. The internal struggles in the Yeltsin Government -- with anti-NATO hard-liners emboldened by the NATO mistake -- could make Mr. Talbott's mission more difficult, according to these officials.
The Security Council became a pivotal part of the solution in Kosovo last week when the seven richest industrial countries and Russia agreed to a set of principles that would end the war, including a proposed international security force.
The President's national security adviser, Samuel R. Berger, said during the weekend that he believed that the Chinese would not veto the international force, for doing so "would put them in the position of wanting to prolong the bombing and being against peace," he said.
But others were not so hopeful. "Whether the Chinese will calm down in a week or two is not at all clear," a State Department official said.

HEADLINE: METRO NEWS BRIEFS: NEW JERSEY;
New Group Will Promote Newark Airport

DATELINE: NEWARK

 BODY:
Continental Airlines and several chambers of commerce announced a coalition yesterday to promote the economic importance of Newark International Airport. The effort is being introduced as a proposed $1 billion upgrade of Continental's Newark terminal is threatened by political turmoil at the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
Continental and the Port Authority plan to build a third concourse at the terminal for the wide-body jets needed to handle more passengers without increasing flights, said Michele Treacy, a Continental spokeswoman. She said Continental would pay $700 million of the cost, and the Port Authority would pay the rest. 
 But like a proposed expansion at Kennedy International Airport, the Newark plan has been stalled by a dispute between Gov. George E. Pataki of New York and Gov. Christine Todd Whitman of New Jersey involving the structure of the two-state agency and lease negotiations with two shipping companies.

HEADLINE: WINE TALK;
Meet The Wallflowers Of Bordeaux

BYLINE: By FRANK J. PRIAL 

 BODY:
CAN'T afford Chateau Margaux any more? Or Chateau Latour, or Chateau Any-Other-Famous-Bordeaux? Have you thought of trying your favorite chateau's second wine?
The principal wine of any Bordeaux chateau is the one that bears its name. But every vineyard produces some grapes that are better than others. Some chateaus mix all their grapes together and ferment them into a single wine. It is a practice that is dying out, and the result is a growing class of second wines, which may not be made from the best of grapes, but do come from the finest houses. 
 They are worth knowing about because for a relatively low price -- $50 compared with $240 in one example -- you are buying the expertise of the great winemakers of the world.
Second labels are mostly a Bordeaux phenomenon, closely associated with the chateau system, although winemakers around the world have resorted to separate names for lesser wines from their principal vineyards. The difference is that outside Bordeaux, the second label doesn't have a consistent meaning.
In fact, in most places -- Italy, Spain, Latin America and California -- the second wine can be the better wine. For example, the very best cabernet sauvignon from Robert Mondavi Winery is designated a "reserve" wine to set it apart from the regular bottlings. But to confuse matters, many more California wineries use terms like "reserve," "proprietor's reserve" or "winemaker's reserve" as meaningless designations on inexpensive, commercial wines they buy in bulk. Mostly, they are just dressing up the label.
But in Bordeaux, the meaning of a second label is very specific. Few Bordeaux vineyards are a single entity surrounding the chateau whose name they bear. Many family-owned vineyards have been cut up over the years to satisfy the demands of France's draconian inheritance laws. Some chateaus have as many as 40 separate parcels of vines spread around the commune in which they are located. A map of most chateaus' vineyard holdings will look like a patchwork quilt.
Because these parcels often have different soil, different irrigation, even different microclimates, they are harvested and vinified separately. What's more, within each parcel of vines, the different grape varieties will also be picked and vinified separately.
The result is many different vats of wine. The best go into the principal wine, called the grand vin; the rest go into the second wine, also known as the second label.
Thirty years ago, when Edmund Penning-Rowsell wrote "The Wines of Bordeaux," the first important book on the subject in English, he barely mentioned second wines. The sixth edition of his book (Penguin, 1989), lists dozens of them.
Some second wines are well known. Les Forts de Latour, the second wine of Chateau Latour, is better known than the first wines of many other chateaus. So is Bahans-Haut-Brion of Chateau Haut-Brion, Pavillon Rouge of Chateau Margaux, Amiral de Beychevelle of Chateau Beychevelle and Carruades de Lafite of Chateau Lafite-Rothschild.
In Bordeaux, second wines are usually, but not always, the product of young vines. A good grapevine maintains its vigor for 35 to 40 years before it is replaced. Almost every Bordeaux chateau has sections of new or young vines whose fruit is no match for that produced by mature vines.
Similarly, different portions of a vineyard produce different quality fruit.
Some parts could have been damaged by hail, for example, while others remained untouched.
Then, too, the grapes mature at different times: merlot is usually first, followed by cabernet sauvignon and, even later, cabernet franc and petit verdot. Each variety is picked separately and fermented individually.
Even a moderate size modern chateau may have as many as 30 fermentation vats to accommodate the different batches of grapes. The blending process, called the assemblage, determines how much wine will go into the first wine and how much into the second.
At this point, economics steps in.
At a great property, owned by a Parisian banker or an insurance company, prestige will always outweigh profit. If half the year's production is deemed even slightly inferior, it will go into the second wine or will be sold off in bulk. There have been years when some chateaus deemed none of their wine good enough for the grand vin.
A lesser property, whose owner makes his living from his wine, may not be able to afford the luxury of such severe selection. Consequently, his wine is not as good as it might be were he able to reject some of his lesser vats.
Alexis Lichine, the late wine writer and owner of Chateau Prieure-Lichine in Margaux, once observed: "Rigorous selection is what really permits the large properties in Bordeaux to be very discriminating, thus enabling them to make the top wines. Selling part of your production at half-price is a discipline demanding a sacrifice that not many chateaus are willing, or can afford, to make."
For the Bordeaux-loving consumer, buying a second label is a question of perceived value. The 1995 Chateau Lafite-Rothschild currently sells in New York for about $240 a bottle. The chateau's second wine, Carruades de Lafite, sells for about $50 -- not a bad price for a wine from Lafite-Rothschild in today's overheated market.
But is the Carruades better than, say, Chateau Pichon-Baron, a grand vin also from the commune of Paui llac, and also about $50?
Sometimes, the price spread between a chateau's first and second wine is not so great. While a 1994 Chateau Haut-Brion will cost around $135 and the Bahans-Haut-Brion of the same vintage about $33, the Chateau Lagrange 1995 from St.-Julien sells for about $40 and its second wine, Les Fiefs de Lagrange, from the same year, is priced at about $25.
Obviously, the second wine of a famous chateau will have been made with all the care and skill of the first wine. Some second wines develop a passionate following of their own. But most live in the reflected glory of their famous siblings; good wines, yes, but not necessarily better than lesser-known chateaus whose first wines sell for the same prices.
Some of my own favorites among the seconds would include the Fiefs de Lagrange, mentioned above; two St.-Estephes -- Frank Phelan, the second of Chateau Phelan Segur, and Les Pagodes de Cos, the second of Chateau Cos d'Estournel -- and Clos de Marquis, the second of Chateau Leoville-Las-Cases.
The second wine of Chateau Mouton-Rothschild can be delicious, too, but it is made in tiny quantities and is rarely seen. It's called Le Petit Mouton, but there is nothing petit about it.
 
TASTINGS
RICH CHILEAN
 
Errazuriz Chardonnay Reserva 1996, Casablanca Valley, Chile. About $15.
THE Casablanca Valley is only a few miles from the Pacific Ocean, which has the same moderating effect on the vines that it does on California vineyards. But the climate and the soil, sandy loam, produce a different style chardonnay from that of California vines. The wine is intense and rich but displays less of the buttery, over-oaked quality of California chardonnays.
The weather in these Chilean vineyards was cooler than normal in 1996 and produced wines with higher acidity, a decided asset. It is, as it should be, a wine for food and not an aperitif.
The style is restrained, and while it retains its own character, it should appeal to devotees of white Burgundy.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Technology andInternet Issues Brighten Wall St.'s Day

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
Stocks were buffeted by a further selloff in the bond market yesterday but recovered and moved higher, led by technology and Internet shares.
Bond prices fell and long-term interest rates rose to their highest level in nearly a year after an auction of new five-year notes was poorly received. Major stock market averages dipped after the auction results were announced in the afternoon but then regained some of their footing. 
 "There is still a lot of concern in the bond market about an overheated economy and what that means for inflation," said Ned Riley Jr., chief investment officer at the BankBoston Corporation. "But that concern seems to be less of an issue in the stock market."
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 18.90 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 11,026.15. But broader market measures did appreciably better.
Buttressed by sharp gains in America Online, Wal-Mart and Cisco Systems, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index gained 15.31 points, or 1.14 percent, to 1,355.61. Meanwhile, the Nasdaq composite index rose 40.29 points, or 1.6 percent, to 2,566.68. The Russell 2000 index of smaller-company stocks increased 4.96 points, or 1.12 percent, to 446.81.
Stocks sensitive to the business cycle, which have moved sharply higher over the last month on signs of vigorous economic growth, surrendered their leadership role yesterday to the well-known, big-capitalization growth stocks that have been the market's standard bearers for a number of years.
International Paper, a Dow component, fell 2 1/4, to 53 7/8. Allied Signal, another Dow stock, fell 1 3/8, to 63 9/16 . And Georgia-Pacific fell 4 3/16 , to 56 15/16 .
By contrast, Internet stocks, which have been under selling pressure over the last few weeks, did much better yesterday.
The group was led higher by America Online, which surged after Mary Meeker, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter's influential Internet analyst, upgraded the company to "strong buy" from "outperform." Later in the session, the company announced that it would develop an Internet television service with several partners.
America Online, which was the most actively traded issue on the New York Stock Exchange, rose 13 1/8, to 141 7/16 .
Cisco Systems, another big company with important ties to the Internet, gained 2 5/8, to 111 7/8. After the market closed, the company posted earnings that were slightly above expectations and announced a 2-for-1 stock split. Mr. Riley and other analysts said the Cisco earnings report could get technology stocks additional momentum today.
Strong earnings helped lift the price of Wal-Mart Stores, a component of both the Dow and the S.& P. 500. Wal-Mart gained 2 1/8, to 47 5/16 .
Despite the rise in interest rates, a number of financial service stocks did well.
