HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Rising Stocks (and Wishful Thinking) in Japan

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON 

 BODY:
Japan's economy may be dead in the water, but the nation is once again the land of the rising stock market. The question is, when will Japan's economy, the world's second largest, begin to justify investors' increasingly high hopes?
So far this year, the benchmark Nikkei index of 225 stocks is up 20.96 percent in yen terms, surpassing even the Dow Jones industrial average. Anyone who invested in the Nikkei in dollars has a 13.58 percent gain for the year. Shares of small Japanese companies are doing even better than the big blue chips. 
 Pushing stock prices higher is a consensus among economists that the worst is over for Japan. Last year, the nation's gross domestic product declined 2.8 percent. In general, economists expect output to shrink only 1.5 percent this year.
Japan, which an economist says is responsible for 20 percent of the world's production of goods, has been mired in its deepest recession since the end of World War II. While some numbers and anecdotal information coming from Japan very recently have seemed positive -- consumer spending has stopped dropping, automobile sales have risen a bit -- real evidence of a rebound is scanty.
"The passage of the bank reform legislation last fall and the extra fiscal stimulus gave people confidence," said Carl B. Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y. "But investors' expectations for the timetable are too optimistic."
This optimism is evident in the buckets of money pouring into Japanese stocks. According to Robert Adler, president of AMG Data Services, money flowing into mutual funds that invest in Japanese equities has exceeded that going into any foreign market in recent weeks. On Feb. 24, assets in Japanese equity funds totaled $1.73 billion, but have since risen to $3.02 billion, a 75 percent increase. Only a relatively small part of that increase in value comes from market gains.
Over the last month, some $77 billion a week has gone into Japanese equity funds. "Japanese inflows are the heaviest they've been since June 1997," Mr. Adler said. "Then, a nine- consecutive-week period with relatively heavy flows was brought to a screeching halt by the Thai baht collapse. Outflows started and investor sentiment hasn't recovered until now."
Many of those putting money into Japan are doing so in the belief that the economy is about to turn up. Others are probably trend-followers, jumping into whatever investment is the top performer of late. Since Japanese stock funds headed the performance lists for international mutual funds offered by United States fund companies in the first quarter of 1999, they have attracted even more attention. And now that interest rates on Japan Government bonds have dropped to 1.32 percent, Japanese investors seem to be heading into stocks, as well.
"Stock markets can be wrong," said Robert H. Parks, professor of finance at the Lubin Graduate School of Business at Pace University. Mr. Parks believes that investors are mistaking low interest rates in Japan -- money market rates are close to zero -- as evidence of relatively easy monetary policy, an approach that would turn the economy around. "But low interest rates are not evidence of fiscal monetary stimulation; they are evidence of a collapsing economy," he said.
Indeed, through March 31, tax revenue was down 7.1 percent, consumer prices had fallen 3.9 percent, and residential land values in Tokyo declined 1 percent. Mr. Weinberg expects corporate earnings to be disappointing and the nation's output for 1999 to be down much more sharply than the 1.5 percent that most economists are projecting.
One of the most closely watched figures compiled in Japan is the so-called bank lending number, a report of lending activities from 19 city banks, which is due late Thursday. A rise in lending, which has been falling for almost two years, would be a harbinger of an improved economy, Mr. Weinberg said. But he suspects that lending is still on the downswing. In March, bank lending fell 3.6 percent from a year earlier; his forecast for April is a 4.1 percent drop from the 1998 period.
Mr. Weinberg said that growth in the gross domestic product does not usually show up until three to four quarters after money and credit have begun to expand. "That means that at the soonest, it will be the first quarter of 2000 before meaningful economic expansion takes place," he said. "And for that to happen, everything has to be perfect."
To try to jump-start the economy, Japanese policy makers have cut taxes and increased spending on public works. But the spending has been financed by the issuance of Government bonds, the wrong approach according to Mr. Parks, because it sops up private funds that might otherwise go to investment or consumption.
Instead, Tokyo must increase the money supply by rolling the printing presses, Mr. Parks said. Policy makers are afraid to do this for fear of pushing the yen down and inflation up. The recent 3.5 percent increase in the broad supply of money in Japan has simply been the result of consumers shifting money around, not the creation of new money, an economist said.
"I'm concerned that Japan's sovereign debt will be downgraded again if they don't shift their policies," Mr. Parks said. "And if yields on sovereign debt shoot up, what would that mean for credit demands that have collapsed as it is? Once the economic decline gains a self-reinforcing momentum, you go right into a depression."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
The approach of summer's first holiday gives signs of a crowded tourist season ahead.

BYLINE: By Edwin McDowell 

 BODY:
STILL haven't made reservations for summer vacation? Well don't wait any longer, because the AAA auto club predicted yesterday that from Memorial Day through Labor Day (the unofficial summer season) Americans would make a record 271 million trips of at least 100 miles from home. Over Memorial Day weekend alone, a record 33.3 million people are expected to get away.
The projections for both the summer and Memorial Day represent a 4 percent increase over the respective travel numbers for 1998, a year in which overall summer travel figures jumped 7 percent from the summer of 1997. If the projections hold, this Memorial Day will be the fourth this decade to show an increase of more than one million in the number of people traveling at least 100 miles from home. 
 The projections are based on an AAA-commissioned national travel survey of 1,500 adults by the Travel Industry Association of America.
The AAA also projects that summer travelers can expect increases of slightly more than 1 percent this year in the costs of meals and lodging, for an average total of $213 a day for a family of four. By contrast, an analysis released on Monday by PricewaterhouseCoopers and Bear, Stearns & Company forecast that Americans would pay "much more" for summer travel this year over last, because of higher prices for hotels, fuel, car rentals and, possibly, domestic leisure air fares.
Whatever the cost, all parties agree that within three weeks, the roads and skies of the United States will begin filling with travelers.
 
2 Cities Add Flights
Business travelers and city officials in New Orleans and Cleveland expect to benefit mightily next month when Trans World Airlines begins a new daily nonstop on June 1 between New Orleans and Mexico City that originates in New York, and when Continental Airlines begins daily nonstop service on June 30 between Cleveland and Gatwick Airport in London.
New Orleans officials expect the T.W.A. flight to increase corporate and leisure travel to their city by millions of dollars a year, and to position New Orleans as a hub for commerce with Latin America.
Projections for the Cleveland-London flight, the first nonstop flight between Cleveland and Europe, are that it will add about $200 million a year to the economy of northeastern Ohio.
To attract the T.W.A. flight, which will be the only daily nonstop between New Orleans and Mexico City, several corporations -- including Harrah's Entertainment, which expects to open a New Orleans casino this fall -- agreed to buy an undisclosed number of tickets for an undisclosed price for a certain period. In addition, New Orleans International Airport agreed to reduce T.W.A.'s landing fees for that flight.
The Cleveland-London flight is symbolic of Continental's steady expansion at Cleveland Hopkins International Airport -- to 268 daily departures currently from 205 in 1995. But it did not hurt matters that $120 million is being spent to expand the airport, including $92 million for a concourse for Continental's regional carrier, Express Jet, scheduled to begin service on Sunday.
With aircraft flying so full over the last couple of years, it is tempting to conclude that passengers will automatically flock to each new flight. Not so. Which is why airlines often start or cancel routes, add or reduce frequencies, fly seasonal schedules and change the size of the planes used on particular routes.
 
Airline Perks
Fly first class or business class to Japan before May 31 and Japan Airlines will give you your choice of up to $300 in American Express gift checks, two free nights at the Bellagio Hotel in Las Vegas, Nev., or private car service from Narita Airport to your hotel in Tokyo.
Fly United Airlines and stay at a Hilton Hotel and you will earn points in Hilton's HHonors program and also in United's frequent-flier program, Mileage Plus. The offer is good through May 31, 2000.
 
Hotels
United States hotels won 5 of the 10 spots in Gourmet magazine's ranking of the best hotels in the world, and one of them -- the Halekulani Honolulu -- came in first The others were the Ritz-Carlton, Naples, Fla. (No. 6); the Boulders, Carefree, Ariz. (7); the Greenbrier, White Sulphur Springs, W.Va. (8) and the Phoenician, Scottsdale, Ariz. (9). The survey of the magazine's readers was conducted by the Willard & Shullman market research firm in Greenwich, Conn.
The renovated 210-room Sheraton Phoenix Airport Hotel has reopened in Tempe, Ariz., with an executive club, conference center and other amenities for business travelers. In Aurora, Colo., the 157-room Hilton Garden Inn Denver Airport is open for business, with a 24-hour business center and three meeting rooms.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: REPERCUSSIONS;
Bulgarians Bet Future On a Link To NATO

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: SOFIA, Bulgaria, May 8

 BODY:
For Yugoslavia's Balkan and Central European neighbors, the war in Kosovo is becoming part of a familiar pattern of casting their lot with the perceived victor.
As Europe's first hot war in half a century damages their economies and public anxiety over the conflict mounts, Governments in this region have made a kind of wager that the future after the guns fall silent will be promising only if they find themselves on NATO's side. 
 Like the other nations ringing Yugoslavia, Bulgaria has taken this course -- even as NATO's bombing of Yugoslavia and Danube bridges cuts this Balkan country of more than 8 million people from its markets in Western Europe and its meager export income plummets. Prospects for foreign investment, crucial for future recovery, have dimmed, and nipped a brief economic springtime in the bud.
Then, last week, the military risks of a shared border with Yugoslavia were brought home to Bulgarians, when a NATO missile tore into the attic of a home of a family of four on the outskirts of Sofia. It was the fourth NATO missile to hit Bulgarian soil. No one has been hurt.
And yet, despite all these events, a broad majority of Bulgaria's Parliament voted last Tuesday, after only five hours of debate, to make the country the latest in the region to open its airspace for NATO bombing missions, in exchange for security guarantees.
The vote was very much in line with the policies of the anti-Communist, pro-business Government that took office in 1997 to rescue Bulgaria from economic collapse. Unlike its neo-Communist predecessor, this Government and its reformist President Petar Stoyanov, elected in 1996, have pushed Bulgaria toward NATO.
Support for the alliance now is "a question of Euro-Atlantic solidarity, and choosing European values," Prime Minister Ivan Kostov said in an interview.
A failure by NATO in Kosovo, he added, would "give the right to any government to commit genocide against its people."
Mr. Kostov's arguments echoed those of Government leaders lined up against Yugoslavia and President Slobodan Milosevic, across the region where Communism once held sway. But the moral stance, opposing evil with good, masks a far more complex reality -- a gamble that may not pay off.
For the people of central and eastern Europe, torn by warfare again and again in this century, the prospect of war breeds fear.
For the last 100 years or more, they have been caught up in a pattern of inimical pact-making. From the Balkan League of pre-World War I, which bred the Balkan War pitting Bulgarians against Serbia and Greece, to the opposing alliances of the two murderous world wars and finally the nuclear standoff of NATO versus the Warsaw Pact in the cold war, they have taken sides to survive, trying to minimize the cost.
For a majority of people in the region, said Ognyan Minchev, director of the Institute for Regional and International Studies in Sofia, "the choice, in a very practical sense, is not between good and evil, but between a lesser and greater evil."
In the case of Kosovo, he said, the lesser evil was NATO air strikes following the brutal purge of hundreds of thousands of ethnic Albanians from their Kosovo homes. The greater evil, in this view, is "being isolated in a security vacuum," given NATO's post-cold-war role as the sole provider of international security in Europe, Mr. Minchev said.
To act otherwise, he said, would be "to remain on the other side of the dividing line, away from those supporting the war, who are also those supporting recovery investments after the war. That is the reason why not a single Government could resist saying 'Yes' to that kind of offer from NATO."
Choosing the lesser evil does not remove the anxiety that stems from fear of future relations in the Balkans, which could be poisoned by having taken sides against a neighbor -- in Bulgaria's case a neighbor, Serbia, with whom the ties of religion and language are close.
"Psychologically, the region is torn apart," Mr. Minchev said.
But the greater worry is that of a protracted war that causes even greater economic and human damage than has so far occurred. Such a prolonged war might seriously destabilize the fledgling democracies of the region, born out of the collapse of Communism a decade ago. New Governments emerging from that prolonged war, Mr. Minchev said, could involve political parties and movements not oriented toward democracy and a market economy -- unlike most Governments in the region now.
The immediate reality is a beleaguered Bulgarian economy facing a halving of growth this year because of the war.
Martin Zaimov, deputy head of the National Bank, counted off the economic casualties. Foreign investment was at a standstill, he said in an interview, because "people are not even willing to travel to Bulgaria -- it's not a question of investing."
With land routes to Western Europe cut in Yugoslavia and a principal waterway -- the Danube -- blocked by bombed out bridges, Bulgarian exports are collapsing. In the first quarter, export revenues dropped 26 percent against last year. Bulgarian growth this year, as a result, is expected to drop by almost half to 2 percent, he said.
Yet the most devastating effect, Mr. Zaimov said, was psychological and involved Bulgarians' "perception of the future."
"For the first time, we had managed to instill in people a reality in which they could sit back and have a longer horizon," he said. "Now, people think, 'This is war. We should sit and do nothing, but wait and see.' "
Bulgaria's political opposition, the former Communist party, seems poised to exploit the malaise. Emboldened by public discomfort with the war, the former Communists' resistance to NATO is stiffening and they publicly question the wisdom of Bulgaria casting its lot with the Western military alliance.
Historically, said Sergei Stanishev, head of the Socialist Party's International Relations Department, the nation had little luck with foreign alliances. "We were always on the losing side," he said.
Moreover, he said, his party's opposition to the war merely echoed common fears that Bulgaria would ultimately be browbeaten into allowing air or ground attacks from its territory.
"If you say a, you have to say b, till the end of the alphabet," he said.
Mr. Kostov accuses the Socialists of opposing strong measures against Mr. Milosevic out of sympathy for a fellow former Communist. Mr. Milosevic "has a totalitarian Communist regime which has sought refuge in the last haven of nationalism and chauvinism," much as Bulgaria's own Communists did in the late 1980's by oppressing and expelling the country's Turkish minority, Mr. Kostov said.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE EUROPEANS;
Dependent On U.S. Now, Europe Vows Defense Push

BYLINE: By ROGER COHEN 

DATELINE: BERLIN, May 11

 BODY:
Alarmed by their dependence on the United States in NATO's military campaign against Serbia, European officials vowed today to develop a strong common military policy.
Meeting in Bremen in northern Germany, defense and foreign ministers of the Western European Union, Europe's long-dormant military arm, issued a statement saying they were now committed to "the development of an effective European defense and security policy." 
 George Robertson, the British Defense Secretary, summed up the mood: "In Kosovo, we have all come face to face with the European future, and it is frightening."
The European Union has long been an economic giant and military midget, content to leave most of its security concerns to NATO. But a combination of the crisis in Kosovo, a new British readiness to contribute to a European military arm within NATO and a growing German determination to play an active security role in Europe appear to have led to a decisive shift of mood.
"With this meeting, we have taken a considerable step toward a common European security and defense policy," Rudolf Scharping, the German Defense Minister, said. "Today, we have too many institutions and too little substance."
The reference to institutional excess was clearly an allusion to the Western European Union itself, an organization of 10 European nations that belong to NATO. Several European governments, including Germany's, have concluded that the Western European Union must now be merged with the European Union as soon as possible.
This measure, combined with the appointment of a European High Representative for the Common Foreign and Security Policy, would begin to give the 15-nation European Union the means to coordinate military policies that now duplicate one another in many areas, increasing cost and diminishing effectiveness.
Several ministers said today that they hoped to push through those reforms by the end of next year.
Europe, with no equivalent to the C-5 and C-17 aircraft, is almost completely dependent on the United States for air transport of troops, an increasingly important asset when mobility rather than static ground defenses are at a premium in the aftermath of the cold war.
The continent also depends heavily on Washington for strategic reconnaissance and has lagged in the development of new military technologies like laser-guided bombs. Eager to cash in the "peace dividend" in the last decade, European governments have cut military spending to an average of about 2.1 percent of gross national product, compared with 3.2 percent in the United States.
In the Kosovo campaign, the United States, with 639 aircraft, already has more than double the number of planes of all its NATO allies combined, and is planning to send 176 more. In effect, the Europeans have been obliged to confront the extent of their dependency.
"We Europeans should not expect the United States to play a role in every disorder in our back yard," the British Prime Minister, Tony Blair, said recently, arguing that Europe's governments had failed to modernize armies for the post-cold-war era.
Mr. Blair played a central role in framing a joint British-French military initiative late last year. It was significant because it seemed to represent the end of a long division between a France committed to a stronger European defense arm, even at NATO's expense, and a Britain overwhelmingly committed to the Atlantic Alliance.
The accord reflected France's grudging acquiescence to the idea that Europe's defense should be developed within NATO, and Britain's realization that it had to work more closely with its European defense partners. Duplication in spending has long made Europe's military outlays much less cost-effective than those in the United States.
The defense ministers said today that a European military arm must emerge "in complementarity with the Atlantic Alliance." Mr. Scharping said recently, "The last aim is to sever the European decision-making process from NATO," adding that the intention was "to strengthen the European pillar within the alliance."
On this basis, the Clinton Administration has supported Europe's efforts to put together a more coherent military organization and force that would be able to undertake some NATO missions using American military assets but not American troops. But exactly how "a common defense policy" for Europe would work in practice remains uncertain.
What seems clear is that efforts to increase military spending will meet resistance from many Europeans, even in the aftermath of Kosovo.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Inflation Fears Continue to Lift Treasury Rates

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Long-term interest rates, which have risen steadily since early April, jumped to their highest level in almost a year yesterday as investors continued to worry about inflation and the next meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers on Tuesday.
Investors have been spooked -- at least for the time being -- by the failure of the United States economy to slow significantly and by a reminder last week from Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, that inflation could become a problem again. 
 "There is a lot of fear and nervousness in the market at this juncture," said Thomas Connor, head government trader at J. P. Morgan Securities.
That is not because investors expect a surge in inflation this year or even that the Fed will raise interest rates next week. Instead, they are nervous because they must wait for new inflation data and the Fed meeting before determining whether the recent rise in long-term interest rates has been overdone -- in part because of Mr. Greenspan's warning -- or will push on toward 6 percent.
The surge in the yield on the 30-year bond, which rose to 5.83 percent yesterday, also cooled the stock market a bit, leaving the Dow Jones industrial average up only 18.90 points, at 11,026.15.
In another sign of nervousness yesterday, investors shrugged off the news that worker productivity rose at an annual rate of 4 percent in the first quarter, an increase that was better than expected. Investors would normally find this news positive because stronger-than-expected productivity has helped keep inflation at bay.
Adding to the gloomy atmosphere was a lackluster auction of five-year Treasury notes and negative comments about the bond market from Stanley Druckenmiller, the manager of George Soros's Quantum Fund. According to Bridge News, Mr. Druckenmiller told investors at a conference in London that bonds were now in a bear market and that the Fed would raise interest rates by the end of the year.
Because of the uncertainty, traders and analysts said that until the results of the Fed meeting were known, long-term rates could edge higher. And the bond market could get a worse shock if two inflation reports -- the Producer Price Index tomorrow and the Consumer Price Index on Friday -- are disappointing.
Both reports are expected to reflect the recent spike in crude oil prices, which saw the price of a barrel reach $18.98 last week, though as of yesterday it had retreated to $18.02. The unknown is whether these two inflation barometers have positive surprises -- as they did in March -- or negative ones. For this month, Wall Street is forecasting a rise of five-tenths of 1 percent in the producer index and a rise of four-tenths of 1 percent in the consumer index.
The Government report on retail sales for April, which is due tomorrow, will also signal how fast the American consumer is still spending. Consumers are the main reason the economy has grown at a brisk 5.25 percent pace in the last six months -- a pace too fast for Fed policy makers to remain comfortable.
Donald J. Fine, chief market analyst at Chase Securities, said he was forecasting an increase of three-tenths of 1 percent in retail sales for April. But he said investors would also keep their eyes on the revision for the March data. An upward revision of that number would add to fears that consumer spending will keep the economy chugging along too quickly and eventually force the Fed to raise interest rates, possibly by the end of the year.
The Fed is not expected to raise interest rates to slow economic growth when the Federal Open Market Committee, its policy-making panel, meets on Tuesday. But some analysts wonder if the Fed will fire a warning shot to the bond market.
To do this, the central bank could indicate with a formal directive that it thinks its next interest-rate move will most likely be an increase.
If the inflation news is not alarming and the Fed stands pat, then there is a chance for interest rates to slip a bit until the next round of data provides a clearer picture of how strong the economy is and how persistent price pressures might become.
The price of the 30-year bond fell 19/31 , to 91 26/32 , while the yield, which moves in the opposite direction, rose to 5.83 percent, from 5.79 percent Monday. That was the highest yield since 5.84 percent on May 27, 1998.
The new five-year Treasury notes yielded 5.37 percent and the demand was weak, traders said.
There is a 10-year note auction scheduled for today. In when-issued trading yesterday, the yield on the 10-year note was 5.49 percent, up from 5.46 percent on Monday. The yield on the current 10-year note rose to 5.57 percent yesterday, from 5.52 percent Monday.

HEADLINE: Clinton Tries to Sell Executives on Inner-City Economics

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: ATLANTA, May 11

 BODY:
Eager to keep his domestic agenda going, President Clinton flew here today to call for corporate investment in inner-city America and said he would tour some of the nation's pockets of poverty, which he characterized as great economic opportunities.
The tour, in July, is to be modeled on the overseas missions that Cabinet secretaries and corporate officers frequently make to help American businesses take advantage of emerging markets. Mr. Clinton said today that some of America's neglected rural and urban areas constituted such emerging markets. 
 "Our greatest untapped markets are here at home," the President said at the White House this morning after a closed-door session with 15 chief executives of major corporations. Mr. Clinton brought the executives here later for a tour of local businesses that have profited from Federal investment.
Aides said Mr. Clinton's tour was to take him to Appalachia, the Mississippi Delta, Indian reservations and aging industrial cities like Gary, Ind. The aides said he would try to get the executives to see the tour sites as sources of customers and make substantial investments in them. There was no immediate reaction from the executives.
The President's schedule was intended to highlight a part of the domestic agenda he laid out when he first campaigned for President, when he said repeatedly that "no one should be left behind." With the war in Kosovo, the shootings in Littleton, Colo., and other issues now dominating his time in Washington, Mr. Clinton is eager to revive this aspect of his Presidency, particularly as former Senator Bill Bradley challenges Mr. Clinton's designated heir, Vice President Al Gore, on broad questions of race and economic equality. Mr. Gore spoke extensively with the executives this morning.
Much of the United States is enjoying the biggest economic expansion in more than three decades. And Mr. Clinton noted that in particular, African-American and Hispanic residents were enjoying the lowest rates of unemployment since statistics have been kept. But he said that parts of the country had had no new investment, no new business and no new jobs and that 37 cities had unemployment rates that were double the national average.
"In the midst of all our prosperity," the President said here, he wanted to point out "both the obligation and the opportunity we have to do better."
The President's support for investment at home was inspired by the Rev. Jesse Jackson's pleadings in the last year to Wall Street to encourage private investors, said Gene Sperling, Mr. Clinton's economic adviser. Mr. Jackson was not with Mr. Clinton today but is supposed to be part of the July tour.
Mr. Clinton spent his day emphasizing that people in poor areas could succeed if someone invested in those areas and if they are aided by federally sponsored tax credits, loan guarantees and technical support. He is also proposing $1 billion in tax credits for businesses in poor areas.
He brought the executives with him here on Air Force One for a round-table discussion staged between stalls at a historic farmers' market. He talked about tax incentives for empowerment zones, areas in the inner city earmarked for economic initiatives, but not before cruising for munchies and coming up with some coffee and sweet potato cheesecake.
"I have lifted things from almost every entrepreneur here," the President said with a laugh. He said the woman who gave him the cheesecake "destroyed my diet today -- and I loved every bite of it."
The market, the Sweet Auburn Curb Street Market, is in Southeast Atlanta's first black commercial district, not far from the home of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. In operation since 1923, the market has fallen on hard times over the years and has been aided with more than $8 million in Federal financing.
The market now employs about 800 people in 24 shops. The President was intrigued by a bin of cows feet and pig ears, recalling that when President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia visited him in Washington, he presented Mr. Clinton with a roasted pig and cut off the ear, telling Mr. Clinton that he would eat it if he were a true Russian.
Many shop owners said business was slow as the executives made their way through the market. The corporate delegation included representatives from Bell South, Aetna, American Airlines, Goldman Sachs, the Rite Aid Corporation, AT&T Wireless, Delta Air Lines, Bankers Trust and New York Life.
The corporation chieftains said they supported Clinton's plans.
Richard Huber, head of Aetna, said his company already employed residents from low-income areas and trained them to sell insurance tailored to low-income consumers. The goal, Mr. Huber said, is to "get in there and really penetrate these communities."

HEADLINE: Have Funds, Could Run;
Unknown but Rich, Corzine Becomes a Top Contender for Senate

BYLINE: By JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
When Goldman Sachs Group went public last week, its former chairman, Jon S. Corzine, became a very rich man. He also effectively became unemployed. Having lost a power struggle earlier this year, Mr. Corzine ended his formal relationship with the Wall Street firm once the public offering was completed.
But it didn't take him long to rebound. By week's end, Mr. Corzine was in Atlantic City for a conference of New Jersey's Democratic Party, using his gentle Midwestern charms to audition for a job even his closest associates never realized he wanted: United States Senator. 
 "I've always been interested in public service," Mr. Corzine (the last syllable of his name rhymes with "pine") said in his hoarse, whispery voice between handshakes at the conference, where few people knew what he looked like but almost everyone had heard estimates of his net worth. (More than $300 million). "I actually care."
To the surprise of many New Jersey Democrats, Mr. Corzine, has emerged as a leading contender in a crowded Democratic field to replace Senator Frank G. Lautenberg, the three-term Democrat who plans to retire next year. Virtually unknown in state political circles, Mr. Corzine, a 52-year-old native of Illinois who now lives in Summit, N.J., has leaped ahead of more seasoned politicians largely on the strength of his fortune, which he has vowed to use lavishly on a campaign.
But he has also been quietly promoted by a coterie of influential Democrats, many of them close to Senator Robert G. Torricelli, who do not want the nomination to go to the best organized of the Democratic candidates, former Gov. Jim Florio. Those Democrats say Mr. Florio, while capable of winning a primary, will certainly lose in a general election, particularly if his opponent is Christine Todd Whitman, the Republican who ousted him as governor in 93.
Though Mr. Torricelli says it is premature for him to back anyone, he came close to endorsing Mr. Corzine in an interview today. "For the Democratic Party in New Jersey and the Democratic caucus in the Senate to have a candidate from the most prestigious banking house in the world has some merit," he said. "This is a guy who can speak on economic and tax issues with some authority. And that is going to be appealing to many Democrats in New Jersey."
Mr. Corzine's supporters are now trying to winnow the field of other candidates and unify leaders from the state's populous northern counties behind the investment banker. They are hoping to set up a one-on-one primary against the tenacious Mr. Florio, who has the support of seven southern county chairmen. A crowded Democratic field, Mr. Corzine's advisers say, will benefit Mr. Florio.
Though the other candidates, including Representative Frank Pallone of Long Branch; Michael Murphy, a former Morris County Prosecutor, and Thomas Byrne, a former state party chairman, say they have no plans to drop out, many party leaders think the pressure on them to step aside will be intense if Mr. Corzine formally jumps in.
"This issue of his money is going to be pretty daunting to the other candidates," said Thomas P. Giblin, the state Democratic chairman, who has met with Mr. Corzine several times but remains neutral in the race.
But while Mr. Corzine's immense wealth may win him fans among some political leaders, some Democrats worry that it could also offend Democratic primary voters who might view it as evidence that he is out of touch with them.
Though he does not plan to make an official announcement for several days, Mr. Corzine has told friends he plans to run, and in an interview last Friday, he said he was leaning strongly in that direction. Two things could hold him back, friends say: opposition from his family and a desire to start a business. Asked about his wife's feelings, Mr. Corzine replied, "She's not opposed."
But in the meantime, he has taken firm steps toward starting a campaign. He has hired Doug Schoen, who does polling for President Clinton, to measure public support for Mr. Florio and Mrs. Whitman. He has talked to Robert Shrum, the veteran Democratic media consultant, about working on the campaign. And he has recruited a former state director for Mr. Lautenberg, Christy Davis, to help him meet New Jersey Democratic officials.
Yet for all his immense wealth and growing support, Mr. Corzine is not a shoo-in, even among the anti-Florio forces. Though he has given nearly $1 million to the Democratic Party over the past decade, almost none of that money went to New Jersey candidates, leaving him with no base of support in the state.
And unlike Mr. Lautenberg, another rich businessman-turned-politician, Mr. Corzine has not been active in local politics, has not run for office and even failed to vote on numerous occasions. Many of his critics think Mr. Corzine is running solely because Mr. Torricelli nudged him into it.
More important to many Democrats, Mr. Corzine must answer some fundamental questions about what he stands for and whether an untested candidate like him can endure the strain of a long campaign. Last weekend, many Democrats were openly wondering whether the party of urban poor and organized labor should endorse a wealthy banker who lives in the suburbs and who ran a Wall Street firm known for helping big companies gobble up smaller ones.
"There's a concern about sending the wrong message," said Paul M. Bangiola, chairman of the Morris County Democratic Committee, who is leaning toward supporting Mr. Murphy. "He's charming. But the rich guy rap is a tough one to overcome."
In perhaps the surest sign that Mr. Corzine is viewed in some quarters as the man to beat, labor supporters of other Democratic candidates have begun circulating a memo asserting that under Mr. Corzine, Goldman Sachs helped finance mergers and acquisitions that led to the layoffs of 74,000 workers.
"Do we really need another multimillionaire businessman in politics?" asked Jimmy Tarlau, president of the Mercer County Labor Union Council, who favors Mr. Pallone. "If it's between him and Florio, I think I'd have to support Florio. At least I know what Florio stands for."
Mr. Corzine's supporters have worked hard to paint a different picture of the candidate. They describe him as a modest farm boy who has been New Deal Democrat all his life. Though he owns a summer home on Long Island's East End, he has also contributed $2 million to help poor minority students attend parochial schools in New York City, and millions more to support public libraries and the performing arts. As co-chairman of Goldman Sachs, they say, he helped create more jobs than were lost through mergers and takeovers.
And though he has never run for office, he has taken a keen interest in public policy, including advising Vice President Al Gore on global economic issues. Mr. Corzine has also been a major fund-raiser for Mr. Gore.
Mr. Corzine bristles at suggestions that he is trying to buy the race, saying he will win on the strength of his ideas for improving education, expanding economic opportunity and restricting gun sales -- though he is not ready to discuss specific proposals.
"This whole gun-control issue, which is easier to make a case about today than it might have been two weeks ago, I think is one somebody ought to really put their neck on the line about," he said in Atlantic City.
Mr. Corzine grew up on a 120-acre farm in Willys Station, Ill. (pop. 17), where his father grew corn and soybeans. His mother taught first and second grade in public schools.
As a freshman at the University of Illinois he was one of just 2 walk-ons, out of 225 candidates, to make the varsity basketball team -- a story his supporters offer as evidence of his determination. But he did not play a minute, and quit during his sophomore year. "A 6-2 forward just doesn't cut it in the Big Ten," he said.
In his senior year, he married a woman he had known since first grade, Joanne Dougherty. The couple, who settled in Summit in the 1970's, have three children.
After college, Mr. Corzine joined the Marine Corps reserves, mainly, he acknowledged, to avoid the draft, and earned a business degree from the University of Chicago. In 1975, he joined Goldman Sachs and became chief executive in 1994.
At Goldman, Mr. Corzine was known for having a cool head and sharp analytical mind in the risky business of bond trading. As he rose through the corporate ranks, he also gained a reputation as an accessible manager and effective consensus builder, traits his supporters say would make him a fine Senator.
"He is not a lone ranger," said Robert D. Hormats, a vice president for Goldman Sachs International. "He works well with people."
Mr. Corzine has clearly succeeded on one front: convincing Democratic leaders that, for all his money, he is a regular guy. Tall, lean and balding, with a thick graying beard and mitt-like hands, Mr. Corzine speaks in a soft, slow, serene voice that seems reassuringly down home.
"To be honest, I was surprised," said Joseph A. Ferriero, chairman of the Bergen County Democratic committee. "I expected a high-powered, obnoxious guy, and was confronted with the opposite. He was warm and personable, with absolutely no air of arrogance."
But Mr. Corzine acknowledged that he has much to do to sell himself to New Jersey's skeptical politicians and wary electorate.
"I'm an underdog," he said. "I don't enter this under any preconception that this is anything other than a very difficult thing to accomplish."

HEADLINE: Whitman Seeks $6 Billion in Work on Schools

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 11

 BODY:
Gov. Christine Todd Whitman put forward a bill today that promises $6 billion in state money to build and repair schools throughout New Jersey, but some worry there may not be enough money in future budgets to pay for the huge construction program.
All districts, regardless of their wealth, would be able to participate in Governor Whitman's program, but it was not clear how the state would end up paying for it. 
 Mrs. Whitman has identified two annual revenue streams: $62 million from the new "Big Game" lottery and $50 million in cigarette tax revenue. But those cash sources may not be enough. It is estimated that over the 5- to- 10-year life of the program, the cost to the state would be about $400 million annually.
Since it will take a few years for the program to become established, it is not likely that the Governor will be faced with paying the biggest part of the construction bill before her term expires in 2002.
State Treasurer James A. DiEleuterio Jr. said that in the future, revenues from the state's general fund -- or some other source -- might be needed to help finance the plan.
Governor Whitman's new school construction bill gives schools more flexibility than previously proposed to use state funds to build new schools. Only those districts that receive more than 50 percent of their financing from the state will be required to use the New Jersey Building Authority for their projects. Other districts have the option of using the authority or a low-interest loan from the state.
State officials have built incentives in the plan to encourage districts to use the Building Authority. They say that by coordinating labor resources and economies of scale, the authority could reduce project costs as much as 25 percent.
Governor Whitman's bill would also increase the square footage allowed for new buildings. Elementary schools would be allowed up to 125 square feet per pupil, middle schools up to 131 square feet per pupil and high schools up to 151 square feet per pupil. School officials had complained that the state's initial size allowances were too small.
In an action affecting some of the neediest schools, Education Commissioner David C. Hespe announced today that he intended to provide $37 million more in state money to pay for special programs in eight of the poorest school districts. But that $37 million represents a small share of the $295 million that 16 districts originally asked for.
Under court order, the state is required to provide additional money to its poorest districts to help needy students overcome their educational disadvantages. Local districts can ask the state to pay for items like social services, teacher aides and extended-day preschool programs.
Sixteen of the 28 "special needs" districts submitted supplemental requests totaling $295 million. Two were disqualified for "failing to document need," Mr. Hespe said. Two others were later withdrawn.
David Sciarra, director of the Education Law Center, which represents poor children in the school-financing battle, said he had not heard a good explanation for how state officials could "chop off 90 percent of what was asked for" from the districts.
Mr. Hespe said the department used a twofold standard in determining who should get supplemental aid: The requests had to be for a program that is deemed essential to meet the state's constitutional obligation to provide a "thorough and efficient" education, and districts had to show a need for the money.
Mr. Hespe said that New Jersey was already spending more per pupil in its poorest districts "than any major East Coast city."
Michael Azzara, the Education Department's assistant commissioner for finance, said that after initial meetings with the districts, $76.3 million worth of requests were voluntarily withdrawn.
But Mr. Sciarra said he believed the districts were pressured into dropping their requests for more money or risk losing other program aid.

HEADLINE: State Senate Republicans Seek to Drop Commuter Tax

BYLINE: By ABBY GOODNOUGH 

 BODY:
Saying that New York City should share its record surplus with suburban residents, Republican leaders in the State Senate announced yesterday that they would vote next week to abolish the commuter tax paid by suburbanites who work in the city.
On its surface, the plan is an unusual act of rebellion against Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a fellow Republican who is close to Joseph L. Bruno, the Senate majority leader. The tax is an important source of revenue for the city, delivering about $360 million a year, and Mr. Giuliani wants to continue it. 
 But Mr. Bruno, a Republican of Rensselaer County, pointed out yesterday that the city is benefiting from a $2.1 billion surplus, and that Mr. Giuliani has proposed $405 million in tax cuts for city residents. The Senator said it was only fair to provide similar benefits to the 450,000 residents of suburban counties in New York State who pay the commuter tax.
"We think that it's very productive," Mr. Bruno said of the proposal, speaking to reporters in Albany. "It just gives people more spendable income."
Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday that he favored cutting taxes, so he would look carefully at the plan. But it is unlikely that the Assembly, which is dominated by New York City Democrats, would agree to abolish the tax, which was introduced in 1966. Patricia Lynch, a spokeswoman for Assembly Speaker Sheldon Silver, would not comment on the proposal yesterday.
But the Senate has some leverage, because much of the commuter tax revenue comes from a temporary surcharge that the Legislature added in 1971, which is set to expire at the end of this year. Both houses must agree to reauthorize it, so if the Senate refused, the surcharge would be eliminated.
The Senate proposal would repeal the commuter tax only for residents of New York State, who pay about $208 million of the roughly $360 million in revenues. The remaining 42 percent of the money comes mostly from New Jersey and Connecticut commuters. A total of 769,000 suburbanites pay the tax, a Senate spokesman said.
Aides to Mr. Giuliani, who is seriously considering a run for the United States Senate and trying to win support in upstate New York, were subdued in their response to Mr. Bruno's plan. The Mayor said in a statement that he was against repealing the tax, but he avoided any criticism of the State Senate.
Other city officials wondered why Mr. Bruno would antagonize Mr. Giuliani, and they theorized that he was supporting the measure only because he knew it would die in the Assembly.
The officials speculated that Senate leaders were pushing the repeal only to help the Republican candidate, Thomas Morahan, for a highly prized Senate seat in Rockland and Orange Counties. Both Mr. Morahan, and his Democratic opponent, Kenneth Zebrowski, have called for abolishing the commuter tax.
Senate approval of the measure could help Mr. Morahan, but more important, it could hurt Democratic Assembly members from the suburbs in the next round of elections. Their Republican opponents could point out that the Assembly foiled efforts to repeal the tax, raising the ire of suburban voters.
Senator Dean G. Skelos, a Republican from Long Island who is sponsoring the measure, suggested that Democratic legislators from the suburbs could suffer if the Assembly did not approve the repeal.
"The Senate will pass the bill next week," Mr. Skelos said. "The question is, will the Assembly Democrats be able to meet the challenge?
But Mr. Skelos dismissed another theory raised by some Assembly members: that the Senate would ultimately agree to continue the tax if the Assembly agreed to raise taxes in Nassau County, which is experiencing a fiscal crisis. Mr. Skelos, who is from Nassau County, said county leaders had not requested a tax increase, so the Senate was not considering it.
Asked why the Senate Republicans would risk angering Mr. Giuliani, with whom they have formed a close alliance, Mr. Skelos was blunt.
"He's done a great job of turning his economy around, but now it's time to give suburban commuters a break," he said. "He has the right to his opinions, but we in Albany are the ones that have the vote."

HEADLINE: String of Rocket Mishaps Worries Industry

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
America's space rockets seem to be failing, blowing up or losing payloads at an alarming rate that has experts questioning the prowess of an increasingly competitive satellite launching industry.
In the last nine months, there have been six significant failures of United States rockets trying to put civilian and military payloads into orbit. The mishaps, involving both older, usually reliable rockets and newly designed vehicles, have resulted in losses totaling $3.5 billion and shaken confidence in the ability of the United States to launch space missions, including crucial communications and spy satellites. 
 Engineers studying the problem say they cannot tell if the recent difficulties are just bad luck or signs of systemic problems in the launching business. A number of explanations have been floated to explain the string of disasters, ranging from an over-reliance on computer models in place of flight testing to the pressures to do more for less money.
"The performance we've demonstrated since last August is unacceptable, to us and to our customers," said Peter B. Teets, the president and chief operating officer of Lockheed Martin, whose rockets are responsible for the loss of four satellites since August. "The worst impact on morale is losing a mission. We have good people who are not feeling very well right now.".
John F. Willacker of the Aerospace Corporation, a private consulting and engineering research company based in El Segundo, Calif., said the nation's space launching industry was suffering from being under the competing pressures of flying more rockets at less cost while also trying to introduce new boosters that are even more economical.
The satellite launching business is booming, with an unprecedented number of customers in science, communications and other industries clamoring to get their payloads into space. At the same time, there is great pressure to reduce the cost of launchings, with American companies forced to compete with low-cost launching services being offered by Europe's Ariane rockets and boosters available in Russia and China.
"The industry is a little stretched, and this pressure is contributing to some systematic problems," Mr. Willacker, head of the consulting company's space launching operations, said in an interview. "I have a hard time believing there can be this much bad luck in a row without there being some common threads. We must find them and straighten them out."
Meanwhile, the troubles are causing apprehension for rocket users as well as flight delays while engineers sort out the problems to determine whether future missions are in danger. With some three dozen military and civilian launchings scheduled from the United States in 1999, this is a particularly busy year for the American launching industry, which in a typical year might have 20 to 25 launchings of unmanned booster rockets.
The Air Force has indefinitely postponed the flight of a giant Titan 4 rocket, which has failed three times in its last three launchings and which was to carry a secret spy satellite into space early this month from Vandenberg Air Force Base in California. This delay, in turn, prevents the scheduled launching of an older rocket, the Titan 2, from an adjacent pad. The Titan 2 is supposed to place a NASA science spacecraft called Quikscat in orbit.
And NASA, which oversaw none of the six failures, has pushed back the scheduled July 22 flight of the space shuttle Columbia, which is to carry the $1.5 billion Chandra X-ray Observatory. An attached booster rocket that is to drive the observatory into its final orbit is the same type as one that malfunctioned last month.
The space agency is going ahead with plans for a July launching of Terra, a billion-dollar satellite that is the flagship of NASA's Earth Observing System to monitor global changes, even though the upper stage of its carrier rocket, a Centaur, is identical to one that misfired last month and doomed a military communications satellite. But a spokesman said NASA was monitoring military investigations to see if it uncovered problems that might affect the launching of the Terra.
The string of mishaps began last Aug. 12 when a Titan 4, the most powerful rocket used by the military, exploded 41 seconds after liftoff, destroying an $800 million communications intelligence satellite along with the $340 million rocket. An Air Force review board blamed damaged electrical wires that had not been detected before the flight.
The two other Titan 4 setbacks, at a cost of about $1 billion each, occurred in April, apparently for dissimilar reasons. On April 9, an upper stage deployed from the Titan as expected, but apparently parts of it failed to separate properly between multiple firings, putting a missile warning satellite in a useless orbit. This booster, made by the Boeing Company and called the Inertial Upper Stage, is the same type that is to propel the Chandra observatory.
And on April 30, a different upper stage, the Centaur, malfunctioned and put a military communications satellite in an orbit thousands of miles too low, where it is doubtful it can ever be used.
The trade journal Aviation Week and Space Technology reported in its May 10 issue that the Centaur went awry nine minutes into the mission because of inaccuracies in computer flight software from the rocket's maker, the Lockheed Martin Corporation. The software was loaded before the flight, and problems went undetected by the company's normal verification process, the report said.
Botched launchings also affected these civilian space missions:
*On Aug. 26, Boeing's new Delta 3 rocket exploded 71 seconds after liftoff on its maiden voyage, destroying the Galaxy 10 communications satellite in a $225 million disaster caused by a design error in its first-stage guidance system.
*On April 27, the Athena 2, a relatively new small rocket made by Lockheed Martin, failed to place a private earth-imaging satellite into orbit after launching from the Vandenberg base A 1,300-pound protective payload shroud failed to separate from the $25 million rocket, dragging the satellite back down into the atmosphere, where it burned up.
*On May 4, the second stage of another Delta 3 rocket did not fire long enough after restarting in space, putting a $145 million Orion communications satellite into a lopsided orbit thousands of miles too low to be useful. Controllers are looking into ways to salvage some of the $230 million mission by using the satellite's internal fuel to nudge it higher.
The Air Force announced on May 6 that it and the National Reconnaissance Office, which deploys spy satellites, would conduct a broad review of military launching capability and the Titan failures. Lockheed Martin, which makes the Titans, as well as the Centaur upper stage and the Athena rocket, also announced it was appointing an independent panel of experts to examine the procedures of its rocket business.
Gen. Richard B. Myers of the Air Force, who is commander of the United States Space Command, said the loss of three new military satellites since August because of launching failures did not jeopardize current military operations but could affect future readiness if problems are not corrected.
"Because these failures have cost us a great deal in financial terms and in future mission capability, we are working hard to identify their causes," General Myers said in a statement.
Mr. Teets of Lockheed Martin said: "My gut feeling is that we're having a very unlucky period right now and that our basic operations are sound. But we want this outside committee to see if there is something going on here, something fundamental, that we can't see on a case-to-case basis."
Gale Schluter, executive vice president of Boeing's rocket systems division, said troubles with the new Delta 3 appeared to be birthing problems of a largely new design and not a breakdown in normal operations at the company. Mr. Schluter noted that Boeing's smaller, older Delta 2 had accumulated a 97.5 percent success rate over 10 years, showing that the company knew how to produce quality rockets.
"We are looking at the Delta 3 comprehensively," he said, "We want to understand the two failures better and deal with them."
Mr. Willacker of the Aerospace Corporation said the rocket business suffered from too few experienced engineers and technicians, particularly those at midcareer, who were being stretched across too many projects.
A dearth in hiring in the industry in the early 1980's has resulted in a cadre of well-educated new engineers in their 20's and early 30's and a seasoned group over age 55 who are approaching retirement, Mr. Willacker said, but few in the gap between these clusters.
Another problem, he said, is an over-reliance on computer simulation and modeling in creating new products and a reduction in testing actual hardware.
"Historically, you would build test aircraft or rockets and fly them before you commit to production," Mr. Willacker said. "We seem to have convinced ourselves that we don't need that luxury today, and it shows."
Boeing, Mr. Schluter said, does a lot of testing of components and subsystems and is highly confident of its results, but he acknowledged that this analytical approach "gets risky" when used for a complete vehicle. This has led to discussion over firing test rounds of new rockets without paying cargo, an expensive prospect for the manufacturer, Mr. Schluter said.
"Customers will have to make risk assessments and trade that against the price of early missions," he said.
Mr. Willacker of the Aerospace Company said that his group kept a database on all space flights and found that there had been about 60 significant launching failures since 1990.
"When looking for common factors, we were somewhat surprised," he said. "We worry a lot about electronics and computers, but the most prominent factors were hardware -- propulsion and ordinance systems."
This means rocket engines and fuel systems with their varied manufactured parts, he said, and explosive bolts, springs and other mechanisms for separating rocket stages.
"These are the kinds of things we should know how to make and operate well," Mr. Willacker said, "It's manufacturing and quality control. Not a lot of this is real rocket science."
Several space historians said the recent run of ill fortune reminded them of a period in the mid-1980's when everything seemed to go wrong. The calamities included the explosion of the space shuttle Challenger, in which the seven-member crew died; the back-to-back failures of two Titan rockets and the destruction of a pair of military reconnaissance satellites; and an Atlas rocket being struck by lightning in flight, destroying a Navy satellite.
"Space launch vehicles are inherently unreliable, and people should understand that this is still risky business," said John E. Pike, an expert on civilian and military space programs with the Federation of American Scientists. "I'm prepared to believe we have had an extraordinary run of bad luck, but when you have something like the Titan 4 failures, where there have been three in a row, you wonder if it's more than bad luck."

NATO Rejects Calls to Halt, And Renews Heavy Attacks

HEADLINE: Giuliani Seeks Deal to Sell 63 Gardens to Land Group and End Suits

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
Faced with three lawsuits and the kind of bad publicity that comes when protesters are willing to risk arrest for the sake of lilacs and tomato plants, the Giuliani administration is trying to strike a settlement with various environmental groups opposed to its plan to auction off public lots that are used as community gardens.
A senior administration official said yesterday that after several weeks of behind-the-scenes negotiations, the city was working on a deal to sell 63 parcels -- scheduled to be auctioned off tomorrow -- to a private conservation group called the Trust for Public Land. The sales price is $3 million, said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity and whose account was verified by others close to the discussions. 
 It was unclear last night precisely which parcels were included in the proposal, although the city official said that they were not ones that the city considered feasible for "economic development or housing." There are 112 community gardens scheduled to be sold at auction; even if a settlement is reached, dozens of gardens would still be put up for sale.
All parties acknowledged that any agreement faces significant hurdles, particularly the city's demand that, as the city official put it, "all the lawsuits go away." Rose Harvey, the senior vice president for the trust, said last night that her organization is interested solely in a real estate transaction and is not involved in any way in the lawsuits.
"I do believe that there's a strong possibility that we will do a deal," Ms. Harvey said. But having the lawsuits dropped "is a condition put forward by the city," she added, "and we have no ability to do that."
Making matters even more complicated is that the plaintiffs in the lawsuits include more than two dozen organizations, from the New York City Environmental Justice Alliance to the More Gardens! Coalition. And not all of the groups share the same agenda.
Lawyers at the Puerto Rican Legal Defense and Education Fund, which is representing several of the garden groups, said that they were angry that they had not been apprised of the discussions between the city and the Trust for Public Land. They also said that they were unlikely to drop their lawsuit unless the city agreed to call off the entire auction.
"We feel a great deal of frustration at the fact that a party, which is not a party to this lawsuit, is coming in and negotiating what the city is now considering 'the deal' -- in effect cutting the baby in half," said Sara E. Rios, a lawyer for the fund. "We think it is not in the interests of our clients and we will continue to aggressively defend our clients, which is all of the gardens."
The potential for an agreement represents a shift by the administration in its dealings with the Trust for Public Land, a nonprofit national organization that has long advocated the preservation of the city's community gardens. Less than three weeks ago, the city rejected the group's offer to buy 165 gardens for $2 million, which city officials said was markedly lower than the properties' fair market value.
The intense negotiations are taking place as advocates for the gardens continue to demonstrate an almost militant resolve, staging demonstrations with people dressed as plants and ladybugs, sending out plaintive E-mail appeals en masse, filing lawsuits and orchestrating acts of civil disobedience. One week brought a protest at City Hall that led to the arrests of 30 people, some bearing kazoos; another week found a man, dressed like a sunflower, screaming, "The gardens must be saved!" from his perch in a ginkgo tree in City Hall Park.
The latest action came on Monday, when three demonstrators shackled their ankles together with a Kryptonite bicycle lock inside a city office. The police had to use an electric saw to cut through the lock before arresting them.
Also on Monday, State Attorney General Eliot L. Spitzer sued the city on the grounds that auctioning off the lots violated state environmental laws. And yesterday, some members of the City Council wore flowers from the gardens on their lapels, reflecting the Council's interest -- perhaps through state legislation -- in blocking or delaying the Giuliani administration's plans to sell the properties.
Two decades ago, the city permitted community groups to transform vacant lots into gardens as part of an open-ended but temporary agreement. That agreement effectively ended with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who wants to sell the lots and return them, if possible, to the public tax rolls. His administration's general response to those who want to keep the lots gardens has been: So then buy them.
The administration has also said that it hoped the sales would lead to more housing; garden advocates dismiss that position as a ruse. Adding further confusion to the debate is the differing conditions of the gardens. Some are verdant gathering places for neighborhoods; others are little more than glass-strewn lots.
The debate reached Federal District Court in Manhattan yesterday, as Judge Allen G. Schwartz considered a request by garden supporters for a temporary restraining order that would stop tomorrow's auction. After being told by city lawyers that the administration was trying to negotiate a deal, the judge indicated that he might issue a decision sometime this afternoon.
In addition, there is a hearing scheduled today in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on two other lawsuits, including the Attorney General's, that are also seeking to stop the auction.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: BEIJING;
China Students Are Caught Up By Nationalism

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 11

 BODY:
Exactly 10 years ago, with protesters in Tiananmen Square, a small grassy triangle in the center of Beijing University became a shrine to democracy, plastered with tracts about liberty and freedom. In recent years it had become a temple for the professions, filled with notices about computers and law examinations.
But in the last four days, the plaza has been transformed anew, into a museum of frenzied nationalism and anti-American sentiment. Hundreds of handwritten letters and posters decorate the fence, the trees and nearby billboards in a vitriolic reaction to the bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, the Yugoslav capital. 
 "Support Yugoslavia and Resist America," one poster read. "Adolph Clinton," another read. A letter suggested that students should cover the American Embassy with garbage.
A poem read, in part: "Resist America Beginning with Cola, Attack McDonald's, Storm K.F.C."
University students here led the angry and sometimes violent protests at the American Embassy over the bombing. With the authorities' permission, the students have vented and displayed for the world the fury that many Chinese say they feel.
But even after four days of nearly continuous demonstrations, it is clear that there remains an extremely deep wellspring of angry emotion on college campuses that students say could percolate for months or years.
For many people, Chinese friendship toward the United States has always been tinged with a drop of suspicion, and the bombings have allowed dormant nationalism and anti-Western sentiments to surge to the surface.
The demonstrations have quickly become a formative experience for college students, who are in some cases making dramatic life decisions like forgoing overseas study based on their new views.
A generation raised on rock music and Coca-Cola is experiencing a complicated shift. "Many of my classmates have been going through their things and planning to burn all American products, at least those they can do without," said a 22-year-old marketing major at Beijing University, whose surname is Zhao.
Many students who cheered Michael Jordan last year and welcomed President Clinton on his recent visit are turning their backs or even lashing out at all things American.
At People's University on Sunday, several American students were surrounded by a group of Chinese students who were screaming, "Blood must be repaid with blood!"
Such incidents are rare, but Westerners who were walking on the Beijing University campus were subject to hard stares, as well as the occasional impromptu lecture on imperialism and anti-American taunts tossed out of dormitory windows.
The scene is a jarring about-face at universities where two months ago the highest achievement was to obtain a place at an American graduate school. In some departments at Beijing University, more than half the students have gone to the United States after graduation in the last few years.
Some students said they worried that rash actions now could haunt China for years. "There is a tone of irrational extremism, and people aren't thinking clearly about what they think and write," said Yu Jie, a popular liberal essayist who is a graduate student at the university. "I think this will have a very bad effect on the economic, social and cultural development of China."
Since Saturday, the universitieshere have sent busloads of students to the American Embassy area. On campuses, students talk of little else, and they have organized accompanying on-campus study sessions and protest rallies.
"I protested because I'm extremely outraged at this trampling on the dignity of the Chinese people," said Chen Wanyi, 20, who marched last weekend.
Although many students opposed the rock throwing that has battered the embassy, they said they understood why it had occurred.
"I know the protest looked extreme," said Lin Yijin, a trendily dressed 28-year-old journalism student at People's University, who protested on Saturday and Sunday. "But I think compared to what we were responding to, it was pretty restrained, just bottles and rocks and things like that."
Students said they believed that the United States had intentionally bombed the embassy in Belgrade, although few explained why Washington might have wanted to do that.
Unlike average Chinese, who can see only state-controlled media, the elite university students generally have Internet access. They read Mr. Clinton's expressions of regret and the NATO explanation, both of which the students dismissed as unbelievable or inadequate.
At the Beijing University triangle, students have posted a full English transcript of the NATO news conference in which officials first explained the bombing. It is covered with comments like "pure lies."
"Chinese are furious, and although we've now heard the apologies, we still feel that the response from NATO and the United States has been superficial," a 22-year-old international business major from northeastern China with the surname Wei. "If you'd seen the pictures of the three corpses, you'd understand why."
Although a number of students said they continued to feel friendly toward the American people, they were keeping their distance for now. Students said they were boycotting American products. Near the university, the usually bustling McDonald's and Pizza Hut restaurants stood mostly empty today.
"Give up the poison of American-style fast food and cultural opium -- Coca-Cola, Pepsi, McDonald's, K.F.C.," read a poster on the triangle.
A Dairy Queen store near the protests was closed this evening, and a Baskin-Robbins store was also closed, hiding its sign under red cloth and placing banners that said, "Down With Imperialism," on its doors.
The anti-American atmosphere is so intense that some students said they were contemplating whether to continue English classes, take jobs with American companies or pursue hard-won acceptances to Harvard University.
Many are clearly torn between the moment's anger and pragmatism. Some said the protest groups were probably smaller than usual today because students were busily cramming for a national English test tomorrow and standardized tests this weekend that are required for American graduate schools.
A group of students at the National Minorities University in Beijing said it wanted to go to Yugoslavia to join the army, and it has posted fliers on other campuses urging others to join.
But a number of students who strongly support the protests said the excesses frightened them. "Are we still in the revolutionary era?" an essay posted on a wall at People's University asked. "Must we answer barbarity with barbarity?"
Jiao Li, 20, a student at the Beijing Transport Technology College, said: "I think this is a passing thing when students are inflamed with patriotism and very emotional. So it's natural for now to respond by not drinking Coke, for example. But I don't think that refusing to work for an American firm will solve any problems."
Students said the anger would fade slowly and only if NATO and the United States offered acceptable apologies.
"What the Chinese want is an explanation and an apology that will restore our dignity," Lin Yijin said. "I wouldn't take the stuff about 'Blood for blood' and 'Attack NATO' too seriously. For us this is about saving face."

HEADLINE: Metro Business;
Company to Return Tax Break Windfall

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
A manufacturing company that promised to create 25 jobs in return for $1.1 million in tax breaks but instead cut 30 jobs from its payroll is giving the money back.
ABB Instrumentation was awarded the Manufacturing Tax Incentive by Monroe County's Industrial Development Agency. Since 1991, the tax break has saved the company $1.1 million on its $21 million plant in Henrietta, a suburb of Rochester. 
 Company officials announced yesterday that they would return the money in response to negative publicity that the tax breaks generated. The money will go to the town of Henrietta and its school district.
Greg LeRoy, a director at the Institute on Taxation and Economic Policy in Washington, said the move by the company appeared to be unprecedented. "I'm not aware of any other voluntary repayment anywhere," he said.
ABB Instrumentation makes instruments that monitor and control manufacturing processes.
The fate of the company's plant remains uncertain. Its parent company in Switzerland, ABB Asea Brown BoveriLtd., has delayed making a decision on whether to move the plant, which employs 400 people, to Pennsylvania.
