HEADLINE: Israeli Race for Prime Minister Is Down to the Wire, With Little Cheering

BYLINE: By DEBORAH SONTAG 

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, May 11

 BODY:
Six days before the Israeli elections, Chaim Yisrael, an elderly Hasidic Jew, hurried to complete his shopping near the ultra-Orthodox neighborhood of Mea Shearim. He was on his way to tutor Torah, he said, but he could spare a few minutes.
"You know, there's only one real leader for us," he said, raising his bearded chin, peering heavenward over the brim of his black hat, and pointing at the sky. 
 Nonetheless, Mr. Yisrael said, he is planning to cast a half-hearted vote for Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
"On the personal side, he looks a little like Clinton morally," Mr. Yisrael said. "But ideologically, he's fine. What choice do we have really? Politics is the land of relativity, and he will be better to protect the land of Israel."
Eight miles away and a world apart, Moussa Ibrahim was equally equivocal. Standing over a mountain of salty pumpkin seeds in his gourmet shop in Abu Ghosh, an Israeli-Arab village, said he will vote for Ehud Barak, the Labor Party leader.
"Not because I am a big fan," he said. "But because I want to be able to go out in the street and say I have a Prime Minister who is not a paranoid, a cheater and a liar."
This election campaign is reputedly a personality competition, devoid of substantive debate on issues like the Israeli-Palestinian peace effort, the economy and tensions between secular and religious Jews. But few Israelis seem inspired by the personalities themselves.
From the craggy hills of the West Bank to the sleepy desert town of Beersheba, from affluent Tel Aviv to depressed Netivot, few Israelis offer rhapsodic endorsements of their candidates. Many say they will cast their ballots while holding their noses. "People vote by way of elimination here," said Vered Alexandrovitz, a bookstore owner in North Tel Aviv.
Israelis tend to be skeptical of predictions. They distrust the polls, which show Mr. Barak ahead of Mr. Netanyahu by about eight percentage points in a five-way race for Prime Minister. A tour of south-central Israel, including conversations with scores of voters, instead leaves the impression that Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Barak are in a dead heat.
Yet the country does not seem gripped by the intensity of a tight election battle. Few balconies are strung with political banners, and road junctions are not routinely staffed by campaign workers. There have been no big political rallies, partly for security reasons, and no political debates between Mr. Netanyahu, whose nickname is Bibi, and Mr. Barak.
Throughout the country, many Israelis said they consider Mr. Netanyahu and Mr. Barak to be cut from the same cloth: both self-confident Ashkenazi Jews with master's degrees from the United States, both former members of the military elite, and both leaning toward the center -- Mr. Netanyahu from the right, Mr. Barak from the left.
"I think they have the same profile," said Shmuel Lederer, mayor of a small West Bank settlement. "No matter who is elected, we won't feel much change."
Many Israelis feel that this is a critical election in which they will select the leader who oversees sensitive negotiations over a Palestinian state, an Israeli military withdrawal from southern Lebanon and the fate of the Golan Heights.
But they are weary of the high-decibel level of Israeli politics, disgusted by dirty deals and profoundly skeptical of the the maturation of the process in the near future.
Navon and Shoshana Armand, lifelong members of Mr. Netanyahu's Likud Party, do not even know if they will bother to vote on May 17, which is a holiday, a day off work.
"Maybe," said Mr. Armand, a bus driver in Beersheba. "If we're not on a picnic."
 
Efrat
 In the large Jewish settlement at Efrat, in the arid, rocky West Bank, the grass is green, the flowers plentiful and the stores modern and well stocked. It looks like an Arizona suburb and, with 6,450 people, it is effectively a bedroom community for Jerusalem. But while some residents chose it for its amenities, many elected to live in Efrat for purely ideological reasons.
In the small shopping plaza, the town bakery, which sells croissants and prayer shawls, is decorated, inside and out, with Mr. Netanyahu's face. In 1996, Efrat voted overwhelmingly for the Prime Minister, and most residents still back him.
Uri Netter, 22, a cheery clerk at the unusually efficient post office, said it did not require much thought.
"He is the only one who supports us," said Mr. Netter, an immigrant from France. "Look how we have grown here and how many new settlements have popped up during his time in office."
Eti Avrahami, however, is sharply critical of the Prime Minister, speaking more like a small business owner than a settler. Her family owns a grocery store in the center of town.
"We used to believe in Bibi," she said. "But everything seemed to come to a halt under him. The economy is down. The society is stuck. There's no forward motion, no swoosh."
Mrs. Avrahami unconsciously echoed the themes of Mr. Barak's campaign against Mr. Netanyahu. People like her, defectors from the committed core of Netanyahu supporters, are very worrisome to his campaign.
 
Bet Haggai
This town near Hebron is a hard-core settlement, a Zionist outpost among the Palestinian towns. Bet Haggai has a frontier feeling, and the many shuttered houses on its edges suggest that the living is hard.
Even here, however, where 98.8 percent of voters selected Mr. Netanyahu last time, the Prime Minister does not have the electorate sewn up. "I think people want to punish Netanyahu because he did not stop Oslo," the Israeli-Palestinian peace agreement signed in 1993, said Mr. Lederer, the mayor.
Yisrael Buskila, 24, is only a renter, a newlywed who moved in because the price was right and the view was splendid. But he believes from his core that Israel should hold onto as much of the West Bank as possible. If Benny Begin, the right-wing candidate for Prime Minister, had a chance, he would get Mr. Buskila's vote, he said. But he doesn't, so Mr. Buskila said he will vote for Mr. Netanyahu.
He said he does not believe in the Prime Minister, but that the traits he finds unappealing -- his perceived arrogance and wiliness -- make him tough at the negotiating table.
"With Netanyahu, you see him holding the Palestinians by the throat," he said. For Parliament, however, Mr. Buskila will vote for the far-right National Unity coalition. "Why?" he asked. "Because they will be holding Bibi by the throat while he holds the Palestinians."
 
Beersheba
In this desert town, far from the political centers of the country, a Barak banner and a Netanyahu banner hang together as if they are one sign -- sharing the same string, between two palm trees.
That would seem to sum up the sleepiness of the campaign in Beersheba, where many voters said they were undecided. Even so, Ruthie Sheetrit, a hairdresser, said the barrage of election news was driving her and everyone else insane. "By May 17, we'll all be meshuga," she said, in her shop at the central bus station.
Sixty percent of Beersheba, a mixed town with many Sephardic Jews, Russian immigrants and Israeli Arabs, voted for Mr. Netanyahu in 1996. Since then, though, the Likud town elected a Labor mayor, and politically it is in flux.
Mrs. Sheetrit said she would vote for Mr. Netanyahu, as she did in 1996. But her endorsement is not ringing. "Barak in power is an unknown," she said. "With Bibi, we already know the bad. So what I'm saying is, I'll go with the known evil."
In Israel, political scientists say that voting is tribal. People are born into political parties -- the Ashkenazi or European power elite and Israeli Arabs are Labor while the Sephardic or Middle Eastern and African working class and the ultra-Orthodox are Likud. But everywhere it seemed that the tribes were shifting ground.
Chaim Crispin, 46, for instance, was among those who selected Mr. Netanyahu last time. But Mr. Crispin, a lifelong Likudnik who owns a small metal business in Beersheba, said Mr. Netanyahu had immediately detached him from his party loyalty. He will vote for Yitzhak Mordechai, the Center Party candidate. And in a runoff election, if it comes to that, he will vote for Mr. Barak -- "if there's no other choice, because no way I'll vote for Bibi."
 
Netivot
This somewhat desolate southern town that is home to poor and working class Sephardic Jews is an unlikely tourist destination. But Netivot has the tomb of Baba Sali, the late Rabbi Yisrael Abuhatzeira, a Moroccan-born sage who was revered as a healer and miracle worker. And Jews of North African descent flock to it in tour buses. If there is anything that is unadulterated Netanyahu territory, this is it.
At a raucous bar mitzvah, celebrated with couscous and grilled meat, one man banged a drum, while another strummed an oud. Shouting above the revelry, Felix Smadar, a port worker, said, "We're Bibi. Why? Because he's a strong man, and all the Arabs are afraid of him."
But within every group, there is a freethinker. Cheli Azulay, who was celebrating her one-week wedding anniversary at the tomb, said she will vote for Mr. Mordechai, defying her new husband, because she dislikes Mr. Netanyahu.
Sometimes, voters' motivations are personal. "He takes his wife everywhere, this Bibi," Mrs. Azulay said. Yitzhak "Rabin -- God bless his soul -- did he drag his wife around with him? What is this? I don't like it."
 
Ashkelon
On the pedestrian mall in this port town that is home to new immigrants from the former Soviet Union and older immigrants from North Africa, Ilana Tveritzim cuddled her small, blond daughter.
A clerk at an employment agency who left Russia nine years ago, she is one of the immigrant voters that the candidates are furiously courting because they seem less wedded to parties than native-born Israelis.
Mrs. Tveritzim is abandoning Mr. Netanyahu. "He tends to bump his head against other heads," she said. "That is not good in a leader. Maybe Barak is more mature.'
At her non-kosher delicatessen in Ashlelon, stocked with sausages, Tanya Levin, of Minsk, said she is defecting from Mr. Netanyahu, too, because the economy is depressed. And Renata Koeppel, who immigrated to Israel four years ago from the Ukraine, said that her friends are feeling the sting of rising unemployment. She works at a new toy store, where she beat out 100 other immigrants for the job, her boss said. "We will vote Barak," she said.
Hearing about their fellow countrymen, Uri and Natalie Datchek were disappointed. "Maybe they are not thinking about Israel, but themselves," Mr. Datchek said, endorsing Mr. Netanyahu because "he is strong."
 
Ramat Aviv Gimmel
This community is so notorious as the affluent yuppie center of Tel Aviv that it is the name of the Israeli television's version of Beverly Hills 90210. In 1996, Ramat Aviv Gimmel came out strongly for Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader who lost to Mr. Netanyahu.
This is one of the places where Israelis say they will sink into depression -- or go abroad for a while -- if Mr. Netanyahu is re-elected.
Sari Yisraeli, a real estate broker with stylishly touseled red hair, was meeting some clients at a cafe in an upscale food court in the local mall. She said she and her friends are panicked at the possibility of a Netanyahu victory.
"If it will be Bibi, it will be tragedy -- disaster," she said. "If he wins, I think I'm going to lock myself in the house for a week. Barak -- I trust his judgment -- I trust it in my gut."
Inside a coffee shop, two well-dressed couples debated their choices of candidates, offering lukewarm endorsements. "I'm a right-winger, so I will have to vote for Netanyahu," Avner Cohen said.
"I don't like him," said his friend, Ms. Alexandrovitz. "He's not a good choice. But don't misunderstand me. I'm not a big fan of Barak."
"I didn't say I like Bibi, either," Mr. Cohen shot back. 
 
Abu Ghosh
In his immaculate shop in this relatively prosperous Arab village in the Judean hills, Mr. Ibrahim stood between towering bottles of olive oil and hookahs, which were on sale.
"A man like me, not a Jew -- on the one hand, they are telling me this is not your state," Mr. Ibrahim said. "On the other, they are telling me you have the right to vote. So what is the value of that right in a place they say I don't belong?"
Election campaigns underscore the quandary of Israeli Arabs, citizens who feel they are treated as second class. With more than 300,000 voters, they represent an important bloc. In the past, their turnout, which is relatively low by Israeli standards, has been somewhat assured by their desire to cast a ballot for the Arab parties in the Parliament.
But in this election, where there is likely to be a runoff, will they be motivated to vote a second time, to choose between Mr. Barak and Mr. Netanyahu? In a close race, the answer is very important to Mr. Barak, and his party is working hard to overcome the cynicism many Israeli Arabs feel.
"The leftist parties scream, "Give us your vote so that we can get back in power and make things right for you,' " Mr. Ibrahim said. "Then regimes change, but nothing changes for us. They are right to worry about the Israeli-Arab turnout."
 
Mea Shearim
In the shopping district near here, the walls are plastered with posters warning against casting a blank ballot for Prime Minister.
"White slip, black future," the new posters say ominously.
The posters are trying to combat a community-wide campaign that is urging strictly religious Jews in Mea Shearim to be neutral. It is a pragmatic response to the possibility that Mr. Barak could win as well as an expression of the feeling that the religious community has become too politicized.
Standing near one wall of posters, Rickie Sofer, who immigrated to Israel 30 years ago from Brooklyn, said she was considering abstaining altogether, even from the vote for Parliament.
"The truth is, between you and me, I think they're all dishonest," she said. "Last time, I voted for Netanyahu. He looks like a gentleman. But I'm very disappointed by his conduct."
Mrs. Sofer is unusually independent-minded. Most members of the religious community vote according to their rabbis' recommendation, although most rabbis have not yet made their endorsements.
Asya Konofnitsky, a young mother who held her tiny daughter's hand at a bus stop, looked stunned when she was asked for whom she would vote.
"How could I know?" she said. "The Torah sages have been silent. What they tell me. That's what I will vote."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Testing an Emerging Market;
Can Wall St.'s Old Guards Cope With the New Trading?

BYLINE: By DIANA B. HENRIQUES 

 BODY:
Late last month, lawyers for Island ECN, a computerized stock-trading service that opened for business less than three years ago, applied to the Securities and Exchange Commission to become America's newest stock exchange.
Island's owners acknowledge they are taking a leap of faith as they set out to compete on an equal basis with the 207-year-old New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq market, born a quarter-century ago. Like those exchanges, Island deals with brokerage firms, not individual investors, but its software offers a difference: automatically matching up orders from buyers and sellers without going through a dealer or trading floor. 
 Island is a novice, though, in the regulatory labyrinth. "We don't even know how much it will cost us to go through the S.E.C. process," said Edward J. Nicoll, chief operating officer of the Datek Online Holdings Corporation, which owns Island. "We've guessed $10 million" -- a figure that Island's 28-year-old president, Matthew Andresen, acknowledged making up out of the blue.
As Americans gallop into the stock market seeking instant riches or retirement security, the basic trading machinery is also being made up on the fly. Driven by technology, upstarts like Island are luring trades away from Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange by offering nanosecond service and microscopic fees. Those older markets are fighting back, proposing longer trading hours, new rules and changes in their ownership structure aimed at making them more competitive.
"This is not a revolution; it is an earthquake," said Robert A. Schwartz, a finance professor at Baruch College in New York.
And the fault lines lead directly to the S.E.C., which is responsible for maintaining investor confidence in a marketplace that behind the scenes is changing almost beyond recognition. The agency must make sure that rapid change does not create new opportunities for fraud or conflicts of interest and that investors are not shortchanged amid the confusion.
"This is a time of evolution and change," said Annette L. Nazareth, the agency's new director of market regulation. "When you have those dynamics, you can't always predict what the next step will be."
The scenarios range from a fragmented world of competing exchanges like Island, each catering to a different trading community, to a monolithic world where today's competitors have merged into a single network that trades foreign and domestic stocks around the clock.
So far, regulators seem sure that whatever market model emerges will be cheaper, faster and fairer for all investors. But the agency's ad hoc approach to a changing marketplace has made it a lightning rod for Wall Street's frustration.
"Regulators are having as tough a time as everybody else trying to figure out what their new priorities should be," said John Byrne, editor of The Trader, a Wall Street magazine. "We all need to tread a little more carefully -- there's too much at stake, from the livelihood of market makers to the health of the nation's economy."
Moreover, the same technology that has produced the market's structural earthquake has produced an explosion of Internet stock gossip and on-line investing, which themselves produce myriad opportunities for fraud.
With Congress urging more attention to on-line abuses, Arthur Levitt, the S.E.C. chairman, announced on May 4 that he was asking for enough new money to double his "cyberforce," the 125-lawyer team devoted to policing the Internet.
And the next day, Senator Charles E. Schumer, Democrat of New York, introduced a bill requiring disclosure of on-line brokers' service records, raising the penalties for on-line fraud and increasing the five-year budget authorization for the S.E.C.'s Internet efforts.
By contrast, little public attention has been paid to the agency's market regulation division -- though that "is where the real changes are happening," said John C. Coffee Jr., a Columbia University law professor.
Island's application is just one of the novel issues pummeling the S.E.C. Others include proposals to extend trading hours on Nasdaq and the New York exchange and to convert the fractional stock quotes to dollars and cents. Nasdaq dealers want to collect fees for matching buyers and sellers, as Big Board floor specialists and computerized traders like Island do, and the Big Board is planning to acquire or build its own computerized system to compete with Nasdaq.
Meantime, the National Association of Securities Dealers, the parent of Nasdaq and the American Stock Exchange, is wrestling over demands for trading halts in volatile Internet stocks. And the Big Board is looking for ways to enable traders to buy foreign stocks in Frankfurt in the morning and sell the same shares in New York in the afternoon.
Some market participants trace the current tumult to two earlier S.E.C. initiatives.
In mid-1996, the commission imposed new rules for handling customers' trading orders, after Nasdaq dealers were accused of fixing prices for over-the-counter stocks. Dealers were directed to display on Nasdaq's trading screens any superior prices they had posted on private trading networks like Island.
Soon, the electronic communication networks' share of Nasdaq trading boomed. Putnam, Lovell, de Guardiola & Thornton, a San Francisco investment bank, calculated that these networks handled nearly 29 percent of all Nasdaq trades the last three months of 1998.
Then, in December, the S.E.C. adopted a new set of rules to govern electronic networks and other "alternative trading systems." The rules allow the networks to apply to become exchanges, the marketplace equals of Nasdaq and the New York Stock Exchange.
Island's application is the first test, and the commission is moving cautiously. After all, Ms. Nazareth said, approving a new exchange has not been done in 26 years.
And Island is a controversial applicant, in part because a sister subsidiary, Datek Online, is an on-line broker catering to day traders -- individuals who speculate on short-term stock positions -- who have prompted so much regulatory concern. Mr. Nicoll said Island would be well insulated from Datek's brokerage business.
 
A Police Force On the Lean Side
A pending investment by Waterhouse Investor Services, a unit of Toronto-Dominion Bank, will put $25 million in Island's coffers, adding to the fraction of a penny it gets for each trade. And as an exchange, Island would get a share of the millions of dollars investors pay for up-to-the-minute stock prices. But it would also take on the costly job of policing its members to prevent insider trading and other misbehavior.
The N.A.S.D. has a 200-member staff and a $60 million budget devoted to market regulation, and the Big Board's internal police force accounts for roughly a third of its 1,500-member staff.
Mr. Andresen said Island would do its duty by being innovative -- for example, it may hire outside accountants to audit its member brokerage firms, at the firms' expense.
Without commenting on Island's status, Ms. Nazareth warned that some electronic networks might not fully grasp "what it is going to entail when you get to the nitty-gritty of being an exchange." Her deputy, Robert L. D. Colby, added, "Doing self-regulatory oversight on the cheap is not going to be sufficient."
Many market experts say that in hindsight the S.E.C. should have envisioned the need for a single self-regulatory police force in a market composed of private, for-profit operations like Island.
As it turned out, that issue is just now climbing up the agency's agenda: the N.A.S.D. is considering spinning off its regulatory arm into just such a free-standing entity -- but it proposes doing so in conjunction with a plan to become a for-profit corporation. That initiative, which could essentially make the Nasdaq market into a Nasdaq stock, got an informal nod from Mr. Levitt last week, but its implementation is at best months away, given the deliberative pace of the agency's rule-making process.
If the regulatory gait is measured, the pace of reinvention is accelerating so fast that market executives are starting to compare it to the convulsive changes that began on May 1, 1975, when fixed brokerage commissions were abolished -- an event Wall Street calls "May Day."
Venerable but bloated firms found they could not survive on the thin commissions that mutual funds and other big investors demanded. Funds flourished as trading costs shrank, but they had to develop direct-to-consumer sales methods because stockbrokers became less interested in marketing their wares. Individuals, meanwhile, became a rich market for Charles Schwab and the other discount brokers born in this era.
 
Wall Street Labels It 'May Day II'
Today, with computers like Island's replacing many human relationships, Wall Street magazines like Institutional Investor and The Trader are talking about "May Day II."
Calling today's changes as significant as any that have occurred since the early 1930's, William R. Johnston, president of the New York Stock Exchange, drew knowing nods at a recent Wall Street conference when he said, "Your competitors today may be your partners tomorrow, and your competitors tomorrow may not even exist today."
How individual investors fare as all this unfolds will depend, in part, on how well the S.E.C. enforces rules that require brokers to give customers "the best execution" of trades -- traditionally, the best price.
But even the definition of "best execution" has been muddied by new technology and the emergence of new marketplaces, with newcomers like Mr. Andresen arguing that the term should encompass the speed and certainty of a trade, not just the price.
Poor execution can cost small investors far more than they save on low commissions, and on-line brokers sending orders to electronic networks are already generating complaints.
In a speech last week, Mr. Levitt warned Wall Street that his staff was finding numerous instances of poor execution. The best-possible execution was "not just good business practice; it's a legal obligation," he said.
But disciplinary cases have been rare, perhaps because regulators "are overwhelmed by some of the best-execution issues that have arisen in this new trading environment," Professor Coffee said.
 
A Big Test For the S.E.C.
Academic studies support the S.E.C.'s pride in how its order-handling rules have narrowed the spread between the prices at which Nasdaq stocks can be bought and sold. But Douglas M. Atkin, chief executive of Instinet, a unit of Reuters Group P.L.C. and the dominant private trading service, argues that the resulting market turbulence has made life difficult for large institutional investors, including pension accounts and mutual funds, which are most Americans' foothold in the market.
"The S.E.C. has done a lot of good things for the retail investor trading 400 or 500 shares," Mr. Atkin said. "What they need to take more into account, as market structure evolves, is that retail investors need a market that will work for them when they give their money to their mutual fund managers, too."
Mr. Colby disputes that institutional investors are discontented. "We have not heard any complaints," he said. But industry executives point out that interest from institutions is one engine driving the proliferation of alternative trading systems.
Some critics say the S.E.C. should focus on protecting investors and let the market evolve. Others argue that investors cannot be protected in a market that is not fairly structured.
But with so much at stake, it is clear that Wall Street is watching the S.E.C. carefully, particularly as it evaluates Island's application. "It is a bit premature to grade them yet," Professor Coffee said. "But this is the big exam."

HEADLINE: Productivity Rose at a Rate Of 4% in the First Quarter

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
The productivity of the nation's workers surged in the first three months of this year, highlighting the economy's continued competitiveness in its ninth year of expansion and easing fears of inflation.
The Labor Department said today that productivity, measuring workers' hourly output of goods and services, rose at an annualized rate of 4 percent in the first quarter of 1999. 
 That was a slight slowing from the 4.3 percent gain in the fourth quarter, but the overall performance was remarkably strong, especially for the advanced stage of the business cycle, when productivity growth is typically much more subdued.
"It seems to confirm the more positive view that people have about the economy," said Fred Breimyer, chief economist at the State Street Bank and Trust Company, referring to some analysts' description of a "new economy" in the 1990's, one that is marked by technological gains, low inflation and high productivity.
The first-quarter advance in productivity for workers outside the farm sector was well above the 3 percent increase expected by economists.
"We are going from strength to strength," said Robert Dederick, economic consultant with the Northern Trust Corporation in Chicago. "It's another factor in favor of the argument that productivity has moved to a new higher ground."
Productivity is crucial to rising standards of living. A more efficient work force gives companies a competitive edge, enabling them to keep prices lower. It also allows companies to grant payoffs to workers in the form of higher wages without cutting into profits.
Indeed, consistent with the robust productivity in the quarter, unit-labor costs, a key gauge of wage inflation, rose just three-tenths of 1 percent, following a drop of four-tenths of 1 percent in late 1998. Economists had expected a gain of half a percent in the first quarter.
But workers pocketed a solid rise in inflation-adjusted pay. Real per-hour compensation rose 2.8 percent in the first quarter, up from 2.2 percent in the prior quarter.

HEADLINE: HOUSE PROUD;
2B + 2H + 2F = A 1990's New York Design for Living

BYLINE: By MARC KRISTAL 

 BODY:
QUESTION: How long does it take to put together a three-bedroom, two-bathroom apartment in the heart of Greenwich Village, with three working fireplaces and a terrace, overlooking an Italianate inner garden, and all for a total of $234,000? Answer: 21 years.
The woman who created the space, Diane Shea, 45, is notable not merely for her perseverance. She also represents a classic New York tale, in a certain time and place: a personal journey from 1970's art student to a collaboration with a 1980's art star to a genteel, familial bohemianism that is typically 1990's. It is equally a chronicle of homesteading, Manhattan-style, and how, as one woman grew with the city, she adapted to changing times -- within her neighborhood, the real estate market, her apartment and her life. 
 It started in 1974, when Ms. Shea was an art major at the Parsons School of Design, crashing with three aspiring musicians in an artist-in-residence loft on West Broadway and Prince Streets, then a quiet, semi-industrial zone. Each paid $85 a month for the privilege of living in a space in which you took the elevator by leaping into the shaft and grabbing a rope, Tarzan-style, then scrambling out again before the car came down and crushed you.
Tiring of the communal life, Ms. Shea decided to get a place of her own. She found a 250-square-foot studio in a crazy-quilt structure created from four tenements erected in the 1850's and combined in the 1920's. The buildings had been joined but not unified, and the results of this poly gamous shotgun marriage were evident everywhere: hallways and window lines abruptly changed levels; closet doors opened onto unresolved bits of stairway. Indeed, there were still two entrances and two addresses, one on Bleecker Street, the other on West 11th.
Her studio was a box, with a half kitchen, and front and bathroom doors that opened directly into the living space. The wiring ran through the original gas lines, and the entire space functioned at the whim of a single 15-ampere fuse. Its sole distinguishing feature was an orange-veined, gray marble fireplace -- more a necessity than a luxury, as the boiler was often out.
But the studio's three windows looked onto a lush garden and former stable, which had been converted to a loggia adorned with found furniture. It formed a remarkable urban oasis. The neighborhood still felt very much like the storied bastion of bohemianism, in which free thinkers drank gin at Chumley's while debating the evils of capital and the glories of art. And at $175 a month, the price was right, though, Ms. Shea noted dryly, no bargain. It was an ideal life for a 20-year-old student enjoying her first New York adventure.
By 1985, when the building went co-op in that decade's real estate boom, Ms. Shea's life had changed. A relatively unknown artist, Robert Longo, had engaged her to collaborate on his work, and along the way he had become one of the brightest of the New York art scene's supernovas. Ms. Shea had, in her own way, arrived. Her priorities became those of a woman whose knockabout youth had given way, at 31, to a desire for more mature satisfactions.
With little in savings, Ms. Shea secured 100 percent bank financing and bought her piece of the Manhattan rock for $48,000. She also bought her next door neighbor's apartment, a 325-square-foot studio, for $68,000, also 100 percent financed, without knowing whether she could legally or structurally combine the two. Neither was anyone's ideal of hearth and home, but it was an opportunity, and she wasn't going to miss it.
Shortly afterward, Ms. Shea married Doug Sloan, a multimedia producer-director and old school chum of Mr. Longo's. She sublet her two studios and moved into Mr. Sloan's apartment in a cookie-cutter, white-brick building on East 46th Street. Still, she pined for Greenwich Village, though as a career woman and soon-to-be mother, for different reasons. The bohemian fantasyland of her youth was giving way to higher rents, fancier restaurants and tonier shops, but it was still home to Public School 3, one of the city's best. And with the Bleecker Street playground just outside the door, the Village remained one of the most civil places in Manhattan to raise a family. So Ms. Shea cast her eye on a third studio, this one a whopping 500 square feet.
There were two problems. The apartment was still occupied, by an elderly woman who paid a two-figure, stabilized rent. The second problem was more troublesome: the third space didn't adjoin the others. The only direct access was through a wooden fire door and across a tar-paper roof to another fire door.
Nevertheless, Ms. Shea urged her husband to buy the apartment from the owner of the building, knowing that he would take much less than if the place were vacant. They were near to closing a deal when the tenant suddenly died -- and the price more than doubled. Swallowing hard, Mr. Sloan ponied up $48,000. The couple now owned three studios, for a total of $160,000, and were still living in midtown.
There ensued two long years, in which Ms. Shea had a second child; worked with Robert Evans, a New York architect, to reconfigure the 1,000-plus square feet into a space that would afford comfort and privacy to a family of four; dealt with New York's protracted permit procedures and the Landmarks Commission, and through her architect hired an expediter to, as she put it, find loopholes in the law and hang around City Hall, making sure the paperwork got moved to the tops of the right piles.
The expediter, John Peachy, earned his keep. He found an obscure, Lindsay-era law stating that the total number of apartments in tenement buildings could be decreased without need of a new certificate of occupancy, which saved Ms. Shea an expense. And Mr. Evans determined that a lot-line window belonging to another building, which sat squarely in the middle of the planned hallway that would connect apartments two and three, could be legally covered.
Ms. Shea also joined the co-op board, which helped insure that her renovation plan would be approved. Once the permits and permissions were in place, she hired all the craftsmen and shopped for bargain appliances and fixtures. When money ran short, she shrewdly used her resources, bartering most of her cache of signed, original Longos at the height of their value to reduce her cash outlay to roughly $70,000 from an estimate of $120,000.
Finally, in 1995, just in time for her elder child to begin first grade at Public School 3, Ms. Shea and her family took up residence. The resulting space remains a model of painstaking planning, highlighting the architecture's best qualities, while catering to individual and collective needs.
This is most evident in Ms. Shea's original studio, which has been transformed into a two-bedroom children's suite and has a ship's snug economy. Her old entrance is now a niche, containing an antique storage cabinet used for linens. Beside it, the tiny Pullman kitchen has been replaced by louvered closets. These are opposite the doors to the new bedrooms; together, they form a corridor, at the end of which is the entrance to the enlarged bathroom.
Off the corridor, the children's two bedrooms form the most amusing and effective of the residence's spatial economies. The original studio had three windows. Each bedroom would, of course, receive one, but which child would get the third?
The solution was sublimely Solomonic: the new rooms interlock like Lego blocks before the center window, resulting in "bunk beds" in which each bunk is actually in a separate room. Mica, 8, has the lower berth in hers, while, 31 inches above, Max, 11, sleeps in the upper in the room next door. An identical-size portion of the original window (sealed with Plexiglas) remains at the foot of each bed. Both spaces, which display a riot of childhood clutter, provide roughly 50 square feet of floor space -- about the size of a dorm room, Ms. Shea noted.
Apartment two, which is a step up from the children's suite and in another building, serves as the couple's living room-kitchen-dining room. The narrow kitchen, which incorporates the old bathroom, is finished with an antique sink, which Ms. Shea found on the Bowery, and cherry-wood and glass cabinets. It is open at both ends, affording both separation and easy access from the front door and the dining area.
The living-dining area, though small, has three generous windows, which overlook the garden and flood the space with afternoon light. The area also reflects the family's priorities: no sofa, but a substantial dining table, designed by Ms. Shea, at which she and her children work on projects.
For the 14-by-20-foot tar-paper roof between apartments two and three, Mr. Evans designed a hallway that connects the spaces via their old fire exits. It is enclosed in what Ms. Shea describes as a little hut, raffishly clad in fire-resistant copper shingles. From the hallway, sliding glass doors open onto a new west-facing terrace, delightfully private and serene.
The third apartment serves as the master suite and departs from the others in atmosphere and architecture. With leaded-glass windows, wide plank floors and beamed ceiling, all original, the space sustains a literal and psychological separateness for parents who need their privacy. Here, the kitchen was removed, and a curved, partial wall installed to form an open walk-in closet/dressing room. This space contains another of Ms. Shea's droll designs for living: a pedestal sink, which taps the former kitchen's water line. While Ms. Shea is occupied in the slightly undersize bathroom, Mr. Sloan can shave in the closet.
Today, Ms. Shea, who still works with Mr. Longo, estimates that her apartment is worth roughly three times its $234,000 total cost. But the family has no plans to move on. For one thing, the feat could not be duplicated, at least in the Village. For another, the couple has built a post-and-beam house on 10 acres near Rhinebeck, N.Y., where the children can roam unrestricted.
Most of all, Ms. Shea expects that as she and her family evolve, the apartment, in one configuration or another, will always play a part in their lives. In a tradition more usually associated with the heartland, but no less applicable to New York, she will remain in her first home forever.

HEADLINE: FOOTLIGHTS

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE VAN GELDER 

 BODY:

NEWS
Roving Minstrels
Led by its artistic director, James Levine, the Met Orchestra today begins a 12-concert, 3-week tour of 10 European cities. Besides making its debut in Lisbon; Bremen and Baden-Baden, Germany; Prague and Geneva, the orchestra will be revisiting Madrid and Valencia, Spain; Hamburg and Cologne, Germany, and Vienna. Soloists appearing on the tour include Deborah Voigt, who will sing Richard Strauss's "Four Last Songs"; the clarinetist Ricardo Morales and the bassoonist Patricia Rogers. One concert in Baden-Baden will feature Act II of Saint-Saens's "Samson et Dalila," with Placido Domingo, Olga Borodina and Sergei Leiferkus in the principal roles. 

Journey Into Light
Eugene O'Neill will be the subject of a two-day conference of writers, critics and scholars organized at Baruch College to coincide with the Broadway run of "The Iceman Cometh." After consideration of O'Neill and his vision of racial, cultural and class conflict, the conference, which begins tomorrow, will end on Saturday with a performance by the Playwrights Theater of New York of O'Neill's one-act "Bound East for Cardiff," which brought realism to the American stage in 1916. The keynote address, "More Than 40 Years of Research and Analysis of O'Neill," will be given by Barbara Gelb, an O'Neill biographer with her husband, Arthur Gelb, the president of The New York Times Company Foundation.
 
Hemispheric
Some 60 works by 50 artists from Latin America, the Caribbean, the United States and Canada are on display through Aug. 9 in "Mastering the Millennium: Art of the Americas" at the Organization of American States' Art Museum of the Americas and the World Bank in Washington. Among the pieces is "WAIS Station Tower," by the Korean-born American Nam June Paik. The work evokes the rapid flow of information by means of a 17-foot-high pyramid with 56 television monitors displaying multiple images on a framework of electronic wiring and computer boards.
 
On the Riviera
The 52d Cannes International Film Festival began yesterday on the French Riviera with 22 films vying for the Golden Palm, to be awarded on May 23 by a jury led by the director David Cronenberg. Other jurors are the opera star Barbara Hendricks, the actors Holly Hunter and Jeff Goldblum, the playwright Yasmina Reza, the actress Dominique Blanc and the directors George Miller, Dorris Dorrie, Andre Techine and Maurizio Nichetti. The opening attraction was "The Barber of Siberia," Nikita Mikhalkov's historical epic of a tragic love. LAWRENCE VAN GELDER

HEADLINE: Essay;
Boris Strikes Again

BYLINE: By WILLIAM SAFIRE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
On the eve of Bill Clinton's impeachment, the President of the U.S. changed the subject by firing missiles. On the eve of Boris Yeltsin's impeachment, the President of Russia dominated the news by firing another of his Prime Ministers. Both stunts were briefly effective; the Russian way is cheaper.
Yevgeny Primakov was sent to the showers not only because he is an economic ignoramus but because he did not stand up for his boss to the Communist impeachers. 
 Until recently he had been warning Communists in the Duma that if they impeached Yeltsin, he would resign as Prime Minister. But this week the ambitious ex-spymaster changed his mind and told them he would stick around, impeachment or not, which impelled Boris to yank him.
In a way, I'll miss Yevgeny; he was the devil we knew. When a team of New York Times correspondents went to interview him last year, he spent the first 10 minutes denouncing my columns as glupo, "stupid" -- a display of thin-skinniness that warmed my heart. But it's good for Russia and the world that he's gone; Saddam Hussein's longtime friend was too adept at evildoing.
Trudging to the mound in relief is Sergei Stepashin, the K.G.B. chief who blundered into Chechnya and the police chief who failed to uncover Gen. Anatoly Kuntsevich's nerve-gas dealings with Syria. He is the fourth Russian Prime Minister in about a year, and mail addressed to him should read "or current occupant."
More important than who Yeltsin's choice is to be seasonal front man is what faction will win elections to the Duma in mid-December. Here's what to root for:
Communists, who now dominate, are using impeachment as their vehicle. Democratic reformers of the Yabloko Party are focused on reviving the failed economy. If the reformers push their Duma percentage up into the teens, they will be kingmakers in the presidential elections next year. Root for that.
But here's the stickler: Although Yabloko opposes four impeachment counts, it supports a fifth, castigating Yeltsin for the bloody war in Chechnya. If it passes, Yeltsin could not disband Parliament, and the Communists could refuse to approve his Prime Minister and Cabinet. Result: deadlock and crisis. Only six years ago, that led to the shelling of Parliament. We should root for the Duma's impeachment to fail.
What does Yeltsin want? He wants (1) to stay in control, politically and physically, until his last day in office; (2) to help defeat the Communists, his foes for the past decade, and (3) to keep the country stable enough to hold elections as scheduled. These are worthy goals and we should root for him to attain them.
Unfortunately, he may also want (4) to guarantee the welfare of his relatives and enriched oligarchs who sustain him, and (5) to bestride the world stage like the superpower Russia is no longer, protecting Serbia from the consequences of its state-sponsored savagery. We should offer catcalls and brickbats and Bronx cheers to call attention to our disapproval of this dangerous pretension.
Above all, Americans now forced to switch channels from economy-watching to military affairs should root for an awakening in the White House to its greatest current folly: using unstable, NATO-resentful, Chechnya-transfixed Russia as the broker in a deal with Serbia.
We do not need any go-between. NATO mediation should disintermediate immediately. If Slobodan Milosevic wants the bombing stopped, he knows what number to call. If we want to send him a message, we can do it over public airwaves.
A middleman only guarantees that we split "core" differences and thereby fail to protect returnees with the guns of the nations proved willing to fight for their rights.
Look beyond Primakov, Viktor Chernomyrdin, Stepashin, even Yeltsin. There looms a presidential front-runner, Yuri Luzhkov, Mayor of Moscow, who revealed his mindset last month to Harvard's Graham Allison in The Boston Globe: If NATO dares send troops into Serbia, Russia would supply the Serbs missiles to shoot down U.S. aircraft. This could "lead to direct military conflict between the U.S. and Russia."
Do not deal through Serbia's blustering ally. Deal direct.

HEADLINE: Earnings Rise at Federated and Kmart

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Federated Department Stores Inc., which owns Macy's and other department stores, and the Kmart Corporation, the nation's second-largest discount retailer, said yesterday that their first-quarter profits rose as they sold more clothes and home furnishings and held down costs.
Net income for Federated, whose chains also include Bloomingdale's and Burdines, rose 45 percent, to $87 million, or 40 cents a diluted share, compared with $60 million, or 27 cents, in the quarter a year earlier. Analysts expected the company to earn 31 cents a share, according to the First Call Corporation, which tracks company earnings. Sales rose 7.3 percent, to $3.71 billion from $3.46 billion. 
 Kmart's profit rose 43 percent, to $67 million, or 14 cents a share, compared with $47 million, or 10 cents a share, in the period a year earlier. The results matched Wall Street forecasts. Sales rose 8.4 percent, to $8.14 billion from $7.52 billion.
Shoppers, benefiting from rising wages and low inflation, splurged on home products such as lawn furniture as well as capri pants and other spring fashions. Both retailers squeezed more profit from sales by keeping costs in check.
Shares of Federated, based in Cincinnati, rose $3.3125, to $54.3125, while shares of Kmart, based in Troy, Mich., fell 43.75 cents, to $17.125. Both stocks are traded on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Mr. Rubin Leaves the Treasury

 BODY:
Robert E. Rubin's decision to step aside as Treasury Secretary was responsibly timed in that the major crises in the world now are not primarily economic. Nonetheless he will be missed, in part because he anchored a changing cast of Cabinet and White House officials. The American economy -- and those of many other countries -- might be in far worse shape had not his expertise and calm determination helped steer the Clinton Administration's economic policies for six years.
Mr. Rubin deserves a significant part of the credit for putting the Government on a course to balance the Federal budget, and he will be remembered as perhaps the most influential member of the Cabinet at a time that economic issues came to rival security concerns in determining American relations with other countries. He can also take pride that it has been more than eight years since the last American recession ended. 
 The understanding of markets that Mr. Rubin gained in a career as a bond trader proved to be invaluable in a world coming to grips with the growing reach of markets and the billions of dollars in capital that can be moved from one market to another by traders interested more in quick profits than long-term development.
Mr. Rubin, a former co-chairman of Goldman, Sachs, the investment bank, was chairman of President Clinton's National Economic Council until he was chosen as Treasury Secretary in late 1994, shortly before the Mexican crisis erupted as that country's currency fell sharply. It was Mr. Rubin who put together a rescue package that enabled Mexico to come through the crisis and also kept that crisis from infecting the rest of Latin America.
The bad part of the rescue -- that investors who had unwisely lent money to Mexico emerged unscathed -- came back to haunt the world by encouraging investors to make ill-considered investments in other countries. That contributed to the Asian crisis that erupted in 1997, but investors who thought such lending was risk-free learned otherwise when no bailout materialized after Russia defaulted on its debts last summer.
While there was criticism of the way the International Monetary Fund, with Mr. Rubin's approval, handled the Asian crisis by forcing countries to raise interest rates and bring on recessions, the fact is that most of Asia is on the mend and those policies now appear to have worked.
Lawrence Summers, the Deputy Secretary named to succeed Mr. Rubin, is an outstanding if sometimes undiplomatic economist who is well qualified and deserves prompt confirmation.

HEADLINE: Higher Prices Reported for Home Resales

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
Prices of existing homes rose in most metropolitan areas in the first three months of this year.
Nationally, the median resale price -- meaning half of homes sold for more and half for less -- was $131,600 during the January-March quarter, up 4.6 percent from the corresponding quarter a year earlier, the National Association of Realtors said today. 
 By comparison, inflation rose at a 1.7 percent annual rate during 1998 and has kept to an even lower 1.5 percent rate so far this year.
"The rise in home prices in all regions has been fueled by a combination of buyers ready to move up to more expensive homes and a growing number of first-time buyers in this favorable economic environment," said James F. Smith, chief economist for the real estate group.
Ten of the 120 metropolitan areas surveyed by the trade group reported median resale price rises of 10 percent or greater; 24 had drops. Median resale prices ranged from $65,700 in Ocala, Fla., to $331,100 in San Francisco.
The top five rises were: Kalamazoo, Mich., 13.6 percent; San Francisco, 13.2 percent; Miami-Hialeah, Fla., 12.9 percent; Boise, Idaho, 12.4 percent, and San Diego, 11.6 percent.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Like Beijing, Taiwan Courts Trade Forum

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, May 12

 BODY:
While international attention has been focused on Beijing's effort to join the World Trade Organization, Taiwan has quietly been moving ahead with its own application.
Representatives of the island, which Beijing considers a renegade province, met formally with trade organization delegates today to report their progress in complying with the market-opening requirements for admission to the 134-member group that makes the rules for international trade. The Taiwan representatives said their administration had essentially fulfilled the requirements. 
 Unstated, however, was the crucial question of whether Taiwan will be able to join before the Chinese Government in Beijing, which is at a much less advanced stage in the application process but has insisted that it must be admitted first.
Taiwan's bid could be completed in July, trade organization officials said. But an approval of its application could develop into a diplomatic confrontation, inflaming the already delicate situation in which China has been avidly seeking admission to the trade organization for a dozen years. Its recent efforts have been complicated by the accidental American bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade only weeks after Prime Minister Zhu Rongji lobbied heavily during a trip to the United States for China's acceptance into the W.T.O.
While Beijing officials have suspended human rights and other discussions with the Clinton Administration to protest the bombing, analysts have noted that they did not cut off trade talks, which are a high priority for the rapidly growing economy. Beijing is almost certain to protest if Taiwan gains entry first.
The issue could result in an effort by China's allies among developing countries, which make up the majority of trade organization members, to block Taiwan's admission. All actions at the trade regulatory body are supposed to be taken by general agreement among member countries. That includes the admission of new members.
However, Taiwan's bid could force a vote in the already splintered trade organization, which has been at very public odds in recent weeks over who will be named its next director general.
China's supporters argue that a 1992 "China first" statement agreed to by the trade organization's predecessor, the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, requires that Beijing gain admission before Taiwan.
Taiwan has always maintained that both applications should be evaluated on their merits, and the United States supports that view. Taiwan's negotiator, Yi Fu Lin, said today that "our opinion has been that the two accessions are dealt with separately."
Under the Nationalist Government -- since overthrown and moved to Taiwan, where successors are still in power -- China was among the 23 original signers of the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. But Chinese membership lapsed after the Communist revolution of 1949. Since 1986 Beijing has been seeking to rejoin the trade forum.

HEADLINE: SPORTS BUSINESS;
Pollin Selling Capitals and Share of the Wizards

BYLINE: By IRVIN MOLOTSKY 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
Abe Pollin, who poured millions of dollars into sports franchises that usually let him down by season's end, announced today that he was selling outright his hockey team, the Washington Capitals, and a minority interest in his other holdings, which include the Washington Wizards basketball team.
The price was not disclosed -- "We never talk about money," Pollin said at a news conference -- but it appeared that a partnership that will make the purchase was investing $200 million now with more to come in the future. 
 Pollin, who is 75, said that both his health and personal finances were in good shape but that his two sons had told him they did not want to follow him into the sports business. The recent basketball lockout did not affect his decision, he said.
The principal member of the partnership that is making the purchase, Ted Leonsis, is a billionaire Internet executive and sports buff who has a full-size basketball court at his house.
Asked why he was making the investment, Leonsis said: "Because I can. I love competition. I went to Georgetown University. I was a Hoya." He is a sports fan from Brooklyn who used to root for the Knicks.
Leonsis is an executive at America Online, but he said that there would not be any connection between his sports and computer interests.
Pollin and his wife, Irene, have been known in Washington for their community activity and he said that the sale would allow them more time -- and more money -- for that.
"I have decided to spend a little less time with sports and more with folks less fortunate than I am," Pollin said at the news conference, which was held on the Wizards' practice court in the MCI Center, an arena he built two years ago with $200 million of his own money in downtown Washington. His immediate concerns, he said, were a major campaign by Unicef for relief in Kosovo and helping Washington's homeless.
When asked why he was selling now, he answered, "First, we did not want a repeat of the mess the Redskins went through with their transition."
His reference was to the disposition of the Washington football team after the death of its owner, Jack Kent Cooke. The trustees of the Cooke estate sold the team to one group, only to have the deal fall apart when it became clear that the owners of the National Football League would not approve the buyers.
Although neither Pollin nor Leonsis would say how much the partnership was paying, Leonsis was asked if it was $200 million and he answered: "That's a good number."
One of Leonsis' partners, Jonathan J. Ledecky, confirmed the $200 million estimate and, after Leonsis had declined to provide the breakdown of the new partnership, Ledecky suggested that Leonsis' share was 60 percent, his own 30 percent and that of Dick Patrick, president of the Capitals, 10 percent.
Pollin remains the majority partner in Washington Sports, which owns the Wizards and the MCI Center, and said he hoped to bring another basketball championship to Washington. He said that he expected the new partnership to eventually invest enough to obtain full ownership of his properties -- the two teams, the MCI Center and Ticketmaster.
Pollin's son Robert, a professor of economics at the University of Massachusetts, Amherst, confirmed later that neither he nor his brother, Jim, who runs a travel business, wanted to follow Pollin as the teams' owners.
Asked whether his father's holdings made economic sense, he said: "Yes. He's got a lot of debt, but he's doing O.K."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: BEIJING;
China Pauses As Remains Of Victims Return Home

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 12

 BODY:
The ashes of the three Chinese killed by NATO bombs in Belgrade returned to China today, carried off the airplane by relatives wearing white flowers of mourning in a sad procession shown repeatedly on national television.
Popular anger over the bombing of the Chinese Embassy on Friday was laced with grief. 
 The authorities, seeking to re-channel the outrage of the last four days, halted the raucous demonstrations that had immobilized the American Embassy and urged students and others to concentrate on their own work to help make China stronger.
This morning, the streets around the embassy were quiet, sealed off by hundreds of police officers. Ambassador James Sasser emerged from the embassy for the first time since Saturday.
He and several staff members walked out the front door, picking their way through shards of glass and heaps of plastic bottles, and chunks of concrete that protesters had heaved against the building.
"I think we need to give our Chinese friends a day of grief, and then we can move on and discuss with them how to mend this situation," Mr. Sasser said before visiting the families of American diplomats who have remained all week in nearby foreigners' compounds. Mr. Sasser later returned to work and then left to sleep elsewhere.
For the rest of the week, a skeletal staff will be working in the embassy and consulate buildings, mainly to clean up. The embassy remains officially closed.
The embassy flags were hung at half-staff in respect for the dead. The gesture was shown on Chinese television, another sign that the authorities were hoping to cool passions as they sought deeper remorse and explanations from the United States.
China flew all flags at half-staff as the entire political leadership paid homage to the dead, who are described as heroes and martyrs.
Killed in the bombing, which the United States says was caused by a misidentification of the building, were Shao Yunhuan, 47, a reporter for the official New China News Agency; Xu Xinghu, 31, a reporter for The Guangming Daily newspaper, and his wife, Zhu Ying, 27, an art director for the paper's advertising department.
Also brought home on the plane today were 6 seriously wounded people and 20 who were sleeping in the embassy when it was hit by at least three bombs.
Ms. Shao's 19-year-old son carried her ashes. Her husband, a diplomat, was one of the severely wounded taken off in a stretcher. Ms. Zhu's father carried two boxes of ashes, those of his daughter and of his son-in-law, in the walk past weeping relatives, politicians and hundreds of representatives of social groups.
The procession was officially met by Vice President Hu Jintao, who was shown on television greeting a bandaged man by saying, "On behalf of the Central Committee of the Communist Party, I welcome you home and offer you sincere condolences."
This afternoon, private memorial services were held at The Guangming Daily and at the news agency.
The television news tonight showed President Jiang Zemin, Prime Minister Zhu Rongji and Li Peng, who ranks second in the Communist Party and heads the Parliament, as well as three other top party leaders, visiting the services before they began, shaking hands with grieving relatives.
Alone among the leaders, the usually unflappable Mr. Zhu was visibly sobbing.
As of late today there was no announcement of any larger public service, an event that some feared might set off demands for additional demonstrations.
The Chinese and American Governments have barely begun to assess how far the bombing and the convulsion of anti-Americanism here have damaged relations.
In view of the political climate in Washington, China may be badly mistaken if it tries to use guilt over the bombing to extract deep concessions on vital issues.
Chinese leaders have made it clear that they still seek American trade, investment and technology and that they still want to join the World Trade Organization.
But even before the bombing, powerful industries here had attacked Mr. Zhu for making too many market-opening concessions in negotiations with Washington over the trade organization, putting those talks under a cloud.
China's leaders surely know that after the outburst this week Congress will be in no mood to grant special economic favors.
Nor has it ever been likely that the Clinton Administration could give China the absolute pledge that it seeks that Taiwan will not be included in a hypothetical missile-defense system.
The Chinese, for their part, have suspended talks on arms proliferation and other issues that are of deep concern to the United States, and it is unclear what it will take to get them back to the table.
Still, the two countries have many shared economic interests, and neither wants to see a costly new cold war.
Outside the embassy this morning, Mr. Sasser said he hoped that "we'll move back in the direction of trying to establish a productive and stable relationship between our two countries."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS & BONDS;
Sellingon the News, Wall St. Recovers

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Wall Street flinched, but then quickly brushed off yesterday's announcement that Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin was resigning and being replaced by Deputy Treasury Secretary Lawrence H. Summers.
Stocks did fall on the news, with the Dow Jones industrial average plunging more than 200 points in the morning. Bond prices dipped and the dollar, which was rallying in Europe because of the sudden dismissal of the Russian Prime Minister, gave up some gains. 
 But it did not take long for traders and investors to realize that the resignation news was not that bad and the three markets began to rebound almost immediately. Indeed, President Boris Yeltsin's dismissal of Prime Minister Yevgeny Primakov had more impact, but it was still muted. While the dollar moved as some investors sought a haven, bond and stock prices fell only moderately in key emerging market countries.
But by the end of the day in the United States, stocks were mostly higher, the dollar rose against the euro and bond prices were little changed.
One reason for the rebound is that Mr. Summers is respected, though his bluntness might mean some volatile trading days when he speaks his mind. Additionally, Clinton Administration policy initiatives -- including support for a strong dollar and open markets, and a focus on the repair of global financial markets -- are not expected to change. The American economy is in good shape and the world financial crisis has subsided.
But more importantly, Wall Street was prepared. Rumors of a Rubin-Summers switch have been circulating for so long that the only uncertainty was the timing of the change. The Treasury went to great lengths to prepare financial markets and investors for the change, even insisting that the cover photograph for a Time magazine article earlier this year on the taming of the global financial crisis include Mr. Summers with Mr. Rubin and Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman.
"This is a move that had long been contemplated," John Lipsky, the chief economist at Chase Manhattan Bank, said. "And there is no sense that Mr. Summers is untried in directing policy."
Byron R. Wien, the United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, said the change in leadership at the Treasury would not have an effect on his outlook for the stock market. But he did say there would be a "vacuum in the Cabinet" because Mr. Rubin's contributions included more than his Treasury duties.
"His influence and his wisdom covered geopolitical areas and areas of public policy well beyond financial and that is what will be sorely missed," Mr. Wien said.
He also argued that with "the credibility of the Clinton Administration damaged, Mr. Rubin was the one person who had the respect of Congress and the respect of our partners abroad. And it will take a while for Mr. Summers to grow into that."
Jeremy P. Fand, the senior foreign exchange strategist at the BankBoston Corporation, suggested that the appointment of Mr. Summers might even give an extra upward push to the dollar.
"The dollar will benefit from his frankness on the problems with the Japanese and European economies," Mr. Fand said, because his comments will presumably make it clearer to investors why they should be investing in the United States rather than Europe or Japan.
Mr. Fand also said that "the dollar is likely to be more volatile because Mr. Summers will be less controlled with his remarks."
In the stock market, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 25.78 points, to 11,000.37. Two oil companies -- Exxon, off 2 9/16 a share, to 79 1/16, and Chevron, down 3, to 95 1/16 -- accounted for most of the Dow's loss as the price of oil fell to $17.57 a barrel, dropping for the fourth time in the last five trading days.
The other major stock indexes ended higher. The Nasdaq composite index rose 39.86 points, or 1.55 percent, to 2,606.54, led by Cisco Systems, which reported better-than-expected earnings for its third quarter and announced a 2-for-1 stock split. Earnings jumped 33 percent and the stock rose 6 7/8 a share, to 118 3/4.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks set a new closing high, finishing at 1,364.00, up 8.39 points. The Russell index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks climbed 2.45 points, at 449.26.
The selloff that greeted the Rubin announcement was a reflection that traders cannot take time to assess important news. If it appears to be bad, they have to sell immediately to defend themselves from steep losses. If the news proves to be less worrisome, they can always buy again, even profiting from the decline.
Bond investors remained nervous yesterday ahead of reports on producer and consumer inflation, set for release today and tomorrow respectively, and on retail sales today.
Yesterday's Treasury auction of 10-year notes went much better than Tuesday's five-year note auction, giving the bond market a little lift. The new 10-year note was auctioned at a yield of 5.51 percent; by the end of the day that slipped to 5.50 percent as the price, which moves in the opposite direction, rose.
The price of the 30-year bond was up 4/32, to 91 30/32, while the yield slipped one-hundredth of a percentage point, to 5.82 percent yesterday.
The dollar strengthened against the euro, with the euro ending the day at $1.0653, down from $1.0715 on Tuesday. The dollar was off slightly against the Japanese yen, at 120.95 yen compared with 120.97 Tuesday. The dollar did rebound from the intraday low against the yen after the Rubin announcement.
In emerging markets, the Bovespa stock index in Brazil dropped nearly 1 percent, while the Bolsa index in Mexico fell 1.74 percent. The difference -- or spread -- between the yield on Russian bonds and comparable United States Treasuries jumped to 42.73 percent, which reflected a 10 percent drop in prices, according to J. P Morgan Securities. But the moves in Latin American bond markets were much smaller. In Brazil, the spread widened less than a quarter of a percentage point to 8.88 percent.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE MILITARY;
Allies Detail Busiest Bombing Yet, but See Clash Continuing

BYLINE: By STEVEN LEE MYERS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
Senior NATO and Pentagon officials said today that after the most intense 24 hours of bombing so far, NATO had weakened Yugoslavia's forces but still not broken their ability to fight.
Gen. Henry H. Shelton, the Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, said the attacks had exacted "a significant toll on Serb forces in Kosovo and throughout the rest of Yugoslavia," including half of the Yugoslav Air Force and a quarter of tanks and other armored forces in Kosovo. 
 President Slobodan Milosevic of Yugoslavia acknowledged today that the NATO attack has caused the deaths of "many members" of its army and police forces.
But General Shelton conceded that the Yugoslav forces could go on for weeks. "It is possible that a force like the one Milosevic is using for ethnic cleansing and terror in Kosovo could hold out for quite some time," he said at a Pentagon briefing.
General Shelton and Secretary of Defense William S. Cohen offered a fairly detailed -- and upbeat -- assessment of NATO's campaign in the Balkans, which reached its 50th day today with no sign of nearing an end.
With clear skies, American and allied warplanes have been attacking in wave after wave. Officials said NATO aircraft carried out 327 strikes over the 24 hours leading up to early today, hitting eight bridges, an air-defense command center in the Belgrade suburb of Rakovica, an oil production center in Sombor, in the province of Vojvodina, and five airfields, where they destroyed a MIG-29 and five MIG-21's.
It began early Tuesday with 36 American A-10's and F-16's, British Harriers, French Etendards and Jaguars and others attacking military vehicles around Suva Reka, in south-central Kosovo. And it ended just before dawn today with 24 fighters and bombers, including B-52's, striking sites in Kosovo, including the airfield in the provincial capital of Pristina, and forces around Junik and Stimlje.
Although the campaign has done nothing to reverse the expulsion of much of Kosovo's Albanian population, NATO and Pentagon officials have portrayed the attacks as successful. "I would simply say that the game's not over yet, quite frankly," NATO's spokesman, Jamie P. Shea, said today when asked to assess the progress so far. "And I don't think we should start writing the history books until the final results are in."
Officials in Brussels and here in Washington continue to report an erosion in morale among Yugoslavia's military leaders, though they have provide little evidence. Other officials have played down the psychological impact of the attacks.
Mr. Cohen said Yugoslavia's senior military leaders had sent their families out of the country.
"Milosevic may not admit that he is taking his country down the road to ruin -- politically, economically and militarily -- but his top leadership is apparently more realistic," he said. "And at the very least, they are hedging their bets by hiding their assets and their families."
Mr. Cohen's aides said they did not have the names of commanders who had sent their families out of the country. Nor could they say how many families they believe have left.
Mr. Cohen and General Shelton vowed to press the attacks -- soon with additional aircraft based in Hungary and Turkey and, perhaps, with Apache helicopter gunships in Albania, which General Shelton indicated were at last ready for combat. Two that crashed have been replaced, bringing the total back to 24.

 	 	 		--------------------	 	
 
Milosevic Admits Casualties
 BELGRADE, Serbia, May 12 (Reuters) -- For the first time since the NATO bombing began, President Slobodan Milosevic publicly acknowledged today that his forces had suffered casualties.
The acknowledgment came in a statement read on Serbian television that paid tribute to the "many members" of the country's forces that have been killed.
"I wish to congratulate all the members of the police forces and the security services and to pay tribute to their efforts to defend the security of the fatherland," Mr. Milosevic's statement said.
"In that struggle, many of your members bravely gave their lives, and their sacrifice is a bright example of their heroism and loyalty to their people and fatherland," it said. "You have had great success in breaking the separatists' movement and their terrorist gangs in Kosovo, who are supported by foreign forces who have committed the crime of aggression against our country."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

S.E.C. Sweep Uncovers Stock Frauds on Internet
Companies are using the new medium of the Internet for the old-fashioned task of separating investors from their money, promising profits that seem too good to be true, and are according to the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Their practices were revealed in an S.E.C. enforcement action against 18 people and eight companies in 14 cases of fraud -- the agency's third sweep in seven months of Internet investment scams. Market Place. Page C9. 

Oxford Health Plans on the Mend
Oxford Health Plans has backed away from the brink of bankruptcy by shedding thousands of loss-making members and raising premiums for its customers. Dr. Norman Payson, Oxford's chief executive, promises profits later this year, after operating losses in the first six months. But even he says the makeover is a "work in progress." C2.
 
Microsoft Is Shaping British Cable
Microsoft is positioning itself as a dominant player in the contest to revolutionize Britain's cable industry for the oft-foretold era when the television cable delivers not just shows but high-speed Internet access. C20.
 
Drabinsky Responds to Livent Suit
In his first detailed response to the suit filed against him, Garth H. Drabinsky, who founded Livent, said in court papers that he had been too caught up producing Broadway musicals to have had time to help keep the company's books, which have been found to be false. C5.
 
Year 2000 Liability Bill Advances
The House approved legislation to limit lawsuits arising from Year 2000 computer failures. Although President Clinton has vowed to veto the measure, the vote keeps the issue, and a possible compromise, alive. C9.
 
Profit Rises at Federated and Kmart
Federated Department Stores, which owns Bloomingdale's, Macy's and other department stores, and Kmart, the nation's second-largest discount retailer, said that their first-quarter profits rose as they sold more clothes and home furnishings and held down costs. Shares of Federated rose $3.3125, to $54.3125, while shares of Kmart fell 43.75 cents, to $17.125. C9.
 
Bidding War Erupts for One 2 One
Britain's smallest mobile phone company, One 2 One, has ignited a bidding war between Europe's biggest telecommunication companies, even though it has yet to turn a profit. C4.
 
Loewen in Bankruptcy Warning
The Loewen Group reported a 77 percent drop in profit and warned that creditors might force a sale or reorganization. C4.
 
USA Networks Ends Bid for Lycos
USA Networks, the media company run by Barry Diller, officially dropped its plan to buy Lycos, the Internet search service, because of opposition from Lycos shareholders. C20.
 
Minimum Wage Increase Expected
Congress will almost certainly raise the minimum wage this year, probably to $6.15 an hour from $5.15, phased in over two to three years. But does a higher minimum wage make economic sense? A growing number of economists say yes, though there is reason for Congress to move cautiously. Michael M. Weinstein: Economic Scene. C2.
