HEADLINE: Cox to Acquire TCA Cable for $3.26 Billion

BYLINE: By LAWRIE MIFFLIN 

 BODY:
In the latest consolidation deal by a cable company preparing to offer telephone, Internet and interactive services as well as ordinary television to its subscribers, Cox Communications Inc., announced yesterday that it was acquiring TCA Cable TV Inc. for $3.264 billion in stock and cash.
The deal moves Cox up the ladder of the nation's largest cable companies from No. 5 to No. 4, behind Time Warner Inc., the AT&T Corporation (new owner of Telecommunications Inc.) and the Comcast Corporation. 
 Cox, based in Atlanta, will have almost 5 million cable subscribers upon the completion of two deals -- yesterday's with the Texas-based TCA, which has 883,000 customers mostly in Texas, Arkansas and Louisiana, and its recent $1.4 billion acquisition of Media General Inc., of northern Virginia, with 264,000 subscribers.
"This company was the last attractive takeover candidate among the publicly traded cable companies," Fred Moran, an analyst with ING Baring Furman Sels, said of TCA. Mr Moran's company was among several investment firms that gave TCA a "buy" rating recently.
The consolidation trend that began with enormously expensive acquisitions by the three biggest cable companies is now spreading to middle-sized companies, analysts said. Cable companies need to acquire more systems and subscribers to achieve economies of scale in building costly new networks capable of delivering telephone and Internet and interactive digital television to homes.
The Cox-TCA transaction is valued at $63.89 a share, with Cox offering TCA shareholders $31.25 in cash and 0.3709 share of Cox common class A stock for each TCA share. Cox will also asume $736 million in debt. The transaction has been approved by both companies' boards.
Mr. Moran said that the deal translated to a multiple of roughly 20 times TCA's estimated cash flow in the current fiscal year, which ends Oct. 31, or a value of about $4,100 a subscriber. He described that price as "right in line with other recent transactions in the industry and very rewarding for TCA shareholders because they get both cash and stock in Cox, which is one of industry leaders."
AT&T paid about $4,600 a subscriber when it agreed to acquire Mediaone Group Inc., last week.
Another large multisystem operator, the Adelphia Communications Corporation of Coudersport, Pa., has made three acquisitions, each for more than $1 billion, of small cable companies in the last two months. The latest was its purchase of privately held Harron Communications in April.
James Robbins, Cox's president and chief executive, said his company planned to make further acquisitions, calling TCA "the cornerstone of our plans to offer advanced services in middle-market communities."
TCA reaches 74 percent of the homes in its markets, well above the industry average of 67 percent. And Mr. Robbins said it had several other attributes important to Cox, including what he called "a powerful commitment to customer service, a solid management team, a strong balance sheet and a technologically advanced network."
Indeed, Cox and TCA are both well ahead of most other cable companies in making many of the technological improvements needed to enable cable lines to provide advanced services and digital television. Both have also been aggressive about deploying new services to customers relatively quickly.
Half of TCA's systems and more than 65 percent of Cox's have two-way capability for data and telephone services. TCA offers high-speed Internet access to about 2,300 customers now in partnership with the At Home Corporation and digital-cable television service to about 5,000.
Cox currently has almost 100,000 digital television subscribers, in eight markets, and provides high-speed Internet access via cable modem to 88,900 customers; it also provides digital telelphone, but to only about 42,000 customers.
"Cox stands today as the most technologically sophisticated cable operator, already," Mr. Moran said. "And TCA, as a well-positioned Southwestern property, complements Cox perfectly because they, too, have been aggressive in deployment of new technology."
Once the transaction is completed, Cox Enterprises Inc., will be the majority shareholder of the new company, with 67.2 percent of the equity and 76.8 percent of the voting power in Cox Communications Inc.
Following the announcement, Standard & Poor's placed debt of Cox Enterprises Inc. and Cox Communications Inc. on Creditwatch with negative implications, apparently because the Media General and TCA deals will require substantial financing. While it has an extensive investment portfolio that includes equity in AT&T and At Home, Cox has not announced a definitive financing plan.
Shares of Cox Communications fell $1.9375, to $8.625. TCA Cable gained $7.96875, or 15.31 percent, to $60.03125.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on May 13 about Cox Communications' acquisition of TCA Cable TV misstated the scope of a previous agreement by Cox, involving Media General. Cox purchased Media General's cable operations in northern Virginia, not the entire company.

PUB-DATE: May 14, 1999,

SECTION: Section E; Part 1; Page 23; Column 1; Movies, Performing Arts/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 2209 words

HEADLINE: MOVIE GUIDE

 BODY:

Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy movies and film series playing this weekend in New York City. * denotes a highly recommended film or series. Ratings and running times are in parentheses. An index of reviews of films opening today appears on page 12.
 
Now Playing
 
* "AFTER LIFE," starring Arata, Taketoshi Naito and Erika Oda. Written, directed and edited by Hirokazu Kore-eda (not rated, 118 minutes). Much of this transcendently compassionate, gently humorous Japanese film is set in a drab office building where courteous caseworkers welcome the week's new clients. The place turns out not to be a social service agency but a metaphysical way station where the newcomers are people of all ages and types who have just died and have three days to select one memory to take with them into eternity. Before they depart, those memories will be filmed. As they tell their stories and make their choices (those who can't choose remain at the processing center as caseworkers), the movie becomes a profound meditation on life's meaning and value and the relationship of movies, memories and dreams (Stephen Holden). 

* "ANALYZE THIS," starring Robert De Niro, Billy Crystal, Lisa Kudrow and Chazz Palminteri. Directed by Harold Ramis (R, 110 minutes). The title, concept and teaming of these co-stars are all funny before the lights go down, so think of this comedy as an offer you can't refuse. Cast as a mobster whose confidence is shaken, Mr. De Niro is hilarious simply by playing his role halfway straight, in classic goodfella style. His mobster finds just the right comic foil in Mr. Crystal as the psychiatrist who utters the immortal, "When I got into family therapy, this wasn't the family I had in mind." There's a lot more where that came from in this breezy comedy (Janet Maslin).
 
* "COOKIE'S FORTUNE," starring Charles S. Dutton, Glenn Close, Patricia Neal, Julianne Moore and Liv Tyler. Directed by Robert Altman (PG-13, 118 minutes). What a treat. The sweet assurance and guerrilla wit of Mr. Altman's vintage ensemble films make a copacetic return with a Southern small-town black comedy. Seamlessly made and completely enveloping, it tells of the machinations set off when a wealthy old woman (Ms. Neal) outrages her diabolically genteel niece (Ms. Close) by committing suicide. As the old woman's dearest friend and the niece's unwitting nemesis, Mr. Dutton is rock solid and appealing. The entire cast works on a single wavelength as Mr. Altman makes the most of a well-woven screenplay by Anne Rapp (Maslin).
 
* "THE DREAMLIFE OF ANGELS," starring Elodie Bouchez and Natacha Regnier. Directed by Erick Zonca (R, 113 minutes; in French with English subtitles). In this very special French film about two freewheeling young women, their turbulent friendship is frayed by sexual passion and economic realities. The weaker and more head-turning of the women (Ms. Regnier) falls for the advances of a rich nightclub owner, while her fiery friend, played with unforgettable immediacy by Ms. Bouchez, rages against what she views as imminent disaster. In the process, Mr. Zonca shows astonishing acuity in observing how the women's diverging values affect every aspect of their lives. A rare and wrenching drama (Maslin).
 
* "ELECTION," starring Matthew Broderick and Reese Witherspoon. Directed by Alexander Payne (R, 105 minutes). From the acerbically funny director of "Citizen Ruth" comes this caustic satire of the American electoral process in a high school setting. Its leading candidate, Tracy Flick, played tartly by Ms. Witherspoon, has a mother who sought tactical advice for Tracy from Connie Chung and Elizabeth Dole. Mr. Broderick plays the hapless good-guy teacher who thinks this wicked little front-runner needs to be stopped. And the hunky newcomer Chris Klein plays Tracy's reluctant opponent in a style best described as early Keanu. With a lovely ear for hypocritical conversation, the screenplay specializes in keeping all the characters a few beats off of what they actually mean (Maslin).
 
"ENTRAPMENT," starring Sean Connery and Catherine Zeta-Jones. Directed by Jon Amiel (PG-13, 105 minutes). This glossy caper film summons the days when being a thief was the profession of choice among debonair movie heroes. And heroines: as the great-looking insurance investigator who is supposedly investigating Mr. Connery's glamorous super-burglar, Ms. Zeta-Jones makes a smashing gymnast and heist expert in her own right. No need to believe the outlandish details of the story; there's enough verve and charisma to the stars to make the escapade easy on the eyes. The action sequence, in which the stars hang off the side of the world's largest skyscraper, is a vertiginous show stopper. And here's a nice bonus: nobody gets killed (Maslin).
 
"EXISTENZ," starring Jennifer Jason Leigh and Jude Law. Directed by David Cronenberg (R, 90 minutes). Not for Mr. Cronenberg the sleek futuristic look of other films that play virtual reality games. This one has the insinuatingly ghoulish hallmarks of other Cronenberg fever dreams (like "The Fly," "Crash" and "Naked Lunch"). And it uses them to weirdly enveloping effect as a renowned game designer (Ms. Leigh) and her wary companion (Mr. Law) try to play the most dangerous game she has yet created. This sci-fi scheme is disturbingly effective as it plays its own mind games with the viewer, complete with a sharp final twist. The title is pronounced "eggs-is-tense" (Maslin).
 
"GO," starring Sarah Polley, Katie Holmes, Timothy Olyphant, Taye Diggs, William Fichtner, Scott Wolf and Jay Mohr. Directed by Doug Liman (R, 100 minutes). This three-episode demimondaine comedy borrows truckloads of inspiration from "Pulp Fiction" but still has some flash and personality of its own. Mr. Liman, who shot the film as well as directed it, uses a supermarket as ground zero and sends a sullen cashier (Ms. Polley) out to make a drug deal. He embellishes this situation fully enough to send his film down the rabbit hole into neo-Tarantino adventures, some of which (guys go to Las Vegas, then get into trouble with strippers, gunplay, car theft and a brake-screeching chase) are a lot more tired than others. The ensemble cast shows cool comic flair (Maslin).
 
* "HIDEOUS KINKY," starring Kate Winslet. Directed by Gillies MacKinnon (R, 99 minutes). Ms. Winslet knew best when she took on this offbeat, richly atmospheric adventure in the wake of "Titanic." The leading role in Mr. MacKinnon's vividly colorful film offers her a field day. She plays a young hippie mother who brings her reluctant British daughters to Marrakesh, circa 1972. The film, about the mother's willfulness, the girls' reaction and the sheer headiness of their surroundings, belongs to the striking subgenre in which it is baby-boom adults, not their children, who most need to come of age (Maslin).
 
"THE MATRIX," starring Keanu Reeves, Laurence Fishburne and Carrie-Anne Moss. Directed by Andy and Larry Wachowski (R, 120 minutes). The time-traveling story steeped in virtual reality will be all but incomprehensible to nontechnofreaks. And the film borrows unapologetically from other sci-fi extravaganzas, with a big debt to "The X-Files" in the paranoia department. But the storytelling is intricately bizarre and the special effects are indeed special, notably when it comes to midair martial arts with a gravity-defying gusto. And Mr. Reeves shows that you can look like a Prada model while behaving like an action hero. One of the main stars here is Bill Pope, an inventive cinematographer. He and the Wachowskis provide a couch-potato epiphany: while the characters seem to be performing marvelous feats, they're often lying stock-still in the grip of virtual reality (Maslin).
 
"THE MUMMY," starring Brendan Fraser Rachel Weisz, Arnold Vosloo and John Hannah. Directed by Stephen Sommers (PG-13, 134 minutes). More like a video game than a movie, this incoherent spoof (very loosely based on the 1932 Boris Karloff horror classic), overloaded with cheesy special effects, suggests an unwieldy hybrid of "Raiders of the Lost Ark" and "Abbott and Costello Meet the Mummy" via "Night of the Living Dead." The intrepid adventurers who disturb an ancient Egyptian crypt that carries a fearful curse are Mr. Fraser (playing a swashbuckling American in the Foreign Legion), Ms. Weisz (as a plucky wide-eyed English librarian) and John Hannah (as her twitty older brother). It's all played for laughs. The only scary moments involve swarming scarabs who burrow under the skin and do awful "Alien"-like things (Holden).
 
* "SHAKESPEARE IN LOVE" (the Oscar winner for best film, best original screenplay, best art direction, best costumes and best comedy score). Starring Joseph Fiennes, Gwyneth Paltrow (the best-actress winner), Geoffrey Rush, Ben Affleck and Judi Dench (best supporting actress). Directed by John Madden (R, 113 minutes). A witty, sexy and merrily literate delight, with an exhilaratingly clever premise that only gets better as the film unfolds. The screenplay, originating as Marc Norman's brainstorm and turned by Tom Stoppard into razor-sharp dialogue reminiscent of his "Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," dares to imagine whatever it likes about the link between Shakespeare's artistic passions and his mad yearning for a certain aristocratic beauty. Meanwhile, this tirelessly inventive comedy envisions an Elizabethan theater fraught with the same backbiting and conniving we enjoy today and has great fun presenting the creation of "Romeo and Juliet," glitches and all. Mr. Fiennes and Ms. Paltrow make a fine, tempestuous duo, and she gives the first great, fully realized starring performance of her career (Maslin).
 
"THIS IS MY FATHER," starring Aidan Quinn, Moya Farrelly and James Caan. Directed by Paul Quinn (R, 120 minutes). Made with obvious sincerity, this story of a glum Chicago schoolteacher (Mr. Caan) in search of his more interesting Irish forebears (Mr. Quinn) involves a third Quinn brother as well. And Declan Quinn's cinematography adds warmth to an atmospheric, sentimental tale featuring stellar Irish actors (Stephen Rea, Brendan Gleeson, Colm Meaney) in cameo roles. Aidan Quinn's sturdy performance, as a lonely farmer in love with a fiery young lass from a prosperous family, does a lot to help the film override its hackneyed elements and keep it moving (Maslin).
 
* "A WALK ON THE MOON," starring Diane Lane, Viggo Mortensen, Liev Schreiber, Tovah Feldshuh and Anna Paquin. Directed by Tony Goldwyn (R, 107 minutes). This evocative 1969 period piece, set on the brink of Woodstock in a Catskills holiday camp, is as seductive as the handsome, itinerant hippie who turns its heroine's life upside down. Thoughtfully conceived and movingly acted, it sweeps a housewife and mother named Pearl Kantrowitz (Ms. Lane) into a torrid extramarital romance and then weighs the consequences. With a tenderness that is unusual for a contemporary American film, it tells an enveloping tale enhanced by artfully selected Woodstock-era music. Mr. Mortensen may strain credulity as the foxiest blouse salesman in the Catskills, but he certainly does wonders for the movie (Maslin).
 
* "THE WINSLOW BOY," starring Nigel Hawthorne, Rebecca Pidgeon and Jeremy Northam. Written and directed by David Mamet (G, 110 minutes). Terence Rattigan's play, about the 1910 schoolboy's trial that created a furor in England, has been artfully pared down to its essentials in this stately and deliberate adaptation. Played with unusually effective restraint by a fine, meticulous cast, it works as a precisely calibrated war of nerves in which the family of a cadet accused of theft is quietly staggered by the consequences of that accusation. Benoit Delhomme's cinematography is beautifully lucid and painterly. Ms. Pidgeon's defiantly arch acting style sets the film's tone and gives her suffragist character a sharp edge (Maslin).
 
Film Series
 
"THE SHARPEST GIRL IN TOWN: ANN SOTHERN." Long before "Working Girl," Ann Sothern was a feminist icon in the 10 MGM Maisie films in which she portrayed a working woman getting ahead in the years of the Depression and World War II. The versatile actress won wide popularity playing street-smart, wisecracking characters in musicals, comedies and melodramas. And now she is being celebrated in a retrospective at the Museum of Modern Art. At 6 P.M. today, she will be seen in one of her most brilliant dramatic roles, as a career woman, wife and wise friend in "A Letter to Three Wives," directed by Joseph L. Mankiewicz, who won an Oscar for his screenplay about three women who receive a letter from a friend saying she has run off with one of their husbands. Jeanne Crain, Linda Darnell, Kirk Douglas and Thelma Ritter play leading roles. Continuing through Sunday at the Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, Manhattan, the series is free with museum admission: $9.50 for adults; $6.50 for students and people 65 or older; free for visitors under 16 accompanied by an adult. Pay what you wish on Fridays from 4:30 to 8:30 P.M. Information and screening times: (212) 708-9400 (Lawrence Van Gelder).

SECTION: Section A; Page 26; Column 4; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 141 words

HEADLINE: Wealth and Taxes

 BODY:

To the Editor:
John Shaw (letter, May 8) argues that the national income accounts should classify workers' Social Security tax payments as a form of saving, because workers view them as such. However, this treatment would be incorrect, because the taxes are not invested in capital that increases the country's wealth. Instead, the taxes are transferred to current retirees as benefit payments. 
The only wealth that current workers acquire from the Social Security system is the expectation that when they retire, part of future workers' incomes will be transferred to them. From a national standpoint, this increase in current workers' wealth is offset by a reduction in future workers' wealth. Since national wealth is unchanged, no saving has occurred.
 
ALAN D. VIARD
Dallas, May 10, 1999
 
The writer is an economist.

SECTION: Section C; Page 2; Column 5; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 493 words

HEADLINE: Latest Economic Report Card Shows a WholeLot of B+'s

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
The economy continues to grow with few signs of accelerating inflation, Government reports showed today.
Retail sales rose one-tenth of a percent in April, matching March's increase, the Commerce Department said. That was a welcome slowdown from the average 1.4 percent rise for the previous three months that suggested the economy was in danger of overheating, analysts said. 
 A separate Labor Department report dispelled fears of higher prices by showing that producer prices rose only one-tenth of a percent last month when the largest increase in oil prices since the 1990 Persian Gulf crisis was excluded.
Retail sales last month were restrained by a drop in auto and department store business and would have actually fallen one-tenth of a percent if it were not for a 2.4 percent rise in gasoline sales.
The overall Producer Price Index rose five-tenths of a percent in April, more than double March's two-tenths of a percent increase, as energy prices surged 5.1 percent. The rise was limited by a 3.9 percent drop in computer costs and the second decline in food prices in three months.
For the first four months of the year, the core rate of the index, which excludes often-volatile food and energy costs, has fallen at a two-tenths of a percent annual rate, compared with an increase at a 2.1 percent pace through last April.
The economy's prospects are for "solid growth and low inflation," Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin said today.
It is also a combination that will probably keep Federal Reserve policy makers from raising the overnight bank loan rate at their next meeting on Tuesday -- or for months to come. "These reports are a clarion call for monetary policy stability," said William Sullivan, a senior economist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter in New York.
Also today, the Labor Department said first-time claims for state unemployment benefits were unchanged last week at a seasonally adjusted 303,000. The less volatile four-week average declined to 304,250 from 308,250.
The news in the producer price report was almost all related to oil. Crude oil prices rose 27.3 percent in April, the biggest jump since October 1990. That pushed gasoline prices up 29 percent, a record increase, the Labor Department said.
In New York, prices for June crude futures ranged in April from a low of $15.88 a barrel on April 8 to a high of $18.66 the last day of the month.
Even so, few economists are worried that higher oil prices will bring about a huge acceleration in inflation.
In high technology, competition and the quest for faster computers are keeping prices low. Producer prices for computers fell 3.9 percent in April.
Analysts expect the Consumer Price Index, scheduled for release on Friday, to show prices Americans pay for goods and services increased four-tenths of a percent in April. Excluding oil and food, the index's core rate probably climbed two-tenths of a percent last month, the analysts said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Brazilian Economy Expanded in First Quarter

BYLINE: By SIMON ROMERO 

DATELINE: SAO PAULO, Brazil, May 13

 BODY:
The Brazilian economy defied pessimistic forecasts of stagnation in the first quarter and actually registered some growth, the Government said today in a report that showed Brazil's surprising resilience to the effects of the currency crisis that erupted in January.
The gross domestic product, the broadest measure of economic performance, grew by 1 percent in the first three months of the year compared with the last quarter of 1998. Agricultural production rose 18 percent, leading the expansion. 
 Brazil is the world's largest coffee producer, and the second-largest producer of soybeans after the United States. The weaker currency may have even contributed to the economy's growth by encouraging farmers to increase output of these and other products since their prices became more competitive abroad.
"There was an immediate reaction throughout the entire chain of our production following the devaluation," said Nathan Herszkowicz, president of Brazil's coffee industry union. According to the organization, coffee exports more than doubled in the first quarter of 1999 compared with the period a year earlier.
Although higher agricultural output contrasted with weak industrial production, the Government figures released today suggest that Brazil's economy is recovering more quickly than thought.
While some analysts earlier this year forecast the economy to shrink as much as 6 percent, most economists are now predicting a contraction of only 1 percent to 2 percent. Optimism has been stoked by six interest-rate cuts over the last seven weeks. On Wednesday, the central bank reduced its main lending rate to 27 percent from 29.5 percent, the lowest level in nine months.
"Interest rates coming down, coupled with controlled inflation, have had a tremendous impact," said Winston Fritsch, president of the Brazilian unit of the investment bank Dresdner Kleinwort Benson. Progress made by the Government in reducing the budget deficit is likely to allow the central bank to continue lowering rates below 20 percent by the end of this year, Mr. Fritsch added.
Brazilian stocks rallied on the growth figures, with the benchmark Bovespa index here rising 2.56 percent. Increasing foreign investment in Brazilian equities together with greater optimism among domestic investors have pushed the index up 83 percent in local-currency terms and 34 percent in dollar terms so far this year.
The better-than-expected growth figures and buoyant stock market contrast sharply with other indicators that show an economy struggling with its worst crisis since a stabilization program was carried out in 1994. The plunge in January in the value of the currency deeply hurt Brazil's financial credibility and borrowing power abroad, which reverberated through the economy with slumping sales, bankruptcies and layoffs. Manufacturers and construction companies were the hardest hit.
An example of the economy's strains was seen this week when 50,000 unemployed workers lined up outside municipal buildings to compete for 10,000 openings for street-cleaning jobs in the city of Sao Paulo. The salary for the temporary, six-month work is 136 reais a month, or $82, Brazil's official minimum wage. Unemployment here in Sao Paulo, the country's wealthiest city, is at a record level of nearly 20 percent.
Brazilian companies have started to shift toward increasing their exports, partly because domestic demand has remained stagnant. A large food processor, Perdigao S.A., exported 18 percent more in the first quarter after the devaluation in January. "In dollar terms, we have the cheapest chickens in the world right now," said Wang Wei Chang, chief financial officer of Perdigao.
Still, the opportunities for companies such as Perdigao to fuel a stronger recovery are limited since domestic borrowing rates remain punitively high and foreign credit markets are still largely shunning Brazilian borrowers. With deeper cuts in interest rates largely dependent on the Government's success in narrowing the budget deficit, companies are anxiously awaiting fresh evidence of spending cuts from the capital, Brasilia. "Now is not the time to relax, not even a little," Mr. Wang of Perdigao said. "We need to see the Government deliver."

HEADLINE: Easy Approval Is Predicted For Summers

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
President Clinton's nominee for Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers, appears to be facing relatively little opposition in the Senate, even from Republican critics of the Administration's economic policy.
Mr. Summers and Robert E. Rubin, who announced on Wednesday his intention to resign, spent part of the day on Capitol Hill, dropping in on key members of the Senate. Mr. Summers left this evening for Malaysia, for a long-scheduled meeting of Asian finance ministers. But he is to return by Monday and is expected to say little in public while preparing for his confirmation hearings. 
 Hearings for any appointee toward the end of an administration are always a bit unpredictable, and it is always possible that Mr. Summers's nomination could become a political football. White House aides said that they suspected Mr. Rubin tried to time his departure to maximize Mr. Summers's chances of confirmation. "The closer you get to the Presidential election," one White House official said, "the more risks you run."
Nonetheless, the Senate majority leader, Trent Lott, who in recent weeks has cast himself in opposition to several Clinton Administration economic initiatives, said this morning that he saw no problems with Mr. Summers's nomination. Later in the day, he met with Mr. Summers, as did Senator William Roth, the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, which will consider the nomination.
Mr. Roth said today that his committee had "a good working relationship" with Mr. Summers, suggesting that he saw no large hurdles to confirmation. His committee might have felt differently a few years ago, when Mr. Summers clashed with the panel over the $12 billion bailout of Mexico. To raise the money, the Administration circumvented Congress and drew on the Exchange Stabilization Fund, which is under the Treasury's control.
Mr. Summers himself was uncharacteristically quiet today, and aides said he would keep public comments to a minimum while his nomination was under consideration. That is hardly unusual for any nominee. But it is considered a particularly important strategy for the sometimes blunt-speaking Mr. Summers, who went out of his way at the White House yesterday to repeatedly use the phrase "subject to the will of the Senate" when referring to his new appointment.
This morning, Mr. Rubin devoted the entirety of a short commencement speech at New York University to talk about decision-making -- detailing how he approached problems on Wall Street and the Treasury by weighing probabilities and focusing more on how a decision was reached than whether its outcome was successful.
It was a subject he often discussed during the Asian financial crisis, when he was often faced with the question of whether propping up a country -- or its currency -- would help promote reform or, in the alternative, take the pressure off politicians to change the country's economic fundamentals.
Several of those bets went bad. More than $4 billion committed to Russia was essentially lost, with no reforms. But the bailouts of Thailand and South Korea went hand in hand with at least some modest changes in banking systems and regulation.
Mr. Rubin recalled facing the decision in June 1998 about whether to prop up the Japanese yen, whose value had been falling sharply -- threatening to touch off devaluations elsewhere in Asia.
"It was, to say the least, a very complicated situation," Mr. Rubin said. The discussion could have gone on indefinitely, he said, not adding that in the Clinton White House, discussions usually do go on at great length. "but we didn't have that luxury: markets wait for no one."
That bet worked out, and the yen's decline was halted. But Mr. Rubin argued, as he did last year during several failed attempts to prop up Russia and Indonesia, that "judging solely on results is a serious deterrent to taking the risk that may be necessary to making the right decision."
"Simply put, the way decisions are evaluated affects the way decisions are made," Mr. Rubin said. "I believe the public would be better served, and their elected officials and others in Washington would do a more effective job, if judgments were based on the quality of decision- making instead of focusing solely on outcomes."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: BEIJING;
China Honors 3 Killed in Belgrade, but the Street Protests End

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON 

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 13

 BODY:
In an elaborate ceremony at the Great Hall of the People, China's leaders bestowed the title of "revolutionary martyr" today on the three Chinese journalists killed by NATO's bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade last week.
The title is one of the Communist Party's highest honors to the dead and the ceremony appeared intended to bring an emotional close to the anti-American activity that took over Beijing in recent days, a rare dovetailing of public sentiment and official purpose. 
 The bombing is widely seen here as a deliberate attack and not the mistake that NATO maintains.
Student-led demonstrations cordinated by the Government have now stopped, and street traffic returned to normal today in the diplomatic quarter, which was besieged by raucous and rock-throwing demonstrators after the bombing.
Yet even if China's leaders want to cool mass displays of emotion, President Jiang Zemin warned at today's ceremony that China would not consider the matter closed until the United States and NATO make a full accounting of the bombing.
"Otherwise the Chinese people will never let the matter go," Mr. Jiang said in a speech.
On state television's evening news, Mr. Jiang and five of China's most senior leaders were shown trooping from one hospital room to another to visit some of the Chinese citizens who were hurt in the bombing and returned to Beijing on Wednesday.
"You are all heroes," Mr. Jiang said to one of the wounded.
In the first of what is likely to be many state-sponsored commemorations of the journalists, The Guangming Daily Press said it would publish a book next week honoring Xu Xinghu and his wife, Zhu Ying, both of whom worked for the newspaper.
The swell of anti-American and nationalist sentiment is likely to have far-reaching if not entirely predictable consequences on China's political, economic and social climate. For instance, Zhu Bangzao, a spokesman for the Foreign Ministry, said today that the atmosphere of negotiations over China's entry into the World Trade Organization would inevitably be affected.
Although Mr. Zhu reiterated Beijing's wish to seek entry to the trade group by the end of the year, his remarks reflect a consensus here that the intensely strained political mood will further stiffen the negotiating position of Chinese officials.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- The Hype Is With Us;
The Lucas Empire Is Invading; Resistance Is Futile

BYLINE: By STUART ELLIOTT 

 BODY:
Coming soon, a film with marketing more choreographed than a Fred Astaire version of "Saturday Night Fever"! More skillfully planned than the mission to save Matt Damon! A campaign more orchestrated than all of Bernard Herrmann's scores for Alfred Hitchcock! Yes, a movie even more unsinkable than Titanic!
It's no surprise what we're talking about. Only those overheated trailers at the Bijous and Orpheums of the 1940's and 1950's can approximate the frenzied peddling of "Star Wars: Episode I -- The Phantom Menace." Though the movie does not open until Wednesday, merchandise is already flooding toy stores, Web sites, fast-food restaurants, computer stores, music stores, supermarkets, bookstores and newsstands. 
 Fed by legions of enthusiasts who have waited years for this moment -- at some theaters, they camped out for weeks to get advance tickets that went on sale this Wednesday afternoon -- the fourth "Star Wars" film has taken on a life of its own.
"There's genuine passion here; no one is telling those people to line up," said Dawn Hudson, senior vice president for strategy and marketing at the Pepsi-Cola Company unit of Pepsico Inc. in Purchase, N.Y., which is spending $2 billion to sponsor "The Phantom Menace" and sequels to be released in 2002 and 2005.
The new installment, the first "prequel" to the original trinity, is largely selling itself -- thanks in no small part to the eager involvement of licensees, merchandisers, retailers and, of course, the news media, churning out programs and articles like this one.
Behind the groundswell of excitement, though, is a well-tended machine, cranking out the biggest marketing blitz ever for a mere movie. And that effort is being supervised down to the teensiest detail by George Lucas, the zillionaire writer-producer-director who created the "Star Wars" juggernaut and whose Lucasfilm Ltd. has been assiduously working on the next chapter since the last film was released in 1983.
Indeed, "the marketing of an entertainment property is becoming the story instead of the property itself," said Michael Schau, executive editor of the Entertainment Marketing Letter newsletter.
"When we went to college," he said, "we didn't ask each other, 'What do you suppose the top-grossing movie was this weekend?' Now we do."
Not since "Gone With the Wind" has there been so much spontaneous anticipation so far in advance.
"There's something there that touches their hearts," said Howard Roffman, vice president for licensing at Lucasfilm in San Rafael, Calif.
"If there's any hype at all, it comes from the media," he added. "They see this as an important story that will get viewers and sell newspapers and magazines. It has resulted in a level of attention we frankly are not seeking ourselves."
At least two major newspapers are printing daily "countdown" features. Magazines with cover articles include Entertainment Weekly, GQ, Newsweek, Premiere, Time, Vanity Fair, Wired -- even Popular Mechanics ("The Machines of 'Star Wars' "), Vogue (" 'Star Wars' Couture") and TV Guide.
"You can't plan on becoming a cultural phenomenon," said Mr. Roffman, who joined Lucasfilm in 1980, or as he dates it, "a couple weeks before 'The Empire Strikes Back' was released."
"It's not like people sat down in 1975 and said, 'Let's create a space mythology that'll last for generations,' " he added. "It all stems from demand from the fans."
That was underscored in November, when thousands of "Star Wars" fans bought tickets for clunky films like "Meet Joe Black" just to catch the 130-second trailer for "The Phantom Menace." And it was further verified this week by the telephone and Internet traffic jams that occured on buying sites around the country after tickets went on sale.
Indeed, "Star Wars" has become a consumer brand, promising quality and performance the way brand-name cars, candy and clothing do.
"Great brands create a relationship between a company and a consumer that secures future earnings," said John Grace, an executive director at Interbrand, a consulting company in New York owned by Omnicom Group. " 'Star Wars' has all the characteristics of a great brand of our time."
Just look at Hasbro Inc., the toy company whose licensing deal with Lucasfilm dates to the first film in 1977. One Hasbro executive, Tim Hall, has a title that says it all: vice president for "Star Wars."
To renew its agreement with Mr. Lucas, Hasbro is guaranteeing an estimated $500 million in royalties from "Phantom Menace" products that range from Darth Maul With Lightsaber to the Anakin Skywalker Podracer to the Hidden Majesty Queen Amidala.
Behind it all stands Mr. Lucas. "I've got to hand it to George," said Jack Trout, president at Trout & Partners, marketing consultants in Greenwich, Conn. "He's turning an 800-pound gorilla into King Kong."
"It's brilliant the way he has carefully nurtured this property over many years," Mr. Trout said. "Eat your heart out, Walt Disney."
The usually reclusive Mr. Lucas, who oversees Lucasfilm and other companies like Lucasarts Entertainment, has granted a score of interviews to help stoke the bonfires.
"You have to admire Lucas for his long-term approach," said Peter Waller, president and chief concept officer at Taco Bell in Irvine, Calif., one of three chains owned by Tricon Global Restaurants that are the fast-food marketing partners for the film.
"It's not just about a great summer movie," Mr. Waller asserted. "It's about building 'Star Wars' in a real brand sense as an experience people want to keep re-entering."
Thus the goal of the promotional blitz for "The Phantom Menace" is to make millions of moviegoers chant once more "May the force be with you" without perceiving they are being force-fed.
There are predictions that "The Phantom Menace," which will be distributed by the 20th Century Fox unit of the News Corporation, could set records by taking in as much as $100 million in its first five days. Topping "Titanic," which garnered worldwide grosses of more than $1.8 billion, would be "a tall order," said Paul Dergarabedian, president at the Exhibitor Relations Company in Los Angeles, which tracks box-office performance. Even so, he added, "if any film has the chance to do it, it would be this one."
Still, "any high-profile film that gets lots of interest and attention can fall victim to the double-edged sword," Mr. Dergarabedian warned, adding that it is particularly true for a film that "has had such a high profile for so long."
Indeed, there are already signs of trouble. Both Time and Newsweek dubbed the new film "The Phantom Movie," and there have been harshly negative advance reviews as well as derogatory columns by critics like Jack Mathews of The Daily News in New York; he mocked the selling of the film with such lines as "May the Sales Force be with you" and "We'll always have 'The Phantom Menace' -- up to here."
And remember "Godzilla" last summer? That brand fell far short of the promises it made in a lavish pre-release marketing assault.
To help cool the overheated expectations, the advertising budget for "The Phantom Menace" is less than $20 million, not much for a film with a budget of $115 million competing in the blockbuster sweepstakes.
"You don't want to overdo it," said Mr. Roffman at Lucasfilm. "The worst thing you can do is to create a plan based on your needs instead of the consumers'."
Mr. Lucas recognizes the potential pitfalls, said Jill Wilfert, senior brand manager at Lego Systems, a unit of Lego Group, who met with him as part of planning for her company's "Phantom Menace" line -- its first licensed merchandise ever.
"He wants people to have a good experience with the movie and not see it as being overly commercialized," Ms. Wilfert said, "because he doesn't want them to be sick of it after a few months."
Of course, the movie will benefit from the spillover of its partners' own marketing campaigns, which will include glitzy commercials by the BBDO New York and TBWA/ Chiat/Day units of Omnicom for Pepsico and Tricon.
"We expect this to be one of our most successful promotions" across "our entire peak summer selling season," said Ms. Hudson at Pepsi-Cola, which hopes to sell millions of cans of five soft-drink brands that feature "Phantom Menace" characters. Consumers who find cans bearing the venerable visage of Yoda can redeem them for " 'Star Wars' checks" worth $20.
At Tricon, which owns Pizza Hut and KFC in addition to Taco Bell, the campaign marks the first time the three brands have united under a single promotional theme. "It's all in the never-been-done-before league," Mr. Waller said.
Each chain will align with one of three planets in the film, Coruscant, Naboo and Tatooine, selling toys and drink-cup lids with names like Opee Sea Creature Chaser, Jar Jar Binks Squishy and Hovering Watto.
For true believers, though, even too much commercialization may not be enough.
"Fans are so into 'Star Wars' that the advertising is almost entertainment to them, part of the cultural impact the film is making," said Tim Doyle, a copywriter at Leo Burnett Interactive in Toronto, part of the Leo Burnett Company. Mr. Doyle and two fellow fans in Australia and Los Angeles have on their own put up a "Phantom Menace" site (www.starwars.countingdown.com).
So how will "The Phantom Menace" do? Beyond the box office, total merchandise sales may reach $2 billion this year -- almost half what the entire "Star Wars" franchise has sold since 1977.
And in theaters, "America is ready to climb back into fantasy land and see the good guys beat the bad guys," Mr. Trout predicted. "Wait till it opens and the lines are wrapped around the block. Wait till you see the press for that."
The final word goes to Mr. Dergarabedian at Exhibitor Relations.
"It will make money whether there is good word of mouth or bad word of mouth," he said, "but what will keep it playing is terrific word of mouth. There's no better marketing than that."

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: WASHINGTON;
Clinton Blames Milosevic, Not Fate, for Bloodshed

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
President Clinton said today that he had misread Balkan history and he apologized for any past suggestions that there is "some Balkan disease" that condemns all sides in Yugoslavia to an endless cycle of ethnic blood feuds.
"The truth is that for centuries these people have lived together in the Balkans and southeastern Europe with greater or lesser degrees of tension, but often without anything approaching the intolerable conditions and conflicts that exist today," he said in a speech here to combat veterans of World War II. 
 Of the notion that the Yugoslavs are locked in implacable hatreds, he said: "I, myself, have been guilty of saying that on an occasion or two, and I regret it now more than I can say."
The President's 35-minute rumination on Kosovo came as the fighting grinds into its eighth week, persisting longer than the war in the Persian Gulf. The President acknowledged that Americans are impatient with the pace of NATO's air campaign.
Taking a cue from Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain, Mr. Clinton warned against "refugee fatigue" and forcefully retold the stories of Albanians who have been executed, raped and routed from their homes.
"I know we see these pictures of the refugees on television every night, and most people would like another story," Mr. Clinton said. "But we must not get refugee fatigue. We must not forget the real victims of this tragedy."
He was voicing a concern that Mr. Blair raised on Wednesday: that without the ability to show pictures of the atrocities being committed inside Kosovo, the news media would tire of repetitious footage of fleeing refugees, and that reduced exposure to such scenes could then weaken public support for the war effort.
Mr. Blair said the Serbs benefited by barring reporters from Kosovo, because that factor, along with editorial boredom with the refugees, was leading the media to highlight NATO mistakes like last week's bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, coverage that cost NATO an edge in the propaganda war.
Taking that argument to heart, Mr. Clinton tried to paint a compelling portrait of the atrocities inside Kosovo, evoking images of Hitler's slaughter of the Jews and detailing eyewitness accounts of mass executions, rapes and people being set on fire.
"Though his ethnic cleansing is not the same as the ethnic extermination of the Holocaust," Mr. Clinton said, "the two are related -- both vicious, premeditated, systematic oppression fueled by religious and ethnic hatred."
He added: "Nine of every 10 Kosovar Albanians now has been driven from their homes, thousands murdered, at least 100,000 missing, many young men led away in front of their families, over 500 cities, towns and villages burned."
The President uttered no new policy in his speech, but seemed determined to clarify, again, the moral imperative for American participation in a war in Europe that began March 24 and shows little sign of ending.
He called the campaign of "ethnic cleansing" being carried out in Kosovo by the forces of the Yugoslav President, Slobodan Milosevic, "an affront to humanity and an attack not only on a people but on the dignity of all people."
In saying he was mistaken to portray Balkan infighting as inevitable, he said Mr. Milosevic, like Hitler in Germany, had been the catalyst.
"You think the Germans would have perpetrated the Holocaust on their own without Hitler?" Mr. Clinton asked. "Was there something in the history of the German race that made them do this? No."
Brushing aside any half-measures -- like the partial withdrawal of Mr. Milosevic's troops from Kosovo that was staged today for cameras that his forces controlled -- Mr. Clinton said that NATO would continue its bombing campaign until Mr. Milosevic met the allies' demands in full.
"The central imperative is this," Mr. Clinton said in his speech, delivered at Fort McNair. "The Kosovars must be able to return home and live in safety. For this to happen, the Serb forces must leave; partial withdrawals can only mean continued civil wars with the Kosovar insurgence."
At the same time, the Administration played down any effect that the internal political turmoil in Russia might have on diplomatic efforts to negotiate a settlement.
James P. Rubin, the State Department spokesman, said that Strobe Talbott, the Deputy Secretary of State, was continuing to work "constructively" with the Russians and that he had detected no setbacks despite President Boris N. Yeltsin's firing of Prime Minister Yevgeny M. Primakov.
Mr. Talbott was in Moscow for two days and had been expected to work with the Russians on plans for the composition of an international security force that would be stationed in Kosovo. He was headed to Brussels for meetings at NATO offices and was also expected to meet Kofi Annan, the United Nations Secretary General, officials said.
As he left Moscow, Mr. Talbott offered no new details, but said, "There are many problems here, but there is reason for hope and we must continue our diplomatic efforts."
The harshest words of the day came from China, where fury still raged at the United States for the embassy bombing, which killed three Chinese. President Jiang Zemin said the United States was using its economic and technological superiority to aggressively expand its influence, pursue "power politics and wantonly interfere in the internal affairs of other countries."
Administration officials said that despite Mr. Zemin's fiery public comments, tensions with China appeared to be easing. David Leavy, a spokesman for the National Security Council, said that in a visit today with the Chinese Ambassador, Mr. Clinton said that the United States would carry out a full investigation of the bombing and would inform the Chinese people of its results.
In exchange, the Ambassador told Mr. Clinton that Mr. Jiang was now ready to speak with him by telephone -- an overture that the Chinese had rebuffed since the bombing. Mr. Leavy said that Mr. Jiang was trying to reach Mr. Clinton and that the two leaders might talk as early as tonight.
At the White House, Mr. Clinton signed a book of condolences for the deaths, writing next to his signature: "With profound grief and sincere condolences to the victims, their families and the people of China."

HEADLINE: Cadbury and Coca-Cola Said to Discuss Deal

BYLINE: By CONSTANCE L. HAYS 

 BODY:
A senior Cadbury Schweppes executive said yesterday that the company planned to sell its brands in France to the Coca-Cola Company after Coca-Cola completed its negotiations with the French Government over the purchase of the Orangina soft-drink brand.
Speaking to reporters in New York at a beverage industry conference, John F. Brock, Cadbury's global managing director for beverages, said, "Once Orangina is resolved, we will sit down and negotiate an arrangement with Coke for France." 
 However, a spokesman for Coca-Cola said the company had no plans to buy Cadbury brands in France. "There is nothing on the horizon at all that would have us buying Cadbury brands in France," said the spokesman, Randy Donaldson.
Coca-Cola's efforts to buy Orangina, the second-highest-selling brand in France, from Pernod Ricard S.A. have run into resistance from the French competition authorities, who said Coca-Cola would have too much market share if the $850 million deal went through. Coca-Cola announced the deal in December 1997 and is still trying to work out a plan with the French Government.
Last December, Cadbury agreed to sell its brands outside the United States to Coca-Cola for $1.85 billion, excluding France and South Africa. The deal was hailed at the time as one that provided benefits to both sides. Since then, many objections have been raised by governments from Australia to Belgium, mainly over the market dominance Coca-Cola would have. The European Union has also balked at the plan, although Coca-Cola and Cadbury executives say it is not clear whether it has jurisdiction in this case.
"We and Coke went into this deal having done a lot of homework," Mr. Brock said yesterday, adding that "we were surprised" by the reaction in Belgium, for example.
"It's a political issue as much as a regulatory issue," he said, noting that "the relationship between the U.S. and the E.U. is not at an all-time high right now."
Mr. Brock said he expected the Coca-Cola-Cadbury deal to be completed eventually.

HEADLINE: City Considering a Modern Fulton Fish Market at a New Site

BYLINE: By SELWYN RAAB 

 BODY:
The city is considering a multimillion-dollar plan to modernize and move the Fulton Fish Market from the storied but gritty site it has occupied for 166 years in lower Manhattan, a top Giuliani administration official said yesterday.
Forced to act because of more stringent Federal requirements regarding the refrigeration of fish, the administration plans to decide by this summer whether to renovate the existing market or to build a new center for wholesale fish and shellfish companies elsewhere in the city, Deputy Mayor Rudy Washington said in an interview. Either alternative would cost $30 million to $55 million, Mr. Washington said. 
 He declined to identify what sections of the city were being considered as possible sites for the market, the nation's largest wholesale seafood distribution point, with annual sales of $800 million to $1 billion. But as fishmongers and workers toiled yesterday in the early morning mists, many said they believed that City Hall was reviving previous proposals to transfer them to a spot near the Hunts Point Produce Market in the South Bronx.
Some merchants and employees also said that the administration was bent on razing the two main buildings of the market, a remnant of 19th century New York that has figured in the writings of Joseph Mitchell and others. Moving the market, people who work there say, could clear the way for real estate development of valuable city-owned land near the South Street Seaport and alongside the East River. Mr. Washington acknowledged that the city could profit from the sale of a three-block area for commercial and residential use if the market is moved. Real estate developers and brokers estimated the property could be sold for $40 million to $60 million.
Mr. Washington said the city was being forced to act because of stricter Federal regulations for the handling and refrigeration of perishable seafood. Much of the seafood brought to the market daily by refrigerated trucks is kept for hours in containers packed with ice but not refrigerated before it is sold to retail fish stores and restaurants, Mr. Washington noted.
He emphasized that there were no health dangers or sanitary violations in the current system. But he said that new rules from the Federal Food and Drug Administration would eventually require more refrigeration, especially in the summer, and other food-safety protection programs that cannot be easily accommodated by the market's antiquated electrical system and in its scruffy buildings.
"To come into compliance with the new regulations," Mr. Washington said, "we must come up with the most economical plan for the city: to retrofit the old buildings or relocate and build another structure."
F.D.A. officials want the city to produce a compliance schedule by this summer, he added, and that is the deadline for a decision on the market's future.
Mr. Washington, who is Deputy Mayor for Community Development and Business Services, said that food safety was not the only reason to revamp the market. "The wholesale merchants understand as well as we do that something has to happen," he said. "The market was built with technology from the turn of the century, not the millennium we are about to enter."
The cost of renovating the old market or erecting a new one will be borne by the city, Mr. Washington said. But the expense, he asserted, could be recouped by enlarging the market and making it more efficient. The changes, he said, would generate more business, more taxes and higher rents by providing space for more wholesale companies.
The city collects $3 million a year in rents from 60 wholesale companies licensed to operate at the market, which extends on South Street from Fulton Street to Peck Slip. The overall market consists of two main buildings and a dozen other buildings in which venders have stalls.
Merchants expressed mixed emotions about overhauling or leaving the market, which traces it origins to fishmongers who set up outdoor stalls on Fulton Street at the edge of the East River in 1833. Some would welcome an enclosed, state-of-the-art facility that would no longer require them to work outdoors in frosty winter weather, dodging trucks and handcarts on clogged, narrow cobblestone streets.
"The conditions we work in are primitive," said Robert Smith, an owner of the Arrow Seafood Company and vice president of the New York Wholesale Fish Dealers Association, one of three trade groups at the market.
Saying that the market lacked water and electricity for increasing business, Mr. Smith said, "It's great for writers to be nostalgic about this place, but this is an industry, not a museum."
Michael Driansky, vice president of Caleb Haley, a company that has been at the market since 1859, said a new facility with better refrigeration would increase business. "I'd love it, if the city put us in a high-tech building for the next 50 years," said Mr. Driansky, who is the secretary of the Fulton Market Fish Mongers Association.
Others said that a move could hurt their businesses by disrupting long affiliations with customers. They also said that lower Manhattan was an ideal hub for supplying seafood in New York City, Long Island, New Jersey and Connecticut.
Frank Mineo, the owner of Smitty's Fillet House, and president of the Sidewalk Dealers Association, had reservations about moving and said that many dealers had made expensive renovations in recent years. "The city has only given us vague generalities and we need specifics about what they are planning," Mr. Mineo said.
"We would be crazy to turn down a new facility if it is in the right place and the deal is right for us. But I love this location because of its accessibility to customers from the tristate area."
Eddie Monani, the head of the Joe Monani Fish Company, said the Giuliani administration wanted to close the market mainly to encourage real estate development.
Noting that the administration in 1995 rejected a proposal by some merchants for a new market in Brooklyn, Mr. Monani said that overall working conditions had improved in the last five years and since the city began to closely monitor the market. "We can meet the government's regulations by icing fish properly." he said. "We know how to handle fish, we've been doing it for 100 years."
Dennis Faicco, secretary treasurer of Local 359 of the United Food and Commercial Workers International Union, a unit that represents 400 market employees, said relocating would be burdensome for many workers who live near the site.
In 1995, in a campaign against entrenched Mafia influence and corruption, the Giuliani administration began licensing and requiring integrity checks of all companies and employees at the market. More than a dozen companies were ousted and law enforcement officials say that organized crime rackets appear to have been eliminated.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

American Airlines Accused Of Illegal Pricing in Texas
The Federal Government accused American Airlines of driving smaller competitors out of one of its most important markets by illegally cutting ticket prices below their cost and increasing flights sharply. 
 The Government said American used its dominance of the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport to prevent weaker competitors from gaining a foothold there in the mid-1990's, only to raise prices and reduce service after they departed. Page A1.
 
Unusual Fee in Cendant Case
The collapse of the stock price of Cendant, which fell below $11 a share last year and cost investors an estimated $14 billion, has touched off litigation. A court hearing next week will consider a novel fee proposed by lawyers who have negotiated a settlement with Cendant on behalf of the holders of one of its derivative securities, called Prides. Market Place. C7.
 
Stocks Mixed; Dow Hits a Record
Stock prices mostly advanced, buoyed by economic reports that pushed down long-term interest rates. The Dow Jones industrial average rose 106.82 points, or 1 percent, to 11,107.19, while the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index edged up 3.56 points, or two-tenths of a percent, to 1,367.56, both new highs. But a selloff in Internet and high-technology stocks left the Nasdaq composite index with a loss of 24.54 points, or nine-tenths of a percent, to 2,582.00. C7.
 
Yeltsin Move Could Hurt Economy
President Boris N. Yeltsin's decision to dismiss his Cabinet may deepen Russia's economic troubles by jeopardizing a badly needed loan-refinancing program from the International Monetary Fund and negotiations with other foreign creditors. C4.
 
Boeing to Cut 7,000 St. Louis Jobs
After losing a key order for its F-15 Eagle jet fighter two weeks ago, Boeing said that it planned to cut as many as 7,000 jobs at its manufacturing plant in St. Louis by the middle of 2001. Boeing said that the cuts were part of its previously announced plan to reduce employment by as many as 46,000 jobs over the next two years. C5.
 
Coca-Cola Disputes Cadbury Deal
A senior Cadbury Schweppes executive said that the company planned to sell its brands in France to Coca-Cola after Coca-Cola buys the Orangina soft-drink brand. However, a Coca-Cola spokesman said the company had no plans to buy Cadbury brands in France. C18.
 
Slower Sales Seen for Oracle
Shares of Oracle dropped 9 percent after several analysts suggested that the company might not meet earnings estimates for its fourth quarter, which ends May 31, because of a slowdown in sales of software that manages corporate information systems. Oracle fell $2.3125, to $23 a share. Oracle shares are down 20 percent this year. C6.
 
Video Game Makers on Defensive
The video game industry opened its annual trade show in a mood part defiant and part defensive about accusations that violent video games contributed to the high school shootings last month in Littleton, Colo. A16.
 
Cleveland Indians Put Up for Sale
Tantalized by rising prices, Richard Jacobs put the Cleveland Indians up for sale less than a year after taking the team public. D2.
 
A New Ford Talks to Stockholders
William C. Ford Jr., a great-grandson of Henry Ford and the first Ford family member to lead Ford Motor in 20 years, took the stage to run the company's annual meeting for the first time. Mr. Ford tried to sell shareholders on the business case for social responsibility. C6.

HEADLINE: Back to Battle Lines

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
With a big and boisterous rally on Wednesday that drew tens of thousands of marchers, New York's labor unions signaled that they were on a collision course with Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani and Gov. George E. Pataki -- one that could have major effects on coming contract talks and political campaigns.
As they harangued the Mayor and Governor from a sound stage within earshot of City Hall, labor leaders insisted that the two Republicans had policies that favored the rich and shortchanged working families, and several leaders threatened to make life tough for Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Pataki in any future campaigns. 
 With contract talks approaching, the city's unions have rallied their troops and sought to throw the Mayor on the defensive, but City Hall officials say they will not be intimidated and will not grant labor's demands unless the city receives something in return. Mr. Giuliani asserts that several previous mayors have driven the city to near bankruptcy by being too generous to municipal unions, but he said this week that he would not cave in to them.
These tensions between labor and the two Republicans indicate a sea change in their relationship; a few years ago, the two politicians received many union endorsements when they ran for re-election. In 1997, Mr. Giuliani won over the city teachers' union by increasing spending on education; Mr. Pataki last year pleased health care unions by increasing health care spending.
But in a few short months, these two politicians and New York's unions have changed course, making conflict inevitable.
With an eye to higher office -- and to the Republican Party's conservative base -- Mr. Giuliani and Mr. Pataki have both tacked to the right, in ways that many unions see as a slap at them. Mr. Giuliani's embrace of a plan to issue vouchers to send children to private schools has angered the teachers' union, while Mr. Pataki's plan to cut $2.1 billion in health care spending this year has enraged the city's largest health care workers' union.
"Last year the Governor and Mayor were focusing on being Governor and Mayor," said Norman Adler, a political consultant, "and now they're focusing on being President and Senator. Both of them see themselves in primaries, and they know that people who participate in Republican primaries are to the right."
At the same time, several New York unions have tacked to the left, often because of changes at the top. Lee Saunders, the trustee named to clean up District Council 37, the giant municipal union, advocates a more confrontational approach than did his predecessor, Stanley Hill, a Giuliani ally who agreed to a two-year wage freeze in the current contract that angered many union members.
Brian McLaughlin, president of the New York City Central Labor Council, and Denis M. Hughes, president of the New York State A.F.L.-C.I.O., are taking a more activist approach than their predecessors. And Dennis Rivera, one of the city's most liberal labor leaders, has greatly expanded his clout, heading not just 1199, the 150,000-member National Health and Human Service Employees Union, but also the 350,000-member state division of 1199's parent union, the Service Employees International Union.
Some critics of labor say its new activism could be bad for the city and the state. They contend that greater union gains could produce budget deficits and ultimately higher taxes, which in turn could discourage businesses from expanding or investing in New York.
Many union members say they have not shared in the city's economic boom even though the wage freeze they accepted helped create the city's $2 billion budget surplus.
"Unions feel a sense of betrayal in that the city was quick to come to the unions when it needed them," said Randi Weingarten, president of the United Federation of Teachers. "But after the unions helped the city create a budget surplus, the Mayor is talking antiunion."
And labor's antagonism could complicate Mr. Giuliani's life if he runs for the Senate. This hostility might not hurt Mr. Giuliani much in a Republican primary -- it might actually help him there -- but it could hurt him badly on Election Day, when he would have to woo all voters, not just conservatives.
Politicians who want to succeed Mr. Giuliani will no doubt take note of labor's new militancy. Several mayoral aspirants, including the City Comptroller, Alan G. Hevesi, and the Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, appeared at Wednesday's rally.
"Whoever the next Mayor is has a force that has to be reckoned with," said Fred Siegel, a Cooper Union history professor. "I don't think it means they're going to have to give in big time to labor, but it means they have to engage in a complicated dance."
Mr. Giuliani said he objected to what he saw as the goals behind Wednesday's demonstration: weakening him politically, pressuring the city in future contract talks and helping elect a labor-friendly Democrat as the next Mayor. Mr. Giuliani warned the unions and any politicians sympathetic to labor that New York voters might prefer politicians who stand up to labor and safeguard the city's fiscal health.
A few marchers joked that the demonstration was the first big unofficial rally for a possible Senate candidate, Hillary Rodham Clinton, although some Giuliani supporters, like Edward Malloy, president of the Building and Construction Trades Council of Greater New York, were on hand as well.
But the rally and its implications could complicate the First Lady's political future. "These older institutional interests in the Democratic Party are reasserting themselves," Mr. Siegel said. "It will make it harder for Hillary to position herself as a centrist."

HEADLINE: AIRLINE IS ACCUSED OF ILLEGAL PRICING

BYLINE: By STEPHEN LABATON with LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 13

 BODY:
The Federal Government accused American Airlines today of driving smaller competitors out of one of its most important markets by illegally slashing ticket prices below cost and increasing flights sharply.
The Government said American used its dominance of the Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport to prevent weaker competitors from gaining a foothold there in the mid-1990's, only to raise prices and reduce service after they departed. 
 The antitrust case is the first predatory pricing action brought by the Government against an airline since the industry was deregulated 21 years ago. It is part of a broader 18-month examination by the Justice Department's antitrust division of the steps that may have been taken by major airlines, including Delta Air Lines, Northwest Airlines and United, a unit of UAL, to discourage lower-priced competition in cities they dominate.
Following deregulation in 1978, the largest airlines have moved to strengthen their control of major metropolitan airports. While airlines have on occasion sued each other on antitrust grounds, the Government has rarely intervened beyond threats of fines from the Department of Transportation.
But a growing chorus of consumer complaints about rising fares and declining service has led to a strong backlash against the industry in Congress, where lawmakers have introduced measures to force the airlines to disclose more about fares and delays, and offer compensation for inconveniences. In addition, the Transportation Department last year proposed punishing airlines that tried to stifle competition.
Senior officials at the Justice Department said the American case was particularly compelling because company documents showed that American, the nation's second-largest airline, had deliberately embarked on a strategy of selling tickets below cost and incurring significant short-term financial losses in recent years to drive out three low-cost competitors -- Vanguard Airlines, Sun Jet International and Western Pacific -- from Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport.
Executives and lawyers at American said the airline had not violated any antitrust laws but simply matched the fares of its competitors.
In 1998, American flew 70 percent of the scheduled seats out of Dallas-Fort Worth, up from 60 percent in 1991. The Government presented evidence showing that after Vanguard announced in September 1996 that it was adding service to Dallas-Fort Worth from three cities in addition to Wichita, Kan., American responded by cutting prices and adding flights on nearly all of Vanguard's Dallas routes. Two months later, Vanguard abandoned its expansion plans. By June 1997, American had reduced capacity between Wichita and Dallas by 30 percent and raised the average one-way fare by more than 50 percent to more than $90 from about $60.
"American quickly realized that these new carriers could be a significant competitive threat, estimating that as much as a billion and a half dollars of its annual revenues were at risk if they were to succeed," said Joel I. Klein, the Assistant Attorney General in charge of the antitrust division. "To make sure that this didn't happen, American adopted a predatory responsive strategy, saturating the market in which the start-up carriers had begun service with as much new, low-fare service of its own as was necessary to drive out the start-ups."
Attorney General Janet Reno said American "invested in short-term capacity increases and fare reductions to maintain its monopoly -- an investment it was able to recover many times over once its smaller rivals had been driven away."
American Airlines disputed the accusations by the Justice Department that it had priced its fares below cost or flooded the market with flights, and said the lawsuit was little more than sour grapes by smaller airlines, which, unable to compete, had persuaded regulators to bring the case.
"Contrary to the Justice Department's lawsuit, this action today is very potentially anti-consumer," said Chris Chiames, a spokesman for the AMR Corporation, the parent company of American. "It would have a chilling effect on the marketplace if companies felt they could not match prices of competitors. We simply matched the competition."
The Justice Department complaint, filed in Federal court in Wichita, seeks an injunction barring American from cutting prices below cost and increasing flights as part of any effort to stifle competition. The case is being brought under Section 2 of the Sherman Antitrust Act.
Justice Department officials said Federal antitrust law does not permit them to seek any fines or monetary awards, but that smaller airlines that were harmed by American's conduct could file their own civil antitrust lawsuits for money.
The complaint quoted from company papers describing its "Dallas-Ft. Worth Low Cost Carriers Strategy." The Government said the strategy recognized that "it could prove unprofitable in the short run." But, according to a company document, the strategy concluded: "The short-term cost, or impact on revenue can be viewed as the investment necessary to achieve the desired effect on market share."
The Government also quoted from internal American papers that suggested that the carrier intended to add flights to Kansas City to drive Vanguard from the market and that American decided to get Western Pacific out of the Dallas-Colorado Springs route before Western Pacific increased its service there.
Company executives declined to answer questions about the American Airlines documents that the Government has called incriminating but defended them in general terms.
"There is nothing wrong or illegal with tough talk about competition," Mr. Chiames said.
Trey Nicoud, a senior lawyer at American, said, "Looking at aggressive conversations in board rooms is very misleading."
To win against any airline, the Government's evidence would need to be strong because predatory pricing cases are difficult to prove. But Justice Department lawyers have argued that it is relatively easy for a large airline to profit after undercutting a rival and driving it out of a market. In the past, the Government has distinguished between legitimate competition and predatory pricing when an airline cut its fares below its costs and added capacity in a strategy that only made economic sense if the smaller rival were forced to leave the market.
Executives from the smaller rivals portrayed as victims by the Government praised the lawsuit. Of the three, Vanguard has since returned to the Dallas-Fort Worth market, Sun Jet no longer serves that airport, and Western Pacific has filed for bankruptcy protection from its creditors and stopped flying in early 1998.

HEADLINE: BASEBALL;
With Prices Rising, Indians Go Up for Sale

BYLINE: By RICHARD SANDOMIR 

 BODY:
Tantalized by escalating franchise prices, Richard Jacobs put his Cleveland Indians up for sale yesterday, less than a year after taking the team public.
"I'll say this," said Jacobs, a 73-year-old real estate developer. "Somebody said Steinbrenner said his team is worth $1 billion and he had a buyer. And I said, 'If that buyer has a brother, give him my number.' " 
 The news that Jacobs may sell drove Indians stock up by 63.5 percent, to close at $16.25. Since going public last June at $15 a share, the stock has underperformed the market, sinking to a low of $5.375 a share. Based on yesterday's closing price, the team is worth about $224 million.
"It'll go for more than that," Jacobs said.
Larry Dolan, a Cleveland lawyer whose brother, Charles, is the chairman of Cablevision, said the plan to sell the Indians came as a "real surprise." In a statement, he said, "It is premature to say whether or not I am a prospective buyer." Recently, Larry Dolan unsuccessfully bid for the Cincinnati Reds.
Jacobs said he was not selling for estate-planning reasons. In fact, he had tried to diversify the company by adding real estate properties like hotels or television and radio stations, which might have made the stock more attractive.
"Maybe he felt the easiest way to boost the stock was to sell the team," said Jeffrey Phillips, a vice president at Houlihan Lokey Howard & Zukin, a Chicago-based investment banking firm that specializes in sports.
But Jacobs was motivated to consider selling by the prices paid last year for other Major League Baseball teams, like the Los Angeles Dodgers, at $311 million, and the Texas Rangers, at $250 million. Earlier this year, the Yankees were valued at $600 million for their merger with the Nets.
Jacobs watched as the National Football League sold the expansion Cleveland Browns for $530 million -- Jacobs was an early candidate in the team's auction -- and kept an eye on the pending $800 million sale of the Washington Redskins.
On Wednesday, Abe Pollin, 75, sold the Washington Capitals and a small stake in the Washington Wizards and the MCI Center for about $200 million.
"I never had any interest in disposing of the franchise until recently," Jacobs said. "But there's a market for it."
Jacobs said he wanted to control the process and keep the Indians in Cleveland. If he is unhappy with the prices offered or the suitors, he said, he will yank the team off the market. But Jacobs has hired two investment banking firms, Goldman Sachs Group and McDonald Investments, to identify buyers.
Whatever the price, Jacobs will profit handsomely. He and his late brother, David, acquired the once-moribund team in 1986 for $36 million. When the team went public, Jacobs collected $60 million from selling four million shares.
Last year, Jacobs was paid a $467,424 salary.
It is difficult to imagine a future owner wanting to flee Cleveland or lose the financial foundation of revenues that flow from the publicly owned Jacobs Field. The five-year-old stadium has sold out 308 consecutive games.
Last year, the team earned operating income of $12.7 million on revenues of $144.5 million, which included $55.8 million for tickets, $16.2 million for concessions, $9.4 million for luxury suite and club seat rentals and $9.8 million for advertising. Playoff revenues totaled $8.7 million.
Although the Indians have maximized most existing revenues, Jacobs said the team expected to benefit greatly when baseball's national television contracts expire after the 2000 season and from selling naming rights to the ball park.
"They can do better than they've been doing," said Andy Zimbalist, an economics professor at Smith College. "They have excess demands for all tickets, and they've thought of merging with the Cavaliers into a holding company that would present a united front to sell TV rights."
Since moving into Jacobs Field, the Indians' record is 464-310, a winning percentage of .599. The team lost the 1995 and 1997 World Series and the American League Championship Series to the Yankees last season.
