PUB-DATE: May 14, 1999,

SECTION: Section A; Page 18; Column 1; National Desk 

LENGTH: 1330 words

HEADLINE: THE FINE PRINT: The Emergency Spending Bill;
Relief Bill Is Laden With Special Projects as It Creaks Through Committee

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK with TIM WEINER 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, May 13

 BODY:
On the face of it, the seven-year battle over a mining company's petition to blow a 900-foot hole in a mountain in northern Washington State and extract the gold inside would seem to have nothing to do with an emergency bill in Congress to aid war refugees in Kosovo and victims of the recent Midwest tornadoes.
But that is only on the face of it. In fact, before House and Senate conferees reached agreement tonight on the emergency spending bill, negotiations were bogged down by the efforts of lawmakers to cut deals, trade favors and insert pet projects. The agreement they reached this evening more than doubled the amount President Clinton had sought for war and disaster relief, to a total of $14.7 billion and included a host of non-budget provisions. 
 That is where Buckhorn Mountain, in the Okanogan Highlands of north-central Washington, comes in. So far, Washington's senior Senator, Slade Gorton, a Republican who is running for re-election next year, has succeeded in attaching language to the spending bill that effectively overturns a Clinton Administration decision to deny a permit for the mine. The Administration has said mining would leave far too much waste rock and cyanide-treated ore on Federal land at the mountain, near the Canadian border.
The pro-mining measure, or rider, is just one that members of Congress from all over the nation are attaching to to the spending bill. Others include hundreds of millions of dollars in farm aid, loan programs for the steel, oil and gas industries and a host of other measures.
Senator Richard C. Shelby, Republican of Alabama, fought, unsuccessfully, for language to force the White House to keep the Alabama sturgeon off the endangered species amendment. Senator Ted Stevens, Republican of Alaska, did succeed in adding $3 million for commercial reindeer herders.
Legislation, of course, is often made in ways that are not pretty, and riders have been around almost since the dawn of the Republic. But many involved in the fight in the Capitol say they find something particularly execrable about the way that this bill, also intended to provide help for victims of last year's Central American hurricanes, has been delayed by matters affecting so many other people whose interests are, to say the least, less urgent.
"I think this is about as low as it goes," said Marty Hayden, director of policy and legislation for the Earthjustice Legal Defense Fund, an environmental group that opposes the Buckhorn Mountain mining project. "The supporters of these efforts are cynically taking advantage of a very real human tragedy, by including this provision and others like it in a bill meant to aid victims of natural disaster and war."
But supporters of the provisions are in a dudgeon no less high. Senator Gorton, for instance, who huddled with a mining lobbyist late Wednesday night outside a Capitol basement conference room, reviewing proposed language, said that including the rider in a bill that is unlikely to be vetoed was a perfectly acceptable way of overturning the Administration's decision to block the mine.
The mining company, Battle Mountain Gold of Houston, and a partner, the Crown Resources Corporation of Denver, have spent years and an estimated $80 million on the permit process and have obtained permits from lower agencies.
Senator Gorton criticized the decision by the Interior Department to block the mining project.
"This is just immoral," he said. "This is not how an honest government deals with its citizens."
The decision is part of the Administration's effort to overturn a century-old mining law that has allowed companies to extract billions of dollars of minerals from Federal land and pay no royalties.
Even though the President is pressing for speedy passage of any package that will allow the United States and its NATO allies to fight the war in Yugoslavia and aid refugees, a White House spokeswoman held out the possibility of a veto and blamed Congress for "trying to take advantage of emergency needs in Kosovo and Central America by loading up this bill with everybody's pet projects."
Senator Gorton has strongly defended the project as an economic boon for a depressed area of Washington, Okanogan County, which has an unemployment rate of about 11 percent, more than twice the state average.
Some residents of the area are enthusiastic about Senator Gorton's support of the mine project, which could employ 140 people for about 10 years and yield as much as half a billion dollars of gold.
"We've had several bad years in a row in the apples market; the timber industry is down," said Jimmie Dale Walker, the Mayor of Oroville, a town of 1,500 people near Buckhorn Mountain.
Others, including the Confederated Tribes of the Colville Indian Reservation, whose members live near five streams with headwaters on Buckhorn Mountain, are bitterly opposed. Many of the critics say the mine threatens the spectacular qualities that have made tourism an important part of the local economy.
"Some people have this kind of star in their eyes that they're going to get rich on the gold mine, instead of looking at the natural beauty all around them and working with that," said Dave Kliegman, executive director of the Okanogan Highlands Alliance, a local environment group.
For Senator Gorton, the legislative maneuver is consistent with his strong support for mining and logging companies in his 17-year career in the Senate.
Such moves have earned him the enmity of environmental groups, including the Sierra Club, whose Northwest regional director, Bill Arthur, said today that the Senator's "latest back-room deal continued a long line of shameless acts on behalf of corporate interests to run roughshod over America's environmental laws."
The Senator's actions on behalf of Texas-based Battle Mountain Gold have also inspired considerable ire in his home state, including that of one Seattle Post-Intelligencer reader who recently wrote to the paper: "Three Senators from Texas and only one from Washington is surely unconstitutional."
In the conference committee, Mr. Gorton succeeded in obtaining language that overturns the Clinton Administration's decision on the mining project, which hinges on a reading of the 1872 law.
That law, signed by President Ulysses S. Grant to encourage Western development and in the pickaxe-and-mule era of mining, still allows mining companies broad access to Federal land for just a few dollars an acre.
Critics, including the Interior Secretary, Bruce Babbitt, say it amounts to a huge giveaway of public resources and has left a dangerous legacy of 500,000 abandoned mines across the West.
Beyond the debate over the 1872 law is the question of whether a measure blocking the Administration's decision belongs in an emergency spending bill.
Mr. Gorton's Senate colleague from Washington, Patty Murray, a Democrat, said late Wednesday that his rider was "the wrong manner" to debate the mining law.
"To address this in the middle of the night in an emergency bill that seeks to address the Kosovo issue is wrong," Senator Murray said.
And nearly two dozen House Republicans, led by Rep. Sherwood Boehlert of Utica, N.Y., signed a letter earlier this week urging that the spending bill be kept free of "extraneous provisions" and riders.
"The supplemental bills address serious and urgent matters, including emergency aid for farmers and money for our troops in Kosovo," the letter said. "Controversial policy decisions ought to have a full airing on the House floor, and should not be added into must-pass bills during conference negotiations. This is particularly true in the case of these supplemental bills, which address genuine emergencies."
But other members of Congress seemed prepared to stretch the definition of what belonged in the bill. "The question of whether it's an emergency or not," said Senator Harry Reid, a Nevada Democrat, "is in the eye of the beholder."

HEADLINE: ART IN REVIEW;
Elizabeth King -- 'Homunculus'

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:

Kent Gallery
67 Prince Street
SoHo
Through May 22
Elizabeth King's sculptures and videos aim to be part of the long history of the lifelike automaton, which means they are both hokey and uncannily mesmerizing. 
 Her third solo show in New York includes impeccable human heads made of porcelain with full lips and big, searching glass eyes; a pair of small hands with the requisite number of joints, a few of which move ever so slightly (from the action of an invisible pendulum and magnets); and an isolated glass eye and its lid, beside a tiny jewel-like video of the two in action. (Think of Tony Oursler, ultra-refined).
There are also two high-definition videos. In "Eidolon," a porcelain head appears to shift and turn, its unchanging gaze replicating anxious attention. In "The Sizes of Things in the Mind's Eye," another, more complete doll is shown examining her hands and fiddling with her fingers. These movements result from a painstaking process of minute adjustments of the figure, alternating with frame-by-frame recording. In this final work, the miraculously moving automaton is nearly upstaged by the video itself, which projects the doll's image in space so that it appears to be suspended within a freestanding metal frame.
Ms. King's ultimate subject may be the transformative wonders of human technology, both old and new, and she makes us see them -- through creatures who themselves do nothing but look -- with unusual intensity. At times the melancholy innocence of these creatures (enhanced by their newbornlike baldness) gives you a view of the human soul in its perpetual isolation.
At other times, they seem overwhelmingly theatrical -- no less breathtaking, but better suited to a high-priced puppet show or a window at Tiffany's. Ms. King deploys her skills with undeniable passion and admirable economy, but her goal, the imitation of life, is rarely more than a fascinating sidebar to either life or art.
 ROBERTA SMITH

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: CHINA'S MOOD;
Real Public Rage Stoked By Propaganda Machine

BYLINE: By ELISABETH ROSENTHAL 

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 13

 BODY:
Ever since NATO bombs hit the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade last Friday, China's state-run media have dished up a ceaseless stream of banner headlines and jarring photos: of bereft parents crying over victims' bodies, of President Jiang Zemin in tears as he greeted families of the dead.
Newspapers and television programs have called the bombing an intentional "criminal act" perpetrated by "U.S.-led NATO forces." The three dead Chinese have been anointed "martyrs." The NATO forces, "barbarians," or worse. 
 But there has been no mention of the rock-throwing that damaged the facade of the United States Embassy in Beijing, nor have the words "ethnic cleansing" ever appeared. And it took two days for China's news media to report President Clinton's initial apology, fanning the flame of public outrage.
State-controlled reports have played a crucial link in the cycle of hatred that has rolled through China this week, both reflecting genuine public outrage and urging it on, sometimes with half-truths and inflammatory calls for the "revenge of blood debts."
The Government's somewhat rusty propaganda apparatus seemed to spring back to life in response to this extraordinary event.
In a country where newspapers and television programs are generally quite diverse and distinct, it was startling to watch China's news media once again speak with one voice. And many Chinese people were moved by what they heard and saw.
"Seeing the news reports and those pictures, I felt furious about America's actions," said Wei Fang, a 24-year-old auditor at an American accounting firm in Beijing.
Luo Zhanggong, a 28-year-old independent businessman who spent the weekend making protest posters for display near his home, said he "simply didn't believe" Western claims that student demonstrators had trashed the American Embassy.
But these days it may be hard to conduct an old-style propaganda campaign in China, where millions of urban Chinese have access to foreign Web sites, watch television beamed in by satellite from Hong Kong and have friends and relatives overseas.
"Chinese people are much more sophisticated than they were 20 years ago," said Minxin Pei, a researcher at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington.
There were some signs that by week's end the official version of events was fraying around the edges. At a Government press conference today, a Chinese television reporter boldly asked the Foreign Ministry spokesman to comment on Western accusations of ethnic cleansing in Yugoslavia.
And on the front page of today's Southern Weekend, a popular weekly with a liberal bent, editors condemned the NATO bombings, but also warned against developing xenophobia and "blind, fanatical, narrow-minded nationalism."
The Chinese news media have become far more lively and diverse in the last decade, partly because, to survive in the country's new market economy, television programs must rely on advertising and newspapers need to attract paying readers.
To this end, dozens of newspapers and television programs have branched into investigative reporting, run editorials on topics like legal reforms and cover stories about unemployment, crime and domestic violence. Today more than ever, China's press and news broadcasts look more like journalism and less like propaganda.
And readers and viewers are more inclined to expect the truth. As one university student told his American professor this week: "The protesters didn't set fire to an American consulate -- that's a lie. If it was true it would have been on China Central Television."
But the news media's core task is still to protect and promote the Government's point of view and this week they moved back to basics. Hours after the bombings, Ding Guangen, the head of the Communist Party's Propaganda Department, called a meeting of newspaper editors to order up coverage.
Since then, virtually every newspaper -- from the trendy Beijing Youth Daily to the party's mouthpiece, People's Daily -- has devoted pages and pages to the bombings, all expressing identical views and often using the same catch phrases. Even specialty papers like Farmers Daily and Health News joined in. Enterprising television programs that normally focus on corruption, has bellowed a similar outrage.
For example, Beijing Youth Daily has devoted at least eight pages to the bombings every day, a dramatic shift from its usual lively mix.
Last Sunday, the newspaper's banner headline "Shock -- Outrage -- Protest" was punctuated with tiny targets, the symbol of Serbian defiance. In another issue, a headline said "The Bomb Attack Was Premeditated." Virtually all newspapers have offered up columns by military experts contending that the bombing was intentional.
The youth paper did not give full coverage to the Western apology until Tuesday, two days after Western leaders first expressed regrets.
Such manipulations left the Chinese people stewing over the apparent lack of an apology for an extra 48 hours.
"Russia and smaller countries all over the world are expressing their condolences, but I haven't seen anything about Western countries expressing these thoughts," said an angry doctor who would give only her surname, Han. "It doesn't seem like the West regards all this as important."
Many Beijingers point out that the vast propaganda campaign was principally effective because it dovetailed with the public's initial gut fury about the bombings, even if careful management fueled that rage and channeled it into certain directions.
The vast majority of Chinese have steadfastly disapproved of the NATO bombing campaign, in part because there has been no reporting about ethnic cleansing and in part because they regard the Western forces as bullies who have no business being there.
"Whatever the disparities between the Chinese media and the Western press, for us there are two simple facts: That NATO bombed the Chinese Embassy and that three people died," said Mr. Luo, who owns a chemical company. "Now I'm not a party kind of person, but this is a matter on which the Chinese people, from the lowest peasant on up, are extremely unified."
Mr. Luo and others dismissed the notion that in 1999 a propaganda campaign could ever manipulate Chinese people's thoughts.
"These days China has become quite open and we get news from a whole variety of sources," said Li Pingwei, a 35-year-old who works in advertising. "I get it from TV, newspapers, the Internet and from speaking to my friends and colleagues who are overseas. I know what the outside world is saying."
For example, Mr. Li said he "had heard" that the American Consulate in Chengdu had been burned. And he said he debated with his Chinese friends working in the West about whether the bombing was intentional or not.
"They definitely have a different understanding of the events from Chinese people here," Mr. Li said. "But they think the American media are to some extent also controlled. Our media say it was deliberate and theirs say it was a mistake. So our opinions differ."
But others had more basic reasons why the media blitz here left them unmoved.
"Of course everyone's furious, three people were killed," said a man surnamed Wang, a shopkeeper. "Would I demonstrate? Of course not! You can't make money demonstrating. And that's what it's all about now, isn't it?"

HEADLINE: METRO BUSINESS;
New Jobs Expected For Seneca County

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
A new maximum security state prison and a treatment center for troubled youths will create nearly 1,000 jobs in rural Seneca County, N.Y., starting next year, Gov. George E. Pataki said yesterday.
Construction of the $180 million, 750-cell prison is under way at the Seneca Army Depot, an 11,000-acre base that stored nuclear weapons during the cold war and is scheduled to close in 2001. 
 The prison, due to open in summer 2000 near the village of Ovid, is designed to hold up to 1,500 inmates. It will employ 638 people and have a payroll of $25 million, state officials say.
Work is to begin in July on the Seneca Woods Youth Residential Treatment Center at the northern end of the depot, state officials said. It will enroll New York children with clinical emotional problems and histories of delinquency.
The center, which is expected to employ more than 350 people and have a payroll of $12 million, is to be operated beginning next spring by KidsPeace, a nonprofit group that runs 25 such children's centers around the nation.
"We can look with confidence to our future," Mr. Pataki told county employees and officials gathered in a county building in Waterloo. "It's happening. Those jobs are going to be here in Seneca County."
Nearly two-thirds of the depot's 800 civilian workers were laid off in 1993, and 500 soldiers were transferred, leaving just a base commander and fewer than 100 other employees.

HEADLINE: METRO BUSINESS;
Ruling on Special Fees

BYLINE: AP 

 BODY:
The New Jersey Supreme Court ruled yesterday that it is legal to charge fees to owners of commercial property in business improvement zones even though residents of the same zones do not have to pay the fees.
Owners of buildings in the Headquarters Plaza mall and office complex in Morristown had filed lawsuits claiming that the extra fee was unfair because homeowners living in the improvement zone did not have to pay it. 
 Their lawyers argued that such selective taxation violated the State Constitution. They also said the exemption for residential property owners meant that the commercial owners had to pay proportionately more.
In 1994, the Morristown Special Improvement District charged a special assessment of 0.1 percent of a property's assessed value, billing the fee on commercial properties only.
Roc-Jersey, a group of businesses that owns Headquarters Plaza, was charged $64,000 in improvement district fees in 1994. The district's budget was used to pay for tourism promotions, visitor guides and downtown beautification.
In their unanimous ruling, the Supreme Court judges said the fee was not a tax, but a special charge in exchange for services of unique value to the business owners.
Associate Justice Alan Handler wrote that homeowners should not have to pay the improvement fees, even though they might benefit from the improvements, because the main purpose of the fees was to improve the business climate.

SECTION: Section B; Page 7; Column 2; Arts & Ideas/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1564 words

HEADLINE: Taking on Sex and the Single Saint;
For Gary Wills, St. Augustine is Just the Latest Chapter in His Study of Culture

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH 

 BODY:
Sinners have always loved Augustine, the fourth-century saint, for he has seemed like such a great sinner himself. He was obsessed with sex, or so it appeared in his great work "The City of God." And he was willing to undertake a rigorous self-analysis in writings like his "Confessions," giving him an almost contemporary accessibility.
But now the journalist Garry Wills has written "St. Augustine" (in the Penguin Lives series of brief biographies), which tries to revise the popular view of the saint, and the work may disappoint some sinners. In the book, Mr. Wills says that Augustine wasn't sex-obsessed at all but concerned with how sexual dysfunction reflects man's fall from grace, and that the "Confessions" was not an autobiography in the conventional sense but "mainly a theological meditation on his own life." "Revelation is not simply a text outside life," he says. "Rather it enters your life in the form of your own experience." 
 Could Mr. Wills explain then, St. Augustine's relevance to the modern world?
But Mr. Wills will not reduce St. Augustine to "sound bites," as he puts it. His full, cherubic face often remains expressionless when he speaks; sometimes there is a thin smile. He is 64 and lives in a large yellow brick house in Evanston, Ill., where one of the interviews with him was conducted. He seems impatient with people who are not as well read as he is. "He's sort of like a good boxer," said his good friend, Studs Terkel. "He doesn't waste any punches."
Nor does he let down his guard for a moment. Perhaps there are parallels between him and St. Augustine with respect to Augustine's quest for self-knowledge? "There are no parallels with my own life. That's nonsense," Mr. Wills said, annoyance coloring his voice. "Don't try to push that idea. It makes no sense. I have no identification with him whatsoever."
Asked how many books he has written, he curtly replied, "Look it up in 'Who's Who.' " "Who's Who" lists 19, including one with a co-author and one he edited. That would make "St. Augustine" his 20th book, and next fall he will publish another, "A Necessary Evil" (Simon & Schuster), about Americans' fear of government.
More impressive than the number, however, is the range. He has brought his talent as a scholar to everything from Italian film to opera, from President Clinton to the Declaration of Independence. He has a mimetic memory of obscure fourth-century North African ecclesiastical texts in his book on Augustine, of Homeric boxing references in an article on Muhammad Ali and of ancient Greek rhetorical terms in his 1992 book, "Lincoln at Gettysburg," a study of the Gettysburg address, for which he won a Pulitzer Prize.
Mr. Wills said he owes his retentive memory to his Roman Catholic school education, with its emphasis on recitation. Robert Silvers, his editor at The New York Review of Books, says the breadth of Mr. Wills's learning sometimes makes him "a little speechless."
"I can't think of anyone who combines this remarkable range of interests and abilities," Mr. Silvers said.
Pressed to identify the common thread in his work, Mr. Wills responds: "I suppose the study of culture." The Presidents he has written about -- John F. Kennedy, Richard M. Nixon and Ronald Reagan -- are what he calls "cultural indicators." They "tell you a good deal about the America they were in."
There is another theme that stands out in Mr. Wills's writing: the constant interplay between myth and reality in American life. In his first big success, in 1970, "Nixon Agonistes: The Crisis of the Self-Made Man," he famously called Nixon a liberal trying to resurrect "a web of myths that have lost their magic." The Emersonian ideal of hard work has lost its power, Mr. Wills argued, and Adam Smith's notion of a self-regulating market place hasn't worked. Politicians must give up their atomistic vision for a more communitarian ideal, he wrote.
"Reagan's America: Innocents at Home," continued the theme of myths. Mr. Reagan, Mr. Wills wrote, "is the sincerest claimant to a heritage that never existed, a perfect blend of an authentic America he grew up in and of that America's own fables about its past." He embodied "an American instinct to claim simplicity," but his sunny nature belied a painful Depression-era childhood. He opposed welfare, but his family received Government relief during the Depression. As President, Mr. Reagan claimed to have reduced Government spending, but he actually increased it.
And in "John Wayne's America," Mr. Wills wrote that Wayne presented himself as the awkward individualist, the brave warrior, defending the endless frontier even though he never served in the military. He played the cowboy but hated horses. He became for Americans "a conduit they used to communicate with their own desired selves or their own imagined past."
Like Wayne, Mr. Wills is a child of the Midwest. He was raised for the most part in Adrian, Mich. His father, John Wills, sold appliances. His mother, Mayno, worked for the State Department of Unemployment. Mr. Wills parents were divorced, then remarried.
Inspired by his Jesuit high school teachers, Mr. Wills entered a seminary. But he didn't make it as a priest. "It was eros specifically and generally," Mr. Wills said. Today he is a practicing Catholic who regularly attends church but says he believes in a right to abortion, marriage for priests and the ordination of women.
He went on to get his Ph.D. in classics from Yale, writing his dissertation on Aeschylus. While at Yale he sent an unsolicited article attacking what he called the glib style of Time magazine to William F. Buckley Jr., the editor of the conservative National Review. Mr. Buckley printed it and began giving him assignments.
When they met, "he asked me if I was a conservative," Mr. Wills said. Mr. Wills told him: "I'm a distributist, like G. K. Chesterton. Communitarian. Anti-capitalist. Anti-government."
"Is that a conservative?" Mr. Wills asked.
"I'm afraid not," Mr. Buckley replied. Nonetheless, Mr. Wills became one of the young writers of National Review's golden age, among them Joan Didion, Renata Adler, John Leonard and Arlene Croce.
But during the Vietnam War his politics began to change. He was arrested twice in antiwar demonstrations. When Mr. Buckley rejected one of his articles on Vietnam, they parted ways amicably, Mr. Wills said. Today Mr. Wills describes himself as a cultural conservative, but when it comes to politics, "I'm more a Democrat than a Republican."
In 1957 Mr. Wills covered the Senate hearings on Jimmy Hoffa for National Review. He was on the shuttle from Washington when a stewardess with "big and mocking Italian eyes" noticed he was reading Henri Bergson's "Two Sources," Mr. Wills wrote in "Confessions of a Conservative." "She said, 'Aren't you a little too young to be reading that?' " The stewardess was Natalie Cavallo, and Mr. Wills married her.
Even on their honeymoon in England, Mr. Wills wasted no time, doing research for his first book, "Chesterton: Man and Mask," published in 1961. Today Natalie Wills is her husband's first reader. She takes photographs to aid his memory. She handles the financial aspects of his career, leaving him time to write in the mornings at home and in the afternoon to do research at the library. They have three children, Lydia, 35, a literary agent; Garry Jr., 38, a film maker, and John, 39, a programmer.
For much of his adult life, Mr. Wills has been an academic. At times he has been accused of having an academic style. "Garry Wills is a bright young man who left his Yale Ph.D. in classics behind him only to bring the academic vices of preciosity and obfuscation to his new career as a political journalist," one Newsweek critic wrote.
In 1988 Mr. Wills gave up tenure at Northwestern University, though he has remained in Evanston, teaching one course annually. He prefers living far from Washington and New York, he said. "I'd rather be remote. I get more work done."
Mr. Wills said he had long been preoccupied with St. Augustine. Augustine was born in 354 in Tagaste, Numidia, in North Africa. From age 16 to 31 he lived with a woman who bore him a son. He converted to Christianity and eventually became Bishop of Hippo. His doctrines on original sin, divine grace and free will have influenced every branch of Christianity.
Augustine wrote frankly about sex in "The City of God:" "At times, without intention, the body stirs on its own insistent," Augustine wrote. "At other times, it leaves a straining lover in the lurch." At another point he describes the Stoics' wanting to defy social codes by having public intercourse. But because they couldn't respond on command, they used clubs to simulate an erection. Still, despite the almost graphic nature of some of his writings, Mr. Wills said, for Augustine sexual turmoil is "one sign of the inner dividedness of the human being. Your body doesn't respond the way you want it to."
"Greed, violence and deception were greater concerns in his sermons," Mr. Wills writes.
Mr. Wills is translating "Confessions" from the Latin and writing a commentary on it. He said he was drawn to Augustine because "he has such a questioning mind, such a fresh way of going at everything."
"In a way the quest for God is a quest into himself," Mr. Wills said. "He's also just a great writer."

HEADLINE: Silicon Valley's New Think Tank Stakes Out 'Radical Center'

BYLINE: By NEIL A. LEWIS 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
In Thinktankland, the main attractions are by now wearyingly familiar. The conservative Heritage Foundation and the American Enterprise Institute and the liberal-centrist Brookings Institution along with several others have for years competed to convert their ideas about taxes, foreign policy, the environment or whatever into policy in the real world.
But since the beginning of this year, a new entry in the public policy community, the New America Foundation, has been trying to provide something different. Led by Ted Halstead, its president, New America has ensconced itself in handsome quarters near Dupont Circle and hopes to change the think tank landscape. Mr. Halstead boasts that New America will introduce younger voices, break out of the traditional liberal and conservative categories and produce unconventional ideas. 
 Yet no matter how many innovations New America offers, none may be as inspired as the one associated with its founding: getting money from the cyberbarons of Silicon Valley. New America's board includes Eric E. Schmidt, the chairman and chief executive of Novell, and Eric A. Benhamou, chairman and chief executive of the 3Com Corporation. Mr. Halstead and James Fallows, the chairman of New America, are courting other leaders in Silicon Valley, most notably Andrew S. Grove, the head of Intel.
Mr. Schmidt of Novell said in an interview that New America was attractive to him and his fellow high-tech entrepreneurs because it was trying to escape the classic liberal versus conservative divide.
"I thought that here is a place in which new ideas can flourish which are not aligned with any partisan view," he said. "A large number of people out here are tired of the left-right debate, which exists largely because it makes for good television."
High-tech entrepreneurs have been so busy making money, he said, they have ignored Government and public policy issues. "But the Government is no longer ignoring us," he said, "so we have to get organized, to have vehicles for this, and this -- New America -- is one."
Mr. Schmidt said that typically when a corporate leader in Silicon Valley meets with a member of Congress, the talk invariably ends with the Congressman's disingenuous interest in the businessman's ideas and a naked pitch for campaign donations.
New America, he said, will not be obliged to champion the broad tenets of Silicon Valley, which some loosely define as meritocracy, individual incentives and as little Government interference as is feasible. "The ideas that come out may well include some I might not agree with," Mr. Schmidt said.
For nearly two decades, the center of gravity in Thinktankland has tilted to the right. The Heritage Foundation, brash and aggressive, and the American Enterprise Institute, its more staid cousin, have been able to wield influence in the Reagan and Bush Administrations and more recently in the Republican-dominated Congress. They have outpaced their counterparts on the left in both influence and money.
The success of places like Heritage -- and perhaps New America -- also underlines the remoteness of universities from real policy-making, which has stirred some ambivalence in the academic world.
Just as Silicon Valley has embraced a youth culture, so does the New America Foundation. Mr. Halstead, who thought up the idea for New America with a few friends, is 30 years old and already on his second think tank. When he was 25 he founded Redefining America, a San Francisco-based foundation that specializes in environmental and economic programs.
In a forthcoming article in The Atlantic Monthly, Mr. Halstead argues that people his age have removed themselves from politics and policy in overwhelming numbers, largely out of distrust of political leaders and institutions as well as impatience with the constricting right and left labels.
At the American Enterprise Institute, the term senior fellow applies to people like Jeane J. Kirkpatrick, the chief American delegate to the United Nations in the Reagan Administration, and Herbert Stein, the Chairman of Economic Advisers in the Nixon Administration.
At New America, senior fellows are in their 30's and mere fellows are in their 20's because, as Mr. Halstead said in an interview, they have not acquired the seasoning to have made a name for themselves.
One of the Heritage Foundation's strategies has been to produce a report to promote an idea and hold a news conference or distribute the report to reporters, but New America's approach is to subsidize the journalists directly.
"The new way, we think, is to get people to write and place their ideas in newspapers, magazines and to discuss them on talk shows," Mr. Halstead said.
The senior fellows this year, Debra Dickerson, Michael Lind and Margaret Talbot, are being given annual grants of $50,000 apiece, health benefits and an office plus whatever fees they earn from publishing their writings. Five fellows are given $25,000 each plus an office and benefits. In return, they are expected to identify themselves as fellows at the New America Foundation when they write. Mr. Lind and Ms. Talbot have each written two articles for The New York Times in which they were identified as senior fellows of the foundation.
So what is the working philosophy of the New America Foundation?
The question produces a series of agonized answers from Mr. Halstead and just about everybody else connected with New America. New America, it seems, has defined itself more by what it isn't than what it is.
"For a young person who is not a conservative and who wants to comment on public affairs, there is an intellectual loneliness," Mr. Halstead said. "There are not enough partners on the ideological center."
In the end, Mr. Halstead said he favors the description "radical center," a term that neatly combines the notion of ferment (radical) with steadiness and a sensible avoidance of fringe ideas (center).
To Mr. Halstead, a shorthand definition of the radical center includes economic populism (as in say, support for higher minimum wages) and skepticism about social programs (including an unease with many forms of affirmative action).
In addition to subsidizing fellows, New America plans specific projects, Mr. Halstead said, like one investigating whether it makes sense for the United States to sell assets like mineral rights or polluting permits to the highest bidder.
"I'm looking for the next New Deal," he said.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
World Trade Group Hiding Substance Behind Emotion

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH OLSON 

DATELINE: GENEVA, May 14

 BODY:
Anger and betrayal have colored the World Trade Organization's deadlocked talks to choose a new leader, but behind the emotions are three substantive issues -- the interests of workers, farmers and the environment -- that have generally polarized the 134-nation group, producing odd alliances of rich and poor, big and small.
Whoever is picked as director general of the organization that sets rules for global commerce will have an important impact on whether it tries to impose some labor and environmental protection rules on everyone, and tries to clear away some existing domestic protections for agriculture. 
 Such changes, on the surface, seem fair and reflect the global forum's commitment to level playing fields in the competition to sell goods and services across borders. But they represent threats to countries heavily dependent on agriculture, farm imports or the use of inexpensive labor.
 These issues have factored into the reasons why member countries are refusing to compromise over the two finalist candidates, Mike Moore of New Zealand and Supachai Panitchpakdi of Thailand.
The deadlock, now entering its third week, has left the organization leaderless since the four-year term of Renato Ruggiero of Italy expired May 1.
The choices of Japan and the United States, the two giant trading powers, particularly reflect concerns over these issues.
The United States wants Mr. Moore, who is seen as a strong advocate of better worker treatment and free trade in agriculture. Japan favors Mr. Supachai because he is viewed as more sensitive to the interests of farmers who worry that they cannot compete with inexpensive imports.
The United States' preference rests partly on concerns that Mr. Supachai would not advocate environmental and labor issues. "It became clear that these issues would take a back seat, as far as Supachai was concerned," a United States official said.
 American environmental setbacks in trade organization decisions, most notably an overruling of United States safeguards for endangered sea turtles caught in shrimpers' nets, contributed to Washington's concern that a new trade leader be attuned to such issues.
Japan and the United States also differ on which candidate would serve each nation's interest best in agriculture. The Americans view Mr. Moore as a forceful advocate of ending subsidies for farmers that keep prices artificially high. The Japanese say such a position is unfair to countries that want to protect small, family-run farms. Yoichi Suzuki, Japan's envoy to the trade organization, said, "Politically speaking, it is not very easy to accept someone from a country which is a free trader in agriculture."
However, Thailand, too, is a large agricultural exporter, especially of rice, a sensitive commodity in Asia, as well as being a member, along with New Zealand, of a major pro-free trade group. So why would Japan back Mr. Supachai? "He is viewed as having a more receptive attitude to the Japanese view that agriculture is a pillar of rural life, of the environment, of conserving old ways," a Japanese negotiator said.
 Not every country with big agricultural interests has based its decision on agriculture alone. France, with entrenched farm subsidies and a powerful farmers lobby, supports Mr. Moore. "This is a case where the labor forces who fear low-wage competition have won out over the agricultural interests," a European diplomat said.
 Other European countries have also split between the two candidates, leaving the 15-member European Union with no unified choice for director general.
Although Washington favors Mr. Moore it has remained conspicuously silent. This has created resentment among a number of trade diplomats in Geneva, who are convinced that American trade officials are maneuvering clandestinely to insure that Mr. Moore wins.
Resentment is also fueled by a belief among many developing countries that they have not benefitedfrom free-trade rules, that liberalized agricultural trade and higher labor standards would hurt them. Many are also convinced that a representative from a developing country, such as Thailand, should lead the organization. Among the most vocal advocates of Mr. Supachai's candidacy are India and Mexico.
"There is a strong feeling, right or wrong, that the United States has prolonged this race to influence the outcome," one envoy from a developing country said. "That has upset a number of delegates, and entrenched positions."

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
U.S. Threatens Europe With Duties in Beef Dispute

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
The United States escalated a trade war with the European Union today by threatening to impose $202 million in punitive duties on the trading bloc for banning imports of American beef from hormone-treated cattle.
Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, said Washington remained open to negotiations to resolve the decade-old dispute. But she told reporters, "We will absolutely protect our rights and we will without question retaliate if the E.U. persists in disregarding the rules." 
 In Brussels, the European Union Farm Commissioner, Franz Fischler, said it would ask the World Trade Organization to review the United States plan to impose $202 million in 100 percent duties on European Union goods.
"We will certainly challenge this sum and the U.S. will have to try to justify before a W.T.O. arbitrator," Mr. Fischler said in a statement.
That review, which could result in a higher or lower figure than the one sought by Washington, would delay any duties until at least July 12 -- the deadline for the trade organization's arbitration.
Goods subject to the duties could include European pork, beef, poultry and other goods like Dijon mustard and spring water. Oats and small-engine motorcycles could also be hit.
Those items were on a preliminary list released by the Clinton Administration in late March. The United States will wait until the arbitrator decides the final amount before announcing which products will be subject to the duties, Ms. Barshefsky said.
American officials said they were forced to seek retaliation after the European Union failed to meet a May 13 deadline set by the trade organization.. Two trade organization panels have ruled that the European Union ban is illegal.
"There is no legitimate reason for the E.U.'s unfair restriction on free trade," Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said. "The W.T.O. decision recognizes that American beef is safe. Scientific study after study confirms this."
Nonetheless, European officials say they remain concerned about potential health risks from eating the beef.
In a trade dispute about bananas, the United States sought permission to impose $520 million in punitive duties on European products. But after the European Union sought arbitration from the World Trade Organization, the final figure was whittled to $191 million.
Given that experience, the National Cattlemen's Beef Association said it supported the Clinton Administration decision to seek only $202 million in retaliation "in order to expedite the W.T.O. review that will now proceed."

HEADLINE: U.S. Industry Back on Its Feet in a Wobbly World

BYLINE: By MICHAEL M. WEINSTEIN 

 BODY:
When financial crisis swept through Asia, Brazil and Russia last year, American industry prepared to duck. With goods accounting for over 70 percent of exports, manufacturers were sure to take a hit.
And sure enough, they did. Manufacturing exports, as estimated by the National Association of Purchasing Management, fell for 14 consecutive months starting in the fall of 1997. Employment in manufacturing, meanwhile, fell by 400,000 last year and the association's widely publicized measure of manufacturing production indicated steady declines throughout 1998. 
 But the negative arithmetic misses the point, says Jerry Jasinowski, president of the National Association of Manufacturers, the industry's largest trade group. "The best estimates show that manufacturing survived the Asia crisis just fine," he said. "In fact, it is thriving."
He backs his assertion with Government statistics different from those compiled by the purchasing managers. His data show that production, which certainly stumbled for a while, has now recovered and is again rising at a brisk pace.
Another sign of manufacturing's revival came yesterday, when the Federal Reserve reported that industrial production rose six-tenths of 1 percent in April, the strongest gain since August.
Industrial employment is continuing to fall, but that trend actually reflects the sector's enduring strength -- fast-paced innovation that drives up productivity, allowing manufacturers to churn out more automobiles, refrigerators and computers with fewer workers. Some of the productivity gains can be traced to "hard technology" innovations embedded in high-speed data processing systems and computer-driven machinery. But other gains are driven by "soft technology" innovations, which alter the way people, equipment and materials are organized and managed.
According to Mark Zandi, chief economist at RFA, an economic consulting firm based in West Chester, Pa., growth in production peaked in November 1997 when it was advancing by more than 7 percent a year. Once Asian economies collapsed, manufacturing slowed, but never actually fell. Now that exports have stabilized, the vigorous domestic economy is pulling demand for manufactured goods back up. According to Government estimates, production rose more than 4 percent last year, about the same rate of growth as in the economy at large.
"The trade shock merely brought manufacturing down from its giddy pace before Asia collapsed to the pace of other sectors of the economy," Mr. Zandi said.
That raises the question of how manufacturing kept pace with services, which suffered little shock from Asia. Chalk the neat trick up to the Federal Reserve, which cut interest rates last year as an insurance policy to keep the American economy upright. Lower interest rates made housing, autos and other goods that Americans buy on credit cheaper.
According to Government estimates, the production of durables -- furniture, industrial machinery, computer equipment, automobiles and the like -- rose over 5 percent from the end of 1997 to the end of 1998. But output of nondurable goods like tobacco products, textiles and apparel fell almost 1 percent during the period.
Economic collapse abroad hit particularly hard at commodities. As Asia bought less oil, steel and other basic goods, their prices fell to punishing levels, forcing cutbacks. That was a boon for consumers, but a blow to American producers.
Yet American industry has proved remarkably resilient. A striking feature of the last several decades is that the share of manufacturing in the overall economy has remained rock steady. "It may appear to the public that we are becoming a nation of hamburger flippers," said Ed McKelvey, an economist with Goldman, Sachs, "but the simple fact is that manufacturers are holding their own."
Yesterday's report by the Federal Reserve on production showed that manufacturing advanced six-tenths of 1 percent during April after rising a revised five-tenths of 1 percent in March. Mining output increased one-tenth of 1 percent; output of utilities rose seven-tenths of 1 percent. Capacity use, meanwhile, remained low, at 80.6 percent, compared with 80.4 percent in March.
Manufacturing accounts for about 20 percent of total production today, and about 20 percent for the last three decades. What has fallen is the share of the nation's labor force working in manufacturing -- from about 35 percent in 1947, to about 18.5 percent in 1988 and about 15 percent today.
The productivity record in manufacturing in recent years has been striking. It has been growing about 4 percent a year since 1995, about twice the rate of productivity growth in the overall economy. In the first quarter of this year, manufacturing productivity advanced at a 5.8 percent rate.
Prof. Paul Swamidass of Auburn University says he thinks he knows why. In a 1997 survey of more than 1,000 factories sponsored by the manufacturers' association and the National Science Foundation, he found that about 85 percent of the companies involved had adopted computer-aided design technologies that permit them to introduce new products more quickly. About 70 percent had adopted computer-run machines. More than 60 percent of the plants had built computer networks linking customers to the plant and linking machinery within the plant. And at least 25 percent of the factories used robots for welding and other repetitive tasks.
One of the newest innovations -- an organizational concept known as cells, which uses small teams of workers to make an entire product rather than passing unfinished product from department to department, each with its own crew of workers -- is spreading fast. The survey showed it had been adopted by more than 50 percent of the companies.
John Heggestad, director of operations at Mine Safety Appliances, a Pittsburgh company that makes safety equipment, including gas masks and other breathing devices, said that "manufacturing cells have allowed us to cut paperwork, transportation and inspections."
Under the new system, a worker inspects aluminum forgings brought onto the factory floor, and, using machines placed nearby, does whatever milling, drilling and threading is needed. Under the old system, the aluminum would have been brought to a receiving area by one worker, logged in by another, inspected by a third, then transported to different areas of the factory floor for milling, drilling, threading and further assembly.
"By moving to manufacturing cells," he said, "we doubled revenues per worker over the past 10 or so years."
Peter Probst, manufacturing engineer at the Falk Corporation in Auburn, Ala., tells a similar story. Falk makes coupling devices that connect motors to equipment. Under its old system, the assembly of a new coupler would start at one end of the factory floor and finish at the other. Now machines are arranged in clusters, sometimes run by a single worker who completes all the steps himself. The process eliminates the need to have unfinished parts sitting around in various stages; Falk has reduced its delivery times from four weeks to one.
Professor Swamidass, in his survey, found that companies raised productivity by about 4 percent a year from 1993 through 1997 and reduced inventories by more than 20 percent. "The record suggests," he said, "that in a tight labor market that chairman Alan Greenspan of the Federal Reserve fears, the use of hard and soft technologies can boost productivity and take the pressure off of labor costs."

HEADLINE: White House Gives Support To Measure On Spending

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
Eager for money to pay for the war in Yugoslavia, the White House today said it expected President Clinton to sign a nearly $15 billion emergency spending measure that doubles what the President had requested for the Balkan conflict, for Central American hurricane victims and for hard-pressed American farmers.
The package was completed by House and Senate negotiators late Thursday night. Republican leaders planned to pass it next week in an effort to bolster their party's credentials on national security after the House's refusal last month to give its political support to the air war in Yugoslavia. 
 The President had sought $6 billion for the air campaign and aid to Balkan refugees and nations bordering Yugoslavia. The Republicans provided $11.8 billion, including money for a general military buildup and to allow for a pay increase for the military.
"Despite our differences over the Administration's Balkan policy, this bill sends a strong message to our troops in the field that the Congress supports them," said Representative C. W. Bill Young, the Florida Republican who is chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.
The spending bill also has $1 billion for relief and reconstruction efforts in Central America, long-stalled in Congress. And the negotiators took care of the needy at home, approving $900 million for tornado victims, mainly in Oklahoma and Kansas, and $566 million for financially troubled farmers.
The Republicans also used the bill to sidestep a looming confrontation over the next census that could have risked a partial Government shutdown. The package lifts a provision enacted last year that would have blocked financing for the Commerce, Justice and State Departments after June 15 because of a dispute over how the census will be conducted.
Emergency spending bills have become magnets in Congress for special-interest provisions because the legislation is usually considered too important to be vetoed. Senator Trent Lott, the majority leader, and Speaker J. Dennis Hastert tried to hold the line against such amendments and riders, although some survived.
Across three days of furious bargaining between the House and Senate, several Republican provisions that the Administration had opposed as anti-environmental were dropped or softened as were some offsetting spending cuts the Administration had opposed. The negotiators also killed a Senate provision providing $40 million for the families of victims of last year's accident in Italy in which a low-flying Marine jet cut the cable of an Alpine ski gondola and sent it plunging to the ground.
The last obstacle to the agreement was overcome on Thursday night when Mr. Hastert persuaded several House negotiators to reverse themselves and reject a guaranteed loan program for some steel companies that was sought by Senator Robert C. Byrd, Democrat of West Virginia. The steel assistance and a similar program for oil and gas companies sponsored by Senator Pete V. Domenici, Republican of New Mexico, was separated from the bill to be considered later in the session. Such stand-alone measures are easier to defeat.
The bill still includes language that effectively overturns an Administration decision to deny a permit for a mine in Buckhorn Mountain in Washington. And it has a provision sponsored by Senator Kay Bailey Hutchison, Republican of Texas, that would block the Administration from using any of the $246 billion the states have won from a legal settlement with the tobacco industry. Mr. Clinton had wanted to use part of that money for health and anti-tobacco programs.
Earlier veto threats disappeared as the President finally won long-stalled aid for Central America, $100 million in aid to Jordan and the money for the Balkan war.
"While the legislation is not perfect, it accomplishes a great deal and represents significant progress," said Linda Ricci, a spokeswoman for the Office of Management and Budget.
Ms. Ricci said the White House was still reviewing the agreement, but "we expect the President will be presented with a bill he can sign."
Mr. Clinton had not wanted to offset the new spending with cuts in other programs. But the Republicans insisted on offsetting $2 billion of the package's cost, by reducing spending for the food stamp program and subsidized housing. The Administration agreed with Republicans that these reductions would not affect the poor, coming from unspent balances that had not been used because of the improved economy.
Most of the new spending was to be paid for by dipping into the Federal surplus, which in the current fiscal year is entirely due to Social Security tax receipts. Republicans have said they are ready to protect Social Security money from being used for other means, but they have argued that the military is a special case.

HEADLINE: Inflation Jumps Enough to Scare Wall Street

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Inflation, driven in part by rising oil and gasoline prices, moved up sharply at the consumer level in April, the Government reported yesterday, leading analysts to say that the remarkable decline in inflation over the last several years may be over.
But at the same time, economists are not predicting that inflation is taking off. It is just that after the meager 1.6 percent rise in the Consumer Price Index last year, which can be attributed largely to plunging oil prices, inflation is now likely to return to the 2.3 percent pace of 1997. 
 On a seasonally adjusted basis, the index for April rose seven-tenths of 1 percent, its biggest monthly increase in eight and a half years. The so-called core index, which excludes the volatile food and energy components, rose four-tenths of 1 percent, the largest increase since January 1995.
"It is not as bad as it looks," said Louis Crandall, chief economist at R. H. Wrightson & Associates.
Still the indication of an acceleration in prices was enough to send stock and bond prices sharply lower and interest rates higher yesterday. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 193.87 points, or 1.75 percent, to 10,913.32. Still, the Dow is up almost 19 percent for the year. Long-term interest rates jumped to 5.92 percent yesterday, their highest in a year.
Stock and bond investors have been worrying about inflationary pressures for several months because the economy, which has grown at more than a 5 percent pace in the last six months, has shown few signs of slowing to a speed that would prevent the Federal Reserve from raising interest rates to curb growth and inflation. Such a move, at least initially, would have a negative effect on both stocks and bonds.
Because of these concerns, the surge in inflation in April will focus even more attention on the meeting of Federal Reserve policy makers on Tuesday. While analysts do not expect the central bank officials to raise interest rates, policy makers could send a signal that a rate increase would be likely if the April numbers turned into a trend.
The April surge in the overall price index followed an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in March and rises of one-tenth of 1 percent in both February and January. Almost half of the April increase came from a record 15 percent jump in gasoline prices. Overall energy prices jumped 6.1 percent after a 1.6 percent rise in March.
Food prices were up one-tenth of 1 percent in contrast to a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in March. The index for fruits and vegetables jumped 1.4 percent after a decline of 2.2 percent in March.
The more worrisome jump of four-tenths of 1 percent in the core index followed increases of one-tenth of 1 percent in each of the first three months of the year. The jump to four-tenths was driven by higher costs for apparel, tobacco and shelter. Apparel prices climbed 1.5 percent, their first increase since August. Tobacco was up 3.6 percent last month after falling 3.5 percent in March.
So far this year, consumer prices over all are rising at an annual rate of 3.3 percent, compared with 1.6 percent for all of 1998. The core rate is climbing at a 1.9 percent annual rate, below last year's 2.4 percent.
In a separate report yesterday, the Federal Reserve said that industrial production rose six-tenths of 1 percent last month after an increase of five-tenths of 1 percent in March.
One reason economists were relatively calm -- and why the Fed is not expected to raise interest rates Tuesday -- is that the April jump seems to be an isolated event. The other important barometers of inflationary pressure are still in check. The pace of wage increases, despite the low rate of unemployment, has been declining this year. Worker productivity, which rose a surprising 4 percent in the first quarter of the year, is rising. The dollar is still relatively strong, meaning that the prices of imports are in check.
The index of prices at the producer level rose five-tenths of 1 percent in April, but the core rate increased just one-tenth of 1 percent. And American companies still seem to have trouble making any significant price increases stick.
"I don't remember a time when the C.P.I., in one report, told you the trend was changing," said James E. Glassman, the senior United States economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. Nonetheless, he said he was considering raising his forecast for consumer prices this year. His current forecast, of a 1.3 percent increase, is based in part on the assumption that the rise in oil prices will retreat significantly; he said if he were revising his forecast now, it would move to around 2 percent.
Ian Shepherdson, the chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y., said that without the tobacco and apparel increases, the core index would have risen just two-tenths of 1 percent, which is what Wall Street was expecting.
He said the apparel increase was attributable to the marking-up of spring clothing by retailers who were forced to cut prices on winter clothes earlier this year because of the mild weather. In addition, the new calculation method for the index appears to have understated price increases earlier in the year and could be overstating them now.
The tobacco price increases, Mr. Shepherdson said, followed months of discounting by producers. "I don't think any of this tells us anything about the underlying inflation environment," he said.
But there still were some worrisome trends. Medicare costs, pushed up by drug costs, rose three-tenths of 1 percent and are up 3.5 percent over the last 12 months. Donald J. Fine, the chief market strategist at Chase Asset Management, said there were also clear upward trends in hotel, education and public transportation costs. In addition, there is no assurance that the recent break in the price run-ups in crude oil and gasoline means that those surges are over.
One of the big questions for both bond and stock investors now is what happens to interest rates. A move above the 6 percent level could become troubling if it undermined stocks by drawing investors to the bond market.
But Jeffrey M. Applegate, the chief United States strategist at Lehman Brothers and a well-known bull, is not worried. "We are not going to jump the tracks," he said. "We are not going to change our asset allocation; this is an outlier," he said, alluding to the April C.P.I. report. His year-end target for the Dow remains at 11,500.
Abby Joseph Cohen, the market strategist at Goldman, Sachs, said at a conference for clients that the country was not facing an increase in inflation nor a spike in interest rates.
In trading yesterday, the Dow was pulled down in part by sharp falls in I.B.M., off 6 3/4, to 239 1/4, and J. P. Morgan, down 513/16 , to 14015/16 . Both stocks had jumped sharply Thursday, I.B.M on Internet hopes and J. P. Morgan on takeover rumors. Yesterday they accounted for more than a quarter of the Dow's decline.
The Nasdaq composite index was down 54.14 points, or 2.1 percent, to 2,527.86, and the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks was off 29.76 points, or 2.18 percent, to 1,337.80. Both indexes are loaded with the high-valuation technology and large- growth stocks that investors have shunned recently. Instead investors have flocked to the relatively undervalued cyclical stocks, which have rallied as the economy has shown much more strength than expected.
In the bond market, the price of the 30-year Treasury bond dropped 130/32 , to 9022/32 . The yield, which moves in the opposite direction, jumped to 5.92 percent, from 5.75 percent Thursday. On Thursday, bonds rallied sharply, and the yield dropped, after the report of the restrained increase in producer prices and the announcement that retail sales had risen only one-tenth of 1 percent in both March and April.
Investors had come to depend on the "strong growth but low inflation" story, said Karen Arrese, head of global bonds at Bank Julius Baer. "But when you pose a threat to that story, the market doesn't like it," she said.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: THE WHITE HOUSE;
Chinese Finally Allow Clinton Time for a Telephone Apology

BYLINE: By KATHARINE Q. SEELYE 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
A week after the NATO bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade, President Clinton was finally able to express his condolences directly to Chinese leaders today in a telephone call that also touched briefly on Chinese efforts to gain entry to the World Trade Organization.
While most of the half-hour conversation was devoted to Washington's regret about the bombing, which killed three Chinese citizens, Mr. Clinton also took the opportunity to say that Chinese entry into the trade organization would benefit both countries, officials said. 
 Despite the cloud cast by the bombings, and longstanding concerns in Congress about China, the Clinton Administration still hopes that trade talks can resume within the next month and that China, which has continued its trade talks with Europe, can join the world organization this fall.
President Clinton had been trying to call Jiang Zemin, the Chinese President, since NATO bombs mistakenly fell on the embassy last Friday. But China, which opposed the NATO war with Yugoslavia from the beginning, went into a public rage when its embassy was hit and rebuffed Mr. Clinton's overtures -- until Thursday night, when it signaled a willingness to ease the tensions.
The Chinese Ambassador's visit to Mr. Clinton at the White House on Thursday night led to the phone conversation today. The White House spokesman, Joe Lockhart, described the conversation as constructive.
"The President once again expressed his sincere regrets and condolences to President Jiang and the Chinese people concerning the tragic accident of last week," Mr. Lockhart told reporters. "The President expressed his desire that we move beyond this tragic accident in our relationship," he said, adding that both sides needed to "continue working" on winning China access to the trade organization.
Mr. Lockhart said the Chinese leader "took the opportunity to express his views," but he would not characterize Mr. Jiang's side of the conversation or say whether he accepted the President's apology.
The official New China News Agency gave no clues about Mr. Jiang's reaction either, saying only that he had taken note of Mr. Clinton's apology. It focused on the bombing, which it described as an outrageous act that had shocked the world and generated sympathy for China. But it did not vilify the United States, as Mr. Jiang had done the day before, and did not demand an end to NATO bombing, as it has done before.
Rather, the news agency said Mr. Jiang repeated China's view that there was a "pressing need" for the United States to conduct an investigation into the incident and to make the results public. China had previously demanded that those responsible for the error be punished, but that demand was not included today.
News of the call was quickly disseminated by the news agency and featured on China Central Television, suggesting that the Government is eager to portray the United States as having bowed to its demands. It waited two days to publicize Mr. Clinton's first apology.
Despite the severe strains between the two countries, officials in Washington and Beijing were exploring when and where trade talks between the United States and China might resume. American officials said it would be up to China to determine when a decent interval had elapsed and put the trade talks back on track.
Charlene Barshefsky, the United States trade representative, said today, "We don't have any specific plans to meet with the Chinese next week." She said that she thought China wanted to "remain engaged" on the trade group issue but that "we will have to work out the specific time frame."
Robert Cassidy, a trade negotiator for China, had planned a trip there next week. Now, officials said, that meeting has been postponed at least another week. Officials said they are seeking a neutral site like Geneva, where the agency is based.
Even as the two leaders engaged in their delicate dance toward easing tensions, the governor of China's central bank indicated that his country was willing to advance the trade talks. He said today that the United States should stop demanding any more concessions from China on joining the trade organization.
Gene Sperling, the President's economic adviser, said the bombing had not changed the requirements China has to meet to join the group, which would lower Chinese trade barriers and make the country conform with global trade rules. "China's joining the W.T.O. on solid commercial terms is strongly in both countries' interest," he said, "not that there's been some alteration in leverage."
Some in Congress also indicated their eagerness. Senator Max Baucus, Democrat of Montana, and about two dozen other Senators from both parties sent the President a letter vowing to support permanent most-favored-nation trading status for China. This would eliminate China's need to seek annual approval for its access to American markets -- and would eliminate Congress's use of the trade vote as a chance to criticize China's rights record. Congress has become even leerier since allegations surfaced that Beijing stole American nuclear secrets.
