HEADLINE: Wheels Bolognese;
Ducati, Italy's Top Motorcycle Maker, Seeks Niche in the U.S.

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: BOLOGNA, Italy

 BODY:
Federico Minoli is not sure if he is selling a luxury accessory, a style of life or a means of transportation.
It is probably a bit of all three, for Mr. Minoli is the new president and chief executive of Ducati S.p.A., the renowned Italian motorcycle maker. And while sales of Ducati's two-wheelers are booming in Europe, where clogged cities welcome anything with fewer than four wheels, Ducati and the builders of other Italian motorcycle classics are casting their net farther afield. 
 Lifting a chapter from the textbook of Italian luxury icons like Gucci and Bulgari and melding it with the profitable formula Harley-Davidson used to create an image out of a pair of wheels, these companies are looking to global markets, notably the United States.
"It's a business opportunity," said Mr. Minoli, who favors jeans and sweaters over ties and suits, "twinned with passion and image."
The Italian drive lifts the spirits of executives in the industry, which boasts a long tradition of making spirited two-wheelers, but whose lack of marketing skill and financial savvy has nearly caused some venerable brands to disappear.
The potential for profit in tapping other markets has not escaped American investors. Last year, the Trident Rowan Group in New York bought out Moto Guzzi S.p.A., another motorcycle maker, and took it public this March. Earlier, Texas Pacific Group, based in Fort Worth, acquired Ducati, which it subsequently took public on the New York Stock Exchange
 Ducati's American depository receipts have been flat since they began trading between $31 and $32 nearly two months ago. On Friday, the A.D.R.'s, each representing 10 common shares, closed at $29.75.
And stock market analysts remain wary. "It's a tough market to get into," said Robert Mescal, who follows initial public offerings at the Institute for Econometric Research in Deerfield Park, Fla. "You're looking at big bucks to get started, and the Japanese and the Americans are not going to give up easily."
Admittedly, Italy has just a sliver of the American market, and little hope of taking any significant share from Japanese giants like Honda and Yamaha, which have parlayed a mix of low-cost manufacturing and high-technology innovation into market dominance. But motorcycle sales are booming again, as baby boomers who flirted with the open road in the 1960's now have the income and the time to don helmets.
So Italian companies like Ducati, whose $263 million of revenues make it the nation's leader, as well as Moto Guzzi, Cagiva and Aprilia, are faring better in Europe and hope to carve off a little of the upper end of the market in the United States. With a wave of sexy new models, they are seeking to exploit the cachet of all things Italian, promoting their bikes as two-wheel Ferraris or the highway equivalent of a Gucci loafer or Versace scarf. Ducati, copying Harley, is opening motorcycle shops, with apparel sections and espresso bars, in the United States.
The Italian crusade got a lift last year when the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in New York included 21 Italian motorcycles, from a 1924 Guzzi to several 1990's Ducatis, in its wildly successful motorcycle show. "The Italians bring design excellence to everything they do," said Ultan Guilfoyle, deputy curator of the Guggenheim exhibit. "And that is very apparent in their motorcycles."
Yet Ducati, he added, provides a textbook case of how brilliant Italian design is often undercut by poor management.
In 1996, Texas Pacific took control of Ducati from Claudio and Gianfranco Castiglioni, brothers who amassed a fortune selling zippers, then sank it into their real passion -- motorcycles. The Castiglionis acquired Ducati, then nearly bankrupt, in 1983 from the Italian Government, which had bought it in the 1950's from the founding Ducati family.
Despite Ducati's reputation for design and technical innovation, the Castiglionis left the company without a sales organization or strategy and bled it financially by siphoning profits to other projects. "We saw a great brand and a great product, a great factory, but no business around it," said Abel Halpern, a London-based financier who scouts European investment opportunities for Texas Pacific. "The hard part had already been done. The easy part was to design a business system around it."
To do so, Ducati bought business talent. Mr. Minoli, 49, a former Procter & Gamble and Playtex executive with long marketing experience on both sides of the Atlantic, was hired from Bain & Company, the consultants who worked with Texas Pacific before the Ducati purchase. To create a marketing campaign, Ducati hired Kristin Schelter, a former Hill & Knowlton executive who had worked on the Bulgari account.
David M. Gross, a former journalist and Harvard-educated lawyer who is Ducati's director of strategic planning, said the advertising budget, at about $5 million, was meager. But by piggybacking onto big spenders, Ducati makes the ad dollars go further. Neiman Marcus has included Ducatis in its men's catalogue, and Donna Karan New York is outfitting the Ducati racing team. "Now people are coming to us," Mr. Gross said. Ducati's New York flagship store, at 11th Avenue and 43d Street, cost about $250,000, also a shoestring operation.
The efforts are beginning to pay off, at least modestly. In the first quarter, Ducati increased sales 13 percent, to $74 million; motorcycle shipments to the United States rose 26 percent, to 1,541.
If imitation is the purest form of flattery, Ducati is not lacking in compliments. The new owners are also reinventing Moto Guzzi, hiring this year as chief executive Mario Scandellari, a former Ducati manager, and bringing in a nine-year Yamaha veteran, Nicola Poggio, as chief of sales. In the United States, another Yamaha manager, John Porter, was lured away to spearhead Guzzi's drive there.
To revive the American market, this year Guzzi will begin a fast, aggressive model called the Jackal, to sell for about $7,900. Last year, Guzzi sold 651 bikes in the United States, up from 401 in 1997.
"The Italians are good at interpreting life styles," Mr. Poggio said. "If I have to eat, I try to eat well; if I have to wear a watch, I try to wear a beautiful watch."
Others are following suit. Aprilia S.p.A. recently rolled out a new flagship for the United States, the RSV Mille. "The people who rode bikes in the 60's and 70's are now earning higher salaries," said Mark Wilhelm, a former Ingersoll-Rand executive who is Aprilia's marketing manager for the United States. "The kids are gone; they have more time and disposable income."
Italjet S.p.A., which produced motorcycling classics in the 1970's before bailing out to focus on scooters, is re-entering the fray with an aggressive new bike that will be tested in racing before full production begins in 2001.
"We're returning to our past," said Leopoldo Tartarini, Italjet's president and a leading Italian motorcycle designer. "The European motorcycle is still made with heart; it's still endowed with human qualities." In a swipe at the Japanese, he added, "When something is too perfect, you tire of it."
If Harley-Davidson, with its lumbering cruisers, is the Cadillac of motorcycles, and Honda and Yamaha are, well, the Honda and Toyota, the Italians want to become the Ferraris and Porsches.
Glenn Brieton buys that. "People who own them, love them," said Mr. Brieton, an audiovisual systems specialist from Lake George, N.Y., who owns two Guzzis. He became hooked on Italian motorcycles, he explained, while serving in the American Army in Italy, and bought his first Guzzi secondhand in 1989 for less than $2,000. Five years later, he picked up a second. "One of the appealing factors for a guy like me," he said, "is that they go up in value." A 1970's Guzzi in mint condition can fetch $20,000 or more. But, he added, "mainly, it's the way to go to be a little bit different."
Greg L. Salchow, who follows the motorcycle industry at Roney Capital Markets in Detroit, said enthusiasts like Mr. Brieton gave the Italians an entree. "There's always going to be a certain group of people who want the real thing," he said. Ducati and Guzzi, he added, enjoy relatively strong name recognition, while lesser-known companies like Aprilia and Italjet would have to struggle harder. "You'd have to be a very dedicated enthusiast to even know them," he said.
The long-term challenge for the Italians, said Mr. Guilfoyle of the Guggenheim, will be to attract young riders and keep the affluent market rolling when the baby boomers step off their bikes. The same challenge, of course, faces Harley-Davidson, he said, whose "buyers are old, an average 40 years old."
Moto Guzzi says its Jackal is aimed mainly at young riders. "The Jackal project leader is 31 years old," said Mr. Poggio, who is 38. "Our bet is to satisfy the hard core of Guzzi buyers, and draw new customers. The Jackal is definitely aimed at the young."
Ducati is investing $15 million to $20 million a year, about 70 percent of it in product development, Mr. Minoli said. Emulating fashion houses, Ducati is trying to build a cult around its chief designer, Pierre Terblanche, a former Volkswagen designer who learned motorcycle design from Massimo Tamburini, creator of some of Ducati's greatest models, including the 916 Superbike.
But to realize their American ambitions, said Mr. Salchow, the analyst, the near-term challenge will be less spectacular -- distribution. "They are not even in a lot of markets, except for small specialty shops," he said. "They need more models, more apparel."
Ducati's long-term goal is to have 200 exclusive stores globally. And the company is investing heavily to speed production.
"The first thing is to crank out as many as you can," Mr. Minoli said. "I don't believe in scarcity" as a marketing device to maintain Ducati's exclusive image. From 20 motorcycles a day in 1996, when Texas Pacific bought in, production at Ducati has risen to 170, creating 350 new jobs, which were so hard to fill in the full-employment area around Bologna that Ducati had to retrain women textile workers from a local lingerie manufacturer.
In the United States, Mr. Minoli said, Ducati has two constituencies: "people really serious about motorcycling, whose interest trickles down from racing, and the people who want a little of everything," adding, "They will have their Porsche -- and their Ducati."

HEADLINE: Board Proposes Rent Increases For Apartments

BYLINE: By BARBARA STEWART 

 BODY:
A proposal by the city's Rent Guidelines Board to increase rents in stabilized buildings by 2 percent to 4 percent came as no surprise to city officials, landlords or tenants Thursday night. But it has nevertheless drawn criticism: landlords say the increase is too low to cover expenses and some tenant advocates call it unfair, especially for the elderly and others with limited incomes.
The board proposed the increases -- 2 percent on one-year leases and 4 percent on two-year leases -- for the one million or so apartments in buildings operating under rent stabilization, which ties increases to overall economic indicators. 
 Increases are proposed after studies are conducted by the Rent Guidelines Board. Current mortgage rates are the lowest in nearly 20 years, and the city's economic growth is at its highest level in 10 years, according to the most recent study.
The meeting Thursday was much quieter than several in the past, when larger hikes were proposed, said Joseph J. Lhota, the Deputy Mayor for Operations. He said the proposed increases were "reasonable -- less than city and national inflation."
Christopher Athineos, whose family's business, Athineos Enterprises, owns seven residential buildings, said that even though the meeting was quiet, landlords were "not thrilled." The proposed increases would not cover maintenance costs, he said.
But Paul Podhaizer, chairman of the tenants' councils for two Coney Island buildings with a total of 1,836 apartments, said the prospect of higher rents has upset many elderly renters. Forty-seven tenants from the two buildings attended the meeting at Cooper Union, he said, making up about half the audience.
"Two and four percent may seem like pennies," he said. "But add it up, and it makes a difference in how people eat and how they live."
Erma Rabinowitz, 80, said she pays $575 a month for a two-bedroom apartment in one of the Coney Island buildings. Thirty-five years ago, when she and her husband moved in, the rent was $154, she said. "I live on Social Security," she said. "Most of my income goes for rent."
Mr. Athineos, Mr. Podhaizer and Mrs. Rabinowitz said they planned to attend the public hearing on the rent increases, scheduled on June 22, at 11 A.M., in the Great Hall at Cooper Union.

U.S. Fines Sears on Child Labor
The Department of Labor announced a $325,000 fine against Sears, Roebuck & Company after investigators uncovered 227 teen-agers working in violation of child labor laws at 44 of the 71 Sears stores they visited in 23 states. The most common violation found was that 16-year-olds and 17-year-olds were operating power-driven equipment like paper balers, freight elevators and fork lifts. Federal law bars children from running such hazardous equipment. A10.

HEADLINE: Commuter Tax Helps City Compete

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Is it really in the self-interest of commuters to repeal the New York City commuter tax, as state legislators are planning (front page, May 14)? Without the $360 million a year the tax represents, the city would have to choose between reducing services and raising taxes on city businesses or residents. Either action would weaken the city's ability to compete with other cities, putting commuter jobs and incomes at risk.
 
CHRISTOPHER JONES
New York, May 14, 1999
 
The writer is director of economic programs for the Regional Plan Association.

HEADLINE: Project to Rescue Needy Stumbles Against the Persistence of Poverty

BYLINE: By JASON DePARLE 

DATELINE: MILWAUKEE, May 14

 BODY:
Imagine what would happen if society could guarantee every poor person a path from poverty: an assured job at a sufficient wage, with child care and health care as well. How many would take it? How many would prosper?
A decade ago, an unconventional band of reformers here set out to find the answer, and their discoveries offer an unsettling new look at the prospects of low-income families at a time of a national exodus from welfare. 
 The Milwaukee experiment with guaranteed jobs, called Project New Hope, came to its scheduled close this week. But it leaves behind the most comprehensive study of poor families of the post-welfare age, with data on everything from parents' earnings to the number of hours their children watch television.
The program is widely being called a success, and it did have a modest impact in some statistical terms. But a close look at the findings, assembled by an independent team of economists, psychologists and ethnographers, suggests inner-city poverty may be even harder to alleviate than is understood.
New Hope recruited 677 low-income adults and made them a simple offer: sign up here, work 30 hours a week and your family will no longer be poor.
But only 27 percent of the main target group managed to stick with their jobs long enough to work their way out of poverty. The target group's average annual earnings were just $6,602, statistically no better than a control group of poor people not in the program.
And despite the conventional theory that going to work makes low-income adults feel better about themselves, New Hope clients showed no declines in depression and no growth in self-esteem, when compared with a control group.
Indeed, even after two years in the program, the average participant still registered levels of depression above the threshold that most psychologists consider cause for clinical referrals.
The problems that kept people from maintaining steady employment comprise a catalog of inner-city ills: drug and alcohol abuse; jealous or violent boyfriends and husbands; conflicts with employers; unreliable baby sitters and cars, and generally flagging spirits. In addition, some participants said they preferred to work less and spend more time with their families, even if it meant staying poor.
New Hope's admirers acknowledge the persistence of low earnings and high poverty rates. But they say the program still shows ways to help low-income families work somewhat more and suffer somewhat less. New Hope's generous subsidies produced demonstrable, if modest, gains in access to health insurance and formal child-care settings. The guaranteed jobs reduced the number of people who never worked at all. And by complementing paychecks with wage supplements, New Hope raised total "earnings-related income" by 16 percent, to about $8,100 a year.
In a surprise finding, the program also appeared to improve the classroom performance and educational aspirations of its participants' children, though only among boys. In describing that effect, evaluators said its statistical magnitude was roughly equal to adding 100 points to a score on the S.A.T. By the standards of social experiments, that is an unusually large improvement, and it has already caused a buzz among academics who study poor children.
Still, for inner-city adults, the main target of the nation's strict new welfare laws, the economic news remains sobering. Even with a guaranteed job at a subsidized wage, 73 percent of the main target group failed to work their way out of poverty without additional support from welfare or a second earner.
"People had the opportunity to work full time and yet they didn't do it," said Michael Wiseman, an economist at the Urban Institute, a Washington research group, who served on New Hope's advisory board. "We've discovered something new that I think is distressing."
The results challenge conventional wisdoms at both ends of the political spectrum. They suggest that poor people may have less success in replacing welfare with work than some conservatives have predicted. But they also suggest that the reasons many people fail to work stretch far beyond the economic barriers -- low wages and scarce jobs -- that many liberals have cited.
Mr. Wiseman said the results particularly "call into question the shortage of jobs as the explanation for poverty," since participants chose to stop working or failed to work full time even when subsidized jobs were assured.
 
Behind Modest Results, A River of Optimism
 New Hope was not technically a welfare-to-work program since it included people not on welfare. Indeed, if anything, it offers an optimistic look at the prospects of those now leaving the rolls because the project operated under favorable conditions: It had the benefit of Milwaukee's unusually strong economy; it worked with volunteer clients who had more motivation and work experience than the average welfare recipient, and it offered them unusually generous benefits.
Yet even counting informal work, like baby-sitting or hair-dressing, the average participant reported working just 27 hours a week, or about 10 percent more than members of a control group. In a world where anti-poverty programs often produce no gains at all -- or even bring negative consequences -- these modest results are being treated, curiously, as resounding good news.
Linda Stewart, who runs the welfare program for the Republican Governor, Tommy G. Thompson, said it "validates our belief that a work-based social contract" will "help reduce poverty in the years ahead." Olivia A. Golden, who oversees welfare programs for President Clinton, said New Hope had brought "very impressive results in helping families stay in jobs and improve the well-being of children."
New Hope grew from conversations in the early 1980's between David Riemer, a zealous advocate of public jobs, and his friends John Gardner and Julie Kerksick, husband-and-wife union organizers then working with the United Farm Workers. For all three, liberal advocacy took quirky turns. Mr. Gardner won an election to the Milwaukee school board and became a prominent supporter of public-school vouchers. Mr. Riemer and Ms. Kerksick became early critics of the welfare system and advocates for public jobs.
Enlisting everyone from Mayor John O. Norquist, now Mr. Reimer's boss, to the head of the gas company, they raised $17 million from corporate and government sources. Conservatives liked New Hope because of its anti-welfare ethos: participants had to work to keep their benefits. Liberals liked it because it guaranteed jobs and subsidized wages.
New Hope created community service positions, like clerical jobs with nonprofit groups, for people who could not find private work. Those posts only paid the minimum wage. But for anyone working 30 hours a week, either in the private or the community service jobs, New Hope added a cash supplement to lift them above the Government poverty threshold. For a family of three, that threshold is now $12,802.
After years of fund-raising, the program began enrolling clients in August 1994. Participants could keep their benefits for up to three years. To evaluate the results, New Hope hired the Manpower Demonstration Research Corporation, a private group based in New York City.
 
'Culture of Defeat' May Be Biggest Barrier
Ms. Kerksick, the program's director, said the program's full impact could not be gleaned merely by looking at averages. As she expected, some people were too troubled to respond at all, she said. But for others, the menu of supports -- jobs, wage supplements, child care and health care -- made a marked difference.
"You can look at this and say, 'Oh my God, look at all those people in poverty,' " she said. "Or we can look at this and say, 'Can you see any difference?' And you can see a difference."
The research examined the program's findings on two groups of participants.
The largest, comprising two-thirds of the clients, consisted of those working part time or not at all when the program began. This group most closely resembles those now leaving the welfare rolls.
A guaranteed job did help them work more. Only 6 percent did not work at all despite signing up for the program. By contrast, 13 percent of a control group did not work at all. Likewise, while only 27 percent of these New Hope participants worked their way out of poverty, that was still better than the control group, where only 19 percent did so.
Ms. Kerksick emphasized that these official estimates understated participants' real-world income, omitting self-employment (like baby-sitting) and the earnings of others living in the same household. And, she said, increased earnings were only one goal. New Hope also reduced the amount of stress participants reported and increased their access to health insurance and child care. "We were able to help people in other ways that made their lives better," she said.
Nonetheless, the modesty of the results highlights the many underlying problems. "This shows it can take people years to become steady workers, even when they are given a generous package of jobs and subsidies," said Toby Herr, director of Project Match, a Chicago employment program.
Lawrence Mead, a political scientist at New York University, said he was particularly struck by the high levels of depression participants brought with them into the program. That supports the notion that inner-city poverty is "rooted in a underlying culture of defeat," he said, rather than in the lack of jobs.
New Hope also enrolled a second group: those already employed full-time when they joined. For them, New Hope actually produced a decline in total income of about 8 percent, to about $14,100. Ms. Kerksick argued that this, too, may have been positive, since many entered the program frazzled by 50-hour work-weeks and second jobs.
But others worried the program may have slowed these workers' progress. After two years, for instance, their average hourly wage of $7.28 was about 6 percent lower than that of a control group. "It conflicts with our hopes for advancement," Ms. Herr said.
 
Surprising Side Effect Turns Up in Boys
Ms. Herr and many others, however, were impressed with New Hope's apparent effect on participants' boys. "That's the big finding," she said.
When surveyed by psychologists, teachers ranked the New Hope boys as significantly better behaved and more academically skilled than boys in a control group. And when surveyed themselves, the New Hope boys were much more likely than those in a control group to say they expected to attend college.
Researchers are unsure why this occurred. One theory is that the boys may have benefited from better child-care arrangements. With New Hope's subsidies, the percentage of boys in formal child care, like Head Start or after-school programs, was 60 percent, compared with 52 percent in the control group.
"With more supervision, they may have had less opportunity to develop problem behaviors," said Aletha Huston, a psychologist at the University of Texas, who helped evaluate the program.
Ms. Herr credited the program's caseworkers for helping place children in structured after-school settings, like scouts and boys clubs. "This shows the importance of getting kids into constructive, extra-curricular activities, even as parents move in and out of work," she said.
The girls in New Hope families also spent more time in formal child care, but they registered no classroom or behavioral improvements, partly because they were already doing better than their male counterparts. The program essentially raised the performance of inner-city boys to the level of inner-city girls.
What remains unknown is whether the boys, who ranged from ages six to 12, will continue their progress as they hit adolescence.
"It's certainly not an unqualified, 'Oh wow, we've solved all the problems,' " Ms. Huston said. "But these are striking findings for the children."

HEADLINE: Younger Than Ever -- And Freer.

BYLINE: By Sara Ivry

 BODY:
On the border between youth and middle age, 35 stands like a sentinel. Growing older can no longer be denied: drugstores offer antiwrinkle potions, radio stations pitch mellow music and the American Breast Cancer Foundation recommends the first mammogram. Even so, 35 today is younger than ever. A thousand years ago, a 35-year-old woman would be just shy of menopause and only 20 or so years from death. Now, 35 is not even halfway there; years of fertility remain, and the highest-earning period probably lies ahead. 
 These, of course, are generalizations. The women here, all 35 in '99, show the specifics. They represent the top job categories tracked by the Census Bureau; the highest concentrations are still in full-time mothering and secretarial work, but managers also make the top 10. These women, from different parts of the country and different social, economic and ethnic backgrounds, reflect a range of choices and circumstances for American women on the verge of the 21st century.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photos: Margo Benoit, homemaker Centralia, Mo., married, three children: "I have a part-time job: I sell a skin-care line. When you're at home you need to have outlets other than your children. Women in my situation, in a real rural area, you can get pretty well set in your ways, afraid to go anywhere. I don't want to get that way. I want to hop in my vehicle and drive the busy highway like everybody else."; Jodi Peikoff, lawyer Los Angeles, single, no children: "I love what I do and want to continue but with more moderation. You get to a point where you think, Have I put in enough hours? Now I can go read the books I want and have a child and do all the things that intellectually I remember are precious. My best friend got AIDS. It really put life into perspective; he's a constant reminder and reality check on what's really important and how long I want to have ridiculous hours, and how much success I need."; Earline Riggins, waitress Salt Lake City, separated, two children, one grandchild, another on the way: "I didn't have very many choices; I stayed home with my kids when they were little. I always wished to have the house with the white picket fence and just raise my children. One of the only regrets I have in life is that I didn't finish school. School and me, we just didn't get along very well."; Leah Willhite, casino worker Winnemucca, Nev., married, two children: "I got married when I was 18. I was infatuated with the word 'love.' I didn't have to work for a while because economically I didn't need to. But working you get more self-esteem. In my family, the men worked, the women stayed home. Even until this day my mother goes, 'Now don't work too hard, you shouldn't really be working, you should be with the kids."'; Victoria Sambunaris, artist New Haven, single, no children: "I remember thinking when I was a kid about how old I would be in the year 2000, and thinking, O.K., I'm going to be 35 and what kind of person would I be. I thought I would be settled down, married, maybe with a job. I envisioned something completely different from where I'm at, but I feel like I had to go through everything I went through to get where I am now."; Sue Hillard, F.B.I. agent Conroe, Tex., single, no children: "I look at other people who are balancing marriages and careers and children and their religious life and I haven't quite accomplished that balancing yet. I love what I'm doing but there's more to life than just that. When you're dealing with families that lost loved ones, or you're recovering a little baby that someone has killed and buried -- that's the stuff that's the real challenge for me."; Michell Fredericks, teacher Tucson, Ariz., divorced, no children: "There are still such societal pressures on what is meant for women to do and be, and perhaps a lot of women aren't true to themselves. I've not been open in my personal life due to professional reasons. I've been with my same-sex partner now for 10 years. I'm not in the mainstream at all. My own sexuality has been something that professionally I have hidden. That has been a challenge for me, but it's not going away."; Katharina Pellegrin, surgical resident Los Angeles, single, no children: "I'm not so sure about getting married, because I see that men are really still having a hard time interacting with a woman that's successful. A lot of the guys who are at my same level, they have three or four kids, but they have a wife to stay at home. A woman's partner is not going to stay home, so you have a double responsibility. If you're the first woman in a department and you make a mistake, people are more likely to say all women doctors are bad or don't have good hands." (Photographs by Malerie Marder for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: A Social Glacier Roars

BYLINE: By Gail Collins; Gail Collins, a member of The New York Times editorial board, is the author, with Dan Collins, of The Millennium Book" (Doubleday, 1991).

 BODY:
A century ago, people who looked ahead to 2000 had an exaggerated faith in the promise of pneumatic tubes. For some reason, when people then thought long-term, they saw everything from business correspondence to ready-cooked meals whizzing across town through underground pipes. Nobody imagined computers. Funny, the things we can't anticipate. When I was researching a book on the millennium a few years ago, I was struck by how people's predictions about the future say much more about the predictors' own era than about what will happen next.
Our ancestors were prescient about the invention of the radio, but never conceived of nuclear warfare -- French cigarette cards in 1899 depicted 21st-century aviators in open planes, dropping little bomblets on the enemies. A writer for an early edition of Ladies Home Journal -- the magazine that made its mark by exposing the evils of the patent medicine trade -- looked forward to our current era and decided that we would all be fit, very fit: "A man or woman unable to walk 10 miles at a stretch will be regarded as a weakling." (L.H.J. also forecast that the English-speaking world would kwit using ekstraneous letters like C, Q and X.) H. G. Wells, who had a particular horror of the clunky 19th-century kitchen, predicted the coal-burning stove would be replaced by a "neat little range heated by electricity" that would make cooking "a pleasant amusement for intelligent invalid ladies." We're still waiting for his self-cleaning windows. 
 Until just a few years ago, women who dreamed of an independent and fulfilling future generally started thinking they had to separate themselves from men. The utopians drew pictures of all-female communes or Amazonian civilizations, and those hoping for a real-life career in which they could control their own destinies generally applied to a convent. It was only recently -- speaking in millennial terms -- that average women saw the possibility of achieving equality in the same world as the opposite sex.
Virginia Woolf thought that having a room of one's own and an income of 500 pounds a year would do the trick. The flapper generation, born at the turn of the last century, was the first to enjoy the outer forms of sexual liberation, like social drinking and one-piece bathing suits. But even flappers knew that they had little of substance, and that their well-being still hinged on picking the right husband. "Oh, why am I a girl?" wails one of F. Scott Fitzgerald's smart, semihysterical heroines, who complains of being born a hundred years too early, "with the brains to do everything, yet tied to the sinking ship of future matrimony."
Women had no faith in their own ability to support themselves, but they had confidence that their great-granddaughters would no longer have to toss down one last cocktail, straighten their shoulders and marry the wrong man because he was the one with the money. Women who had been freed to cut their hair, discard their corsets and cuddle in the rumble seat with the football hero would eventually get the vote, get careers and get more efficient birth control, and before you knew it, the sinking ship of future matrimony would be totally optional.
History seldom evolves by tidy progression toward happy endings -- the Muslims who welcomed Jews and Christians to tolerant little kingdoms like Granada a thousand years ago got driven out by the folks who gave us the Spanish Inquisition. But in 20th-century industrialized nations, women really have kept marching forward. In America, the proportion of women in the work force has been steadily increasing since those flappers were in diapers, while the number of children they bear has been dropping.
Women are now a majority of the electorate. They receive 55 percent of the nation's college degrees and are much more willing to reinvent themselves as adults by returning to school. They live longer, and because they survive their husbands they wind up controlling a large share of the nation's personal wealth. They own more than a third of the businesses, employ a quarter of the workers and make up nearly half the students in medical and law schools. Among two-income families, nearly a quarter of the wives now earn more than their husbands.
That's a very narrow snapshot -- this is still the same planet on which many women can be killed by their male relatives for refusing to marry the man of the family's choice, or on the mere suspicion of promiscuity. The status of women has actually declined in parts of eastern Europe since the collapse of Communism. But you still might say -- with dozens of qualifications and a nervous glance over your shoulder -- that women have won. If they haven't achieved gender equality, then at least they've created the tools to get it in much of the developed world. We mate by preference, not out of necessity. We can get all the education we desire. If we do not all achieve the careers we want, at least our chances are not dictated by Y-chromosomes.
A romantic modern young man who builds castles in the air generally presumes that his future wife will help pay the mortgage. Men who may be chauvinists on the job and patriarchs in the living room will nevertheless kill to make sure their little girls get all the opportunities the little boys get. Given daughters' tendency to stick closer to their parents than sons do, there is no better hedge against old age than a female child with a good income.
But it still seems doubtful that women will soon reach full equality. At the present rate, it will be 2270 before women are as likely as men to become top managers in corporations and 2500 before there is gender parity in Congress. So far, no culture has constructed a truly level playing field for sharing family responsibilities and job opportunity. "Women in Sweden have lots of day care, but when you look at where most of their jobs are, they work in the public sector," says Andrew Cherlin, a professor of public policy at Johns Hopkins University. "You can't make partner in a Stockholm law firm working six hours a day. Mothers get more support caring for children, but it doesn't remove inequities in the labor force."
We presume that all these things will change as women use their present and potential power to remake the world. Analyses of how women will vote and set social policy, in fact, generally seem to presume that our instincts and priorities are just, well, better. Women are less enamored of the use of force, leery of quick fixes and more willing to pay more taxes for social concerns like feeding the poor.
If women continue to gain economic and political power, the government of the 21st century will probably spend more on nursing homes and home attendants for senior citizens, and on better schools. There might not necessarily be more access to abortion services but there would be stronger gun controls. Their attitudes also reflect an emotional conservatism, a fear of sudden moves or drastic action. If women get to run the show, Americans had better hope they're running it in other countries too, because our economy will probably be more regulated and less able to compete against a testosterone-fueled capitalism elsewhere.
Our attempts to hedge against disaster and provide more services might also create a larger bureaucracy. "It would have a strong safety net," says Heidi Hartmann, director of the Institute for Women's Policy Research in Washington. "It's hard to know how bureaucratic it would become. Women do tend to perhaps value security and stability more. If men spent as much time being caretakers as women, their attitude toward risk might be different, too." When most women lived on family farms, Hartmann noted, they ran the truck gardens that produced a modest but steady income from vegetable sales, while men focused on the large, high-risk crops. "Women's economic strategy was always, Well, let's make sure we have a little bit to count on here."
But all these projections say more about us now than in the future. Right now we know we want children and careers, but we don't want to be deprived of job advancement because of one or be forced to scrimp on our attention to the other. We want our husbands to take equal responsibility as parents, but are often reluctant to drop our role as the primary caregivers. James Levine of the Families and Work Institute in New York says he believes that while women often want men to do more of the parenting, "they want them to do it the 'right way,' and if Dad doesn't do it, Mom takes it back and the cycle continues.o
Levine, the author of "Working Fathers: New Strategies for Balancing Work and Family," has been running workshops on this issue for 25 years, and whether he's in Omaha talking to the agricultural extension or in midtown working with corporate executives, he hears the same complaints. One classic involves getting kids ready for school. "Dad is dressing them and the preschooler comes down with purple pants and an orange top. Mom says, 'She can't wear that,' which is saying: 'You don't know how to dress the kid. I have to do everything myself.' " Working-class parents are showing their wealthier peers a way out of this particular battle: if Dad is the only adult in the house when the kids are dressing for school, purple and orange rules. Nearly half of fathers who have municipal jobs like fireman, or service jobs like gas-station attendant, care for the children while their wives are at work. "All I do is watch the kids and work," says a Wisconsin correctional officer who chose a night shift so he could be home while his wife worked days.
That is, of course, what women have been saying for decades, and the ideal answer would be an economy that allows both sexes to advance on the job without requiring so many hours at work. In that early era we now refer to as "the 60's," many young women believed that's what the developed world would look like by the year 2000. Technology would improve productivity, creating a society in which job-sharing or 20-hour workweeks were the norm. Even single mothers would be able to pursue careers and still get home in time to pick up the kids after school. Needless to say, that leisure society wound up in the same category as the self-cleaning windows.
Instead, we got a global economy that pits the American factory worker with a 12-year-old alone at home against a third-world sweatshop in which the 12-year-olds are the workers. Unless the underlying economy changes strikingly, our future will probably involve opportunities that are limited only by our ability to come up with jerry-built solutions to the competing demands on our time.
The most significant development on the immediate horizon is the graying of the industrialized world. People 65 and over accounted for 4 percent of the U.S. population in 1900, but in 2015, some say, they could be at least 20 percent, and two-thirds will be women. If Social Security gets propped up and the political power of seniors continues to increase, those older women will consume a large portion of the national budget -- and control a hefty portion of the assets.
Our great-great-grandmothers waited a lifetime for the social glacier to creak forward an inch. Charlotte Perkins Gilman, a turn-of-the-century American utopian, spent her life agitating for the liberation of women from the chains of household duties, for a world where child care and housework would be done by well-paid, well-trained specialists who preferred that kind of career and where every family would enjoy "the professional service of cooked meals to the home." When she started writing her autobiography in the 1920's, Gilman admitted that she'd seen only the tiniest of changes after 37 years of effort: Reason has no power against feeling, and feeling older than history is no light matter,o she said philosophically. It would have been nice if she could have at least lived to order takeout pizza.
These days, you wake up one morning and a social phenomenon that you thought immutable will have vanished. I must have written at least a dozen essays decrying the fact that the entertainment industry targets boys when it creates movies and TV because everybody knows that girls will watch male heroes but boys usually won't watch girls.
It was just the other day, really, that I noticed that teen-age girls now seem to have their own TV network, WB, while teen-age boys get professional wrestling and Ninja Turtle reruns. One of the most famous WB series is "Buffy the Vampire Slayer," in which a teen-age girl rescues humanity from extinction every week. Last year she had to kill her vampire-boyfriend, and though he has been resurrected, she keeps noting that it could happen again at any time. Buffy really rides alone, just like the male heroes in the TV westerns that dominated my own childhood. The most popular was "Bonanza," the story of Ben Cartwright, a rancher and three-time widower, and his three adult sons. The Ponderosa took out wives faster than a toxic-waste dump, and even the least sophisticated viewer eventually got the message that you could not have an interesting time on the frontier if you were saddled with a woman.
At some point while I wasn't looking, the idea that girls didn't have adventures seems to have faded out of our popular culture, just like the idea that only boys get to play rock music. The most successful movie of the last decade is "Titanic," in which a young woman falls in love with a charming artist, who dies after making a long speech urging her to seize the day. She lives for about 80 years of thrills and romance before being reunited with him after death.You do have the feeling that if he hadn't drowned, he would have got in the way. I always hoped that some day women would become co-heroes with men in entertainment programming. But instead, the sexes may just be switching responsibility for suffering an untimely death in the second act. Things progress, but never exactly the way you'd expect.
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Photo: The Millennial Woman
 
How much have women changed over the last 10 centuries? Anthropology offers informed estimates of the physique of French peasants of the year 1000 and cultural history tells much about what they wore. To find a modern-day equivalent, the magazine sent scouts to comb the countrysides of France, Louisiana and Quebec. In Burgundy they found Martine Jouttier, a 40-year-old medical technician and horse breeder.
 
A French peasant woman dressed in layers, for both warmth and varying degrees of formality. Her only undergarment (not shown) was an open-necked, short-sleeved, ankle-length chemise of fine bleached linen. Over it went a heavier natural-linen dress, unfitted and of sweeping length. For modesty, the sleeves hugged the wrists and the front opening was laced close to the neck.
 
Married women wore a draped head covering of fine bleached linen with an oval opening for the face that completely covered the hair, which was pulled tightly back into a bun.
 
A braided girdle tied around the waist allowed her to hitch up the skirt. For church or festivals, she would add a tunic, also of heavy linen, dyed with madder to a rich red and trimmed with embroidered bands. She might add another braided girdle.
 
Thigh-high stockings of soft linen were cut on the bias, sewn up the back and gartered around the knee with strips. Over them went flat leather shoes with pointed toes.
 
--Anne Hollander, art and dress historian and author of "Sex and Suits" and "Seeing Through Clothes."
 
The millennial woman was not that different from today's inhabitants of central France, Switzerland, southern Germany, northern Italy and the Balkans. Living circumstances and nutrition account for the most conspicuous changes. The wear and tear of farm life and successive pregnancies would make a woman of 26 look about 40, by today's standards, with lean, hard muscles and a sturdy build but little subcutaneous fat.
 
The average woman was just about five feet tall and weighed between 100 and 110 pounds. Noses tended to be relatively long with a high bridge. Fine, slightly wavy brown hair and brown-to-hazel eyes were most common.
 
Rigorous chewing of foods that were tougher than today's developed the facial muscles, producing the sharp angle at the back of the jaw and prominent cheekbones that give the face its squarish cast. Teeth were worn flat with an edge-to-edge bite, the result of tearing food into bits.
 
Years of manual labor produced hands that were strong and sturdy. Skin would have been tanned and roughened by a lifetime of exposure. The feet would have been toughened by going barefoot for prolonged periods, with the toes squared and slightly separated.
 
-- C. Loring Brace, professor of anthropology at the University of Michigan, is author of the textbook "The Stages of Human Evolution," Fifth Edition. (Photograph by Michael O'Neill)

And Bear in Mind
(Editors' choices of other recent books of particular interest)
 
Breath and Shadows, by Ella Leffland. (Morrow, $24.) Suffused with a moonlit melancholy, this novel braids together three generations of a Danish family to pose a haunting question: What do we leave behind to prove we have ever existed?
 
BYRON: Child of Passion, Fool of Fame, by Benita Eisler. (Knopf, $35.) A biography finds that the poet was a spoiled brat, more interested in being a lord than a writer, with a private life that was even a bigger mess than anyone knew.
 
A Dangerous Friend, by Ward Just. (Peter Davison/Houghton Mifflin, $23.) As its well-meaning civilian hero attempts to find an American officer captured in Vietnam, this novel emerges as an allegory for our country's place in the increasingly deranged world of the mid-1960's.
 
ENGLAND, ENGLAND, by Julian Barnes. (Knopf, $23.) This satirical novel suggests that while there may always be an England, its immediate future looks more like a theme park than an empire.
 
FOR THE RELIEF OF UNBearable Urges, by Nathan Englander. (Knopf, $22.) Ambitious short stories by a 29-year-old former yeshiva student from New York, now living in secular Israel; his characters are able to flourish in a borderland between the author's old world and that new one.
 
HOME TOWN, by Tracy Kidder. (Random House, $25.95.) The author turns his investigative eye on Northampton, Mass., a city of 30,000 that most young natives leave when they grow up but that is changing its blue collars to white through the steady arrival of newcomers.
 
HUMAN VOICES, by Penelope Fitzgerald. (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, paper, $12.) In her wry novel set during the blitz, the author uses the BBC's Broadcasting House as a microcosm in which the 9 o'clock news kept Britain abreast of the progress of its finest hour.
 
Lords of the Horizons: A History of the Ottoman Empire, by Jason Goodwin. (John Macrae/Holt, $32.50.) A journalist and travel writer illuminates the history and culture of a former seat of imperial splendor, from its humble origins to glittering eminence to lumbering decline.
 
THE PITY OF WAR, by Niall Ferguson. (Basic Books, $30.) The traditional views on the causes of World War I are called into question, and the author suggests that had England stayed at home, the world might be a different place today.
 
WINSTON AND CLEMENTINE: The Personal Letters of the Churchills, edited by Mary Soames. (Houghton Mifflin, $35.) The private correspondence of one of the century's most fascinating couples, edited by their youngest daughter, traces the "love & honour" of one of "the gt romances" through the "colour & jostle of the high-way" of the 20th century.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 30; Column 2; Book Review Desk 

LENGTH: 1116 words

HEADLINE: Flipping Burgers

BYLINE: By Jason DeParle; Jason DeParle, a national correspondent for The Times, writes about poverty issues.

 BODY:

No Shame
 in My Game
 The Working Poor
 in the Inner City.
 By Katherine S. Newman.
 388 pp. New York:
 Alfred A. Knopf/The Russell Sage Foundation. $27.95. 
 Katherine S. Newman got the inspiration for this book in a Harlem traffic jam. Crawling crosstown in the back of a cab, she stared out at one of the country's most famous pockets of poverty and saw throngs of people heading to work, just as in blue-collar neighborhoods. As it happened, Newman, an anthropologist now at Harvard, was on her way to a conference on the poor -- the jobless, welfare-dependent poor who dominate public discussion. "What do we know about the others, the hard-working people of communities like Harlem struggling to get to work?" she wondered. "Not much."
In "No Shame in My Game," a study of Harlem fast-food workers, Newman champions poor workers and seeks to reorient the poverty debate. She wants to de-emphasize self-defeating behaviors like teen-age pregnancy, and to stress what she sees as the larger issues: the injustice of low wages and the apathy of more prosperous citizens. These low-income workers "are not people whose values need re-engineering," she writes. "They work hard at jobs the rest of us would not want because they believe in the dignity of work."
Newman's effort to recast the inner-city poor as neglected, working-class heroes fails on two counts. Even her highly sympathetic portraits make many of them seem less striving and more party to their troubled circumstances than she realizes. And the world is not as unaware of their economic woes as she believes.
Still, she is right to recognize that most poor people do work, at least sporadically. The problem is that work alone often fails to transform their lives. With tougher welfare laws sweeping the country, this is a crucial point -- even programs that get people into jobs may fail to uplift the ghettos. Newman argues that the problem is mainly economics: low wages and scarce jobs. But her findings suggest a more complicated set of issues. Newman and her graduate students interviewed 300 workers and job applicants at a fast-food franchise she calls "Burger Barn." The students spent four months working behind the counters, and the research team followed 12 workers over a longer period. While Newman heralds the "rich, detailed data that poured in," this is not a book of rich, detailed portraits. The workers are known only by first names -- Jamal, Kyesha, Tiffany, Latoya -- and they blur together. There is no narrative or human drama; the organization is topical.
Nonetheless, Newman asks interesting questions, and some new insights emerge. Examining the demeaned "McJob," she finds it more intellectually challenging and socially rewarding than most outsiders would guess. Yes, abuse flows in from disgruntled customers, including mocking peers. But the workers bond among themselves to "build a moral defense of their work." Yes, wages are low and the work is hard. But the Burger Barn managers mix profit motives with "a missionary impulse" toward rescuing inner-city youth. "The fast-food industry is actually very good about internal promotion," Newman writes.
This discovery of a management track is an interesting bit of news, since these are supposed to be dead-end jobs. But like many of Newman's findings, it is at odds with her larger view of a class-bound society where opportunity is "distressingly limited." She does not resolve -- often she does not even acknowledge -- such contradictions. Newman argues that her Burger Barn workers are filled with mainstream aspirations about school, work and family. And she relays some uplifting stories of tenacity against the odds. A particularly affecting tale involves William, a fat, bullied teen-ager who takes refuge in his work despite the derision of others his age.
But Newman sees everyone she meets in a similarly flattering light, as if she is afraid to make any judgments. "Latoya does not lack the desire to go to school, just the life circumstances that would make more education feasible," Newman writes. What "life circumstances"? As a "heavy partygoer," Latoya dropped out of school at 16 and had a baby. Her mother said keep studying but, Latoya said, "I was like, 'Yeah, whatever.' "She winds up with three children by two or three men (the number of fathers is unclear). Latoya is not even poor. While she earns about $15,000, Jason, the father of her third child, is a union carpenter who earns $15 an hour, or about $30,000 a year. Newman vigorously defends the "irregular social structures" of the inner-city family. But if Jason and Latoya would marry, their family income would top $45,000. Finally they do marry -- and they escape poverty. Jason's earnings are unusually high, but Latoya could leave poverty even if Jason earned half as much. "Irregular social structures" -- the lack of stable marriages -- are clearly part of the problem.
Newman is particularly puzzling when she says American society assigns low-wage workers "the untouchable status of the Indian low castes." In fact, support for low-wage workers has been growing at a noteworthy pace. Two years ago, a Republican balanced-budget bill found $24 billion over five years to subsidize health care for low-income families. And that pales next to the $30 billion the country now offers the working poor in annual wage supplements. The program, called the earned income tax credit, provides annual cash bonuses of more than $3,700 per family. This may or may not be enough, but it is scarcely apathy or scorn. Newman races past the program -- the centerpiece of policy toward low-wage workers -- in two paragraphs.
Of all the workers she meets, Jamal steals her heart. She is impressed by the "doting love he has for his young wife," Kathy, and finds him "something of a hero" for boarding a bus to a minimum-wage job each morning at 5. But as Newman goes on to explain, Kathy is not his young wife -- she is his girlfriend. She ran away from home to join him at 16, and soon they had a child. The infant was put in foster care after Jamal apparently struck her. His temper "has its explosive side," and he has had problems with cocaine. Newman sees Jamal as a striving worker blocked at every turn. He has a less romantic view, describing himself as "going from here to here to here, and doing this and that." It is little wonder that he is adrift and depressed -- his mother is a longtime crack addict, and he has never known his father.
No doubt Jamal has appealing qualities and untapped gifts; many needy people do. No doubt better jobs would help. But as Newman inadvertently shows, his problems stretch far past Burger Barn.

LENGTH: 687 words

HEADLINE: Avoiding a Crash

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris; Floyd Norris writes editorials for The Times. He is a former markets editor and columnist for the paper.

 BODY:

THE RETURN
 OF DEPRESSION ECONOMICS
 By Paul Krugman.
 176 pp. New York:
 W. W. Norton & Company. $23.95. 
 In late 1994, just when Mexico seemed on the verge of entering the economic big leagues, its currency suddenly collapsed and the country entered a deep recession that would have been much worse had not Washington put together a $50 billion rescue plan. The blame was laid at the feet of Mexican authorities. They had allowed Mexico to borrow too much and let the peso become overvalued. Then they mishandled monetary policy and devalued the currency in a way that proved they were inept.
Having persuaded themselves that the so-called "tequila crisis" was all about Mexico and not about the rest of us, investors could go back to business as usual in the rest of the world. And they could be stunned -- shocked, really -- when some very similar problems devastated Asian countries in 1997 and 1998.
Paul Krugman, an economist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, recalls in his excellent new book, "The Return of Depression Economics," that Guillermo Calvo, a prominent economist then at the World Bank, kept telling people after the Mexican crisis that while Mexico had made mistakes, the important question was, "Why was so large a punishment imposed for so small a crime?"
The answer is neither simple nor certain. Part of it surely lies in the way the world's financial system has evolved in recent decades, with big flows of capital moving into countries that are popular with investors and then moving back out again very rapidly. As Krugman notes, countries with controls on capital movements have tended to do better in the crisis environment than those without. That is a long way from conventional economic wisdom, and is one reason that reading Krugman as he glances over the economic history of the past several decades is both enjoyable and thought-provoking.
The title may be a bit misleading. Krugman does not think the world is about to descend into a 1930's-style depression. In fact, he argues that such a fate can be avoided if we instead remember the economic theories born of the Depression, most notably the work of Lord Keynes. Depression economics, Krugman says, "is the study of situations where there is a free lunch, if we can only figure out how to get our hands on it, because there are unemployed resources that could be put to work." He thinks that in some places, most notably Japan, it is time for government to actively seek inflation. I think he is too severe on Japanese policy makers, who finally are pulling out all the stops to get their economy moving, but Japan would be in better shape now if Krugman's advice had been heeded earlier.
Krugman argues that now, as in the 1930's, there is too much emphasis on economic orthodoxy and on somehow restoring the confidence of investors. To be sure, confidence is of immense importance at certain times, and a major reason that country after country suffered currency collapses was that investors took flight. But countries facing crises now are not going to be any more successful than Herbert Hoover was at winning confidence by slashing public works spending while their economies stagnate.
What appalls Krugman now is not the problems the world faces but the reluctance to learn from them. "Those who worried about balanced budgets back when uncontrollable deficits were the problem suddenly insist that raising taxes and cutting spending will actually prevent a recession, because it will improve confidence," he says. "Those who wanted stable prices back when inflation was the risk now claim that 'managed inflation' will somehow backfire."
The reality to Krugman is that there are few, if any, economic policies that are always right for all countries. What you should do depends on where you are and on an ability to think clearly about how you got there. There are times when capital controls can work, and when they would be disastrous. There are times when fixed exchange rates can work wonders, and times when they can blow up. That is not the easy answer, but it is the right one.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 36; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 841 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Scott Veale

 BODY:

Everybody Was So Young:
Gerald and Sara Murphy. A Lost Generation Love Story
By Amanda Vaill. Broadway, $15.
The Murphys were a dazzling, rich American couple who knew and entertained just about everybody who was anybody in Paris and on the French Riviera in the 1920's, from Fitzgerald to Picasso. In 1998 our reviewer, Brooke Allen, called this "a marvelously readable biography" by "a skillful and compassionate writer."
 
About a Boy
By Nick Hornby. Riverhead, $12.95.
Will Freeman is a smug but aimless London bachelor in his 30's who devises a dating scheme to tap the market in sexy divorced women by pretending to be a single dad and joining a support group full of single mothers. Before long, though, he runs into a troubled 12-year-old boy who sees right through him, and the two become unlikely soul mates. "Hornby . . . combines a skilled, intuitive appreciation for the rigors of comic structure with highly original insights about the way the enchantments of popular culture insinuate themselves into middle-class notions of romance," Hal Espen wrote here in 1998.
 
A Walk in the Woods:
Rediscovering America on the Appalachian Trail
By Bill Bryson. Broadway, $13.
The author chronicles in breezy, good-humored fashion his five-month struggle to hike the 2,100-mile Appalachian Trail from Georgia to Maine. Bryson is "a satirist of the first rank, one who writes (and walks) with Chaucerian brio," Dwight Garner wrote here last year. Searching for Yellowstone: Ecology and Wonder in the Last Wilderness, by Paul Schullery (Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $14), is an environmental and human history of Yellowstone National Park by a longtime park ranger and administrator. "Schullery . . . has given us a refreshingly unhyperbolic look at the place he loves," Michael Parfit wrote here in 1997.
 
Freedomland
By Richard Price. Island/Dell, $7.99.
This novel tracks the racial turmoil that erupts after a white woman turns up in a New Jersey city and claims her 4-year-old son was abducted by a black carjacker. " 'Freedomland' is infinitely more than a detective story," Francine Prose said here last year. "It aspires to the heft and weight of a 19th-century Russian classic."
 
WORMHOLES: Essays and Occasional Writings
By John Fowles. Owl/Holt, $16.
This grab bag of musings by the 73-year-old English novelist covers a lot of territory -- from autobiographical pieces to cantankerous forays into politics and culture. "The book is as various, quirkily learned, beguiling, opinionated and, in parts, as sumptuously written as Fowles's fiction," Roger Kimball wrote here last year.
 
The Iron Tracks
By Aharon Appelfeld. Schocken, $12.
This Israeli novel is about a concentration camp survivor who wanders through Austria buying sacred books and other remnants of the Jewish culture that once flourished there while searching for the Nazi officer who murdered his parents. "Appelfeld's controlled fiction compresses large themes into small spaces," Jonathan Rosen said here in 1998. Bronstein's Children, by Jurek Becker (University of Chicago, $15), is another novel about the psychic aftershocks of the Holocaust, in which an 18-year-old German Jew in 1973 stumbles onto his father and two other camp survivors as they torture a former Nazi guard. "Becker, writing simply and clearly in an unstrained narrative, speaks with the voice of knowledge," Eva Figes said here in 1988.
 
The Collected Poems of Amy Clampitt
Knopf, $19.95.
Clampitt's poetry is full of restless motion and energy as she evokes places like the Quaker village in Iowa where she was born and Greenwich Village, where she cultivated a resolute bohemianism. In 1997 in the Book Review, Christopher Benfey called this posthumously published collection a testament to an "extraordinary life's work."
 
A Beautiful Mind
By Sylvia Nasar. Touchstone/Simon & Schuster, $16.
This biography of John Nash, the Nobel Prize-winning developer of game theory, follows him from his early career through his crippling bouts of schizophrenia to his recovery years later. The author, who writes about economics for The New York Times, "offers a remarkable look into the arcane world of mathematics and the tragedy of madness," Simon Singh wrote here in 1998.
 
Green Fires:
Assault on Eden. A Novel of the Ecuadorian Rainforest
By Marnie Mueller. Curbstone, $13.95.
A former Peace Corps volunteer revisits the jungles of coastal Ecuador on her honeymoon in 1969 and becomes involved in a battle between the native people and American oil companies. "The characters are well drawn, and the novel has adventure, intrigue and romance as well as politics," one critic said in 1994.
 
Havana Dreams: A Story of a Cuban Family
By Wendy Gimbel. Vintage, $13.
The lives of three unhappy women -- a wealthy bourgeoise, her daughter and the daughter's child by Fidel Castro -- provide a striking perspective on Cuba and its odd destiny. "The result is a shimmering book," Alma Guillermoprieto said here last year. Scott Veale

HEADLINE: FILM;
Choose One Memory to Take With You, He Asks

BYLINE: By B. RUBY RICH; B. Ruby Rich is the author of "Chick Flicks: Theories and Memories of the Feminist Film Movement."

 BODY:
THE afterlife. Today it rivals Vancouver as one of the most popular movie locations. Ever since Ernst Lubitsch sent a departed mortal hurtling back to earth in "Heaven Can Wait," heaven itself has been fascinating Hollywood. When Wim Wenders sent his angels earthward in "Wings of Desire," a trend was reborn. What with John Travolta, Robin Williams and Brad Pitt all going celestial, heaven has never been more hip. Heaven help future historians tempted to interpret this era's spiritual proclivities from a close reading of recent movies. Luckily, they -- and we -- now have some help from the Japanese director Hirokazu Kore-eda. His new film, "After Life" (at the Film Forum) redefines our notions of what comes next in a charming fable that's as profound as it is simple.
"After Life" asks its audience to imagine that humans, after death, enter a sort of purgatory that resembles nothing so much as an aging school building or government depository. There, a helpful staff informs them one by one of their status, offers sympathy ("So sorry for your loss") and then provides assistance with the task that confronts them: to choose one memory out of their entire life to take with them for all eternity. Everything else about their life on earth will be forgotten. 
 Already, "After Life" has proved its ability to cast a spell over its audiences, in part perhaps because of its unusual combination of fiction and fact. What memory would you take with you? What would you pick? In France, the film took the grand prize at the Nantes Festival. In Argentina, where memory and amnesia regularly duke it out for ownership of history, it struck a particular chord, picking up a distributor instantly and winning awards for both Best Picture and Best Screenplay at the Buenos Aires Film Festival. At festival screenings in the United States, it has acquired cult status. Even at the Sundance Film Festival, "After Life" managed to transfix its notoriously untransfixable crowd.
Mr. Kore-eda seems to believe that the very essence of humanity is memory, if his recent career is any indication. In "Maborosi," the feature debut that brought him international fame in 1995, a young widow is haunted by grief over her husband's suicide even after a new marriage offers happiness. Mr. Kore-eda's contemplative regard for this character and the exquisite gravity with which he invested his images of her memory and sorrow captured audiences and awards.
But "Maborosi" told only part of the story. Mr. Kore-eda made eight documentaries, before and after "Maborosi," exploring the lives of Japan's outsiders, victims and renegades. The most recent, "Without Memory," tracks the astonishing case of a man who was the victim of a botched medical procedure. He was left with his memories intact but stripped of the ability to form new ones. In effect, he remains condemned to an eternal present excavated by continual forgetting.
The third of this trio of memory pictures, "After Life" synthesizes the lessons learned along the way. Whereas "Maborosi" was a polished fictional construct, this time Mr. Kore-eda decided to retain his documentary style and process. He investigated the nature of memory by visiting temples, parks and homes for the elderly to pose his question: If they could carry only one memory with them after death, which would they choose? After 6 months and 500 interviews, Mr. Kore-eda came to an unexpected realization. "Originally, I intended to 'steal' their stories," he said through a translator at the Sundance festival. "But I was so compelled by the authenticity of those stories, and their facial expressions as they told them, that I realized I could never beat them and just decided to cast them as they are."
The director's willingness to learn from his own process made "After Life" a hybrid in which scripted actors and nonactors are filmed in the act of actually retrieving their own memories. Mr. Kore-eda eschewed big-movie techniques in favor of natural light, 16-millimeter cameras and extended shots to avoid unsettling his nonprofessionals. It's risky , but it pays off brilliantly. One woman particularly captivates audiences. She recalls a joyous girlhood moment, when her favorite brother bought her a red dress to wear to a special dance and then showed her off to his friends afterward. All these years later, she's still intoxicated by the memory. Other characters recall other memories: the taste of rice balls cooked in a bamboo grove, the feel of a breeze blowing in the window of a tram, the sight of clouds in the sky.
"After Life" is hardly a sober film, however. Its purgatory staff, for instance, assists the dead by filming their memories, for their reliving as well as for the collection they solemnly call "the archives." In one hilarious scene, they even order up a lifetime of surveillance videos for a man who needs a refresher course on his own life. A documentary filmmaker all his life, Mr. Kore-eda cannot resist poking fun at the film production process itself while gently considering the relationship between a film crew and its subjects.
Still, it is memory and its unreliability, its vagaries and gaps, that fascinate Mr. Kore-eda. "I developed this idea, at a young age, that you forget everything, and then you die," he said.
He forged such beliefs in his own childhood, living with a grandfather who started losing his lucidity, then developed dementia and senility as Mr. Kore-eda grew up. Alzheimer's had not yet been named. "One day, he no longer recognized our faces," Mr. Kore-eda recalled. "Finally, he could not recognize his own." Haunted by this experience, Mr. Kore-eda imagined an alternative: "What if you got to hold onto one thing?" Out of this idea, first conceived 10 years ago, Mr. Kore-eda developed "After Life."
His film continually challenges viewers to sift and sort artifice from authenticity, yet the line between the fictional and the factual can never be entirely clarified. One character, for example, recalls her life of prostitution, then chooses to remember a tender encounter that was the exception to the rule. Or was it? Her story changes drastically as she gets deeper into its telling. Surely she must be an actress with a script? Not quite. Now an actress, she was once a well-known Japanese porn star.
Mr. Kore-eda noted how the film's production was shaped by unusual transformations: "There was a script, but the actors on the set were so moved by the stories of the real people that they began to insert their own lives into the script. She wanted to tell this story." It's not surprising to learn that the film's title was suggested by a Japanese vaudeville expression meaning "neither here nor there."
If audiences wonder to what extent "After Life" reflects Japanese attitudes toward life after death, Mr. Kore-eda avoids grandiose claims. Asked about whether the bells heard tolling in "After Life" are a reference to the 108 chimes at Japanese New Year for the 108 sins of man, he said, "I think I just like the sound of bells." He happily discusses a range of Japanese faiths: that there is a heaven and hell; that there is nothing after death, according to scientific empiricism; that the divide between the brain and the objective world is no longer clear. He links this last view to Oliver Sacks's study "A Leg to Stand On," which has had a great influence in promoting the idea of mind-body connection in Japan.
In Mr. Kore-eda's films, what stands out most is the compassion with which characters are imbued. This is a director who is infinitely patient, prepared to wait and to listen. Perhaps this capacity for empathy was forged in childhood, when his family experienced Japan's postwar economic boom of the 1960's within the confines of a poor Tokyo neighborhood called Gumma. "My family was very poor," he said. "We drew our water from a well, our bath was heated with firewood. It was hardly evocative of metropolitan Tokyo life."
If his grandfather lost memory, his father retained it: "He was in the military. He became a prisoner of war in Manchuria and spent two years at hard labor in Siberia. I believe that the deaths of his fellow P.O.W.'s and friends in the camps in Siberia had a major impact on his life." His mother, in turn, loved to watch Hollywood movies on television, especially "those starring Joan Fontaine or Ingrid Bergman," he recalled.
It is out of this mix of pleasure and deprivation, trauma and memory, that Mr. Kore-eda has emerged as one of Japan's most original cinematic talents.
"After Life" taps into a wellspring of emotion in audiences drawing on intensely different public and political histories. In Japan, its sold-out screenings are a striking phenomenon for a culture that prefers to dismiss its memories. As Mr. Kore-eda points out, "The Japanese, after all, at the end of every year have a bonenkai, literally, a year-forgetting party, in which all the events of that year are put aside." Such a party is unimaginable, of course, in American culture, where memory can be malleable or marketable, exposed on daytime television or sold on the memoir circuit, rewritten or restored, but never discarded.
Here, too, "After Life" has riveted audiences. People leave the theater strangely silent, caught up in revery, perhaps reviewing the events of their life. Mr. Kore-eda, by fashioning a story of death and memory, has slyly delivered a movie that reaffirms life -- and the magic of movies.
