SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1419 words

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey;
High-Tech Company Offices Expand in Monmouth

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
TO gain a presence in this country, J. D. S. Fitel, a Canadian company that develops fiber-optic products, opened a 14,000-square-foot office last June at Monmouth Executive Center, not far from Routes 9 and 33 in Freehold Township in Monmouth County. Since then the company has leased an additional 3,500 square feet there.
In Holmdel, also in Monmouth, Market Ware International, a computer software firm that focuses on servicing banks and financial brokerages, grew from a 1,500-square-foot office to 11,400 square feet of space at Holmdel Executive Center, close to Exit 114 of the Garden State Parkway. It is considering leasing an additional 7,600 square feet. 
 In the last 18 months high-technology companies such as these have leased about 500,000 square feet of space in Monmouth County, according to the Schultz Organization, a commercial brokerage in Woodbridge. The space includes offices alone and offices combined with warehouse, research and development and light assembly facilities.
The activity is helping to absorb available space in the one-time resort area's 6.3-million-square-foot office market. In the first quarter the vacancy rate for Class A space fell to 2.8 percent, from 6.3 percent the year before, and the rate for Class B space dropped to 11.7 percent from 16.9 percent, according to Grubb & Ellis, the national commercial brokerage.
The brokerage put the average annual rents for Class A space at $20.89 and for Class B space at $18.19. Average rents for space in North Jersey are $25.98 and $21.26, respectively.
Jonathan B. Schultz, president of the Schultz Organization, said that because of the county's lower rents, access to skilled labor and highways as well as its projected residential growth he expected the flow of such firms to continue into the next millennium. This flow, along with an infusion of back-office operations of service firms, "will create the potential for new construction," he said.
And build-to-suit projects have sprouted. One is a 138,000-square-foot building recently completed in the Eatontown Business Park, off Route 35 in Eatontown, for TSSL Laboratories, the research and development arm of TYCO Submarine Systems Ltd., based in Morristown. In addition, work began last week on the renovation of an empty 737,000-square-foot building in Tinton Falls into modern office space. The developer is the Matrix Development Group of Cranbury.
The activity by high-technology firms in the county also reflects the broader trend of such firms expanding in or relocating to New Jersey. The state has identified the industry as one of five influencing New Jersey's economic growth. The others are health care, financial services, entertainment and logistics, which collectively added 37,000 of the 78,000 jobs the state gained in 1998.
THE high-technology sector had the greatest expansion, adding nearly 14,000 jobs, a 5.2 percent rise over 1997, for a total of 279,400 high-technology jobs statewide in 1998, state figures show.
Some of those jobs are filtering into Monmouth County for several reasons, industry professionals said. Among them is the fact that it is home to the Army's Fort Monmouth in Eatontown, which has long been associated with developing high-technolgy communications systems, as well as to the telecommunication giants AT&T and Lucent Technologies. The three are among the county's largest employers.
In January AT&T renewed its commitment to the county. It completed the renovation of an 836,000-square-foot building and built additional structures, totaling 1.4 million square feet, at a 262-acre campus off Laurel Avenue in Middletown. The site is AT&T's main research and development complex.
Of the company's statewide work force of 24,500 employees 22 percent now work in Monmouth County, said Ritch Blasi, an AT&T spokesman.
Lucent has a statewide workforce of 20,000. Some 5,300 of them work in Monmouth County, where the company has concentrated its research and development in optical networking and software, said William Price, a Lucent spokesman .
Given that scientific base, Edward J. DaCosta, a senior vice president at the Iselin office of CB Richard Ellis, another national commercial brokerage said: "Many high-tech companies are drawn to the county because they have government contracts with the Army or working relationships with AT&T or Lucent."
For example Lucent, through its New Ventures Group, helps launch new technology firms, including its first in New Jersey -- Persystant Technologies, a developer of software that integrates voice and data communications over the Internet. Launched this month, Persystant is based in Eatontown and is owned by Lucent and Unixpros, a software development company also based in Eatontown.
Mr. DaCosta said another draw for large and small high-technology firms was the availability of skilled labor. Mr. Schultz added that with the state's unemployment rate at 4.6 percent, finding qualified workers is becoming a critical issue for many firms.
Marc R. Rene de Cotret, a spokesman for J. D. S. Fitel, the Canadian firm, said his company had selected Monmouth County because it offered "proximity to AT&T and Lucent and access to a pool of qualified labor." Its Freehold office, in the 173,000-square-foot Monmouth Executive Center, employs 30 people.
"This office allowed us to gain a foothold in the U.S.," he said. "The industry is robust and we feel we are well-positioned to take advantage of that."
THOSE factors, along with more affordable office rents, were also important to Market Ware International, said Jose Pierre, its chief executive. He traded off his job as a technology executive on Wall Street to start the firm in 1996 in an office at the 78,000-square-foot Holmdel Executive Center.
"The key," Mr. Pierre added, "is that we wanted to be away from hustle and bustle and in an area that offered a better quality of life." He said his firm would add 14 employees this month for a total of 44 and anticipated adding 14 to 30 more, fueling a need for more space.
From 1990 to 1998, population in the 472-square-mile county rose by 9.6 percent to 606,229 and it is expected to grow by an additional 2 percentage points by the end of the decade, according to the Monmouth County Planning Board.
There were 3,148 housing permits issued in the county in 1998, second only to Ocean County in the number of permits issued among the state's 21 counties. And since 1997 construction of 876,418 square feet of retail space, as well as nearly 2 million square feet of office and industrial space, has either been under way or has been proposed.
"Monmouth County is like an untapped market for retailers and high-technology firms," said Bruce Fary, who heads the county planning board's development review section.
Because there has been no significant office construction in the last decade, Mr. Schwartz said, "the county can use more space."
To make up for this deficiency, Matrix is renovating its huge building in Tinton Falls, equidistant from Exits 105 and 109 of the Garden State Parkway. Kenneth A. Griffin, a Matrix partner, noted that the county offered "more housing choices and lower labor rates" than in northern New Jersey and Manhattan. Moreover, he said, the building "will have a significant cost advantage" over newly constructed ones in the state.
The seven-story structure was built in 1973 and leased until recently by the Army for its communications and electronics command center. That operation has since been relocated to Fort Monmouth.
"High-tech firms are absolutely among the tenants the building will be targeted to," said Richard S. Baumstein, an executive director at the East Rutherford office of Cushman & Wakefield, the brokerage that is marketing the building. For such companies relocating from North Jersey or Manhattan, "the county is a likely place for them," he said, adding that average asking rents at the Tinton Falls building would be $22 a square foot.
Under the $40 million to $45 million renovation plan, the old building will be stripped to its steel skeleton, and given a new facade and interior space, as well as upgraded mechanical systems and fiber-optic capabilities, said Mr. Griffin.
The building, with four wings and 100,000-square-foot floors, can accommodate users needing one or more floors, though the space can be divided into blocks of 25,000 square feet or less, Mr. Griffin said. He added that completion was expected by the end of the year.

SECTION: Section 2; Page 28; Column 1; Arts and Leisure Desk

LENGTH: 1440 words

HEADLINE: DANCE;
Dancing On Top of the World, With Malaise

BYLINE: By VALERIE GLADSTONE; Valerie Gladstone's most recent article for Arts and Leisure was on the dancer-choreographer Bebe Miller.

 BODY:
DAVID PARSONS sounded distressed. "Lately, every time I start a new project, I get unnerved," he said over lunch in Manhattan recently. Although this 39-year-old dancer-choreographer looks like a hunky, happy-go-lucky movie star, during this conversation he came across as an angst-ridden artist. "In the back of my mind, there's always the word 'accessible' that's constantly thrown at me as an insult. What does it mean? That I attract the masses? That's bad? My work's not about getting people to love me. It's about following what I want to do."
Ever since he established his modern-dance company 12 years ago, some critics have called his work superficial, accusing him of catering to the lowest common denominator. But why do their opinions affect him so deeply now? After all, he has had plenty of time to build defenses. Moreover, his company consistently attracts new fans, makes money and pleases many more critics than it disappoints. Obviously something else was wrong. 
 Events of the last two years have made him especially vulnerable, Mr. Parsons said. His confidence became seriously eroded. "I hit bottom," he said. "I became mean. I gave my dancers a hard time. I had a terrible breakup with a woman. I didn't have a permanent place to stay in the city. I tore the cartilage in my knee and had to have an operation." He winced. "It's coming back very slowly."
Yet in spite of his malaise, Mr. Parsons acknowledges that he still has ample reasons to feel positive. The Parsons Dance Company attracts large audiences, in locations as diverse as Brazil, Italy, Australia and St. Louis. And its two-week engagement at the Joyce Theater, starting Tuesday, is nearly sold out. "Almost all the music will be live," he said proudly; troupes appearing at the Joyce usually can't afford musicians. On the first week's program is his newest work, "Fill the Woods With Light," which had its world premiere at the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., last summer. It is set to a commissioned score by the jazz saxophonist Phil Woods, who will play it at the Joyce with his Little Big Band. To a mix of funky rock-and-roll, blues and bossa nova, Mr. Parsons created, according to Mr. Woods, "a warm dance, sort of down and dirty."
The second week's program features six works by Robert Battle, a veteran Parsons dancer. A choreographer new to the New York stage, Mr. Battle offers "Rush Hour," a world premiere, and four New York premieres, all of them to commissioned scores by John Mackey, a 28-year-old contemporary composer, who will perform with his ensemble of 10 Juilliard musicians. "Takademe," Mr. Battle's sixth New York premiere, is to the recorded songs of the Indian singer Sheila Chandra.
Mr. Parsons's widest exposure yet will come on New Year's Eve. The Times Square Business Improvement District chose him to stage a continuous outdoor show on 42d Street from 7 A.M., Dec. 31 until 7 A.M., Jan. 1. "Basically, it's a TV program going by satellite to a billion people," Mr. Parsons said. As chief of a creative team that includes Michael Curry, designer of the oversize puppets in the Broadway musical "The Lion King," Mr. Parsons has been asked to create a series of theatrical events, full of pageantry and with universal appeal. Although the show is still in the planning stage, he already knows he'll use 150 performers, 10 of them his company members, and that well-known composers around the world will do the music.
Mr. Parsons got the job for several reasons. "David has a devoted and very extensive following," said Peter Kohlmann, the executive producer of Times Square 2000. "We also knew he had standing in the dance world. Those qualifications, plus his visual sense and his reputation for being easy to work with, made us pick him."
Like Mr. Kohlmann, presenters and booking agents find Mr. Parsons's wide popularity pure gold. "Last year, David filled our 2,300-seat opera house five nights running," said Maria Rita Stumpf, president of Antares Promotions in Rio de Janeiro. "It's the joyfulness, the exuberant physicality of his work and his dancers." Three years ago, he did as well in Italy. According to Antonio Gnecchi, a producer who began representing Mr. Parsons 10 years ago, his troupe sold out in 18 cities. "David communicates directly, without pretension," Mr. Gnecchi said. Sally Bliss, executive director of Dance St. Louis, was equally enthusiastic. "Both little kids and the elderly love his work," she said. "You can't imagine how many friends his company makes here."
How does Mr. Parsons accomplish this? With a catholic repertory that includes the show-stopping "Caught" (1982), in which a dancer appears to fly; "Anthem" (1998), inspired by the dissolution of Eastern-bloc dictatorships, and "Ring Around the Rosie" (1993), which refers to AIDS. The first two, along with "Union" (1993), to "Nefertiti" by the jazz composer Wayne Shorter, will be presented this season.
But accomplishments aren't enough, and beneath them are deep reasons for Mr. Parsons's blue mood. "Sometimes you get so confused," he said earnestly. "You don't know how to separate your personal life from your professional life. I became bogged down, erratic. There's always a deadline; every time we do a show, there's a critic. I feared my creative juices were drying up. I was afraid of losing the joy in creation."
Mr. Parsons fell in love with dance as a 12-year-old in Kansas City, Mo., and has been immersed in it since, so it's not surprising that he eventually reached an impasse. Frequently dancer-choreographers become devastatingly discouraged in their late 30's and early 40's, when they must look to a future when they can no longer perform. Paul Taylor, with whose company Mr. Parsons starred for nine years, weathered a similar crisis, as did Twyla Tharp. But it wasn't just the inevitable physical changes that got to Mr. Parsons. The responsibility for his dancers -- he provides at least 45 weeks of work and full health and unemployment insurance -- and the constant touring became too much. He had little energy for choreographing.
A couple of changes have slowly begun to turn the tide; for one, Mr. Parsons travels less with the troupe. "The pressures built up in David, and he took it out on us," said Jaime Martinez, who recently became assistant artistic director of the company. "Today he gives older members, Liz Koeppen and me, a lot more responsibility, and it's been great for all of us." Second, Mr. Parsons now plans to produce work by other choreographers regularly, shifting the weight of creating all the company's new dances. Mr. Battle is the first choreographer to benefit from Mr. Parsons's decision. "David sees this as the future of dance," said Mr. Battle. "No more one-choreographer companies."
Mr. Parsons says when he auditions now, he looks for dancers who want to choreograph as well. Before being hired, his three new company members, Kate Skarpetowska, George Smallwood and Sumayah McRae, submitted videotape of pieces they had created. The idea wasn't new to Mr. Parsons; putting it into practice was. For nine years, his troupe spent time every summer at the New Arts Summer Festival in Fort Myers, Fla., teaching choreography and technique. Now he is trying to establish a school in New York, a permanent place to nurture dancers and choreographers. "My school will be open to everybody," he said, dreaming out loud. "I'll have a summer session where semiprofessionals from around the world can come and taste the city and get a feel for other choreographers and our technique and repertory."
His mood picked up. "I want to do more video. I've already used video to teach disadvantaged kids to dance. I'll do my own productions and make films for television to get people who don't go to theater interested in dance."
Mr. Parsons likes collaborations. This season, Missoni and Donna Karan created many of the company's costumes, and he talked excitedly about the possibility of working with Mikhail Baryshnikov on a piece using Vari-Lite, a lighting system run by computers. Made famous in the shows of the rock group Genesis, Vari-Lite can rotate 360 degrees, fading from one color and pattern to another. He then switched to explaining that he might try as backdrops the underwater photographs of Howard Schatz, or enormous close-ups of the dancers: "In film, close-ups are usually what get you emotionally involved," he said. "I'll have to figure out how we can do that."
Rising to leave, he paused to say: "You know, I'm actually feeling better. Something's coming back that is very beautiful." And he was smiling.

SECTION: Section 11; Page 9; Column 1; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 1458 words

HEADLINE: In the Region /Long Island;
In Jericho, a Developer Is Buying a Rural Legacy

BYLINE: By DIANA SHAMAN 

DATELINE: JERICHO

 BODY:
TIME is soon to catch up to a 19th-century farmhouse, several barns, and the nine acres of fields and paddocks surrounding them that have survived as a rural oasis on busy Jericho Turnpike just east of the Route 107 cloverleaf. They have been owned by members of one of Long Island's older families, the Underhills, for almost 130 years.
But economic realities have persuaded the four owners that renting the property to a boarding stable known as Jericho Run Farms no longer makes good sense. 
 Samuel Underhill Mitchell, 68, his 97-year-old mother, the former Alice Underhill, and Mr. Mitchell's two cousins, Phebe Alice Apgar of Burke, Va., and Morley L. Smith Jr. of Montreal, have signed a contract to sell the parcel to a Manhattan developer, Forest City Daly Housing, which has proposed developing it for 20 houses and a 90-unit assisted-living residence.
Under the sales agreement, the farmhouse must be preserved. But even so Mr. Mitchell, a direct descendant of Capt. John Underhill, who founded the family in 1661, said it was painful to part with the property. "It is full of fond memories," he explained.
His great-grandfather, Samuel S. Underhill, purchased the house along with 160 acres in the mid-1870's. His mother and her sister, his aunt Phebe Underhill Smith, grew up there.
He remembers playing there as a boy and spending his summers helping his grandfather, Samuel S. Underhill Jr., work the farm, which originally extended east to Robbins Lane and south to the Long Island Rail Road tracks.
Most of the land was sold off in the 1950's, as farm after farm in the area gave way to development.
To the west there is commercial development, including a motel and a gas station a half-mile distant near the cloverleaf connecting Jericho Turnpike to Route 107. To the east are office buildings, a shopping center and an industrial park. To the south, high ranches and colonials occupy quarter-acre lots that were once part of the Underhill holdings. To the north there are more houses.
But horses still graze in the fields of the Underhill property, a reminder of the days when the family raised cattle and, later, potatoes, corn, cabbage, tomatoes and other produce.
The five-bedroom farmhouse has two parlors, one on each side of the front door, eyebrow windows on the second floor and wide plank floors. An iron potbelly stove still stands in the dining room. With its sagging front porch framed by wisteria, and with the adjoining barns sporting an American flag, the house looks more like part of rural upstate New York than suburbia.
But property taxes are $62,000 a year, which the rent being paid by Jericho Run Farms, the riding establishment, doesn't begin to cover, Mr. Mitchell said.
Developers have been trying for years to purchase the property, Mr. Mitchell added, but until the idea of an assisted-living facility came up, he turned down all proposals.
"I want to see something built here that the family can be proud of, and with which it can leave its stamp on the property," he explained. "This is a quiet, peaceful use and something many people need. It's also a way to preserve the home."
Forest City Daly has proposed dividing the property into two parcels. A three-acre portion fronting on Jericho Turnpike would, subject to a zoning change, be developed for a 90-unit assisted-living residence for the frail elderly.
Designed by Perkins Eastman Architects in Manhattan, the two-story building would incorporate some of the traditional architecture of the existing farmhouse, said Michael D. Daly, the president of Forest City Daly. The concern is an affiliate of Forest City Enterprises of Cleveland, a publicly traded real estate company.
Forest City Daly, which builds only assisted-living projects, would retain ownership and manage the complex here. Residents, expected to be in their mid-80's, would pay up to $4,000 a month. The rent would include three meals a day and all their daily living needs.
THE three acres, which have residential zoning, would require a zoning change from the Town of Oyster Bay, so the developer is first seeking the support of bordering homeowners organized as the East Birchwood Civic Association. The group has met with Mr. Daly several times.
A previous proposal by the Strausman Construction of Great Neck for an assisted-living project with 350 units was met with such intense opposition that it was withdrawn.
The civic association has not yet taken a stand on the current proposal by Forest City Daly, said the association's president, Todd Fabricant. But he indicated that his group was more favorably inclined toward Mr. Daly's plan.
"We realize that we need places for our seniors to go as people get older, and we felt that this compromise, which we are still working on, is a fairly decent one," he said.
The six acres to the rear of the property, which would become a buffer between existing houses and the assisted-living complex, would be developed with 20 houses on quarter-acre lots in line with the existing residential zoning. The new subdivision would be entered from Ellen Place, a side street.
Forest City Daly intends to sell off the six acres to a residential builder, Britt Realty of Hauppauge, which is proposing four-bedroom houses selling in the $600,000 range.
The Underhill homestead, which is very close to Jericho Turnpike, would be moved 100 feet back in case the thoroughfare is ever widened, Mr. Daly said, adding that he intended to restore the building and possibly use it for administrative purposes.
"Saving and refurbishing the homestead is very admirable," said Mr. Fabricant, the civic association president. "Leaving some remembrance of this family for future generations is very important."
Captain Underhill was one of the Town of Oyster Bay's earliest colonists. He settled in what is now Lattingtown and Mill Neck on 150 acres given him by members of the Matinecock Indian tribe after he negotiated a land claim for them. All that is left in family hands of the original Underhill holdings is a burial plot marked by a 40-foot-high obelisk commemorating the family founder, which President Theodore Roosevelt dedicated in 1908.
At one time, various branches of the Underhill family collectively owned thousands of acres on Long Island. But now the Jericho farmhouse and the nine acres on which it stands is probably the last large holding still owned by a family member, said Harry Macy, the editor of the Manhattan-based New York Genealogical and Biographical Record.
Mr. Macy is himself an Underhill; his great-great-grandmother was sister to Mr. Mitchell's great-great-grandfather.
According to George Underhill of Louisville, Ky., who is president of the Underhill Society, which collects and preserves family archives, members of the Underhill family live all over the world. But few still reside on Long Island.
And their numbers are dwindling. Margaret Young Underhill, the widow of Henry Willets Underhill, who once owned a 200-acre farm on Jericho Turnpike just west of Route 107, died in February 1998 at the age of 85. She still owned a family homestead on 14 acres, which has since been purchased by neighbors.
In March, Mr. Mitchell's aunt, Phebe Smith, died at the age of 92. Both women are buried in the cemetery of the Jericho Friends Meeting House on Old Jericho Turnpike, where Mr. Mitchell and his mother still attend Sunday services.
The meeting house, built in 1788, is another throwback to rural times, a green oasis surrounded by highways and office buildings. In its cemetery are buried members of many of Long Island's distinguished Quaker families -- the Underhills, Jacksons, Seamans and Woodnuts to name a few.
The Underhills were active in the underground railroad that assisted escaped slaves to freedom and now the family's history has become part of the argument being made for the preservation of 81 acres on Jericho Turnpike, once owned by Henry Willets Underhill.
The Tilles Investment Companies of Woodbury, which purchased the parcel in 1981, is in contract to sell it to the Holiday Organization of Westbury. Holiday wants to develop it as 270 detached homes, but litigation by local groups against the Town of Oyster Bay for approving the project has so far stopped development.
The site has been designated a critical groundwater recharge area, and there are efforts under way to purchase it with public funds so it can be preserved.
Proponents say that the land's place in Long Island's history is as significant as its environmental qualities.
"It is just so extraordinary that this land was owned by the same family for over 200 years," said Denward W. Collins Jr., the president of the Nassau County Historical Society.

HEADLINE: Vacant Schools Now Shelter the Elderly

BYLINE: By JOHN RATHER 

 BODY:
CHURCH schools once built to serve the children of the Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre are now often empty. But they are finding new use as housing for the elderly. The diocese is in the midst of a program to provide low-income apartments for senior citizens, Long Island's fastest-growing age group, in vacant schools and other church buildings.
The program, administered by Catholic Charities and financed under Federal and state programs and by the church, rents one-bedroom apartments for as little as $100 a month, and provides tenants with social and health services. There are long waiting lists for finished complexes, and new housing on the way. 
 "We took a look at parish properties and saw so many schools that were no longer used as schools and were just sitting there," said Paul A. Chedda, the director of housing for Catholic Charities. "So we thought, why don't we take some of these parish properties and rehab them?"
The program extends the useful life of diocesan facilities and parochial school buildings built during the 1940's and 50's to accommodate a surge in young Catholic families. School enrollment peaked in the 1960's, church officials said, and then began to decline steadily. In the 1980's, when the diocese regionalized Catholic education on Long Island, many schools closed.
Officials of Catholic Charities said the housing program, which is open to all the elderly and not only Roman Catholics or Long Island residents, provides living quarters for people who are no longer able to maintain private homes or are priced out of the Long Island housing market.
In some instances, where renovation of vacant buildings is not practical, buildings will be torn down to make way for apartments for the elderly.
Even before apartments are available, Mr. Chedda said, hundreds are on waiting lists. Under guidelines set by the Federal Department of Housing and Urban Development, tenants must be 62 or older and have annual incomes of under $25,650 for one person or $29,300 for two.
Mr. Chedda said most applicants had no difficulty meeting the income requirements. "They laugh and say they don't even make half those amounts," he said. Under H.U.D. regulations, tenants pay no more than one-third of their monthly income in rent.
Mr. Chedda said a typical tenant was a widow in her 70's, from a community near the complex and with relatives on Long Island or in the metropolitan area.
At St. Hedwig's Gardens in Floral Park, one of three housing complexes now using parish properties, Catholic Charities renovated a vacant school to create a 27-unit complex that is fully occupied with a one-year waiting list.
The complex, dedicated in September, was financed in part by the New York State Housing Trust Fund and by the Federal Low-Income Housing Tax Credits program.
"They are so grateful," said James Verity, referring to the residents of St. Hedwig's. A pastoral care-giver for diocesan housing for the elderly, Mr. Verity said, "They say they never dreamed they would live in a place like this at this stage of their lives. Where else could they go?"
"We are just scratching the surface here," said Mr. Verity, who is 73. "So many others are being forced into poverty. I don't know what to call some of the places they are forced into. It's a terrible way to go out when you've been a productive citizen."
Catholic Charities is beginning construction of a 100-unit low-income senior housing complex in Brentwood to be called St. Anne's Gardens, using the same state and Federal financing sources at St. Hedwig's. Unlike St. Hedwig's, the project entails knocking down a vacant parish school on the five acres where the complex will be situated. Monthly rents will be $475 to $550 for one-bedroom apartments. The complex is set to be completed in the summer of 2000.
In another example of how the housing program uses vacant land, Catholic Charities purchased a parking lot from St. Martha's Parish in Uniondale as the site for a 45-unit residence for the low-income elderly. The 75-unit Bishop Ryan Village in Hampton Bays, which has a waiting list of 200 people, is on land Catholic Charities bought from St. Rosalie's Parish.
Mr. Chedda, a lawyer with with a business background, said Catholic Charities was able to purchase vacant land and surplus buildings from Catholic parishes for less than market value. He said three other projects for the elderly were also planned, and that Catholic Charities was continuing to survey parish properties for more housing.
Housing experts say that public opposition to low-income housing for the elderly had declined in recent years on Long Island.
"I can remember 12 years ago there was resistance to senior citizen housing," said Jim Morgo, the president of the Long Island Housing Partnership in Hauppauge. "Now they are much more accepted and much better designed."
The partnership, a private group with support from Long Island businesses that specializes in affordable housing for first-time buyers, is also involved in housing projects for the elderly.
The group arranged financing two years ago for Rivoli House, a 112-unit rental complex for the low-income elderly at the site of the old Rivoli Theater in the Village of Hempstead.
Another project for which the group arranged financing, Broadway West in Brentwood, will provide 72 units for the elderly, with rents ranging from $500 to $690.
Mr. Morgo said his organization also offered counseling on reverse mortgages that helped the elderly who were "house-rich but cash-poor" convert home equity into monthly income that allowed them to remain at home.
Experts said Long Island demographics make it clear that much more housing for the elderly will be needed.
A study by the Suffolk County Department of Planning based on census figures showed that the number of Nassau residents aged 65 or older increased from 80,847 in 1960 to 187,725 in 1996. For the same period, the increase in Suffolk was from 56,814 to 148,193. In Suffolk, the number of people aged 75 or older leaped from 18,005 in 1960 to 65,220 in 1996.
Peter K. Lambert, a senior planner in the department, said the median age continues on a "slow and steady increase" on Long Island, rising up from 30.8 in 1960 to 36.6 in 1990 in Nassau and from 30 to 33.5 over the same period in Suffolk.
The Catholic Charities program to provide low-income housing for the elderly appears to surpass efforts by other religious groups.
The Rev. Thomas W. Goodhue, the executive director of the Long Island Council of Churches, an association of Protestant churches, said many congregations took part in the Habitat for Humanity program, in which they helped construct low-cost housing. But he said he knew of no organized effort among other religious groups similar to the Catholic Charities program.
Rabbi Bruce Ginsburg, the president of the Long Island Board of Rabbis, said enrollment patterns for Jewish religious schools were "just the opposite" of those for Catholic schools. "The schools don't have enough space and are bringing in temporary structures," he said.
Rabbi Ginsburg said that while he was not aware of any housing projects for the elderly by Long Island synagogues, his own synagogue, Congregation Sons of Israel in Woodmere, had considered a project on synagogue property. He said the plan was dropped because the parcel was too small.
"I can't speak in terms of what the Jewish community is doing as a whole, but this is certainly something we have thought of," said Rabbi Ginsburg. "It seems to me all the way around it would be a benefit if there is land or a building that can be used for this purpose."
And at least one municipality is getting involved with converting an empty church-owned school. In Garden City, St. Paul's, a preparatory school formerly operated by the Episcopal Diocese of Long Island was bought by the Village of Garden City for $7.25 million in 1992 after it was closed by the diocese.
The village is now negotiating a long-term lease with a company that wants to convert the 500-room building into an assisted care facility for senior citizens.

HEADLINE: First-Time 'Customs,' Not Cookie-Cutters

BYLINE: By MORRIS NEWMAN 

DATELINE: CHINO HILLS, Calif.

 BODY:
THE home-buying experience of Kevin and Danniele Flora in this community 35 miles east of downtown Los Angeles may be a bellwether of current trends in home building, especially in the first-time home-buyer market.
Mr. Flora, 30, is an account executive for a computer company, and his wife, 28, is an account executive for a clothing manufacturer. In August 1998 they committed to buying a house, their first, in Ridgeview, a subdivision of more-or-less conventional single-family homes. 
 What was unconventional was the degree of control that the young home buyers exercised over the design of the house and such things as types of floors and fixtures, which in new construction is usually given only to buyers of more-expensive move-up housing. The Floras paid about $230,990 for a house with 2,141 square feet of space.
Before the house was built, the couple selected one of about a dozen floor plans, with an extra-large kitchen and master bedroom, all included in the basic package priced at $220,990. But because the Floras opted for such things as a brick-and-vinyl facade and special bathroom fixtures not included in the options, they had to pay an extra $10,000.
The Floras were even encouraged to visit the home under construction, and were given a camera to document its progress by the home builder, Kaufman & Broad Greater Los Angeles Division, a unit of Kaufman & Broad Home Corporation, both based in Los Angeles.
"We added our own touches," said Mr. Flora. "It felt almost like a total custom home." The couple moved into the house last November.
The Floras' experience in buying a home in the Ridgeview development exemplifies the strategy Kaufman & Broad has been pursuing in the last four years to maintain a hold on the first-time-buyer market.
THAT strategy is driven, in large part, by consumer-preference surveys, conducted among buyers of both new and used homes in each of the company's 16 market areas. Such surveys are common in many industries, but not in home building, according to Bruce Karatz, the company's president and chief executive.
While the company builds homes in several price ranges, Kaufman & Broad is particularly interested in following the tastes of the youngest segment of buyers aged 24 to 34, which it calls "baby zoomers." The name hints at the professional ambition, fast-growing income and high material expectations of many people in that age group.
The surveys found a desire for greater choice among first-time buyers.
With the current strong economy and low unemployment "people don't feel boxed in, they have lots of choices," Mr. Karatz explained.
Home buyers "want it their way," added Jeffrey Charney, the company's senior vice president of marketing. "They don't want a cookie-cutter house," he said.
The surveys also showed that many buyers value practicality over display, according to Glen Barnard, a senior vice president who is regional general manager of the company's Denver office.
"This generation may be less interested in glitz and more interested in functionality," he said. The current generation, he added, are "more utilitarian than other generations."
That trend corresponds to a "back-to-the-basics" theme in both car design and volume-discount retailing, according to Mr. Barnard.
One response to the desire for choice was to offer up to 12 floor plans, each of which allows further permutations. Previously, Kaufman & Broad offered two or three floor plans.
SOME buyers opt for nontraditional features not often found in tract housing, such as media centers, sleeping lofts, Jacuzzi bathtubs, or kitchen islands.
In general, the surveys revealed that buyers in the 24-to-34 age group were interested in buying enough space for growing families, and something more luxurious than the traditional image of a starter home.
The most sought-after amenity, it turned out, was size, according to Mr. Barnard. "In every market that we have surveyed, the single most important factor, beyond just being able to buy a house, is getting the most square footage for the money," he said.
That trend, he observed, is a "reversal from the 80's when people wanted upscale amenities," such as cathedral ceilings, bay windows, marble-floor entries, chandeliers and other symbols of affluence.
Maximizing space was a deciding factor for Benjamin Jackson, 30, an emergency-response social worker, and his 30-year-old wife, Charlotte, a tax auditor for the State of California.
Although the Jacksons, who have two children, had originally looked at existing houses near their place of work in neighboring Orange County, "I was looking for as much space as I could possibly get for the money," said Mr. Jackson, who said he liked to retreat to "a little corner of the house" after stressful days at work. "This space allows me to do that," he added.
The three most important places to add space in developments like Ridgeview with larger than usual starter homes, according to Mr. Barnard, are kitchens, master bedrooms and storage areas, particularly closets.
OFTEN, home buyers are willing to "trade off" or live without other home features to maximize the size of those amenities, Mr. Barnard said.
If necessary, buyers are often willing to accept smaller garages or lesser number of bathrooms. They will settle for smaller living rooms, or for consolidating the dining room and living room into a single "great room."
Buyers also have a choice of facades. "If somebody is an achiever and wants his or her house to make a statement, we've got the elevation that allows them to do that," Mr. Barnard said. On the other hand, he added, if people with "inner-directed values and lifestyle prefer that a house does not make a statement, we've got that, too."
Even without the surveys, Kaufman & Broad executives sensed that current home buyers were often experienced consumers and wanted to make home buying more of what Mr. Karatz calls "a retail experience."
To emphasize that "retail experience," Kaufman & Broad has created large showrooms, sometimes as large as 20,000 square feet, in most of its major markets, where prospective home buyers can select fixtures, paint colors and such things as carpets, tile, cabinet styles, bathtubs and fireplaces for their future houses.
The showrooms are intended to make home buying into something more like shopping, to make buyers feel more comfortable, more "in control" during the often intimidating process of making a six-figure purchase.
"I want to take the mystery and anxiety out the home purchase," Mr. Karatz said.
The Floras, for example, opted for a carpet with extra padding to extend the life of the carpet, as well as tile, ceiling fans, his-and-her bathroom sinks and windows for the garage door.
 For Mr. Karatz, the good reception of Kaufman & Broad's recent developments may augur some changes for the home-building industry away from the cookie-cutter sameness that has typified American home building since Levittown.
"This is not the assembly line," he said. "We are going to build 22,000 homes this year, one at a time."

HEADLINE: Flounder Are Down, But Who's at Fault?

BYLINE: By ROBERT A. HAMILTON 

 BODY:
SINCE Colonial times, winter flounder have generally been so plentiful in Niantic Bay that an angler could quickly fill the bottom of a small boat with the odd-looking but popular flatfish.
But since the 1970's the catches have been noticeably dwindling, and some environmentalists blame it on the Northeast Utilities nuclear plants at Millstone Point, on the east shore of the bay, which suck in millions of gallons of water each minute -- and many billions of fish larvae over the years -- in the process of cooling the reactors. 
 "I've been fishing in Niantic Bay since I was 10, and back then we used to fill bushel baskets with flounder," said Martin T. O'Rourke of Willimantic who was recently fishing in the bay. "Now, you're lucky if you catch three if you stay out all day."
Late last month, Judge Robert Hale of Connecticut Superior Court in Hartford agreed that the environmentalists might have a case.
Despite the impending approval of the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission that Millstone 2 could restart after sitting idle for three years because of safety problems, the judge ordered that the plant wait until after the flounder spawning season had ended.
Though the judge has since lifted the injunction, critics of the power plants said that the eight days that Millstone 2 remained shut down because of the judge's order has created ripples that will spread out from Niantic Bay and around the world.
"It's an issue that is still in its infancy, but it will continue, and grow," said William N. Smith, executive director of the Long Island-based Fish Unlimited, one of the organizations that filed suit against Millstone. "You can already see signs that the nuclear industry in general is watching this fight very closely. They realize how vulnerable they are, that this is something they're going to have to deal with. This is their Achilles' heel."
Nancy Burton, the Redding, lawyer who argued the case for the environmentalists in court, said that the preliminary court order barring the restart of the plant would encourage environmental groups to take action against other industries anywhere in the world that kill fish through large cooling water intakes.
"For eight days, Millstone 2 was shut down for the sake of winter flounder larvae," Ms. Burton said. "That is unprecedented in the history of nuclear power in this country, and was an absolutely amazing victory by itself."
Already, she said, officials from the Federal Environmental Protection Agency are talking about putting stiffer standards in place for industrial cooling water intakes to prevent fish larvae from being killed. "This is now an issue we've put on the front burner for environmental groups around the country," Ms. Burton said.
Northeast Utilities had fought to bring the plant back on line after a long shutdown for safety issues. The company estimates that each month the 880-megawatt reactor is out of service costs it $20 million. The company said it was now preparing the plant for the weeks-long restart process.
Joseph T. Pillittere, a spokesman for Northeast Utilities, said the company was considering installing a system that would return to the bay adult fish caught on the intake screens, and it would continue the environmental monitoring program that has provided state fisheries experts with what they call some of their most comprehensive data on a specific winter flounder population.
"We want to become the best, whether that has to do with operations or the environment," Mr. Pillittere said. He also said it was the company's contention that overfishing of adult flounder, not the destruction of larvae, had been the greatest contributor to the decline in the fish population. He said it was also important to recognize that the nuclear plants allow the state to avoid the use of oil- or coal-burning plants. "If we didn't have nuclear, we'd have to be using fossil fuels, and that has its own associated environmental effect, in terms of air emissions."
Anglers agreed that the flounder population in Niantic Bay is in trouble.
Arnold F. Costello of Waterford, who was putting his boat into the water last weekend, said the problem affected all species.
"I used to catch 8- and 10-pound weakfish in the river, and 30- or 40-pound striped bass between the bridges," Mr. Costello said "The last time I caught a weakfish was probably 30 years ago. My grandson here, he probably doesn't even know what a weakfish looks like."
But anglers seem split over the cause of the decline.
"We've seen commercial boats dragging in eight feet of water right in the bay," Mr. Costello said. "They do at least as much damage as Millstone, but no one is trying to shut them down."
Wayne H. Maheu, who owns a summer house in Niantic, said he never believed the plant could cause such problems either, until he saw some of the statistics on fish mortality that came out during the lawsuit.
"Then you start to wonder -- could it be true?" Mr. Maheu said.
Joseph B. Young of Meriden, as he prepared his boat for a day on the water, said it was easy to blame overfishing or Millstone, but a look around the bay shows a lot of residential development, so there are also issues such as sewage runoff and sedimentation that could be affecting the fish population.
"The fact is, everyone wants air-conditioning and all kinds of appliances -- where do they think all that electricity is going to come from?" Mr. Young said. "I think there's a lot more than Millstone affecting the fish, but even if it was Millstone, we can't shut it down."
The state's Department of Environmental Protection estimates there are no more than 7,200 adult flounder in the bay now, down from more than 60,000 in 1991.
And it's undisputed that Millstone 2, which draws in 2 million gallons of cooling water from the bay every minute it is in operation, kills a lot of flounder larvae: 514 million in 1992, the worst year, and 87 million last year, according to the utilities' own environmental reports. About 5 billion larvae were killed from 1986-96, and billions other species were also killed, according to the reports.
Penelope T. Howell, a senior state fisheries biologist, said those larvae represent an average of 12 percent of the larvae population per year. But she said one could not correlate that to a 12 percent decrease in adult fish.
"There's the issue of compensation, which means the ones that are left have a greater chance for survival because there is less competition for the food that is there," Ms. Howell said. "It's not a nice, clear-cut situation."
Ms. Howell says Millstone is just one of the factors causing the Niantic Bay flounder population to collapse, and is not even the major factor. But she said that if Millstone 2 stopped killing larvae, the flounder population would recover faster if other factors, such as overfishing, were also addressed.
The judge's injunction came as a result of a lawsuit filed on March 11 by four environmental groups, three of them from Long Island and one from Connecticut, and the New York Assemblyman, Representative Fred Thiele of Sag Harbor, Long Island. The suit claimed that Millstone 2 was responsible for decimating the flounder population in Niantic Bay.
Mr. Thiele said he believed Connecticut anglers and even regulators might be trying to balance the environmental impacts with the benefits of having a large taxpayer and employer along the coast.
"My sense is that this is an economic issue for Connecticut residents," Mr. Thiele said. "Those plants, that industry, is such a large part of the economy, it tempers any environmental considerations."
Mr. Thiele said he has been a strong supporter of efforts to clean up Long Island Sound and Peconic Bay. He said the five towns on the north shore of Eastern Long Island have spent $40 million in the last 20 years preserving open space.
"That's why the issue of Millstone is so maddening for us," Mr. Thiele said. "At the time the government is spending so much money and there is real progress being made, we have reports of radiation in the sediment and fish kills off Millstone. I think people involved in environmental issues see Millstone as the biggest threat to Long Island Sound today."
The plant had already been shut down for nearly three years when the groups filed the suit. On April 27, Judge Hale agreed it should remain shut down until June 15, after the spawning season. Two days after that order, the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission said the plant was safe enough to be put back into operation, pending the outcome of the environmental case.
Less than 24 hours after testimony in the court case ended on May 6, the judge ruled that overfishing is a more likely cause of the fish decline and lifted the injunction against starting the plant.
"This is a temporary setback, but it's definitely not the end of this battle," Mr. Smith said.
Ms. Burton, the lawyer for the four groups, said she hoped the appeals court would decide that the judge relied too heavily on the company expert witnesses, who worked at the Millstone environmental lab. Her own expert witness, a fisheries biologist from Rhode Island, estimated that 60 percent of the flounder mortality in the bay is the result of the Millstone nuclear power plants.
In fact, the latest survey by the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institute showed that flounder populations along most of the coast have increased because of state and Federal fishing restrictions, she said.
When Northeast Utilities was issued a permit for Millstone 2 in 1970, the company estimated an impact of no more than 6 percent on the flounder population, she said.
"Their best numbers show the impact has been at least twice that," Ms. Burton said. "This permit was based on seriously flawed predictions. Maybe we would have said no to the plant back then if we knew how many fish it was going to kill. Or maybe we would have required a closed cooling system."
A closed system uses a tower to cool water from the plant, rather than continuously drawing cooling water from the bay and discharging the heated water back into Long Island Sound. The company's experts testified during the trial that such a system would be feasible, and would cost about $100 million.
"It's a small victory that the judge says a closed system would be desirable, but he says that's up to the licensing authority," Ms. Burton said. "Unfortunately, those kind of license changes will take years to accomplish."

HEADLINE: Long Beach, Young Again;
Once an Elegant Resort, Then a Family Haven, Now on a Quiet Comeback

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

DATELINE: LONG BEACH

 BODY:
PAUL MISTRETTA and Priscilla Cipollini were veterans of the Long Beach single life when they happened to buy mirror-image condominiums along the boardwalk with facing terraces. One thing led to another, and last June they got married.
Now the couple -- he's 35, she's 37 -- has just moved into a spacious new $375,000 home in Long Beach built in a style that the developer describes as Victorian Colonial. It has four bedrooms, a fireplace and a view of Reynolds Channel, which is named for William H. Reynolds, who developed Long Beach as a planned community, starting in 1906. 
 To Mr. Mistretta and Ms. Cipollini, Long Beach is Long Island's best-kept secret, a city that has made a quiet but impressive comeback after years of decline. They say they never seriously considered buying anywhere else because Long Beach provided everything they wanted: a wide, beautiful and well-maintained beach within walking distance, a community of health-conscious people and a growing selection of appealing restaurants.
Ms. Cipollini, a buyer for Macy's, can also walk to the train station in the center of town and be in her Manhattan office in about an hour. Her husband, a computer technician, works for Chase Manhattan Bank in Garden City.
Their new neighbors -- some of whom live in houses on the channel that cost $500,000 or more -- are other professionals who also discovered the attractions of Long Beach as renters. "Long Beach probably has the reputation for not being as nice as it is," Ms. Cipollini said, "but we all know different."
Ms. Cipollini and her husband are part of a trend that is setting Long Beach apart from the rest of Nassau County. Built on a narrow barrier island separated from the Long Island "mainland" by three bridges, this city of 35,000 is getting younger just as the county is growing older. Between 1980 and 1990, as the proportion of residents over 65 rose by nearly 4 percent countywide (from 10.6 percent to 14.2 percent), the elderly population of Long Beach declined by almost 3 percent (from 21.5 percent to 18.6 percent).
And there are indications that the trend is continuing. More strollers are being pushed along the two-mile boardwalk, the number of children participating in city-sponsored recreational programs has more than tripled since 1990 and a new skateboard park is expected to open next month. Increasing numbers of young singles are moving to the lower-priced West End.
Newcomers say there are several factors that make Long Beach special: Its beach is the equal of any in the Hamptons and yet the city is affordable, unpretentious and an easy commute from New York. Unlike its neighbors to either side, Atlantic Beach and Lido Beach, Long Beach is easy to get around on foot or by local bus.
Angelica Pulvirenti moved from Greenwich Village to Long Beach 15 months ago but has yet to buy a car. "It's not like living in the suburbs," said Ms. Pulvirenti, a pastry chef at Lespinasse, a Manhattan restaurant. "I didn't feel I was going to be stranded."
Long Beach is never going to be the elegant resort it was in the 1920's, when people got dressed up to stroll on the boardwalk. A lot of the retail stores are on the shabby side and most of the retirement homes and other high-rises built smack up against the boardwalk (in the only Long Island community that allows such beachfront construction) are unlikely to win awards for architectural distinction.
But signs of the city's resurgence are everywhere. A Starbucks has just opened near City Hall, not far from the new library. There is a new $8 million public recreation area near the fishing pier at Reynolds Channel, where children can play roller hockey outdoors. A new private health club, where an annual membership costs nearly $1,000, has sprung up in place of a long-shuttered supermarket. The crumbling bulkhead along the bay is undergoing repairs, and trees and flowers are sprouting on the median dividing Park Avenue, the city's main shopping street. And in a year or so, a small rundown movie theater that opened in 1923 is expected to make way for a new theater with seven screens.
A decade ago, Steven Guasco opened the first upscale restaurant on Park Avenue. "I had it nice," Mr. Guasco said recently. "I was the only kid on the block." These days, Stevens Pasta Specialties has competition from a half-dozen or so establishments. Among them are several new Japanese restaurants and a place called Prashanthi that bills itself as Indian, vegetarian and kosher. The owner, Shanker Chapa, said he hopes certification from a rabbi will bring in customers from among the city's sizable Orthodox Jewish population.
Housing prices are keeping pace. A luxury three-bedroom apartment on the boardwalk in the Avalon Towers rents for as much as $3,800 a month, and a one-bedroom can fetch $2,000, said Anthony Chiaravalloti, the owner of Coldwell Banker Beach West Realty.
Large oceanfront condos are selling for as much as $500,000, up from about $350,000 five years ago, said Marilyn Topper, the owner of Topper Realty Corporation. In general, said Richard B. Nunziata, the manager of Century 21 Petrey, "Housing prices have gone up about 20 percent in the last five years, most of it within the past year."
William McCaffrey, who moved from Queens to a well-appointed condo facing the ocean after he retired from the insurance business, said his friends were dubious about his decision.
"They have it in the back of their mind that it's a bad area," he said. "But it has certainly cleaned itself up and is on its way back."
In most places, changes like these would be small beer, but they are remarkable in this city, which was known for years as a nest of political corruption and a dumping ground for discharged mental patients and people on welfare, who took up residence in dilapidated rooming houses and hotels that had once welcomed vacationers. Edwin L. Eaton, the former City Manager, said that about 2,000 people who had been released from mental hospitals under the deinstitutionalization movement of the 1970's -- about 80 percent of the total number on Long Island -- were living here. But their numbers dwindled after city officials got the state to close many of the substandard adult-care homes where they were housed. Today, the city has about 225 former mental patients living in two adult homes, Mr. Eaton said.
By 1975, property values had declined so precipitously and the city was being so badly managed that Long Beach nearly went bankrupt and city workers had to accept promissory notes in lieu of paychecks.
With new construction and renovation going on all over town, Bruce Nyman, the new City Manager, recently announced that for the first time in six years, the city no longer had a deficit and would not have to raise taxes in the coming fiscal year, which begins in July, to meet its $38 million budget. Mr. Nyman said the taxable value of the city's real estate had increased by $3.6 million since last year, raising the total assessed valuation to $195.4 million.
Mr. Nyman took office in March, replacing Mr. Eaton, who played a major role in the city's transformation, a process that was slowed by the recession that began in the late 1980's. In a city notorious for its turnover in city managers -- there were eight of them in the 1970's alone -- Mr. Eaton spent a record 20 years on the job. During that time, the city demolished 2,300 substandard apartments and private developers built 1,853 new housing units, he said. He said that Long Beach also had 398 units of public housing, more per capita than any other community on Long Island.
Although he has just moved into City Hall, Mr. Nyman, 48, is not exactly a new face. He was raised in Long Beach and had represented the city's district in the County Legislature (and the Board of Supervisors, which preceded it) since 1986, rising to minority leader before accepting the municipal post.
Mr. Nyman has a vision for his city that harks back to the 1950's, when middle-class Jewish families like his were drawn to Long Beach because of its excellent schools. Here, in this compact city only three and a half miles long, they found a version of suburbia where kids could go to the movies or the bowling alley without being chauffeured by their parents.
In the years after World War II, families from New York would move to Long Beach for the summer because of the easy commute to Manhattan. But as air-conditioning became more prevalent, people no longer saw the need to escape for an entire season, and other vacation destinations, including the Hamptons, pushed Long Beach aside.
Now, Mr. Nyman said, the city is experiencing a rebirth, with young people moving in again just as they did in the '50's. "We are becoming a different community," he said.
Different, yes, but not quite a throwback to the 50's. For one thing, the Long Beach schools are no longer considered among the best in the state, let alone the nation. For another, much of the development that followed the postwar influx is now seen as a mistake. Long Beach, said Mr. Nyman, "would be paradise if we didn't have that Chinese wall of apartments" on the beach.
Mr. Nyman said the city needed to spend millions to repair or rebuild the city's aging streets and fix its storm and sewer systems and water mains.
Some residents voiced complaints about the lackluster shopping district, where stores close before many commuters get home; the absence of amenities on the boardwalk, and the competition for parking spaces during the summer, when the population grows by about 15,000. This summer, residents will be able to rent lockers under the boardwalk for the first time as an incentive to leave their cars at home, Mr. Nyman said.
City officials boast about the city's low retail vacancy rate, but four storefronts near the Waldbaum's supermarket on Park Avenue have stood empty for several years, throwing a cloud over the shopping strip, which is near the center of town.
The new movie theater is expected to swell pedestrian traffic on Park Avenue, to the delight of merchants down the street like Ted Milan, who sells hand-rolled bagels and smoked salmon at his newly opened Max Bialystok. But the multiplex will be a modest community theater, said Michael G. Zapson, the former president of the City Council, and is not likely to raise the profile of Park Avenue's retail district.
"The downtown will never be a thriving retail community," said Mr. Zapson, who won a special election on May 4 to replace Mr. Nyman in the county Legislature. "It's a mom-and-pop kind of community."
Residents say few people from other parts of Long Island will cross a bridge to shop in Long Beach unless their destination is Mimi's Bags, a 40-year-old store that carries alligator purses costing $1,000. Mr. Eaton said national retailers have told him that they would rather be on a major thoroughfare and visible to thousands of drivers each day.
It is also uncertain whether Mr. Nyman and other city leaders can fulfill their goal of bringing Long Beach its first hotel in several decades. Last year, officials unveiled an ambitious plan to develop an empty site next to the boardwalk known as the superblock. The proposal, which called for an outdoor amphitheater and a hotel, did not go anywhere. Mr. Nyman is hopeful it can eventually be revived, but others are not as optimistic.
"The superblock is still high on the list of possibilities," said City Councilman Joel Crystal, who grew up in Long Beach along with his brother, the entertainer Billy Crystal. "But I'm willing to look at Plan B, whatever that might be."
The superblock plan also included an upscale assisted-living center for the elderly, but some longtime residents say Long Beach already has enough services for the aged, including a new extended-care center under construction next to City Hall. "I'd love to see a bowling alley come back into town," said Ms. Topper, the real estate broker.
While the superblock proposal languishes, Arnold Gumowitz, a developer, said he had asked the city to allow him to upgrade his drab luncheonette, the only sit-down restaurant on the boardwalk, and add a clam bar. But Francesca M. Capitano, a former City Council member -- and a Republican in a Democratic stronghold -- said more needs to be done to enable Long Beach to catch up with other resort communities. "There's still very little to do in the boardwalk area," Ms. Capitano said. "It remains underutilized."
More development on the boardwalk would make sense, city residents say, because Long Beach attracts thousands of day-trippers during the summer. The boardwalk is open to all, and to descend to the beach costs $5 for the day. Visitors from Manhattan can buy a $12 pass that includes a round-trip train ticket and admission to the beach. A family membership costs $50 for the season ($65 for nonresidents).
If Long Beach is going to entice more of these visitors to become permanent residents, it will have to improve the image of its public school system. The diverse student population is one-third black and Hispanic (including 2 percent who are non-English-speaking when they arrive), and many people have a negative impression of the schools even though students at the elementary and middle-school level do comparatively well on state reading and math tests.
Donna H. Fielding, president of the Parent-Teachers Association at the Lindell School, an elementary school, said the harshest assessments usually come from people who are looking at the schools from the outside.
"People who have children in the schools seem to feel that the schools are very good," she said, "even though there tends to be a perception sometimes that they're not."
Among the younger people in Long Beach who share that perception are Marcy and Andrew Cohen, both 32 and lawyers who practice in Jericho. They like living in a community they describe as a "private haven" but expect to buy a home somewhere else before their 1-year-old daughter, Jenna, is ready to go to school. "If the schools were significantly better," Mr. Cohen said, "we would consider staying here."

HEADLINE: The State, Quite Contently, Goes Minor League

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH 

 BODY:
MINOR league baseball, once on the verge of extinction, is booming around the country, and nowhere is its resurgence more evident than in Connecticut.
The state, which last month lost out in its attempt to bring the New England Patriots football team to Hartford, had only one minor league baseball team in 1993. But since then, one after another, teams have moved to the state, taking over old stadiums or building new ones. Today, five teams play in Bridgeport, New Britain, New Haven, Norwich, and Waterbury. 
 The state, aware of the advantages that minor league baseball can bring to a community, has invested millions of dollars for new ball parks. Indeed, of the $10.5 million needed to construct Dodd Stadium for the Norwich Navigators, $6 million came from the state, while another $1.5 million was granted by the Connecticut Development Authority. Another $500,000 to help cover the cost of sky boxes was donated by the Mashantucket Pequots, whose casino is in nearby Ledyard. The state also invested $8 million toward New Britain Stadium, whose overall cost was around $10 million. Of the $17 million spent to build The Ballpark at Harbor Yard in Bridgeport, the city contributed $7 million.
James Abromaitis, the commissioner of the State Economic and Community Development Department, said the state money is being well spent.
"It's hard to quantify exactly how much a community derives from the teams and the stadiums," he said. "But in most cases, almost all of the materials, including concession items, are purchased locally. And all of the signage on the outfield fences is usually bought by local area businesses. Then there are all the jobs created. Plus there's the feel-good aspect that is generated in the towns which have minor league teams in the state."
That's certainly the case in Bridgeport, where the Bluefish last year drew 305,123 fans to Harbor Yard, the striking new ball park that is between I-95 and Bridgeport Harbor. That was the highest attendance of any team in the state. The team has been such a success that Bridgeport officials hope that the Bluefish and its stadium will be the catalyst of a billion-dollar redevelopment project along the city waterfront.
"You drive along I-95 on game nights and you can't miss seeing the ball park and knowing that something is happening in Bridgeport," Mr. Abromaitis said.
This year the Bluefish, of the independent Atlantic Baseball League, are off to a strong start, drawing capacity crowds of more than 5,000 to their first two home games.
In New Haven, the Ravens, after spending their first five seasons as the Class AA affiliate of the Colorado Rockies of the National League, have switched their affiliation to the Seattle Mariners after drawing fewer fans at Yale Field than in either of their first four seasons.
To the east, the Norwich Navigators, a farm club of the New York Yankees, have a popular former New York Mets' outfielder, Lee Mazzilli of Greenwich, as their new manager.
In Waterbury, the Spirit will begin their third season on May 28 in a new league after having spent their first two years in the Northeast League, which is now the eastern division of the Northern League.
Bob Wirz, the president of the Spirit, said he hopes his team will be playing in a new stadium by 2001. The Naugatuck Valley Development Corporation has begun feasibility studies for a new ball park on a site where the Rogers Spoon factory once stood.
"Ultimately a new stadium will be needed for the Spirit," said Mr. Wirz, who owns a sports public relations and marketing business in Seymour. "New ball parks, as has been demonstrated in Bridgeport, Norwich and New Britain, make a big difference in drawing fans."
But all those teams are rookies compared to the baseball organization in New Britain, which has fielded teams in the area for 27 years. Although baseball will continue in New Britain, the man who has kept the game in the area as other teams around the state disappeared has said this season will probably be his last.
On an early evening in late April, Joe Buzas, the owner of the New Britain Rock Cats, greeted old friends as they entered the New Britain Stadium for that night's gamewith the Portland Sea Dogs.
"Hi, kid," Mr. Buzas, wearing a Rock Cats cap, called out to a middle-aged man who is a regular at the four-year old ball park in Willow Brook Park.
Many of the fans know that Mr. Buzas may sell the team, after owning Eastern League farm teams of the Boston Red Sox and Minnesota Twins in Bristol and New Britain since 1973. "A lot of them have been saying to me, 'You're not going to sell, are you, Joe?' " Mr. Buzas said. "And I tell them, I really don't want to because I love it here, but it looks like I will. I know they're very grateful that I kept a team in New Britain despite some difficult times."
Perhaps the worst time was in 1994 when he rebuffed an effort by the Red Sox management to move the New Britain Red Sox to Springfield, Mass. As a result, he lost the franchise, and found himself without a team until he reached an agreement with the Minnesota Twins, who placed their Class AA team in New Britain the next season.
Now, after 17 years in New Britain -- to which he had moved the Red Sox from Muzzy Field in Bristol -- Mr. Buzas has agreed to sell his team to a group of investors headed by Coleman B. Levy, a New Britain native who is a partner in a Farmington law firm, and William F. Dowling, a Manhattan lawyer who was an executive with the New York Yankees in the 1980's.
"It's a done deal as far as I'm concerned," said Mr. Buzas, who has done everything from waiting on customers at concession stands to helping get the field ready for play.
"They've given me a $100,000 deposit and have until Oct. 1 to pay the rest of the $7.5 million price that we agreed on," he said. "These are very respectable people and I don't see any problems developing."
Before winding up in New Britain, Mr. Buzas moved the franchise, a Red Sox affiliate until 1995, from Allentown to York and then Reading in Pennsylvania, to Pittsfield, Mass., and Pawtucket, R.I. Since he became a club owner in the 1950's, Mr. Buzas has had, as he puts it, "88 baseball operations" in 18 different cities, while running as many as four teams in four different leagues at the same time. And Mr. Buzas has even played the game, appearing in 30 games for the New York Yankees in 1945 -- including a start at shortstop on opening day at Yankee Stadium -- and spent about a decade in the minor leagues.
He is proud that in all his years as an owner he "made money in every single town.". That is particularly remarkable because the minor leagues reached their nadir during the 1970's and early 80's when scores of teams, and leagues, folded across the country, mainly because of the proliferation of televised baseball.
Indeed, from 1987 until the New Haven Ravens began play in 1994, New Britain was the only minor league team in the state after teams in West Haven and Waterbury had folded.
"I've succeeded because I've always been a hands-on owner, with good people around me," said Mr. Buzas, who, for the last decade, also has owned the Salt Lake City Buzz of the Class AAA Pacific Coast League.
Even with his dedication to the New Britain team, attendance has been chronically poor. Even though the Rock Cats won the Northern Division championship in the 10-team Eastern League last year -- many of the teams's players are now starters for the parent Minnesota Twins -- the Rock Cats drew a league-low 181,643 spectators to 6,146-seat New Britain Stadium. Crowds averaged 2,000 a game. At that, it was a team attendance record in New Britain. By comparison, the Norwich Navigators and New Haven Ravens, who finished fourth and fifth (last) in the Northern Division, attracted more fans -- 243,817 and 197,342, respectively. And the Ravens' attendance was the team's lowest since the franchise was founded in 1994.
"The team has done lousy in attendance, but we think we known how to market it better," said Mr. Levy of West Hartford, a partner in the Farmington law firm of Levy and Droney. "For one thing, we feel that, apart from the baseball, we have to provide more entertainment and enthusiasm at the ball park. Also, we view it as a Hartford area team and want to expand the fan base. After all, there are about a million people living within 20 minutes of the stadium."
Mr. Levy has no experience in professional baseball, but Mr. Dowling does. From 1986 through 1988, he was the general counsel and a vice president with the New York Yankees. After his three years with the Yankees, Mr. Dowling was a part owner of the Spartanburg, S.C., club in the South Atlantic League for several seasons.
"We have the opportunity to exploit a gorgeous ball park," Mr. Dowling said, "and with good promotion and marketing I'm sure we'll do well."
Mr. Dowling, who like Mr. Levy has been a lifelong baseball fan, will be the team's chief executive. "Even though I'll continue with our law firm in Manhattan, I'll spend two or three days at the ball park," said Mr. Dowling, who is a native of Holyoke, Mass. "It's not often in life that you get the chance to do something you've dreamt of doing, and I'm going to get that chance."
