HEADLINE: IN PERSON;
Let's Make A Deal

BYLINE: By KIRSTY SUCATO 

DATELINE: TRENTON

 BODY:
WHEN state officials hired Anthony R. Coscia, a 29-year-old lawyer who had never been to Trenton, to run the State Economic Development Authority in 1991, they did not have much to lose.
The independent agency, whose mission is to stimulate jobs and development by doling out low-interest loans and technical advice to businesses, had bottomed out. The recession was in full swing. Banks were reeling from bad debt and Congress had just overhauled the tax code, reining in a major lure to investors: tax-exempt development bonds. Even as the state's failing economy needed its help the most, the E.D.A. slumped. Its lending had dropped from about $500 million in 1986 to $95 million. 
 Mr. Coscia, a corporate finance lawyer known for his experience as a consultant to troubled financial institutions, was idealistic enough to think he could transform the agency. To everyone's surprise, he did.
"It was a unique mixture of self-confidence and naivete," said Christopher J. Paladino, president of the New Brunswick Development Corporation and deputy director of the E.D.A. from 1991 to 1994. "No one dared tell him that he shouldn't be able to accomplish it."
During the eight years of Mr. Coscia's tenure, the E.D.A. has become one of the most aggressive nonprofit development agencies in the country. Last year it lent $786 million to 258 projects. It has helped finance the New Jersey Performing Arts Center in Newark; a 600,000-square-foot aerospace manufacturing complex in Camden now owned by Martin Marietta, and the Technology Center of New Jersey, a research park in North Brunswick designed to lure high-technology businesses to the state.
Mr. Coscia's tenure, spanning two administrations, has taken him from unpaid consultant to executive director to volunteer chairman, appointed by Gov. James Florio as the first non-Cabinet member to hold the post. Governor Whitman thought enough of his abilities to keep him on in 1994.
Gualberto Medina, Mrs. Whitman's Commerce Secretary, said he intended to fire Mr. Coscia, and take the influential job himself, but changed his mind after meeting him.
"The tendency is basically to replace key people with your own people," he said. "But Tony transcends party politics because he brings a technical know-how, a passion and commitment to the economic growth of the state that frankly defies political affiliation."
Words like vision, dedication, and savvy pop up frequently when insiders talk about Mr. Coscia, a partner in the law firm of Windels, Marx, Davies & Ives, in a pattern that seems almost too good to be true. For his part, he describes himself as a dull family man who loves to put together deals.
That family -- his wife, Alice, and their five children, ages 3 to 11 -- lives in North Caldwell, where Mr. Coscia coaches his 7-year-old son's Little League baseball team and takes the clan to church on Sundays.
"I'm sure if you ask any of my neighbors, they have no idea what I do for a living because I don't even bring it up," he said.
For the record, Mr. Coscia is not active in local politics. He doesn't have any particular hobbies (he says he is terrible at golf). And he doesn't drive a flashy car -- he has a 1991 Acura Legend).
He's simply a man who gets his kicks putting together complicated financial transactions to improve the New Jersey economy.
The Economic Development Agency's turnaround began in 1991 when Mr. Coscia began operating it like a bank, rather than a state agency. He imposed stiffer financial reporting requirements on applicants, fired and reorganized staff and developed new financing programs to lure Wall Street investors.
"Some of the things that you could put in place to clean up the agency's financial situation internally as well the image it would project externally were relatively easy things to accomplish," he said. "But they were never really done up to that point because it never really pictured itself as what it was, which was like a bank."
He instituted a program that bundled loans for small businesses in $50,000 packages, and sold them to large investors. To entice banks battered by bad credit into lending to small and mid-sized businesses, the agency began to guarantee portions of commercial loans and to finance gaps in project costs at lower interest rates, something the E.D.A. had not been done before.
"The E.D.A. used to be a place that would take what money it had and lend it to a company and hope they'd get it back," Mr. Paladino said. "Tony made it a place where he took that dollar and got the private sector to match it with four or five or six dollars."
Douglas L. Kennedy, the president and C.E.O. of Fleet Bank-N.J., said Mr. Coscia was widely respected as an expert in structured financing. Fleet recently agreed to lend $25 million to high-tech companies in the state as part of a larger E.D.A. program.
The Trenton-based agency has 105 employees and is self-supporting, generating its $10 million annual operating budget through returns on investments. (It started in 1974 on a $200,000 state loan.) Its basic mission is to leverage state and Federal dollars into investments that will help companies to expand or move to New Jersey.
In one large project, the Camden E-Center, the agency combined $25 million in state, county and Federal aid to buy a 15-acre vacant industrial lot on the Camden waterfront. It leased the property to Blockbuster, Sony Music and Pace Entertainment, which spent $31 million to build a 25,000-seat amphitheater for concerts and sports events there. The E-Center, which opened in 1995, will return about $23 million to the city and investors over 30 years from a surcharge on ticket prices. It employs 500 people, mostly Camden residents.
Some lawmakers have criticized E.D.A. programs, saying they venture too far into the realm of corporate welfare. Last year, State House Democrats fiercely protested a plan to give A.T.&T. an $8 million incentive grant to open a research laboratory in Monmouth County. Under the plan, the company agreed to create 1,500 jobs. But in a separate move, it announced that it would lay off about 3,500 workers at other sites.
Senator Richard J. Codey, the minority leader, introduced a resolution, still in committee, that would require a net job growth before the E.D.A. could award employment incentive grants to companies.
"A company is not supposed to get a grant if it creates 100 jobs in one location in New Jersey but eliminates 500 positions in another part of the state," Senator Codey said. "Business incentives should be used as bargaining chips to build employment in New Jersey. Commerce officials seem eager to throw a stack of chips at any company that comes calling for them."
Mr. Coscia, who was raised in Paterson as the son of an immigrant cement mason and a seamstress, takes pains to point out that most of the agency's money goes to companies with fewer than 200 employees, with priority going to urban centers and businesses owned by minorities and women.
He points to successes like Eatem Corporation, a Vineland-based company that manufactures soup bases and other food. It has expanded from three men working out of a small cheese factory to 65 employees in an 41,500-square-foot factory. The E.D.A. has backed four loans to the company over the past 10 years worth about $6.8 million.
The agency has increasingly focused on technology companies. In 1997, it approved a $1.3 million grant over 10 years to lure Datek Online Brokerage Services Corporation, then a four-year-old Internet trading company, a division of Datek Securities Corporation, from Manhattan to Iselin.
The company, which started with 30 employees, now has 468 workers; it expects to hire another 700 over the next two years with the help of another $2.5 million grant.
Mr. Coscia says he plans to stay on as chairman for as long as he is needed.
"He has had the opportunity to be creative in areas where people 10 and 15 years his senior usually get to be creative," said Mr. Paladino. "He's gotten to break new ground normally broken by people with gray hair. The only downside now is that people expect him to do it every day."
 
For Rent: 50 Acres of High-Tech Space
IT has been a common complaint among high-tech companies thinking of moving to New Jersey: The state may be known as the pharmaceutical capital of the world, but it has no decent laboratory space for rent.
That is finally beginning to change, thanks to a $35 million project by the State Economic Development Authority to convert an old Johnson & Johnson laboratory and administration building in North Brunswick to a research park.
The 50-acre campus, called the Technology Center of New Jersey, will eventually have five buildings with a total of 300,000 square feet of laboratory space. The project, now about half complete, has already achieved 80 percent occupancy with seven tenants, including Merial Limited, a global company that does research on animal health and poultry genetics, and Celgro, a subsidiary of the biotechnology company Celgene Corporation, which develops herbicides and pesticides.
The companies are neither tiny start-ups that attract venture capitalists nor established corporations that can afford to build their own laboratories, said Anthony R. Coscia, the chairman of the State Economic Development Authority. Rather, he said, they fall in a middle ground that is less compelling to investors.
"The idea is that if you go back to E.D.A.'s fundamental mission, which is to be a bank to bridge the gaps, we found that even though the economy was strong, we were still lacking in capital for expansion," he said.
The agency financed the project largely through a $22.2 million loan from the A.F.L.-C.I.O.'s Building Investment Trust, a pension fund that invests in commercial real estate development. The remainder came from state grants, E.D.A. loans and rent paid by tenants, Mr. Coscia said.
John W. Jackson, the chairman and C.E.O. of the Celgene Corporation, said he was attracted by economic incentives including a grant program that offered $100 a square foot for new equipment.
"By getting the funding from the E.D.A., it made it a very simple decision to stay in New Jersey," he said.
Other tenants include Advanced Care Products, which develops over-the-counter hygiene products; Datamark Software Inc., a marketing firm; the Agriculture Research Project of Rutgers University's Cook College, which coordinates the research activities of 37 labs across the country, and Chubb Computer Systems, which provides training and consulting for information systems.
James W. Hughes, the dean of the Edward J. Bloustein School of Public Planning and Policy, called the park an example of the intelligent re-use of a site.
"It would have had a 'for rent' sign on it and it might have been another discount mall rather than an area of any economic activity," he said. KIRSTY SUCATO

HEADLINE: ON THE MAP;
A Street Chess Club Goes to College

BYLINE: By STEVE STRUNSKY 

 BODY:
In the game room of the Paul Robeson Student Center at Rutgers University's Newark campus, a cacophony of rap music and the clicking and clacking of Ping-Pong and billiard balls ricochets over the bowed heads of the Downtown Chess Club. But what distraction could a few student activities be after you've played chess outdoors on a winter night?
The club had been shooed from its first home, under the awning of the old Bamberger's on Halsey Street. Two years ago, when work on their next location, Military Park, threatened them with another eviction, campus officials invited them indoors to the Robeson Center. The club has since joined the United States Chess Federation,and its members provide competition for the Rutgers-Newark Chess Club. 
 The Downtown president, Ause Dye, 52, a contractor who lives in Newark's South Ward, recently talked about the club.
Q. How did the club start?
A. The Downtown Chess Club is a gathering of street chess players, who started out playing on Halsey Street and Market in downtown Newark. When I first met these guys they were for the most part unemployed older guys. They were interested in chess, but didn't have a formal club setting or any place to play.
Q. Why "Downtown?"
A. Playing downtown was a key ingredient because, for me, for a lot of the other guys, it was an ambassadorship. You come, you play, you see the guys out there. You don't have to be afraid of the citizens of Newark. It's not about carjacking, it's not about mugging or robbing. You know, you sit down to play chess, the first thing you have to do is give me enough respect to understand I have some type of intelligence. And if we can play this game, we can communicate with each other. People have said how safe they felt in working late knowing that we were playing in the park, till 10:30 or 11 at night in the summer.
Q. How did you start playing chess?
A. I've been messing around with chess for about 10 years, on and off. It was in the basement of a coffeehouse, the Presbyterian Church on West Market and Roseville, in the late 60's, early 70's. I used to go to New York, to the New York Chess and Checker Club on 42d Street, right off Eighth Avenue. There was one elderly gentleman who taught me how to play for time and coffee.
I disappeared from chess for a couple years, then I started again at the Driftwood Lounge on Fourth Avenue in East Orange. It was just a bar where a lot of guys got together and played chess. The Peppermint Lounge was like that, that's Orange, Central Avenue. And there's another little place on Springfield Avenue in Newark called Mercedes & Main, where they play chess.
Q. What do you hope the club achieves?
A. Given a formal environment, we're looking to see a lot of productivity. We're looking to see a lot of Bobby Fischers and Maurice Ashley potentials coming out of the woodwork. You give them something to sink their teeth into young. Chess may not be the way they should go, but it will be a venue to help them get where they're going the right way. STEVE STRUNSKY

HEADLINE: STRATEGIES;
Impersonating The Insiders: Yes, It Pays

BYLINE: By MARK HULBERT; Mark Hulbert is editor of the Hulbert Financial Digest, a newsletter based in Alexandria, Va. His column on investment strategies appears every other week.
E-mail: strategy@nytimes.com.

 BODY:
DO they or don't they? Do corporate insiders -- like company directors and officers -- know so much more than we do about their company's prospects that we can beat the market simply by imitating their purchases and sales?
Opinion varies widely on this question, partly because researchers themselves have changed their minds. The initial answers came more than 30 years ago, in several academic studies that found that investors could beat the market simply by buying the stocks that insiders were buying. Particularly compelling was the fact that unlike some other strategies, this one was so easy to pursue. The Securities and Exchange Commission requires insiders to report their purchases and sales, and several investment newsletters translate that data into investor-friendly formats. 
 The strategy was the conventional wisdom for many years. But serious doubts were raised in the 1980's, when researchers found that the insiders of small-capitalization companies were more likely to buy their companies' shares than were the insiders of larger companies. And they found that insiders of value-oriented companies -- defined as those trading at the lowest price-to-book ratios -- were more likely to buy than those of growth-oriented companies.
That research placed the earlier studies in a very different light. It meant that those landmark studies from the 1960's might have discovered little more than the long-term tendency for small-cap stocks to outperform large-cap stocks, and for value stocks to outperform growth stocks. The upshot of the newer research was that if your portfolio was already concentrated in small-cap value stocks, you gained no advantage from paying attention to insiders.
That new consensus also lasted for some years. But it, too, has come under fire, as a number of researchers have looked into whether the patterns have endured.
In fact, they have found several wrinkles.
One study, circulating as a working paper, was conducted by Leslie Jeng, an associate professor of finance and economics at Boston University, and Andrew Metrick and Richard Zeckhauser, an associate professor of economics and a professor of political economy, respectively, at Harvard. In effect, they have found that the studies from the 1960's were on to something after all. Though the impact of insider buying and selling is strongest among small-cap value stocks, they found that it nonetheless exists among large-cap growth stocks, too.
The professors reached their conclusion by examining every stock insiders bought from 1975 to 1996. A hypothetical portfolio that held each of these stocks for one year, and in the amounts bought by the insiders, would have outperformed the market by 7.4 percentage points annually, before transaction costs. The study found that only one-third of this outperformance could be explained by the disproportionate propensity of insiders at small-cap and value-oriented companies to buy their companies' stocks. That means that even investors in large-cap growth stocks can bolster returns by following the insiders' lead, though not as much as with small-cap value stocks.
FORTUNATELY, you don't even have to react immediately upon learning of an insider's buying. True, such a stock most likely will have already risen by the time the insider's purchase is reported publicly. But the professors, looking at the amount by which such a stock beat the market over the next year, found that two-thirds of the outperformance came after the first month. In other words, you needn't be a day trader to benefit from the strategy.
Still, the professors found that stocks sold by insiders performed no better or worse, on average, than the overall market. That makes sense, because insiders have many reasons for raising cash. But there is just one primary reason insiders buy their company's stock: They think it will go up.
More companies have been lending money to insiders to buy their shares, prompting suggestions that the insider-imitation strategy could become less profitable. But these loan programs have gained steam only in the last two years, after the period in the study, so their effect is not yet known.

It has beaten the Russell 2000 Value Index, which tracks these stocks, but both trail the Standard & Poor's 500 index of large-cap stocks.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST SIDE;
A Rent Battle That Arose When Reagan Was President

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
In the sometimes Dickensian world of New York litigation, how long does it take to settle a case? Ask Peter and Alexandra Rose, who have been fighting with their landlord over their rent for 15 years. And it's not over yet.
Flashback: it's 1975. Abraham D. Beame is Mayor, Gerald R. Ford is President. Mr. and Mrs. Rose sign a lease for an apartment on East 58th Street that is subject to the city's rent-stabilization laws. The previous tenant, a commercial one, is the First National City Bank, as Citibank was then called. 
 Flash forward to 1984. The Roses have long been suspicious that they had been overcharged by their landlord. The overcharges are continuing, they say, because under their lease, the periodic rent increases are premised upon the previous rent. The couple file a complaint with the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal.
After many stops and starts -- the agency apparently misplaced their paperwork, so that they had to file again in 1986, before the original paperwork was then found -- Mr. and Mrs. Rose won their case. The landlord asked for reconsideration; the Roses won again. Then the landlord filed an appeal. That was in 1989.
Flash forward again, to November 1998. Like a bear lumbering to life after nearly a decade's hibernation, the Department of Housing and Community Renewal renders its decision. It reversed the previous orders and raised Mr. and Mrs. Rose's rent retroactively, rendering them liable for "something like $18,000 in back rent," said Rose Ann Magaldi, their attorney.
Ms. Magaldi has brought a proceeding in State Supreme Court in Manhattan to overturn the procedure used by the state to reach its findings. Her legal arguments involve issues such as "applicable base dates" for rent determinations and the appropriateness of using commercial rents in determining residential rents.
The state and the landlord, Blair House, have submitted papers supporting the increase, which Stuart F. Shaw, a lawyer for Blair House, called "reasonable and rational." Acting Justice Jane S. Solomon is expected to rule within a few weeks.
In the meantime, Mr. Rose, an art dealer, and his wife, a photo researcher, remain liable for the higher rents. They say they will suffer extreme hardship if the rent increase is upheld. "There's a $300 to $400 a month difference," with the new rent pegged at more than $2,000, Mr. Rose said, not to mention the arrears, which he laid to the state's delay.
So why did the state take so long to decide this case? A reasonable question, but an answer is unlikely at the moment. "We do not comment on matters in litigation," said Diane Ackerman, a spokeswoman for the Division of Housing and Community Renewal. BERNARD STAMLER

HEADLINE: Now, Before You Go Cruising You Must Do Some Choosing

BYLINE: By JIM McCRAW 

 BODY:
JUST five years ago, if you wanted a cruiser motorcycle you bought a Harley. End of story.
But that was before cruisers became an American phenomenon. Come summer, highways and parking lots from coast to coast will be buzzing with these machines designed for easy long-distance travel and characterized by their roomy saddles and upright, relaxed riding positions. 
 Cruisers now represent 55 percent of the American motorcycle market, according to Don Brown of DJB Associates, a consulting firm in Irvine, Calif., up from 10 percent in 1991. He estimates that cruiser sales grew 17 percent last year, to 154,000. He expects sales to top 180,000 next year.
Cruiser motorcycles offer their buyers -- many of them baby boomers -- freedom from their cars, and also individuality, adventure and fellowship with other riders. Beneficiaries of increased disposable income in a booming economy, cruisers offer an alternative to adult toys like sports cars or boats. They are more maneuverable than heavy touring bikes and more comfortable than agile sport bikes.
There are more cruisers for sale this spring than ever before. Not only is Harley-Davidson working on new models -- it already has 24 on the market -- but all four Japanese manufacturers have invested heavily in cruisers and the Europeans aren't far behind. There are also two new American manufacturers, Excelsior-Henderson and Polaris.
Harley-Davidson's share of the American cruiser market may have slipped -- to about 55 percent from 100 percent in half a decade -- but it still sets the tone for all cruisers. Harleys have an imposing presence -- visually and aurally -- with their big V-twin engines, big torque, big fenders, big tanks, big saddles for two, small mufflers (the better to keep the noise level high), low seat height (more accommodating for either male or female riders), lustrous paint and chrome and lots of custom accessories.
Harley-Davidson may have had this market to itself for decades, but its tremendous success -- customers routinely have to wait six months for delivery -- convinced other motorcycle companies to jump into the cruiser segment. Here are eight of the leading cruisers on the market this summer:
 
BMW R1200C -- The giant German auto and motorcycle maker introduced its first cruiser last year after going 75 years without one, and it quickly became the company's best-selling motorcycle.
The R1200C uses BMW's traditional horizontally opposed 1,170-cubic-centimeter fuel-injected engine -- the company's largest, most powerful ever. The smallest engine in the senior cruiser group, it produces more than 70 foot-pounds of torque with a five-speed transmission and BMW's time-tested shaft-drive system.
The suspension is unlike most cruisers', with the company's patented Telelever front and Monolever rear suspension instead of conventional forks and swing arms. The R1200C is the most radical-looking cruiser, with its pulled-back handlebars -- nearly chopper style -- a solo saddle with a pillion pad behind it, a simple bar-mounted gauge cluster and more chrome than you'll find on any other BMW. Options include saddle bags, a tank bag and -- unique among cruisers -- anti-lock brakes.
Inside track: The flashiest cruiser.
 
EXCELSIOR-HENDERSON SUPER X -- A combination of two classic American motorcycle brands that went out of production decades ago, the Excelsior-Henderson is built by the Hanlon family and their staff in a new factory in Belle Plaine, Minn.
The Super X has a 1,386 cc 50-degree V-twin engine with overhead cams, four valves per cylinder and electronic fuel injection. There is an exposed coil spring leading-link front suspension; the forks go right through the fenders, just like those on the 1931 Excelsior. The fenders are fully valanced -- they cover the tread, and much of the sidewall, of the tires -- another nostalgic touch. The Super X has quiet belt drive instead of chain or shaft drive.
The Super X is pricey -- $18,000 for solid black, more for two-tone versions.
Inside track: Lots of power; great brakes.
 
HARLEY-DAVIDSON ROAD KING -- Of Harley's 24 models, the Road King is the prototypical cruiser. This year, it features the all-new Twin Cam 88, a 45-degree V-twin engine of 88 cubic inches that produces 82 foot-pounds of torque. The engine is mounted indirectly to minimize vibration and is linked to a five-speed transmission and a quiet, reinforced rubber-belt drive system.
Like all Harleys, the Road King makes few concessions to weight reduction; while the Japanese and German bikes are using aluminum, the Harley packs a lot of iron and steel under its paint. Consequently, it weighs 699 pounds on a short 63.5-inch wheelbase.
The Road King can be dressed out with hundreds of Harley-Davidson accessories from windshields and extra driving lamps to saddle bags and chrome dress-up items.
Inside track: The best all-round Harley.
 
HONDA VALKYRIE -- Instead of a V-twin engine, Honda uses the "flat," or horizontally opposed, 1,520 cc six-cylinder engine from the huge Gold Wing touring bike, only with more power and torque. The Valkyrie is the quickest and fastest cruiser you can buy.
For 1999, Honda offers the basic Valkyrie, the dressed-up Valkyrie Tourer and the full-dress Valkyrie Interstate, all using the flat six with six carburetors and more than 100 horsepower. They all have five-speed transmissions, shaft drive and triple-disk brakes.
The dry, or unloaded, weight is 682 pounds. The Honda has a 66.5-inch wheelbase and a relatively tall seat height of 29.1 inches. Valkyries run from $12,799 to $15,999, depending on the model and paint.
Inside track: Tops in power.
 
KAWASAKI DRIFTER 1500 -- The new Drifter is a cruiser designed to look like the venerable Indian Chief last produced in 1953. Its designers chose black paint instead of chrome for its frame, forks, headlamp housing, fender braces and bag mounts -- a decidedly retro thing to do.
The Drifter's 1500 cc V-twin engine has four valves and two spark plugs per cylinder and uses digital electronic fuel injection. There is a counterbalancing shaft and rubber engine mounts for smoothness. The five-speed transmission automatically helps the rider to find neutral and uses shaft drive to transmit power to the rear wheel.
The Drifter weighs 668 pounds, rides on a 65.2-inch wheelbase and has a 29.1-inch seat height. Prices start at $11,499; a lot of accessories are available, including two saddles, a tank trim panel and accessory headlamps.
Inside track: Long on torque and nostalgia.
 
POLARIS VICTORY V92C -- This is the first motorcycle from Polaris, a company famous for its snowmobiles and personal watercraft. Built along very traditional but very clean lines, the deep-fendered Victory uses a 1,507 cc V-twin engine with the cylinders splayed at a 50-degree angle.
It is a single-overhead-cam engine with oil cooling, four valves per cylinder and electronic fuel injection that produces a lot of torque. The Victory uses a five-speed transmission and belt drive, as well as cast aluminum wheels. Unlike most cruisers, the Victory's engine is used as a part of the frame to give the chassis added strength.
Inside track: An excellent first effort.
 
SUZUKI VL1500 INTRUDER -- Suzuki builds V-twin cruisers with the most radical designs, featuring very tall engine cylinders with a narrow V-angle, chopper-style gas tanks and alloy front and rear wheels.
The VL1500 Intruder has a 45-degree V-twin engine like the Harley's, liquid-cooled and tuned for peak torque at very low engine speeds. The engine uses dual-downdraft 36-millimeter carburetors and hydraulic valve adjusters for minimal maintenance. There is also a digital electronic ignition system, a five-speed transmission and maintenenace-free shaft drive. The suggested retail price is $9,899.
Inside track: The four-digit pricing is attractive.
 
YAMAHA ROAD STAR -- This is the most Harley-like of all the Japanese cruisers, and its mechanical formula is simplicity itself. It uses a 1,602 cc 48-degree overhead-valve V-twin engine, the largest in the industry. It has one cam, four valves and two spark plugs per cylinder, and the most torque -- 99 foot-pounds. The single-carburetor engine puts power through a five-speed transmission and Yamaha's first belt-drive system.
The Road Star has a retro instrument cluster with Art Deco graphics, lots of chrome trim and more than 100 accessories from lights to luggage.
Inside track: Awesome torque, Harley looks.

HEADLINE: PERSONAL BUSINESS;
Wedded To Its Moral Imperatives

BYLINE: By ANDREA ADELSON 

DATELINE: FALLEN LEAF LAKE, Calif.

 BODY:
HERE amid the snow-covered pines near Lake Tahoe, Patagonia Inc. held its fourth annual weekend training conference last month. In what one participant called a "summer camp for tree-huggers," community organizers in various environmental causes came from far and wide to learn how to be more effective.
David Olsen, chief executive of Patagonia, the trendsetter in specialty outdoor clothing, told the 70 or so participants, "We've invited you here because we want you to raise hell and we support you in raising hell." 
 Known for elegantly simple product design, Patagonia, based in Ventura, Calif., has long practiced environmental responsibility quietly, converting its buildings to wind power, eliminating toxic dyes from its products and making baby clothes from fabric scraps left over from the adult line. But now the privately held company's owners have renounced that reticence. It's their business, and they've decided to use it as their soapbox, as well. "We came out of the closet," said Yvon Chouinard, Patagonia's president and co-founder.
The company's spring catalogue, mailed to 725,000 people worldwide, takes a stand on an issue way beyond the clothing realm: removal of dams in five areas around the country, including the Snake River of Washington. And all six of its board members recently demonstrated to save an ancient redwood forest in Northern California.
In short, Patagonia is risking its brand name and reputation on an unusual brand of corporate philanthropy. Rather than just writing checks to local charities, it is training activists and taking bold positions.
That can alienate customers, of course. Patagonia's latest crusade was criticized as a "biased and misleading diatribe" by Francois X. Forgette, an official of the Tri-City Area Chamber of Commerce in Kennewick, Wash., which could suffer economically if four dams on the lower Snake River were razed. Mr. Forgette called for a boycott of Patagonia and suggested that the company "stick to its knitting."
Mr. Chouinard says it is. He considers environmentalism a fundamental part of the company's image, and when he saw that reputation shifting toward rivals like North Face and R.E.I., he decided to increase company efforts. And this comes even as some of Patagonia's early innovations, like spinning fleece from recycled soda bottles, are being jettisoned by others that had copied them. "Unless Patagonia gets out there and talks about it, they won't be an exemplar," said Chris L. Desser, a Patagonia board member and a recent appointee to the California agency that regulates coastal development. "Most companies are wholly driven by the bottom line, but Patagonia is not going to sacrifice the environment for the bottom line."
Although environmental good deeds would seem to burnish a company's image with many potential customers, donations to environmental causes may not rank very high. Among foundations, grants to such causes make up just 2 percent of all financing, according to the Foundation Center.
There was considerable soul-searching among Patagonia's managers over whether the company should seek to use its environmental ethic as a corporate guide, Mr. Chouinard said. "We don't want to be accused of green marketing" -- trying to profit from the appearance of doing the right thing -- Mr. Chouinard said. But a big change swept in a year ago, after Patagonia commissioned its first customer survey. Executives were appalled to find Patagonia was seen as dead last among outdoor companies considered environmental leaders.
Yet the company's environmentalism may not be helping. The privately heldcompany had sales of $165 million in the fiscal year ended April 1998. It does not report profits, but there are signs that they have been flat. The company donates 1 percent of revenue, or 10 percent of pretax profits, whichever is higher, to local environmental groups, and that figure has held steady at about $1.2 million for the last three years. The company may also have been hurt because it failed to capitalize on two popular sports, indoor rock climbing and snowboarding.
But Mr. Olsen, Patagonia's chief, is unconcerned. "A lot of environmental things we're going to do whether they give us a benefit in the market or not," he said.
One thing the company is committed to is the "tree hugger" camps. The youthful local organizers paid their own way to the three-day event, which cost Patagonia about $60,000. Seasoned organizers shared secrets of fund-raising, marketing and building membership. Their environmental causes ranged from buffalo herds to logging.
Patagonia suppliers are also subject to environmental evangelism, pressed by the company to show ecological gains or risk losing Patagonia's business.
The idea has met with some resistance from suppliers who "thought it wasn't a level playing field," said Rob C. Koeppel, vice president of Shawmut Mills, a division of R. H. Wyner Associates, a maker of laminated fabrics. He said offshore suppliers could more easily show environmental progress because of lower standards.
A private company, though, can afford to pursue moral imperatives since it need not cater to shareholders, an argument Mr. Chouinard said he's heard numerous times.
"I'm absolutely convinced everything we do does benefit the company," Mr. Chouinard said, before leaving for mountain climbing in Tibet. "Most companies give money to the symphony. It's safe. When other companies see nothing bad comes of it," he said of Patagonia's advocacy, "they'll be emboldened. It's not going to come back to bite us."

HEADLINE: At Ivy Club, A Trip Back to Elitism

BYLINE: By MONIQUE P. YAZIGI 

 BODY:
SHOULD the members of the Ivy Club ever face the withering scrutiny of a Fifth Avenue co-op board or a Fairfield County country club, they will be well prepared.
To get into Ivy, the oldest, most expensive and most patrician eating club at Princeton University, candidates must sit for 10 one-on-one interviews with members, whose attempts to plumb their souls touch on what their parents do, where they spend summers and who their friends are. 
 Then the entire century-old club votes on prospects in all-night sessions. Like an English men's club, there is a blackball rule: if one of 130 members vetoes a candidate, he or she is rejected -- "hosed" in the tart campus vernacular.
Lately, more and more students are being hosed who don't fit Ivy's image as a haven for Eastern establishment, Social Register types, what one former member called "a club full of sons and daughters of C.E.O.'s."
At Princeton, where more than 80 percent of juniors and seniors eat meals in one of 11 privately owned clubs on Prospect Avenue, known as "the Street," the eating clubs dominate social life. They determine not only the students' dinner partners but also whom they socialize with on Thursday and Saturday party nights, and in some cases they can imprint a person's identity for life.
A few years ago, in the wake of a widely reported 1990 court decision that forced Princeton's eating clubs to admit women, Ivy became more democratic and socially open. Not only women, but also students of different races and more diverse social backgrounds were welcomed during "bicker," the yearly selection process.
"I remember meetings, open discussions about changing the perception of the club," said Sophie Glenn of Princeton's class of '92, who was one of the first women admitted to Ivy. "It was brought up that it would be in the club's interest to be more diverse, especially in the backgrounds of people, because it was always perceived as a snotty place for rich white kids.
"There was a conscious effort to diversify," she said.
But now the pendulum is swinging back, in part a reflection of an increasingly status-conscious, money-conscious era. The race for credentials and connections like an Ivy membership begins, at least in places like New York and Los Angeles, with selective nursery schools, and is incited by a culture that makes popular heroes out of Wall Street's winners.
Today, Ivy has fewer members from minority groups and public schools than in the early 90's, present and past members say. Atu Darko, a senior who dropped out of Ivy in February, was one of four of nine black members who left the eating club in the last academic year, citing their discomfort. "When I first got there, it was more international, but over the years it became very WASP," said Mr. Darko, who is the son of Ghanaian immigrants and graduated from the Bronx High School of Science. "It had to do with the membership's choosing new members. I think less international kids bickered, or less minorities bickered because they felt uncomfortable."
He added: "To get into Ivy you have to know a lot of people. You have to be well liked. You have to have a social background. It's so much social climbing."
As Ivy swings back to what F. Scott Fitzgerald called a "detached and breathlessly aristocratic" club, present and former Princeton students and faculty members are not surprised.
"In a way the Ivy Club is certainly in tune with current trends, if not even ahead of the curve," said Uwe E. Reinhardt, the James Madison Professor of Political Economy at Princeton, whose daughter, Kara, was in Ivy. "If you look at American society, in certainly the world Fitzgerald wrote about, we are divided by class. We are sliding back toward a society dominated by a corporate society. I think in our corporate elite, there is a Marie Antoinette complex, and that percolates down to Princeton."
Marshall Heyman, a junior from Bridgewater, N.J., whose mother was congratulated in the supermarket when he got into Ivy, said, "When you got here, you knew it would be academically competitive, but it took a while to learn that it's even more a socially competitive place."
The Ivy Club, where membership costs $5,660 a year, is a three-story brick mansion set behind iron gates. The dining room, billiard room and library are a procession of red leather club chairs, mahogany walls and oil paintings of Fitzgerald-era "lacrosse gentlemen."
Members eat at long tables covered with crisp white linens and set with 19th-century Sheffield silver candelabra, which are lighted even when daylight streams into the windows.
After dinner, the men tend to separate from the women and socialize with drinks in hand, discussing the day's Wall Street Journal, a scene more reminiscent of 30-year-olds at a country club than of college students.
"You might as well train these kids in the mannerisms of the well-to-do because most of them are going to wind up there," Professor Reinhardt said. "They are served food. There are tablecloths. It's very genteel, and I'm not sure what's wrong with that."
The formality can unnerve some not to the manner born. Mr. Heyman said that though he is a product of private schools and professional parents (a lawyer and a doctor), he would have been mortified a year ago at dropping his knife, as he did at dinner the other night. When the knife dropped, he looked into the eyes of his table mates to see if anyone had noticed. No one had. "That would have made me more nervous a year ago," he said, quickly retrieving the knife. "But I'm much better now."
When Nat Zilkha, who grew up in Portland, Me., and went to boarding school at Andover, was accepted by Ivy, his older sister had one piece of advice: "Get a tux." The club sponsors nearly a dozen black-tie parties a year, including one during February's initiation week for new members (which also includes the tradition of passing newcomers naked down a staircase, modified in the 90's to allow women to keep their underwear on).
A woman who dropped out of Ivy last winter, because she felt she was not from a prominent enough background, said the club is full of "people who don't have any concept of money." She did not want to be identified because she felt it would be bad for her social life. Raised in a middle-class family, she felt uneasy being served four-course dinners by a uniformed staff. "If you're not flying off to London on spring weekends, you'll end up feeling left out," she said.
Ivy's current membership of 130 includes Mary Bonner Baker, a daughter of James A. Baker 3d, the former Secretary of State; Moira Forbes, a daughter of Steve Forbes, the Presidential contender, and Mary Firestone, a descendant of the founder of the tire company.
James Q. Griffin, a 1955 Princeton graduate and president of the alumni board that governs Ivy, said that in membership, "I can't see any difference between the way it is now and 50 years ago."
He added: "It's a Jeffersonian democracy, taking the natural aristocracy, as you were. There's no social pyramid."
In essence, cream rises to the top.
He pointed out that interest in joining the club was at an all-time high, and "by that very definition, there is something that seems attractive."
In the latest bicker, 130 sophomores and juniors applied to Ivy, and 67 were accepted. All along the Street, the five clubs that select their members attracted the most sophomore applicants since 1994, and the six eating clubs that accept new members by lottery attracted the fewest since 1994.
The popularity of the bicker clubs frustrates some Princeton administrators, who have never been entirely happy with the system, one that is unlike that at any other Ivy League university. "I think there are problems with selectivity of any kind on the college campus, because selectivity excludes people," said Janina Montero, dean of student life.
But the administration and the clubs, whose relations have swung between hostility and accommodation over the years, are in a period of relative truce in the 90's.
Ivy's popularity seems inseparable from a wider fixation on elite schools, blue-chip addresses and the trappings of upper-class gentility. Alumni in New York in their 40's say that for the first time friends are seeking their help in getting children who are in private secondary schools into Ivy. "It's absurd," said an alumnus who said he was asked to provide references. "Why don't they worry about getting their kid into Princeton first?"
He did not want to be identified because he thought it might spoil the chances for his own high-school-age son to get into Ivy one day.
Collectively, Princeton students are more racially and ethnically diverse than in the past, and as a dress code, the L. L. Bean styles of a generation ago have been replaced by T-shirts, baseball caps and Birkenstocks, a generic geek chic. Ivy, however, is a last bastion of traditional dress and etiquette.
"When you see a movie about Princeton -- proper, WASP, preppy, they dress nice and they are smart and tell you how smart they are -- that's Ivy," said Joe Juliano, a senior, who worked as a bouncer during Ivy parties but is not a member. "Princeton doesn't look like that anymore, but Ivy does."
Still, the question of members' ethnic and economic backgrounds is more complex. The membership seems calculated to be a mix of old-line families, new-money heirs and even a group on financial aid. "Of course, there's still diversity," one Ivy alumnus said. "About 20 percent. They are there to make the other 80 percent show they are democratic and feel more superior."
Ivy members invariably maintain that the club is diverse. "We pick people who are diverse," said Mr. Zilkha, the social chairman. He spoke of members who perform in an a cappella singing group, play the guitar and are active in the arts and drama.
"Exactly," responded Mr. Darko, the student who resigned from Ivy this year. He said the club interpreted diversity to mean members with broad interests, rather than with broad ethnic and economic backgrounds. "Diversity to me means seeing different faces, people with different income brackets and different clothing styles," he added.
Mr. Darko, a senior classics major who won a Fulbright fellowship for study abroad after graduation, said that he did not feel racial bias at Ivy; he simply grew tired of the homogeneity and closed-mindedness. "I couldn't identify with the people in the club," he said. "Everything was the same old same old. Same old music. Same bad beer. The club is not open to change."
"Ivy would never play Motown," he added.
Reared in Manhattan by parents from Ghana -- his mother is a psychotherapist, his father a probation officer -- Mr. Darko said that when Ivy does select blacks, they tend to be from immigrant or foreign families. "Being black to the club means being an international black," he said. "They aren't African-American from New York."
Asked to comment about the high number of black dropouts, Mr. Griffin, the graduate board president, said: "There are plenty of blacks that do feel comfortable. It's just an individual decision. The very fact that the people who dropped out were taken in the first place means what they are implying is not true."
He said the profile of each new class of Ivy members is determined by the undergraduates in the club. Current officers did not respond to repeated requests for comment on their criteria for admission.
"There is no pattern, except the quality of the people is very high," Mr. Griffin said. "The undergraduates have a geometry. Just because they are young doesn't mean the sociology is any less complex."

SECTION: Section 14; Page 7; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 339 words

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: EAST VILLAGE/LOWER EAST SIDE;
One Cultural Center Stays, Another to Go

BYLINE: By ERIC V. COPAGE 

 BODY:
Two lower Manhattan cultural centers known for their radically different approaches to City Hall once again found themselves facing divergent fates last week.
For 20 of its 33 years, one center, Charas/El Bohio, an umbrella group of cultural organizations, has been in a former school building at 605 East Ninth Street in the East Village. But last July, the city sold the building to a private developer for $3.15 million. Charas, an outspoken opponent of many city housing and social service policies, was told it would have to leave to make way for an international youth hostel, said a lawyer for Charas, Foster Maer. 
 In papers filed last week in Federal District Court, Charas sought to block the building's sale. It asserted that because Federal money was used to renovate the school, it had to be used as a "public facility."
Charas also accused the city of going ahead with the sale in retaliation for Charas's opposition to city policies.
The Clemente Soto Velez Cultural Center, also an umbrella group, has been apolitical in the six years since its founding, the center's president, Edgardo Vega Yunque, said last week. Its headquarters, a former school at 107 Suffolk Street on the Lower East Side, was to be auctioned last Thursday.
But, Mr. Vega said, on Monday the Mayor's office called to say the building had been spared.
"We have always been prudent in our approach to the municipal administration," Mr. Vega said. "That has produced an atmosphere of communication.
"Artists have a difficult enough time in a society that doesn't respect what they do," he continued. "So to take on confrontational politics is not a good idea."
Mr. Vega said he hoped the city would transfer the building to the Economic Development Corporation from the Department of Citywide Administrative Services. That would allow it to be sold to someone other than the highest bidder. Mr. Vega said his group hoped to buy the building, appraised at $1,050,000, and had $210,000 for a down payment. ERIC V. HEADLINE: ECONOMIC VIEW;
Making a 'To Do' List For the Treasury Handoff

BYLINE: By RICHARD W. STEVENSON 

 BODY:
Lawrence H. Summers, Deputy Secretary of the Treasury, was nominated last week to succeed his boss, Robert E. Rubin. When Mr. Summers sits down for the first time at his new desk, he might might find a letter like this from his predecessor.
 
DEAR Larry:
Before you settle in, you might want to run over this list of unfinished business. For all the talk of my having been the best Treasury Secretary of the century (shucks), there remain some explosive problems out there, scattered among the achievements. 
 Let's start on the plus side. I bequeath to you a strong, sound banking and financial system. Most of us in the United States take it for granted these days, but it is nonetheless an absolute prerequisite for taking advantage of the global economy's opportunities and weathering its turbulence. Unless you want us to follow Japan into a deflationary spiral, don't let a credit problem develop on your watch.
I also leave you a close working relationship with Alan Greenspan at the Federal Reserve. Fed chairmen and Treasury secretaries haven't always gotten along, but you and Alan and I have not only developed a good rapport, we also basically agree on nearly every big issue. On one where we don't -- whether Treasury should cede some of its regulatory authority over banks to the Fed as part of the financial services bill moving through Congress -- you should consider conceding the point, as a signal that your partnership with Alan is more important than a turf fight.
When I took office, we assumed that Federal budget deficits would be with us for a long time. They are gone now, and you will have a key role in determining how we use the surpluses that seem likely to mount rapidly in coming years. If you hold the line and don't allow the surpluses to be squandered, you may even have to begin planning for something that no Treasury Secretary in a century has had to contemplate: Retiring the national debt, possibly within a decade if you believe the rosier projections.
NOW let's turn to a few really complex issues. I've argued for years in favor of keeping the dollar strong. It's always been a tough sell in some quarters -- no doubt Ford, G.M. and Chrysler will come a'knockin' again soon -- and it's not getting any easier, with our trade deficit heading rapidly higher.
If that deficit goes totally out of control, there's going to be pressure from all sides to bring the dollar down. Resist it. The strong-dollar policy has helped dampen inflation and benefited consumers by keeping the prices of imports relatively low, and it has made the United States an attractive place for the rest of the world to invest. And these days, we need price stability and capital inflows a lot more than we need a few extra export sales at the margins.
Then there's the stock market. I have no idea whether it will prove to be a boon or a curse for you. Alan frets over those stratospheric valuations, but even he says they might just turn out to be justified -- if the recent surge in productivity turns out to be lasting. Then again, as Alan said in Chicago earlier this month, no good thing goes on forever. Remember, my trader's instincts are very strong, and they told me to get out of Washington while I was still a hero to the 401(k) brigade.
IF all those matters don't keep you busy enough, there are a few others that could steamroll you if you're not careful. Russia and China come to mind immediately.
You don't have to stretch to come up with nightmare scenarios involving Russia. The good news is that by now, the Russian economy has been reduced to insignificance, so its collapse probably would not drag anyone else down with it. The bad news for you is that the only approach we have to dealing with Russia involves throwing money at Moscow. Doing that in some kind of prudent way without enraging Congress is your responsibility now.
China could be even trickier. No doubt you'll have a deal to bring it into the World Trade Organization within a few months, once the embassy bombing in Yugoslavia has blown over. But selling a deal on Capitol Hill was going to be a tall order before we saw those pictures of our Ambassador, James Sasser, peering through the broken glass in Beijing. It'll be even tougher now.
In the longer run, it's an open question whether China's leadership can continue to encourage development of a market economy without releasing its authoritarian grip on power. The implications for economic development and political stability throughout Asia could be profound.
Larry, it's probably silly for me to run through these issues, since you're smarter than just about anyone in Washington. Congratulations on learning to hide it; nothing irritates Republicans more than a know-it-all Democrat from Harvard. You know how to work the policy and political machinery within the Administration. If you can just learn to smile and tell them what they want to hear on Capitol Hill, you'll do fine.
Never forget that it's now your signature on the dollar bill -- and on that ghastly new 20. I'm going fishing.
 Your friend,
 Bob

HEADLINE: INVESTING;
Taking Portfolio Cues From a Magazine's List

BYLINE: By RICHARD A. OPPEL Jr. 

 BODY:
CAN you get rich investing in the companies that created the wealth of the Forbes 400? Or in those that Fortune magazine lists as America's most admired? You may soon be invited to find out.
Cashing in on the popularity of unit investment trusts, which are similar to mutual funds but hold an unmanaged portfolio of securities for a set period, John Nuveen & Company has bundled into a U.I.T. the stocks on Fortune's annual list of the 10 most admired companies. 
 Not to be outdone, Prudential Securities expects by this summer to begin selling a U.I.T. composed of the 40 publicly traded stocks that are the largest equity holdings of people on Forbes magazine's list of the 400 wealthiest Americans.
Like many broker-sold U.I.T.'s, these don't come cheap. The Nuveen-Fortune America's Most Admired Companies Portfolio has an up-front sales charge of 1 percent; investors who hold it for its full two-year duration will have an additional 3.5 percent deducted over that time as a deferred sales charge, plus annual operating expenses of 29.25 cents for each $100 invested.
Investors in the Forbes 40 Index Trust will pay 1 percent up front and an additional 1.75 percent deferred sales charge over the one-year term; those who renew at the end of the year will not have to pay another up-front fee, but the 1.75 percent will be deducted every year. There is also an annual trustee's fee of 19 cents for every $100, according to Kenneth Swankie, a Prudential senior vice president. (Sales charges for both trusts are reduced somewhat for purchases over $50,000; the minimum investment is $1,000 for the Nuveen-Fortune trust and $250 for Prudential's Forbes U.I.T.)
In comparison, the average United States diversified stock mutual fund charges 1.42 percent of assets for annual expenses, excluding sales charges, according to Morningstar Inc., the fund researchers in Chicago. Fees for unmanaged portfolios, like index funds, tend to be far lower.
Most of the trusts' fees go to brokerage firms, but the magazines will also get a portion for the use of their names. Fortune, owned by Time Warner, will receive 10 cents a year for every $100 invested in the Nuveen trust, said Bill Adams, an executive vice president at Nuveen. Forbes Inc. said its cut from Prudential had not been determined.
Defending the fees, Mr. Adams said U.I.T.'s are "a fairly economical way of being able to purchase a basket of securities that pursue a particular strategy."
Nuveen does not offer any back-tested data of the Fortune portfolio in its prospectus. The Forbes U.I.T. prospectus, however, says that a hypothetical portfolio of its stocks -- the Forbes 40 index -- would have had an annual average return of 22.5 percent from January 1989 to December 1998, versus a total return of 19.2 percent for the S.& P.
Executives at the two magazines said they saw no problem with such use of their proprietary lists, noting that publishers like Dow Jones have licensed the use of their names for investment products.
Both trusts include many large-cap highfliers, like Wal-Mart Stores, Microsoft and Dell Computer.
A. Michael Lipper, chairman of Lipper Inc., the research firm, said such stocks could be among the most susceptible to a broad market downdraft. But he added that the Forbes trust "directs investment into the more entrepreneurial companies, and over a sustained period that's probably a good thing."
The Fortune U.I.T., he said, is a "much more difficult call." After all, he said, "most stocks at their peak are admired by somebody."

SECTION: Section 14; Page 1; Column 1; The City Weekly Desk 

LENGTH: 3047 words

HEADLINE: From Dumping Ground to Destination?;
Staten Island Makes a Bid to Shed Its Outcast Image

BYLINE: By JIM O'GRADY 

 BODY:
IN a photo promoting a recent television movie, Mike Logan, a police officer, glowers on the upper deck of the Staten Island ferry, Manhattan behind him. Logan's punishment for punching a politician was reassignment to New York City's southernmost and least dramatic borough. His hope is that if he can navigate the underworld links and possible police corruption involved in a local murder and solve the case, he can get back to Manhattan. He is, as the title of the movie proclaims, "Exiled."
The message is clear. Staten Island is a place apart from the rest of New York City. A place where failures from Manhattan go. A far place vaguely redolent of at least three kinds of rot: police corruption, mob ties and the world's largest pile of trash. 
 A 1998 marketing survey for the Empire State Development Corporation asked New Yorkers to give their reasons for going to Staten Island, if they went at all. At the top of the list? "Visiting friends and relatives." Next was "passing through." ("Because I punched a politician" wasn't mentioned.)
The director of the Columbia Center for Urban Research and Policy, Ester Fuchs, said that because the borough was out of sight for most city residents, it was also out of mind. "The majority of New Yorkers perceive Staten Island the same way New Yorkers perceive Chicago," she said. "They don't."
Staten Islanders themselves have contributed to their isolationist reputation, notably six years ago when they voted 2-1 in a referendum to secede from the city, an effort that failed. But now the borough seems to be showing signs of emerging from its exile.
The Fresh Kills landfill, one of the secession movement's flash points, is scheduled to close on Dec. 31, 2001. And Staten Island has been improving its transportation links to Manhattan. The centerpiece of the borough's efforts to get itself noticed, though, is a half-mile waterfront complex that the Borough President, Guy V. Molinari, has named St. George Station.
Already, most of the financing is in place to refurbish the St. George ferry terminal -- "our front door," as the borough's director of land use, Frank Chaney, calls it -- and flank it with a minor league baseball stadium. Also in the works are the National Lighthouse Center and Museum, and a Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences museum, designed by the avant-garde architect Peter Eisenman, noted for the proposed Holocaust Memorial in Berlin and the Wexner Center for the Arts in Columbus, Ohio.
Of course, these developments could falter. But many residents are intrigued by what these plans might bring if they are completed. Will Staten Island finally shed its image as New York's dumping ground and become, in the parlance of urban planners, a destination?
To date, there have been no signs of organized community opposition to any of the St. George Station projects, though residents have expressed concern about traffic jams and parking problems, most recently at a hearing on the baseball stadium at Borough Hall on April 13. And some people are skeptical about whether the complicated project will ever materialize.
The president of the St. George Civic Association, Theo Dorian, said that while he and his organization fully supported the St. George Station project, in the past ambitious development plans have foundered. "The history of positive projects moving forward in St. George demands that an intelligent person be skeptical," Mr. Dorian said. In 1983, he and his family moved from Greenwich Village to St. George. Reading about a proposed revitalization of Staten Island's North Shore waterfront helped persuade them, he said, though the development plans were never realized.
Last week, Mr. Chaney spread the architectural renderings for the remodeling of the ferry terminal on his desk. They showed a building transformed from its current public restroom esthetic to a gracious and light-filled space. Traffic patterns around the building were streamlined and pedestrian access was enhanced by a walkway leading to a curving plaza with a shorefront restaurant. Wide corridors lined with cafes and shops opened on glass walls facing the water, with views of lower Manhattan.
Mr. Chaney smiled. He considered the plan, created by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, the designer of the Camden Yards stadium in Baltimore, a vast improvement over the existing building. "I've seen it so many times," he said. "A few tourists get off the boat and trepidatiously wander up a corridor and look at the bus ramps, then turn around and get back on the boat."
The city Department of Transportation estimates that some 19.8 million people -- 1.5 million of them tourists -- take the ferry every year. Mr. Chaney, among others, sees a golden opportunity in the horde. "This is economic development," he said of the terminal renovation. "We want to encourage tourists and city residents to come into the neighborhood and spend money."
Mr. Chaney estimated that the terminal renovation project would cost $75 million to $80 million. Mr. Molinari said the Transportation Department had committed $55 million, and he planned to ask the city for more. Congress, meanwhile, has authorized $20 million for the project. The ferry will continue to operate during the renovation, which is to start this fall and be finished by 2001.
While the ferry terminal is getting its makeover, a 6,500-seat minor league stadium is to go up about a hundred yards to the west. The stadium, also designed by Hellmuth, Obata & Kassabaum, will be home to the Class A Staten Island Yankees of the New York-Pennsylvania League. Last year, the city paid $12.75 million for the 52-acre site, a former rail yard that now serves as a municipal parking lot. Beginning this fall, the New York City Economic Development Corporation will spend $29 million to build the stadium, which it will own and manage. Before construction starts, the bulkhead will be repaired and the ground decontaminated, at a cost of $7.6 million.
The franchise is owned by Sandlot Sports, a company held by Stanley and Phyllis Getzler of Manhattan and their son Joshua, and the Sunshine Group, which includes five relatives of George Steinbrenner, the owner of the Yankees. Sandlot Sports owned and managed the Watertown Indians for the last three seasons, but switched to the minor league Yankees last year.
Joshua Getzler, the team's chief operating officer, said the Yankees would play their first two seasons at the College of Staten Island in Willowbrook before moving to the new stadium in 2001. Mr. Getzler said the team sold its 1,000 season tickets on Staten Island in less than two days.
But will other New Yorkers be interested in attending minor league baseball games? Stanley Getzler, a former stockbroker and the team's chairman, said he hoped that the stadium's waterside lights would draw Wall Street workers and others from lower Manhattan to buy a ticket, for $6 to $10, drink a beer and watch the next hot Yankee prospect launch a long ball toward the World Trade Center. The half-hour ferry ride to the refurbished terminal, he said, would be part of the appeal. "I can't help but think that people are going to want to be transported to a minor league game, both literally and figuratively," he said. "Especially after a hard day's work."
As Mr. Molinari sees it, "Each one of these initiatives feeds the other." He remembered pacing nervously at a public event last summer while awaiting word on the lighthouse museum. Staten Island was locked in competition for the museum with seven other sites around the country. The borough's main rival was Mackinaw City on Lake Michigan, whose boosters had a pledge of $1.5 million for the museum from Michigan's Governor, John Engler, who also promised to help raise $20 million more. But Mr. Molinari had lined up $5 million in city and state money to support the Staten Island bid.
The museum's program director, Henry Stephenson, said he expected the first phase of the project -- a lightship, an exhibition space and a restaurant and gift shop -- to open in 2001. But renovating the seven dilapidated historic buildings on the 10-acre site, a former Coast Guard base and lighthouse service depot, will cost an additional $15 million, which has yet to be raised. Five of the buildings are on the National Register of Historic Places, and the administration building, which dates to 1869, is also a New York City landmark. Mr. Stephenson said he expected $1.3 million worth of work to stabilize the buildings to begin this week.
Ralph Eshelman, the president of the national steering committee of lighthouse preservation groups that selected Staten Island for the museum, said the historical resonance of the location went a long way toward helping it win, and so did the "visitor potential" of those 19.8 million ferry riders.
The other museum planned for the waterfront couldn't be more different. On a little less than an acre between the ferry terminal and the stadium, the Staten Island Institute of Arts and Sciences wants to build the 150,000-square-foot museum designed by Mr. Eisenman; it would house a permanent exhibit on the history of New York Harbor and environs, with space for rotating shows.
The design calls for five or six levels of overlapping crescent-shaped ramps that wrap around a 10,000-square-foot atrium with a glass wall facing the harbor. The museum would share an entrance plaza with the ferry terminal, and be about the same height. The roof would be a semi-translucent Kevlar skin that would shine against the night sky.
"It will be one of the most interesting postmodern structures that anyone has seen in New York City," said the president of the institute, Michael Botwinick. "The ferry terminal's design will be very clean and appealing, but it won't change peoples' minds about the waterfront visually," he said. "Our project becomes much more the emotional signature of the place."
The building and permanent exhibit are expected to cost $50 million to $55 million, Mr. Botwinick said, and he is shooting for an opening date in 2002 or 2003. But most of the money for the project has yet to be raised. Though the New York State Dormitory Authority has granted the institute permission to issue up to $40 million in bonds, he said, that money will probably be tapped for bridge loans during construction.
Clearly, a fully realized St. George Station has the potential to present Staten Island in a far more welcoming light to tourists and New Yorkers from the other boroughs. But will it move Staten Island politically or psychologically closer to the rest of New York City? Not if the city doesn't close the Fresh Kills Landfill on time, said the president of the Staten Island Chamber of Commerce, Lawrence J. DeMaria.
"Any large-scale development plans on Staten Island are going to fail if they don't close the dump," Mr. DeMaria said. "If you think the secession movement was strong the last time, there will be civil disobedience this time."
A Sanitation Department spokeswoman, Paula Young, said: "The city is closing the Staten Island landfill on Dec. 31, 2001. You can take that to the bank." But lawsuits by Brooklyn community groups opposing waste transfer stations in their neighborhoods have slowed the department's plans to ship garbage out of state.
"It would be nice if Staten Island could be known for a baseball stadium instead of the dump," said Dan Mills, the owner of Mills Court Restaurant, which would be across the street from home plate when the ballpark is built. He added, "I'll reserve my cartwheels until I see a hole in the ground for the stadium."
David Goldfarb, a lawyer who has lived in St. George for 26 years, said the borough would have trouble making strides while it remained fixated on shutting down the dump. "Closing the landfill will have to be a huge weight lifted," he said. "We will finally be able to move on to other issues."
The director of the Taub Urban Research Center at New York University, Mitchell Moss, said the fact that there was a dump closing date at all was a sign of how the borough, which often votes Republican, had enjoyed increased clout under the Republican administrations of Gov. George E. Pataki and Mayor Giuliani. "The last three years have been one of those rare political moments when the Governor, the Mayor and the Borough President have all been politically in tune with what Staten Island wants," Mr. Moss said.
Mr. Molinari himself makes much of what he characterizes as his productive relationship with the Governor and the Mayor in obtaining city financing for St. George Station and getting the 1996 state law that set the landfill closing deadline passed. But, he said in an interview, "I am concerned about how this borough will be treated in the post-Giuliani era."
City Councilman Jerome X. O'Donovan, a Democrat from the North Shore, who is considering a run for borough president when Mr. Molinari's term runs out in 2001, said a Democratic lineup would be just as good. "Just as Guy Molinari touts his relationship with a Republican Mayor," he said, in principle "the same thing applies to a Democratic mayor and Democratic borough president."
Mr. O'Donovan said he supported city financing for the stadium, the lighthouse museum and the ferry terminal renovation. He expressed reservations, however, about the siting of the arts and science institute museum. He said it might cheaper to use two vacant buildings at the Snug Harbor Cultural Center two miles away in West Brighton.
Both Republicans and Democrats on Staten Island agree that a major issue in the borough's evolving relationship with the rest of New York City is transportation. Staten Island has no subways, and its commuters have long complained about inadequate public transit. But there have been some recent improvements. The elimination in 1997 of the 50-cent ferry fare and the introduction of the Metrocard, with its free transfers, has reduced the daily off-island round-trip to $3 from $6.50 for many Staten Islanders. The borough's transportation director, Dan Jacobs, said this probably accounted for much of the 2.4 million increase in ferry ridership the following year.
But the fare reduction also hastened the demise of two private ferry lines, Fast Ferry and New York Waterway, that offered commuters speedy service between St. George and midtown Manhattan. The service, which charged $9 per round trip, with cheaper monthly rates, and sold upscale coffee, was popular. Yet both companies dropped it in 1997, after about a fifth of their riders returned to mass transit. The president of Fast Ferry, John Koenig, said his company might reinstitute a daily run during the morning and evening rush hours.
More ferry service arrived last December when the Department of Transportation started a Monday-to-Friday midnight ferry on a trial basis. Staten Islanders, who were tired of rushing from restaurants and concerts to catch the 11:30 P.M. boat to avoid waiting for an hour at Whitehall Terminal, flocked to the midnight ferry, and the service has been extended to at least Labor Day.
But the head of the St. George Civic Association's Staten Island Ferry Rider's Committee, Tamara Coombs, said, "If Staten Island is going to truly be part of New York City, we have to be connected with half-hour ferry service all night long."
South Shore commuters had been advocating more and better express bus service for years. This spring, the Transit Authority replaced 180 old city buses with roomier and more comfortable coaches, and it plans to soon add a high-occupancy-vehicle lane to the median strip on a long stretch of the Staten Island Expressway, which should make the commute to Manhattan quicker.
Mr. Moss of N.Y.U. sees the expanded express bus service as a sign of deepening economic ties between Staten Island and Manhattan. "The express buses used to go only to lower Manhattan," he said, "but now when you walk on Fifth Avenue you can see express buses to Staten Island."
Mike Azzara, who has been a columnist and reporter for The Staten Island Advance, the borough's daily newspaper, for 26 of the past 36 years, said he thought Staten Islanders didn't complain any more than other New Yorkers about how City Hall neglected them.
But Mr. Azzara said that when a United States Supreme Court ruling in 1990 led to the abolition of the Board of Estimate, transferring power from the borough presidents to the mayor and the City Council, "there was a feeling that Staten Island's voice in government would be lost." Mr. Azzara said many in the largely suburban borough felt it would suffer because of its relatively small population, which was approximately 407,000 in 1998, according to the city.
That remains a concern. Mr. Molinari still keeps a brass plate on his desk that reads: "We may not secede, but by God we will fight." But generally, the antagonism has been muted over the past six years as many Staten Islanders seemed to enjoy New York's prosperity and an ongoing honeymoon with Mayor Giuliani, who usually gets standing ovations at the town hall meetings he holds in the borough three times a year.
Tyrone Butler, a deputy commissioner in the Department of Records when David N. Dinkins was Mayor, and a Staten Island resident who unsuccessfully ran for Congress in 1994 and 1996 against Susan Molinari, Guy Molinari's daughter, suspects that this contentment does not run deep. "Just watch," he said. "If a Democrat becomes mayor, they'll start pounding the secession drums again."
St. George Station. Better transportation. No more 10,000-ton daily gifts of garbage from the rest of New York City. If Staten Islanders feel they've made real progress on each of these fronts by 2001, some say, those drums may well stay muffled. After all, the borough voted overwhelmingly in 1898 to join a consolidated Greater New York City. So who is to say that if Staten Island becomes less of a place to ignore or pass through, and more of a destination, that sentiment won't return?
The players in the St. George Station complex, at least, are optimistic. "It's exciting," Mr. Botwinick said. "It's the first time in a long time that Staten Island has looked across the harbor and said, 'Hey, look at me!' "
