HEADLINE: MARKET INSIGHT;
A Voice Of Caution In a Chorus Of Gamblers

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN 

 BODY:
WHEN Robert E. Rubin went to Washington in 1993 as chairman of President Clinton's National Economic Council, the Dow Jones industrial average was under 4,000, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index was trading at less than 500 and the Federal budget was $255 billion in the red.
As he leaves as Treasury Secretary, the budget is in surplus. The decline in interest rates as the budget deficit receded has allowed an estimated 19 million mortgages to be refinanced, saving homeowners $23.4 billion, according to the Mortgage Bankers Association. Some of that money has found its way into the stock market, which has done stupefyingly well. 
 Mr. Rubin isn't uniquely responsible for all these good things, of course. But he will be a tough act to follow. And he couldn't have picked a much better time to cash out.
The bad news is that all good things must end, a fact that worries Barton M. Biggs, chairman of Morgan Stanley Asset Management. Mr. Biggs took time last week to discuss Mr. Rubin's years at the Treasury and the markets he is leaving behind.
 
Q. The sense seems to be that Mr. Rubin would not be leaving Treasury if he wasn't confident the worst of last fall's financial crisis had passed. Do you share that view?
 
A. I am not necessarily convinced Mr. Rubin thinks that things are improving. At a small reception about two weeks ago, Larry Summers, his likely successor, cautioned people against being overly optimistic about global economic recovery. There are a lot of trouble spots, particularly Japan.
 
Q. What do you consider Mr. Rubin's most important contributions to the country?
 
A. We all had the confidence he was a steady hand, that if the markets and the global financial system got in trouble, he knew what to do. He did it with Mexico in 1994 and 1995 and again last summer. He understood markets and had great intuition. The fact that he decided to announce his departure now is because he felt the market was stable.
 
Q. Has this view influenced your investment strategy? Worry about the future doesn't seem to be priced into too many of the world's equity markets just now.
 
A. I am scared but fully invested, and we are hugging our benchmarks because we are scared about the tremendous excesses we see in these markets. There are literally no cheap markets in the world right now.
 
Q. How have you weighted your portfolio?
 
A. We are slightly overweight in equities, underweighted in the United States and Europe but overweighted in the United Kingdom and Japan by about 10 percent in each case. We are overweighted in non-Japan Asia and in the emerging markets.
About 62 or 63 percent of our portfolio is in equities. The remainder is in bonds.
 
Q. Given the performance of Japanese stocks the last decade, how can you say that market is expensive?
 
A. Compared with the United States or Europe, Japan is not expensive. But compared with important market bottoms in the past, it is. Here is a country that is in a depression and its market is selling at 75 times earnings and 2 times book value. In the 1930's, the United States stock market sold at half of book value. So, Japan is not exactly cheap by historical standards.
 
Q. What about the emerging markets?
 
A. Japan, other Asian markets and the emerging markets are coming out of long bear markets. They will be the best place to invest after the next bear market and will be the best places to be in the short run as long as this bull market lasts because they are going to go up more and come down less. But I can't say they're cheap.
The same is true for small- and mid-cap stocks in this country. They are as cheap as they have been in a long time relative to the S. & P. 500, but at about 15 times to 17 times earnings, they are not historically cheap.
 
Q. On what is your worry about a looming selloff based?
 
A. Our economics people are looking for a recovery, but I think the United States is going to lose some momentum, that the Japanese are going sideways at best and that the Germans are bottoming out.
There is still a great deal of overcapacity in the world. I was in Europe last week talking to businessmen and industrialists, and I didn't meet anyone who said economic activity was picking up, either from orders abroad or within Europe itself.
These markets are priced for perfection, and if something bad happens, the market has the potential to go down a great deal.
 
Q. In this environment, what advice would you give to individual investors?
 
A. I would say they should not be deluded by advertisements that suggest any amateur can make money in the stock market.
We are perpetuating a gambling mentality that is similar to the 1920's. I read somewhere recently that 15,000 new Internet trading accounts are being opened every week. That is frightening.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS;
Satisfying an Age-Old Thirst

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH 

 BODY:
NEARLY half a century ago, on Feb. 21, 1952, the front page of The New York Times hailed a "revolutionary process" for turning sea water into drinkable drops. The process was complicated and expensive, requiring lots of energy to push water through membranes that filtered out salt. Still, the article predicted that desalting would "open vast new reservoirs of fresh water" for use "wherever water is now scarce."
Well, not quite. People drink desalted ocean water in some Caribbean hotels and in big swaths of Saudi Arabia, and local authorities in Santa Barbara, Calif., and Key West, Fla., have toyed with the process at times. But desalting plants do not dot the world's coasts, and water shortages have not been consigned to history. 
 Yet those rosy predictions from 1952 may have only been premature. Years of gradual improvements in membranes, declining energy costs, growing water demand and fears about groundwater contamination are combining to make widespread commercial-scale desalting viable.
"A lot of people spent decades sweating the details of bringing costs down and reliability up, and it's finally paying off," said James D. Birkett, director of the International Desalination Association.
And Arthur L. Goldstein, the chairman of Ionics, a desalting pioneer in Watertown, Mass., has taken to comparing the industry's time line to that of aviation. It took decades from the Wright Brothers' first plane "for airline transportation to become commercial," Mr. Goldstein said.
Sea-water desalting still isn't cheap. Even at the most efficient plants, a thousand gallons of desalted water costs around $2 to produce, twice the typical cost of water pumped from underground aquifers or other freshwater sources.
But in many places, those sources are contaminated, overused or out of reach.
"Desalination is always more expensive than getting water from a lake or river, but those aren't always options," said Larry Pelegrin, vice president of sales for Hydranautics, the Oceanside, Calif.-based membrane technology subsidiary of the Nitto Denko Corporation of Japan.
In many parts of California, for example, the options have narrowed to desalting ocean water or treating waste water, a choice that often brings the local citizenry into the desalting camp, fast. "It's a lot cheaper to treat waste water, and it yields perfectly clean water, but the idea just disgusts people," observed Karen G. Rasmussen, a water industry analyst at Frost & Sullivan, a research firm in San Francisco.
SO ocean desalting is moving to the fore when cities need to shore up water supplies -- and not just coastal cities. "As desalination prices keep going down, it could make economic sense for a desalting plant in California to pipe clean water to inland cities hundreds of miles away," said Robert W. McIlvaine, president of the McIlvaine Company, a research firm in Northbrook, Ill.
Engineering and construction companies, membrane manufacturers and water treatment specialists say they are swamped with requests for information and are increasingly asked to bid on projects.
Lance Johnson, who runs global marketing for the water treatment business of Dow Chemical, called sea-water desalination "one of our biggest growth areas."
Poseidon Resources, based in Stamford, Conn., until recently a wholesale provider of electricity, has sold its power plants to concentrate on providing water, particularly through desalting. "Wholesale power is mature, but this water industry is in its infancy," said Walter Q. Howard, Poseidon's president. And a recent McIlvaine study found desalting to be one of the fastest-growing markets for membrane makers.
The Middle East, Spain and other arid places are eager buyers of desalting plants. Singapore, tired of relying on neighboring Malaysia for its drinking water supply, plans a 36 million-gallon-a-day plant. Even Britain, whose reputation as a dank, wet place ignores large areas on its eastern coast where fresh water is scarce, has a desalting plant under construction.
Not surprisingly, North American corporations want to capitalize on the growth. Hydranautics just relocated an executive to Abu Dhabi, and Zenon Environmental, a water treatment company in Burlington, Ontario, recently set up a subsidiary in the Middle East.
"Desalination is a really healthy global industry that is going to grow at a significant rate," said James W. Hotchkies, a manager of business development for Zenon.
It already has for Osmonics, a membrane and pump company in Minnetonka, Minn. In three years, desalting has quintupled to 10 percent of Osmonics sales, "and I wouldn't be surprised if it becomes a third of our business," said D. Dean Spatz, the chief executive.
Desalting's prospects in the United States may rest heavily on a closely watched project in Florida, where depletion of ground water threatens vital wetlands. Tampa Bay Water, the water utility serving Tampa, St. Petersburg and New Port Richey, recently hired a consortium led by Poseidon and Stone & Webster to build a plant that will yield 25 million gallons a day, or 10 percent of the area's water usage, at a cost that will average $2 for every 1,000 gallons over 10 years. The plant is scheduled to begin production in 2002.
The consortium will design, build and run the plant for the utility under a single contract, an approach that allows it to make advantageous trade-offs like installing automation equipment to save on operating labor and using more expensive but more efficient pumps. Such combinationswould be impossible if Tampa Bay followed the traditional route of seeking competitive bids for each facet of the plant.
Even the consortium's competitors wish the project well.
"Desalination has never had a lot of public support in the United States," said Fared Salem, the desalination industry manager for the DuPont Company, a major supplier of membranes and a losing bidder on the Tampa project. "But maybe Tampa will cause renewed interest in a technology that can really address the 21st century's water problems."
 
http://www.nytimes.com

GRAPHIC: Chart: "From Brackish to Potable"
Of the three main ways to turn salt water into drinkable water on a commercial scale, two depend on special-purpose membranes that have improved and fallen in price in recent years. The third, distillation, requires much more energy than membrane systems do.
 
Electrodialysis
When electric charge is applied, membranes allow ions from dissolved salts to pass through and be carried off in brine, leaving fresh water behind.
 
Reverse Osmosis
When sea water is under high pressure, water molecules, but not salts, pass through membranes and are collected for use, leaving brine behind.
(Source: International Desalination Association)

LENGTH: 995 words

HEADLINE: PRIVATE SECTOR;
The Bad-Boy Voice of Wall St.

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

DATELINE: CHICAGO

 BODY:
JONATHAN HOENIG, the 23-year-old founder of Capitalist Pig L.L.C., has just finished broadcasting his morning radio financial report for WNEW, a modern rock FM station in New York, and already he is showing why he is a hit with the MTV generation.
"Don't you just love Maria Bartiromo?" he says, eyeing the CNBC anchor on his television set while taking a drag on a Lucky Strike cigarette at his makeshift broadcast studio in downtown Chicago. "I love what she represents: sexy finance." 
 That's the way he sells young people on investing. For him, it's hard-core. It's sexy. And it's entertaining, or should be. That is precisely why he once booked an exotic dancer on his radio show: sort of Howard Stern meets Louis Rukeyser.
"We had a stripper on with a mutual fund manager to talk about her needs," he said over lunch the other day. "He put her into a short-term bond fund."
Outrageous? Sure. But just a few short years after he began broadcasting a financial program called "Capitalist Pig" on Northwestern University's radio station, Mr. Hoenig has burst onto the scene as a journalist, financial commentator and author of "Greed Is Good," an investment guide for people under 35, to be published later this month by Harper Business.
He was named one of the top 30 financial journalists under 30 by TJFR, a newsletter for public relations professionals. He made the cover of Institutional Investor. ("It's Personal Finance, Dude!" blared the headline.) He is also a regular contributor to P.O.V. magazine and is a financial commentator on "Market Place," the public radio program.
It was bound to happen. Wall Street is hot. Financial programs are multiplying like rabbits and even Grandma is pointing and clicking on E*Trade. So why not the rise of a young man with slick hair and raging blue eyes who finds a way to worship Michael R. Milken and Hugh Hefner in the same breath as Malcolm X?
"This is not a hard sell," Mr. Hoenig says of his Capitalist Pig media operation, which now consists of a monthly newsletter, Capitalist Pig Report; T-shirts; a Web site; syndicated columns; television and radio programming, and even his mom's pig-shaped cookies. "Somehow, the 'Antiques Road Show' on PBS sounds like a lot harder sell than this."
Mr. Hoenig, who flops around in unlaced Doc Martens and a tie studded with pigs, doesn't find anything unusual about the way his often racy conversations veer from rising interest rates to the movie "Ferris Bueller's Day Off."
He says he simply wants to soak up all the good things in life as soon as possible -- an urge he ascribes in part to the deaths of his father and his older brother when he was still in his teens.
He grew up in Glencoe, Ill., a Chicago suburb, in the 1980's, when greed was in style, he said. When he was 9, his father gave him two shares of Boeing stock, and he promptly fell in love with investing. He borrowed his mantra, "Greed is good," from Gordon Gekko, the ruthless financier played by Michael Douglas in the film "Wall Street."
About the same time he got a public affairs radio program at Northwestern, he took a job clerking at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Before long, his interests converged and he turned his radio program into Capitalist Pig.
Investment advice, often emphasized with profanities, was delivered against a backbeat of music from bands like Guns 'n' Roses. A highlight of each program was his naming the "finance babe of the week" and running an advice segment called "Ask the Pig."
As for financial wisdom, this self-taught Wunderkind of Wall Street ("I just started on the Barnes & Noble bookshelf and read everything from Benjamin Graham to Marty Zweig") has a very common-sense approach to investing. He preaches diversification, the benefits of compound interest and the debilitating effects of credit card debt. And while he doesn't have a track record as a stock picker, he simply advises young people to educate themselves about the market and start investing.
Making $5.50 an hour just doesn't kick it. "That's good money, if you're 15, Amish or inhabiting a corrugated cardboard box," he says in his new book. And for him: "The notion of being able to make money without actually doing much of anything jazzed me to no end."
The popularity of the campus radio program led to appearances on CNN and MTV. He has also helped write a college textbook, "Personal Finance" (Irwin/McGraw Hill, 1999).
He dropped out of Northwestern in 1998 (he says mother wants him to think of it as a leave of absence) to focus on trading his own money in the futures pits of the Chicago Board of Trade and to begin branding himself and his company under the Capitalist Pig logo, which features a cigar-puffing pig. He even hired the same agent who represents Phil Jackson, the former coach of the Chicago Bulls.
"We speak the language of brands," Mr. Hoenig said of his target audience, 18- to 35-year-olds. "Since Day 1, we've been affixing logos and marketing slogans. What I want to do is start a life-style brand and tie it to something that is central to all of our lives: money."
Mr. Hoenig -- a tireless self-promoter whose press kit arrives as a stuffed suitcase -- is trying to create a brand that delivers financial advice with wacky wit and an unapologetic philosophy that money is everything.
He boasts of having a unique voice. And, well, how often does Mr. Rukeyser mock day traders by coining a phrase like, "Just buy after Regis and sell after Rosie"?
Talking about stocks, after all, is just like talking about sports, he says. "Instead of talking about E.R.A.'s, you're talking about P/E ratios."
He counts James J. Cramer of Thestreet.com and Alan Abelson of Barron's among his heroes. In his office, just above his desk, is a large photocopied portrait of Lou Dobbs, the CNN financial news anchor. Is he another hero?
"No," Mr. Hoenig said, flashing a sly grin, "We just used that as a dartboard at my book party."

LENGTH: 961 words

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Hey, Nice Headlights;
In Detroit, a Sex Change

BYLINE: By ROBYN MEREDITH 

DATELINE: DETROIT

 BODY:
RUN your eyes over the Dodge Durango, one of the newest sport utility vehicles on the road. Muscles seem to ripple under its shiny sheet metal, causing its fenders to bulge. Its hood is lifted above the brawn, like the short neck of a wrestler rising from beefy trapezius muscles. Buyers imagine the Durango whispering huskily that it is strong and dependable. And many of its brother trucks at the forefront of Detroit's design efforts are even burlier.
Now think back to Detroit's design heyday in the 1950's. Then as now, cars were big. But they were Eves to today's Adams, Marilyn Monroes to our Hulk Hogans. In the 50's, "there were hood ornaments and bumpers that were bulbous and busty," said David L. Lewis, a professor of business history at the University of Michigan. "Nowadays there is no question that a lot of these sport utility vehicles are masculine." 
 Back then, cars looked like women. Now they look like men.
Auto historians and designers puzzle over why. Some say the booming economy gives Americans a go-anywhere, do-anything confidence represented by brawny sport utility vehicles and trucks. Or perhaps the designs have changed because more women are buying cars. Others believe the world feels less safe, causing people to look to their cars for protection, as if their daily commutes require bodyguards.
Whatever the reason, it is as if Detroit's metal has had a sex change operation. Today's design kings are nothing like the voluptuous Chevrolet Corvettes built between 1968 and 1982, the ones with the sultry silhouette of an hourglass on its side. The1950's Cadillacs had chrome bumper guards in the shape of breasts -- the 1953 model was a real looker. Here in Detroit they are still known as "Dagmar" Cadillacs, after the tall, blonde television starlet who went by the single name Dagmar and was known for her ample chest.
Back then, machismo filled the air at General Motors. "It was certainly sexual, but it was the sexual fantasies of men," said Jerry P. Hirshberg, a G.M. designer in the 60's and 70's who is now president of North American design for Nissan. "When we lapsed, we were doing design pornography."
That's what everyone suspected. "The psychologists have thought for years that the auto makers, subliminally or otherwise, would build cars with sex appeal, mostly to appeal to men," said Mr. Lewis, the historian. Women in tight sweaters appeared in television ads for cars, and men got the point: "Here you have a curvy model and a curvy fender." No more. Today, we have muscle cars. Back in the 60's, of course, "muscle" referred to horsepower, not design.
Nissan's first sport utility vehicle, the Pathfinder, was nicknamed the "hardbody," and designers described the "triceps" around each wheel. There are the square-shouldered Jeeps, born of the battlefields, with a look DaimlerChrysler calls "chiseled." Other sport utility vehicles have been growing bigger and bigger, as if the highways have become a survival-of-the-fittest contest: The Ford Explorer spawned the Ford Expedition, and it evolved into the enormous, soon-to-come Ford Excursion.
Each designer or auto historian seems to have a theory about the changes. "In the 90's, people started moving away from the weaker-looking cars to the stronger-looking trucks," said Edward R. Golden, Ford's truck design director. "It has to do with the end of the cold war and people feeling more confident."
OR more endangered. "I don't think there were drive-by shootings in the 1950's," said Neil Walling, design vice president at DaimlerChrysler, which builds the Dodge Durango. "One of the allures or attractions to trucks and sport utility vehicles is that they carry a very protective image."
Perhaps now that women buy about half of all new vehicles, they are objectifying men just as men objectify women. "Women would really rather have a vehicle that's more masculine than a vehicle that is more feminine," said Jerry P. Palmer, director of design for G.M.'s North American Design Center. "People still like vehicles that are sexy," he said, and today's popular models "are masculine but they still have that sex appeal."
Is it sex or is it power? "A lot of women are buying trucks and sport utility vehicles, and I believe that they don't want to be seen as the weaker sex," said Mr. Golden, the Ford designer. "They want to be seen as equals."
OF course, not all the latest models get such expressive designs. The nation's best sellers are mid-sized cars like the Honda Accord, the Ford Taurus and the Toyota Camry. Designers say those boy-next-door cars still carry messages. Mr. Walling of DaimlerChrysler said cars like the Camry are saying, " 'I'm not trying to be powerful, I'm not trying to be fashionable, I'm not trying to be leading-edge. I'm the friend who is always here -- I'm not the Arnold Schwarzenegger.' "
But even sports cars seem less sexy now. Today's Corvettes have just a slight air of femininity -- they are nothing like the Playboy-magazines-on-wheels of the 1960's. The latest Corvettes and other sports cars are more like the "boys with breasts" of Tom Wolfe's latest novel, "A Man in Full" -- the thin, fit, females found climbing stair machines at the neighborhood gym.
"In the 50's and 60's, just when I was fantasizing about Dagmar, automobiles were not only a status symbol but a sex symbol," said Clive Chajet, a corporate identity consultant in New York. "Driving is no longer sexy," he concluded.
Why have bulging metal muscles replaced soft steel curves? The men in the auto industry are still puzzling it out. "If a sports car is a man's mistress, what is a pickup truck?" asks Robert H. Casey, curator of transportation at the Henry Ford Museum in Dearborn, Mich. "Is it his buddy?"
 
http://www.nytimes.com

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: WESTERN QUEENS;
It's Showtime In Queens As Studios Plan to Grow

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY 

 BODY:
New York's biggest borough is rapidly becoming one of the country's biggest film and television production centers, too. Two studios are expanding and another may be on the way. Hollywood, apparently, sees the flickering light at the end of the Midtown Tunnel as more filmmakers shout: "Lights! Camera! Queens!"
In the last five years, Queens has become "a vital player in the record-breaking film and television production occurring in the city," said Patricia Reed Scott, commissioner of the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting. 
 Industry leaders say that trend will grow with the expansion plans of the two studios, Silvercup Studios in Long Island City and Kaufman Astoria Studios.
Stuart Match Suna, president of Silvercup, at 42-22 22d Street, pointed to "the tremendous growth in feature films and episodic TV in New York" as the fuel for his company's expansion. The studios, with 250,000 square feet, have been used for several feature films and hundreds of commercials. They are also home to two television series on HBO, "Sex in the City" and "The Sopranos."
"Together, they take up half of our studios," Mr. Suna said. "Last year, their shooting schedules didn't overlap, but now they do and they are gobbling up a lot more space."
And so, Mr. Suna and his brother Alan, the company's chief executive, recently acquired a 150,000-square-foot site about a mile away, at Starr Avenue and Van Dam Street, near an entrance to the Queens-Midtown Tunnel. Built in 1936 as a steel plant, it was also once a concrete factory.
The Sunas bought the site from a Korean agricultural group, which never occupied it. They said they had paid $8 million for the building and property and are now spending $12 million more to construct five studios, each with 16,000 square feet and 28-foot ceilings.
"It was designed to function like a Hollywood lot," Stuart Suna said. "It's self-contained and gated, with its own 12,000-square-foot production shop, 25,000 square feet in offices, set, prop and wardrobe areas and parking for up to 300 cars." He said productions there would create about 500 jobs. The first studio should be in use by next month.
"Queens has many, many advantages," Stuart Suna said. "Buildings cost less, they are much larger than Manhattan, and there's more space around them for parking trucks and getting equipment in and out."
Kaufman Astoria Studios is also planning an expansion, said Jane Bartnett, a spokeswoman. "We plan to announce the news in three to six months," she said.
Meanwhile, Gregg Sullivan, a Queens native who worked in film for a decade in Los Angeles, wants to buy a 100,000-square-foot power plant on the East River in Long Island City and convert it into a film and television studio.
Mr. Sullivan, who also owns Hollywired Inc., a movie industry Web site, said the building, at 50-09 Second Street, once generated power for railroads. It was designed by McKim, Mead & White. Mr. Sullivan wants to name it Stax Studio, after the building's four giant smokestacks.
Mr. Sullivan said he has applied to the city's Economic Development Corporation for $25 million in bond financing for the studio. But, he said, "I'm talking to two different groups about financing. They are huge real estate entities. If either comes on board, I won't need public financing." DAVID KIRBY

HEADLINE: The Nation;
The Personality Cults Of Impersonal Economics

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
THE curse and the blessing of the global economy is that no one's in charge. To those it has flattened recently -- the Russians, many Asians, the Brazilians -- it resembles a bullet train on autopilot, roaring across borders and barreling over slower-moving vehicles while a bunch of wealthy Americans down champagne in the club car. To free marketeers, it is the triumph of the invisible hand, a system governed by economic laws and not meddling economic planners, fueled by the Internet instead of ideology.
But global economic forces are not always as faceless and automatic as they seem. And when Treasury Secretary Robert E. Rubin announced his resignation last week, it was a reminder that in matters economic, personalities and the confidence they inspire still matter. 
 Historians will debate for years whether Mr. Rubin helped spark the amazing boom of the 90's by preaching fiscal austerity to free-spending Democrats, or whether he just got lucky. They will argue endlessly whether his moves to save Mexico created an expectation that America would keep countries from going under, and thus invited a far worse global panic. They will make a convincing case that Mr. Rubin and his colleagues never had a workable plan to save Russia from itself as they poured billions down a pipe dream.
But even Mr. Rubin's harshest critics agree on this: Like his weekly breakfast partner, Alan Greenspan, the chairman of the Federal Reserve, he understands that markets are manic-depressive -- and that averting disaster means making sure that someone, preferably someone in Washington, has the credibility to step in and tame the worst mood swings. When crisis struck -- in Mexico in 1995, Asia in 1997 and New York last September -- it was partly the cult of confidence in the Rubin-Greenspan tandem that restored stability.
Some of that was smoke and mirrors: Governments can tinker with interest rates and budgets, of course, but in a world where a trillion dollars changes hands daily, their firepower is diminished. Yet one of the lessons of the past decade is that when confidence in economic leadership is lost, the results can be disastrous: Just ask the Japanese, who once had it and then squandered it.
Maybe it was the way Mr. Rubin dressed, or maybe it was his 26 years on Wall Street -- which he was always invoking in conversation -- but somehow he had an an uncanny sense for the words and signals that would calm the global herd.
"Rubin was something like an old family doctor in the days before antibiotics," said Paul Krugman, a professor of economics at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology. "He knew that even if there was not much he could always do, most things get better over time. So the important thing is to have a good bedside manner and help people through it."
Mr. Rubin himself acknowledged, in a conversation last week, that bedside manner is an important element of the job -- though it works only with "the credibility you establish through fiscal discipline and an understanding of how what happens outside our borders can affect our economy."
The power of his presence paid off one afternoon in October 1997, the early days of the Asian crisis, when a huge convulsion in the Hong Kong market led to a 554 point drop in New York -- more than 7 percent -- and shut down the stock exchange early.
Mr. Rubin walked out on the steps of the Treasury, faced the cameras -- and said nothing particularly memorable. But his few lines, all about the underlying strength of America's "fundamentals" and keeping markets operating smoothly even in the face of potential crisis, were intended, he recalled last week, to show that "there was a lot of focus on the issue, a lot of concentration." In the end, whether it was Mr. Rubin's calm or something else, the Dow's fall halted at 7,300. It has since risen another 50 percent.
THE most important jawboning takes place in private. South Korean officials say the only reason they avoided national default in December 1997 was Mr. Rubin's effectiveness in arm-twisting American banks to roll over South Korea's loans -- stopping a panic that many feared would spread to Japan and beyond. Mr. Rubin now counts South Korea's brush with disaster as one of the "scariest" moments of his tenure, along with the near-collapse of the global financial system in the wake of Russia's default on its loans last year.
That was when it seemed as if the driverless train was headed over a cliff -- and it may well have been. The panic around the globe was so broad and deep that it was clear that no words, no walk down the Treasury steps, would suffice. So the strategy was to create the sense in the markets -- some would say the illusion -- that Mr. Rubin and Mr. Greenspan had temporarily taken the wheel, not only of the American economy but of all the major industrial economies.
They coordinated a series of statements by President Clinton and other world leaders that the biggest risk to the world was no longer inflation but rather a global economic slowdown. And then, over a period of weeks, came a series of interest rate cuts that turned the markets around. Of course, the moves were a Band-Aid, and much of the impassioned oratory heard then about the need for remaking the "global economic architecture" has since died out. But the Band-Aid stopped the bleeding. Until the next time, anyway.
To this day, no one is quite sure why it worked. "Credibility is born of past success," says Stanley Fischer, the No. 2 official at the International Monetary Fund and a key player during several crises. So part of the Rubin-Greenspan magic, he argues, comes from the fact that the American economy has been up for so long.
Japan's Finance Minister, Kiichi Miyazawa, who at age 78 has had longer and deeper experience than almost any of his counterparts, doesn't cut the same ice. That is because Japan's political paralysis has undercut not only its own economy, but its influence in the global economy. Europe hasn't done much better.
BUT what about President Clinton's designee as the new Treasury Secretary, Lawrence H. Summers? While Mr. Rubin and Mr. Summers have been close partners, they could not be more different. Mr. Rubin is rail thin and always in a banker's suit. Mr. Summers, a 44-year-old former Harvard economist, tells jokes about his weight and often looks as if he has stayed up all night. Unlike Mr. Rubin, he can be acerbic and cutting, although lately he has tempered his impatience with those who don't understand the bruising dynamics of the global forces at work.
With an inclination to be more of an interventionist, he speaks with greater sweep than Mr. Rubin does, with declarations like, "The major challenge for the United States is whether it can become the first outward-looking, continental, non-imperialist power in history." But whether he can speak the language of the markets -- whether he can walk down the Treasury's steps and convey a sense of calm -- is a test yet to come.

HEADLINE: The World: Big Chill;
It's Not the Cold War, but There's a Nip in the Air

BYLINE: By ERIK ECKHOLM 

DATELINE: BEIJING

 BODY:
IF a space traveler had returned to Earth last week after 35 years, he could have been excused for thinking that nothing had changed. Russia and China hated the West. Their leaders and citizens were angrily flinging words like "imperialism" and "hegemony." A strange war in an obscure corner of the planet seemed to be the occasion for mounting global tension.
No world leaders were seen banging any shoes, but a Chinese President, after allowing jeering crowds to stone the American Embassy, hinted darkly that if America did not mend its ways, it "will face doom." 
 Of course the space traveler would have to be told that the cold war really was over, and that for 10 years the Americans, the Russians and the Chinese had agreed that their most vital interest was in the common pursuit of prosperity.
That, at least, was how many Americans had come to understand the new world.
But in Russia and China, as events have shown, the picture was not quite so straightforward. Whatever goals Russia and China share with the United States, the crisis in Kosovo -- and especially the mistaken bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade -- has revealed the degree to which these former enemies still distrust Americans, and also the blinders Americans wear as they imagine how Russia and China perceive their own vital interests.
Many Americans might well believe that these two needy behemoths are shooting themselves in their economic feet, with their fulminating hostility over events in an inconsequential place called Kosovo.
But posing the issue this way, Chinese people say, reveals the problem. There can be no doubt that China really wants to open up and become part of the Western-led world economy. But it has other profound interests and fears as well. And many people here have felt with growing force that the United States simply doesn't take China seriously -- that it blithely ignores China's vital security concerns as it constructs a Pax Americana.
The Russians, dependent on the International Monetary Fund's huge loans and suffering a political meltdown that includes an impeachment drama and successive shuffles of the Government, have likewise stewed about what they regard as ignorant and disrespectful treatment from the West.
NATO leaders, having long been lectured by the Russians about NATO expansion, knew the Russians would hate the decision to bombard Yugoslavia, though they may have underestimated the long-term damage to relations if the war persisted. China's vitriol about the intervention in Yugoslavia was another matter. Though surprisingly harsh, it didn't seem that important at first because it was only oratory. And Kosovo was so far away from Beijing.
"Americans don't make the connection between Kosovo and China, they just don't see it," observed Jonathan Pollack, a military expert at the Rand Corporation in California.
But for the Chinese, it is now clear, the decision by what it pointedly called "U.S.-led NATO" to bomb Yugoslavia without United Nations sanction meant the world. Culminating with the attack on their own embassy in Belgrade, the bombing campaign has ignited a major reassessment here of global politics and relations with the United States.
"The bombing in Yugoslavia showed us that the United States can do anything it wants to do," said Zhang Yunling, director of Asia-Pacific Studies at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, which advises the Government. "We see that the United States will use its supreme position, its high technology and its allies to dominate the world."
"Although Kosovo is far away, this has alerted the Chinese," Mr. Zhang added, noting that China could face similar demands for international military intervention some day in Taiwan or Tibet.
The bombing in Yugoslavia followed other perceived signs of hostility -- including what is regarded as politically driven opposition to China's entry into the World Trade Organization, rumbles of major military support for the renegade province of Taiwan and a broadened defense agreement with Japan.
THESE created a powerful sense here that the United States was worse than a neglectful friend. America, many people feared, wants to stamp China down, just as it emerges as the world power it was always meant to be.
That fear turned into a certainty last week, after NATO bombs killed three journalists in the embassy in Belgrade. However outlandish the idea seems to Americans, almost everyone in Beijing thinks the attack was deliberate, a belief encouraged by official propaganda. The most common theory voiced by demonstrators was simple: The United States wants to test the upstart China.
So a Westernized generation of Chinese youths, the same people who normally crowd any of Beijing's 44 McDonald's outlets and yearn to attend U.C.L.A, unleashed a fury of anti-Americanism. And this raised the possibility of real hostility growing between the two countries. For however distant the old cold war hostilities have become, frictions are nevertheless inevitable as China's growing power rubs against longstanding American partnerships and interests in Asia.
For now, American diplomats here feel their own sense of betrayal. From Ambassador James Sasser on down, they had devoted the last few years to building a web of friendly ties with China, trying to wall off the obvious disputes over human rights. Last year, President Clinton and President Jiang even inaugurated a hot-line.
But instead of using the hot-line last week, Mr. Jiang initially refused to take a call from Washington. The leaders pushed America to the limit, busing in students and letting them pelt the American Embassy here for four days while the controlled media fanned hatred.
BY week's end, the popular furies had subsided to a slow burn, and Mr. Clinton and Mr. Jiang had talked. But both sides knew that Chinese-American relations could never be quite the same and both Governments were feeling their way toward new terms.
China was clearly trying to turn down the temperature -- not only by halting the demonstrations but also by making surprisingly minimal demands for redress, including apologies, a public investigation and punishment of those responsible.
Most remarkably, Chinese officials insisted that their economic engagement with the West should not be affected by politics and said negotiations for entry to the World Trade Organization should pick up where they left off.
In a monumental misperception of American political realities, some officials even suggested that the United States should now, in a kind of reparation, relax its negotiating stance.
Mr. Zhang, the scholar and adviser, said the embassy attack had spawned a changing view of Chinese-American relations among foreign policy specialists here. Many, he said, had believed that a generally cooperative relationship with the United States was possible. "But now it seems the United States will dominate the relationship, and where there are disagreements it may resort to military force," he continued. "China might even become a target some time in the future," he said, noting possible conflicts in Taiwan or the Koreas.
In the new circumstances, China may well increase military spending, Mr. Zhang said, although economic development will remain the top priority.
How deeply this new perspective will be entrenched, Mr. Zhang said, will depend on how well the two Governments manage their relationship in the months ahead and how the Kosovo crisis is resolved.
NATO's bombing of the embassy has had the ironic effect of thrusting China into the center of the search for a diplomatic solution in Yugoslavia. The approach Russia developed with the NATO powers involves sending troops under a United Nations flag into Kosovo. This would require China's assent, something likely to be given only grudgingly.
LONG before the current crisis, the one-time enemies China and Russia had realized that it was in their strategic interest to foster better ties. Now, more than ever, China the emerging power and Russia, the flailing one, have been brought together by a shared sense of exclusion.
There is no basis for a serious strategic alliance, but "China has used friendly sniffs to remind the United States that they can shift northward," said Richard Baum, an expert on Chinese politics at the University of California at Los Angeles. "Russia can't offer what China needs for modernization," Mr. Baum said. What it does offer is weaponry in exchange for cash.
Chinese leaders are gambling that even as political relations with the United States go through the grinder, Western trade and investment will continue unaffected.
"Capital and technology are now beyond political control," Mr. Zhang said. "As long as the social situation here is stable and the economy is open, capital will come."

HEADLINE: The World;
Kosovo War Doesn't Do Much for U.S. Recruitment

BYLINE: By DIANA JEAN SCHEMO 

 BODY:
A DECADE ago, Americans watched the United Nations' entry into the gulf war almost as if it were a video game, distant and unreal. Each night's newscast brought a fresh batch of satellite pictures of Iraqi targets exploding as smart bombs zeroed in.
The victims of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait were seldom seen, and the greatest moral issue for most Americans was probably that of controlling the supply of oil or protecting Israel. 
 This time, the Kosovo Albanian refugees are all too real. Their stories of mass rapes and massacres echo a level of brutality that evokes the death camps of World War II. Washington is engaged in a war where the overwhelming feature is not oil or geopolitics but the morality of ethnic cleansing.
And yet many young Americans enlisted to fight Iraq in the gulf war.
Today they have been sitting out the Balkan conflict, according to military recruitment experts like John Sibley Butler, a sociologist who is the Reserve Officer Training Corps faculty adviser at the University of Texas. For a few years, the gulf war helped stem the steady decline in enlistment since the end of the cold war.
Thanks largely to a healthy economy that has increased the choices available to those entering the job market, the Army and the Air Force have fallen short in their recruitment goals.
Still, with 1.36 million Americans serving in the military, the United States for the moment runs no risk of a shortfall in troops to face down the Serbs.
But the dearth of recruits limits American options, suggesting that a long war may be problematical. And it raises intriguing questions about attitudes toward military service and the meaning of modern warfare to young people.
The apathy of young people toward the conflict in the Balkans comes at a moment when war is paradoxically at its most intimate and most distant.
Through television Americans have access to virtually continuous coverage of the war, be it NATO bombings in Belgrade or briefings in Brussels, or the live reports from crowded refugee camps in Macedonia and Albania. Through the Internet, they can communicate directly with Serbs or Albanians.
At the same time, the American military wages war at a distance, using methods that reduce the likelihood of casualties. Planes fly higher to cut the chances that they will be shot down by Serb forces, even if that means mistaking a civilian target for a military one.
For many young people, such "safe" strategies drain war of its very meaning, said David R. Siegel, author of "Recruiting for Uncle Sam" (University Press of Kansas, 1989).
Although the military has relied on increasing pay and benefits to draw recruits, Mr. Siegel's previous research suggests that young people enlist for patriotic reasons, or to build character. A war that carries risk to only one side strikes many of them as unfair, or at least unworthy, he said.
"It's like they're saying, 'I'm willing to lay my life on the line, but my country won't let me,' " he said.
"The non-war in Kosovo," which batters Yugoslavia from the air but does not risks troops, may be precisely what is keeping young people away, Mr. Siegel said. They sense they are not needed, Mr. Siegel says.
It is also possible that continuous television coverage of the conflict has prompted people to tune out rather than tune in to the war. "War has become a movie that other people do, and something we watch rather than something we engage in," Professor Butler said.
Americans reason that abominations "are going on everywhere," he said, and they ask, "But do we go everywhere to fight them?"

HEADLINE: Editorial Observer;
So, Exactly When Is Bill Bradley Going to Enter the Charisma Phase?

BYLINE: By GAIL COLLINS 

 BODY:
It was somewhere near the New Hampshire seacoast that Bill Bradley declined to tell reporters what books he likes.
"I don't want to go down the road of favorite novel," he said, during a three-day campaign tour of youth centers, senior centers and many variations on the theme of the Presidential-candidate forum. There was a credibility issue at stake here. What, he demanded, would the press say if he picked one book now and then changed his mind six months down the line? And what if he mentioned something like "Crime and Punishment"? The reporters might theorize that he was identifying with the murderer-hero. No, we're not going there. 
 Mr. Bradley, you see, is in the Vision Phase of his campaign, and, as he firmly explained earlier in the New Hampshire tour, you do not talk specifics when you are in Vision Mode. "It's discipline and sequencing," he said, in a tone that suggested the reporters would really not respect him in the morning if he lathered them with details of his health-care initiative that night. Sometime this summer, he plans to kick into the Principles Phase, to be followed in the fall by the Policy Phase, when he will be prepared for "taking the necessary hits you get when you are specific." After that comes the Action Phase, in which the candidate responds to the hits and, presumably, comes back with a few good licks of his own.
The Bradley staff swears he did not pay a consultant to think this up.
It may be an indication of the Bradley campaign's self-confidence that it does not seem particularly desperate for attention at this point in the game. Unlike most long-shot candidates, Mr. Bradley does not accept invitations to appear on cable television shows. He resists photographers' attempts to get him near a basketball or a hoop. He is a serious candidate, and if you do not believe it, just try listening to him tell a group of Manchester citizens his opinion on the Uruguay round of the international trade negotiations.
So far, it all seems to be working pretty well. The voters at the forums, coffees and house parties appear to like the Vision Phase, particularly Mr. Bradley's rather fuzzy but seemingly heartfelt concern about "values." His fund-raising pales next to Vice President Al Gore's mountain of cash, but money can't buy you love.
The Gore candidacy is so wobbly that President Clinton recently assumed the role of Spinner in Chief. He said Mr. Gore's leaden speeches and inert staff add up to inevitable victory.
Follow Mr. Bradley around during Phase One and you will learn that what he is most concerned with is children, particularly poor children who do not get enough parental supervision. He has a vague but intense preoccupation with getting people to think of themselves as part of a larger community, a greater cause. The rhetoric of self-realization sometimes sloshes over into other areas. "Before somebody's going to join the international economy, they have to be comfortable with their identity where they are," he said during a discussion of Kosovo.
As a former basketball star, Mr. Bradley, unlike most politicians, has never had to beg for attention. This seems to have given him a quietness that allows him to draw people out by simply sitting there -- head down, chin tucked in, peering up with a look of slightly amused interest -- and waiting for them to volunteer some information. It works particularly well with young people, whom he asks to describe what they are "most afraid of," with sometimes remarkable results. "I'm afraid of not making it," piped up 17-year-old Jose Rivas in Nashua. "What if I've come this far and it's as far as I can go? It's not as far as I want to go, but what if it's as far as I'm allowed to go?" He told Mr. Bradley that he wanted to attend cooking school but might not be able to raise the tuition.
Unfortunately, the same calm confidence that makes Mr. Bradley a good listener makes him a dreary public speaker. Even his most dramatic speech, a really admirable call to re-address the issue of racial division, is devoid of applause lines. It would be a profound problem in a different year. But no matter who wins the Presidential primary, boring is something the Democrats are just going to have to learn to live with.
When it comes to comparing himself with the Vice President, Mr. Bradley says "specific issue differences will be laid out in the fall," when it is time for the harvest and Phase Three. If all goes according to plan, sometime around August Mr. Bradley may also volunteer that he likes historical fiction, and before Thanksgiving the campaign may reveal that he has read "Ragtime" twice.

HEADLINE: New York's Baffling Zoning Code

 BODY:
New York City's antiquated zoning code runs about 900 pages and rivals the Internal Revenue Code in complexity. Unless you are a member of the coterie of zoning lawyers, the odds of accurately interpreting one section of the code in relation to another are slim to none. Joseph Rose, chairman of the City Planning Commission, now plans to rewrite parts of the code so that rules for building height and other crucial standards are not only clear, but sturdy enough to withstand attempts to twist them into pretzels.
The urgency of this undertaking is visible on both sides of the East River. Developers and neighborhood groups have already squared off over the skyscraper Donald Trump wants to build near the United Nations and David Walentas's plans for a retail and entertainment complex on land near the East River waterfront in Brooklyn. Both disputes reflect the muddled state of city land-use policy. 
 Under Mr. Rose's plan, parts of the 1961 zoning code, which he calls a "hodgepodge of conflicting visions and objectives," would be reformulated to encourage innovative design while respecting neighborhood character. Among other things, he would set height limits for buildings outside Manhattan's Central Business District, create a process for granting occasional waivers for buildings of exceptional design, reopen some manufacturing zones to community uses and rethink commercial-use rules for doctors' offices and other businesses.
Equally important is his plan to abolish plaza bonuses for residential buildings. Time and again, this tradeoff -- more square footage for a developer in exchange for a plaza -- has saddled the city with unattractive and inaccessible public spaces.
As useful as it is, Mr. Rose's reform agenda ought to be treated as an invitation to think more broadly about zoning issues and land-use opportunities. When he unveiled his ideas in a recent speech, he expressed a preference for pursuing a short list of reforms. A full-scale review of the code, he fears, would be paralyzing. But rethinking land use does not have to result in civic meltdown.
A number of American cities, including Pittsburgh and Minneapolis, have developed fresh land-use principles, written a new code and survived the process. New York's 50-odd community boards, various civic groups, architects and builders should be invited to compile their own lists of the most vexing zoning problems. A comparison of all these lists should make it possible to choose between full-scale review of the entire code and taking a triage approach by focusing on the top 10 to 20 issues.
The dialogue Mr. Rose has opened should logically lead everyone to grapple with two other areas -- redeveloping the city's vast but often dilapidated waterfront and identifying the environmental values that should be loaded into the building, zoning and tax codes. The dog days of summer that New Yorkers dread will be testimony to the wisdom of examining environmental issues. During extremely hot weather, New York creates heat islands. Dark road pavement, buildings with dark roofs and other impervious surfaces boost already uncomfortable temperatures and help produce ground-level ozone. Planting trees, a zoning code issue, and requiring the use of reflective materials on roofs and streets can lower temperatures. As New York reinvents itself, it should not be hamstrung by a Sputnik-era rule book.

HEADLINE: Pay Raises for Police? Where's the Money?

 BODY:
The police officers of Nassau County do not deserve a pay raise, nor is it in the county's best interest at this time.
Once again the County Executive, Thomas S. Gulotta, has demonstrated poor leadership. Nassau County is in financial crisis and Mr. Gulotta is culpable. He is willing to curry favor with the police union while giving the citizens of Nassau County the political shaft. 
 When will Mr. Gulotta stand up to the police and tell them they are already well paid as it is?
Nassau County police officers can now retire on very high pensions. If Nassau County officers believe they are not well paid, they might try the New York Police Department. Officers of the N.Y.P.D are leaving for Nassau and the attractive pay scale and working conditions.
Meanwhile, instead of defending his record, Mr. Gulotta should apologize to the taxpayers of Nassau for his office's mismanagement.
 
RICHARD CAMERON
Bellmore

HEADLINE: DATABANK: May 10-14;
Ending Up With the Wrong Kind of Bang

BYLINE: By MICKEY MEECE 

 BODY:
Oh, those unforgiving Fridays. Investors ended the third week in a row pummeling the Dow Jones industrial average, pulling the sell trigger because of fears of inflation.
 The first two times, the Dow recovered, posting new highs the next week. But the outlook for a similar rebound is uncertain. Although the Fed is unlikely to raise interest rates on Tuesday, it may be considering higher rates in the near future. 
 One indicator the Fed will consider is the sharp rise in consumer prices reported on Friday. The report shook investors. But Michael Farr, an investment bank-er with Miller & Washington in Washington, brushed off the worry behind the 193.87-point decline on Friday.
 This is an emotional reaction, not a rational re-action, from a market that is more inclined than not to pull back, Mr. Farr told The Associated Press. If you characterize the advance as irrational, then the pullbacks ought to be just as irrational. But you can't complain if you're enjoying the ride up.
 Despite the selloff, the Dow was off just 1 percent for the week, closing at 10,913.32. The Standard & Poor's 500-stock index fell fractionally, while the Nasdaq rose nearly 1 percent, to 2,527.86. MICKEY MEECE

HEADLINE: Auto Pollution Plan Is Drawn Into a Vortex

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 15

 BODY:
An Administration plan to require cleaner gasoline and automobiles that emit less pollution, described by officials as the most ambitious anti-pollution initiative of the Clinton Presidency, is drawing heavy lobbying by environmentalists and industry and strong interest by politicians eyeing next year's Presidential campaign.
The Environmental Protection Agency estimates that imposing the higher standards would reduce respiratory illnesses and save the lives of up to 2,800 Americans a year. These improvements would come at substantial cost -- $3.5 billion annually, five times as much as any other Clinton Administration rule aimed at specific sources of pollution, according to the agency. 
 Industry critics, particularly oil refiners, say the costs would be far higher. Emboldened by a Federal appeals court ruling on Friday rejecting the Administration's plans for tighter national air quality standards in the future, oil industry lawyers warned that the gasoline and auto initiative may not hold up in court. But an E.P.A. official said the appellate court ruling would not stop the agency's plans.
By requiring substantial reductions in car pollution and the elimination of 95 percent of emissions from sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks, the gas and auto rules would drastically cut smog.
"This is the biggest action by the Clinton Administration to protect the environment and the health of the American people," said Carol M. Browner, the regulatory agency's administrator.
With such high stakes, advocates and opponents are trying to influence the Administration and Congress during the public comment period, which ends on Aug. 2. Environmentalists and auto makers generally support the plan while seeking limited modifications. Oil companies are implacably opposed to the requirement for cleaner gasoline and are encouraging Republicans in Congress to step in, having concluded that the Administration is not likely to make any significant changes before the rules become final at the end of this year.
Vice President Al Gore has strongly backed the pollution initiative. Republicans are keeping a close eye on his comments, particularly regarding sport utility vehicles, in hopes that they can be used against him in next year's elections.
"This kind of position on this kind of an issue is tailor-made" for television advertisements, said Gov. John Engler of Michigan, a Republican who is one of the 10 members of Gov. George W. Bush's Presidential exploratory committee. "I do think it's a good issue."
The future of the Administration's initiative is clouded by Friday's decision by an appellate court in the District of Columbia. The court rejected only the Administration's plan to set more stringent national targets for smog and soot in the air. The plan did not specify which industries would actually reduce pollution. But F. William Brownell, lead lawyer for the industry coalition that won the case, said that unless the E.P.A. won an appeal, it could no longer prove a need for the stringency of the new gas and auto regulations.
E.P.A. officials and environmentalists disagreed, saying that because the Administration initiative was partly based on longstanding national air quality goals predating the Clinton Administration and unaffected by Friday's decision, the court's ruling should have no effect. E.P.A. officials, planning an appeal, said they would proceed with public hearings on the auto emissions and gasoline proposal next month without modifying it.
Sparring over the air pollution plan is likely to intensify this summer. The Public Interest Research Group, a liberal advocacy organization, is planning to send volunteers to knock on the doors of four million households in a bid to muster 135,000 postcards to Federal regulators in support of the proposal. Other environmental groups, including Friends of the Earth and the Sierra Club, are backing the Administration plan, although they are calling for faster cuts in pollution by sport utility vehicles.
Oil lobbyists contend that the plan could add 6 cents a gallon to the price of gasoline instead of the 1 or 2 cents estimated by regulators. The lobbyists expect the Administration to change the rules little if at all after the public comments. So the industry is preparing for two hearings in the Senate next week by one of their allies, Senator James M. Inhofe, Republican of Oklahoma, who is drafting legislation.
Top American and foreign auto executives met in Washington on Wednesday to map out their strategy. The industry has been pleased with the cleaner gasoline rules, which will make it easier to build cleaner-burning engines.
Increasingly interested in improving their environmental image and irritated by criticism of pollution by sport utility vehicles, auto executives have been reluctant to criticize the Clinton initiative, instead proclaiming their "general support." But the industry is asking regulators to extend by two years, to the 2011 model year, the deadline for large sport utility vehicles and pickup trucks to meet car pollution standards.
Mr. Gore said he thought that the Administration would prevail in imposing tough rules this year. "It has taken several years to get to this stage and we of course don't have the final rule yet, but I'm optimistic," he said in an interview this month.
But if Republicans win next year's Presidential election, they might be able to revise the gas and auto emissions standards, possibly citing Friday's court decision.
Republicans have been watching Mr. Gore's comments on automotive issues closely. President George Bush ran television advertisements in Ohio and Michigan in 1992 warning that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Gore would tighten fuel-economy standards and force tens of thousands of auto workers into unemployment. Mr. Engler, the Governor of Michigan, said similar criticisms could be leveled against Mr. Gore next year.
Mr. Engler, who has won three consecutive races for governor in this fiercely contested industrial state and is a possible Republican Vice Presidential candidate, said American families liked the interior space and perceived safety of big sport utility vehicles. Voters in general and auto workers in particular will be leery, he said, of a Democrat whose environmental views could be portrayed as advocating a return to "little tiny cars" of the sort still seen in Europe.
Though top auto executives may see tighter rules as inevitable, there remains an undercurrent of hostility here toward any limits on automobiles. An editorial cartoon in The Detroit News on May 8 showed Mr. Gore in an immense 18-wheeler labeled "Big Gov't," honking the horn while tailgating a sport utility vehicle. The explanation at the top of the cartoon read, "Al Gore's plan to get oversized S.U.V.'s off the road."
Auto executives have warned that large sport utility vehicles might have to be made smaller or less powerful to comply with the latter stages of the new rules, which will be phased in between 2004 and 2009. But Mr. Gore made a point of saying in a speech here that he thought the new regulations provided enough flexibility to industry to avoid reducing consumers' choices.
Representative John D. Dingell, a Michigan Democrat who has been consulted by Mr. Gore on electoral strategy in the Upper Midwest, said he strongly doubted that voters would hold the new regulations against the Vice President.
"Gore isn't cracking down on sport utilities -- the E.P.A. is," Mr. Dingell said, also pointing out the willingness of auto executives to go along with more stringent rules.
Edward V. Sarpolus, a vice president of EPIC/MRA, a polling firm in Lansing, Mich., which works for both parties and the news media, said there was little evidence that the 1992 Republican advertisements had been effective. Michigan workers tended to blame corporate downsizing, rather than regulatory policy, as the main cause of layoffs.
The E.P.A. estimates that beginning in 2004, the new rules will add $100 to the cost of a car and $200 to the cost of a sport utility vehicle or pickup truck. Auto lobbyists say those are underestimates, but Mr. Sarpolus said the price increases were small enough and far enough in the future to play down their political importance.
Insurance industry studies indicate that sport utility vehicles are not especially safe; their occupants are just as likely as those in cars to die in crashes, while more likely to kill other people in collisions with other vehicles.
Senator Inhofe has been trying to draft legislation that would alter the gasoline provisions of the Administration plan without starting another broad fight over the Clean Air Act, a controversial piece of legislation covering all aspects of air pollution that tied up Congressional leaders for months in 1990. But Mr. Dingell said it was impossible to make any changes in the law without reopening the whole issue.
The Clean Air Act authorizes the E.P.A. to draft national air quality standards, but the appeals court found on Friday that the agency behaved unconstitutionally in not asking Congress for detailed instructions on drafting the standards.
The auto and gasoline rules do not cover fuel economy. In the interview, Mr. Gore said he had been talking with auto executives about ways to triple the fuel economy of sport utilities through joint research programs with the Government to explore alternative fuels.
Though Mr. Gore advocated tighter fuel-economy rules when he was in the Senate, he and Mr. Clinton largely abandoned that position in 1992 after the Republican television campaign, calling instead for Federal research subsidies.

HEADLINE: A More Selective Cuba Rethinks Foreign Investment Policy

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: HAVANA, May 15

 BODY:
Nearly a decade after Cuba began opening its state-run economy to foreign investment, President Fidel Castro's Government says it has become more selective about choosing partners from abroad.
But the Government also says it remains committed in principle to encouraging foreign investment as a "complement" to its own efforts to guarantee recovery from the economic crisis that hit Cuba after the collapse of the Soviet bloc. 
 "The policy is the same -- the country remains open to new investments," said the country's Foreign Investment Minister, Ibrahim Ferradaz Garcia, in an interview in his Havana office on Friday.
Other factors have changed, he said. "It's not like the first years when we were waiting for the foreign businessman to come looking," Mr. Ferradaz said. "Now, we go out ourselves to look for a partner for an investment need."
Although official figures are unavailable, Cuba is estimated to have attracted more than $2 billion in foreign investment disbursements or pledges this decade.
That figure is small for other Latin American nations, but large for Cuba, whose Communist Government expelled foreign businesses after Mr. Castro's 1959 revolution and has kept its small and fragile economy under strict control since.
With a United States embargo in place for the last 37 years, most external capital has come from Canada and European Union countries, notably Italy and Spain. Although Cuban law theoretically allows 100 percent foreign ownership, the majority of investments are roughly 50-50 joint ventures with the state.
Mr. Ferradaz said 26 new joint ventures had started so far this, compared with 58 in the whole of last year. Cuba has signed 36 bilateral investment accords, and is negotiating two more to eliminate double taxation with Italy and France on top of one signed with Spain.
The traditional investment areas of tourism, oil and mining are being complemented by projects in other sectors such as energy, banking and tobacco, Mr. Ferradaz added.
He also reiterated Cuba's "definitive" rejection of privatization of, or foreign investment in, the sugar industry, a mainstay of the economy.
Asked if foreign criticism of Cuba's recent measures against internal political opponents had affected investments, he said the number of joint ventures spoke for itself.
"Businessmen definitely aren't politicians," he said.
"It is part of the sovereignty of a country to make the laws it decides it should do, and carry out the judicial processes it decides it should do," he added, alluding to the trial of four dissidents and the passing of new anti-subversion legislation, which prompted foreign protests.
The impact of the Helms-Burton law -- passed by Congress in 1996 to tighten the embargo and to discourage other countries from investing in Cuba -- "cannot be undervalued, although it is impossible to gauge it exactly," Mr. Ferradaz added
The law's basic objective to halt investment "obviously has not been fulfilled," he said. At the same time, he added, an unknown number of potential investors, and some loans from abroad, have been deterred by fear of reprisals.
Mr. Ferradaz said the island, despite what is now its third year of drought, was on track to achieve or surpass its goal of 2.5 percent growth this year, thanks in part to a good sugar harvest and tourism.

HEADLINE: Goats in Trial as Urban Weed Killers

BYLINE: By The New York Times

DATELINE: DENVER, May 15

 BODY:
A sign in a city park here says it all: "Goats at Work."
A herd of about 100 Cashmere goats that has been munching at the park and other weed-choked areas around the city since April is working for the City of Denver as part of a program to fight invasive weeds that have taken over native plants and wildlife habitats. 
 "It's unusual to have goats graze within the city limits, right along a managed city park," said Judy Montero, a spokeswoman for the Denver Parks and Recreation Department. "We hope the goats will reduce our use of herbicides and pesticides in the long run."
This year, the city will spend $50,000 in grant money on this experimental weed control program. The goats will be used to help restore 25 to 35 acres within the city limits, including sites along the Platte River and around Cherry Creek.
"It's the oldest weed-control technique known to mankind," said Lani Lamming, an owner of Land Whisperer, the Alpine, Wyo., company that is leasing the goats to the city. "It's so logical and simple. In my opinion, we're using life to nurture other forms of life. No natural resources are being wasted."
Mrs. Lamming, who owns the company with her husband, Fred, said goats preferred the broadleaf weeds to grass, unlike cows and horses, which graze grass first. The herds are managed alternately by the Lammings, their three teen-age sons and professional herders.
The goats, which work in two four-hour shifts daily in a temporarily fenced-in area, can mow down about one acre per day. They can reach areas that machines cannot, and they serve other purposes as they graze: tilling the soil, re-seeding and fertilizing.
Part of the plan for the park is to re-establish native grasses. As the goats are nibbling on the broadleaf weed varieties, a park official said, their hoofs are trampling in seeds of desirable native species distributed by city employees.
The cost of a job varies depending on conditions, but Land Whisperer estimates the average cost is $100 per acre, using 50 to 100 goats.
In the past, the city has relied on mechanical mowing, spraying herbicides and pesticides and pulling weeds by hand. But those methods have hazards: air pollution from mowing and contamination of groundwater from chemical sprays.
"The goats alone can't get rid of the weeds," said Gayle Weinstein, a naturalist for the parks department. She said the goats could work the same site only about three times during a growing season and still get enough to eat. After that, most of the seed heads should be gone.
"Then we'll come in and spray when the plants are weakened, " she said. "Maybe with this combination we could get rid of the weeds in a couple of years."
For Denver, like cities and counties in many other Western states, laws require any landowner, whether a private party or the government, to control noxious weeds on the property or risk being fined or even criminally prosecuted.
If noxious weeds are left uncontrolled, they create a chain reaction of ecological and economical disasters. The weeds eliminate native plants and possibly lower the water supply, harming the wildlife that feeds on those plants. The land can then lose its value for future development, for farming and ranching, and for recreational uses.
"We can lose it all if we allow weeds to take over," said Dr. John M. Randall, an invasive-weed specialist with the Nature Conservancy in Davis, Calif. "It's not a stretch to say invasive species -- and that includes insects and wildlife as well as plants -- are the biggest threat to natural habitats next to development, the subdividing land for housing and shopping malls."
Although Dr. Randall is in favor of using the goats, he and other experts say the use of goats and other livestock should be in addition to an arsenal of tools to fight noxious weeds.
"One technique is not going to be the silver bullet, and no one should rely on one method," said Eric Lane, weed coordinator for the Colorado Department of Agriculture.
The state has an annual fund of $225,000 to promote weed control projects on all lands, from Federal to private, Mr. Lane said, and $15,000 was given to the city this year to help pay for the goats. The cost of fighting invasive weeds is even higher in other Western states. In Montana this year, the Legislature passed a bill to put $1.1 million into the state's noxious-weed management trust over the next two years.
"Weed management is extraordinarily expensive, and it requires persistent action," Mr. Lane said. "The advantages to using the goats are that this technique is uncontroversial, and because the goats are attractive, it gets the public interested too."
