HEADLINE: Mexico Measures Identity in Dollars

BYLINE: By JULIA PRESTON

DATELINE: MONTERREY, Mexico

 BODY:
A Mexican conference speaker exploring the possibility that his country might adopt the dollar as its currency displayed a slide of a 50 peso bill alongside a single American greenback. George Washington's benign gaze was fixed on his fierce-looking counterpart, Jose Maria Morelos, the father of Mexican independence.
"Whenever we talk to American officials about dollarizing Mexico, we always ask them when they are going to print Jose Maria Morelos's face right there next to the other one," said the speaker, Francisco Gil Diaz, a former senior official of Mexico's central bank. 
 The audience chuckled. But Mr. Gil's comment pointed up a major sticking point that has emerged in an intense debate in Latin American about whether to abandon local currencies and embrace the legal tender of the United States.
A growing number of economists agree that the dollar's stability would do much to cure the chronic inflation and volatility that undermines growth in many Latin economies, especially Mexico. But political leaders in the region are reluctant to give up the policy powers and sense of national identity that go along with trading in their own money, no matter how unpredictable it might be.
Latin policymakers are quick to point out that the European Union countries achieved monetary accord by agreeing to add a new currency, the euro. But in the Americas the choice that nations must weigh is whether to take on the money of the United States, an overpowering neighbor with which most of them have had uneven relations.
The debate gained new urgency in January when President Carlos Saul Menem of Argentina announced he was considering dropping the peso for the dollar and entered into informal talks with American Treasury and Federal Reserve officials.
In March, Eugenio Clariond Reyes, leader of the Mexican Businessmen's Council, the most influential private-sector association, startled President Ernesto Zedillo by pressing him at a public meeting to allow dollars to flow more easily in Mexico.
Another Mexican business leader, Alfonso Romo Garza, the chairman of Pulsar International, was host of a gathering here in recent days of economists and businessmen from both sides of the border to build momentum for dollarization.
To the chiefs of big Mexican industry, whose capital is Monterrey, being legally authorized to do business in dollars would merely ratify well-established de facto practice. Already their costs and prices are quoted in dollar terms and they finance investments with dollar loans from foreign banks. Only workers' wages continue to be based on pesos.
Mexico's economy already runs on dollars at the bottom as well, especially in regions where workers maintain their families by migrating across the border to jobs in the United States.
But mid-range Mexican enterprises must seek financing from Mexican banks where, because of the peso's persistent ups and downs, interest rates remain around a crippling 20 percent.
"Sustaining a currency like Mexico's has an enormous cost," Mr. Clariond, chairman of Grupo Imsa, a manufacturing conglomerate, said in an interview. "Living with its fluctuations is a luxury we can no longer afford."
When Mexicans are asked if they would like to see dollars move freely in the economy, they invariably express overwhelming support. In a poll this month by El Economista newspaper, 86 percent said they would like to be able to open dollar bank accounts in Mexico.
But when the question is whether to do away with the peso, Mexicans are more ambivalent. One financial titan in Mexico who came out against dollarization was Carlos Slim Helu, chairman of Telefonos de Mexico and one of the wealthiest men in Latin America. He argued that switching currencies could not substitute for Government fiscal discipline.
"The way you have to stop inflation is by cleaning up your financial house," Mr. Slim said. "Besides, the idea that the Federal Reserve would want to take responsibility for our financial system is absurd."
The National Action Party, a conservative but nationalistic opposition party, proposed a bill in Congress recently that would rule out dollarization by hardening into law the current policy of a floating peso with some intervention by the Banco de Mexico, the central bank.
Proponents of dollarization argue that what they call "the sovereignty factor" should not trouble Mexicans. Under any plan to dollarize, the central bank would relinquish its authority to manipulate the peso in the event of unexpected shocks.
Steve H. Hanke, an economics professor at Johns Hopkins University, told Mexican business leaders here that if they were allowed to pick and choose freely among currencies for business they would not have to worry about "blowing away the central bank."
"It's a good thing to give up monetary policy sovereignty," Mr. Hanke said. That kind of decision-making power, he said, "only gets you into a lot of trouble."
Mexican finance officials acknowledge that a brisk debate is under way among them over the issue. Guillermo Ortiz, head of Mexico's central bank, has said that the North American Free Trade Agreement could one day be a natural vehicle for a plan to adopt a single currency. "We happen to live in the right neighborhood," Mr. Ortiz said.
But officials also recognize that a serious proposal to sideline the peso would provoke the fury of nationalist Mexicans. And Mr. Zedillo, an economist who has suffered painful setbacks with sound economic policies that were politically unpalatable, does not seem eager to be the President who replaced Jose Maria Morelos with George Washington.

HEADLINE: Uncertain Future for a Nuclear Plant Short on Space to Store Waste

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD

DATELINE: BUCHANAN, N.Y.

 BODY:
All the fuel that the Indian Point 2 nuclear reactor has ever used since its first chain reaction 26 years ago is here at the bottom of a 40-foot-deep pool about the size of a basketball court.
Plant engineers say the pool, its water made to appear a Ty-D-Bol blue by the boron that smothers further nuclear reactions, is very safe and very clean. But it is also nearly full. Within a few years, the plant will run out of space to store the radioactive waste. 
 The future of the spent fuel and the plant itself is very much up in the air, caught in a tangle of questions about the economics of nuclear power, the deregulation of the energy industry and the environmental safety of nuclear waste disposal. And the uncertainty has left some neighbors of the plant, 35 miles north of Manhattan, deeply uneasy.
Environmentalists and others who have long opposed the plant would like nothing more than to see it shut down forever. But under one possible outcome, they could end up living next to both an operating nuclear reactor and a nuclear waste storage site. (A near-twin of the reactor, Indian Point 3, is operated by the New York Power Authority. But it is younger and has a bigger pool for spent fuel, so it faces no immediate crisis.)
The plant's owner, Consolidated Edison, says it would like to send the spent fuel more than 2,000 miles west to a proposed storage site near Salt Lake City, but that plan has run into fierce opposition in Utah. The alternative is to keep the spent fuel at the plant here, encasing it in giant sealed containers made of steel and concrete, a process known as dry-cask storage.
Further complicating the picture is the possibility that Con Ed may not be allowed to own Indian Point 2 much longer. Under state energy deregulation rules, the utility has already sold most of its non-nuclear generating plants, and it is awaiting a decision from state regulators on whether it will have to sell the reactor here, too.
If Con Ed keeps Indian Point 2, it could apply for permission to extend the plant's operating license and to build dry-storage casks for its spent nuclear fuel. That would require public hearings and approval from the state's Public Service Commission.
If a private company bought the plant, it would probably have fewer hurdles to clear to keep the reactor going. And some of Indian Point 2's neighbors, realizing that the plant could keep running for decades with even more radioactive fuel kept at the site, find this possibility extremely disturbing.
"I certainly don't think we should do on-site cask storage in order to allow it to continue to operate," said Mark Jacobs, director of the Westchester People's Action Coalition, a nonprofit group that opposes Indian Point 2. "It should be very clear if we do not know what to do with the nuclear waste, we should stop producing it."
In the salad days of nuclear power, the 1960's, the Federal Government had grand plans for the nation's spent nuclear fuel. A commercial plant, the first of several planned, was built near Buffalo to reprocess uranium and plutonium for reuse in reactors. But virgin uranium turned out to be cheaper, and President Jimmy Carter, concerned that the spent fuel could be turned into nuclear weapons, banned the process.
Then the Government promised that by 1998, it would have a place to bury the waste permanently. But now, the Energy Department is saying that site will not be ready for at least 11 years. So scores of nuclear plants around the country will soon find that they, too, have run out of room to store spent fuel.
Several plants have already put their fuel into dry-cask storage. The Nuclear Regulatory Commission routinely approves such a step, but state public utility commissions can veto cask construction if they think the expenditure is unwise.
And opponents of nuclear power have used political pressure to prevent dry-storage casks from being built at some sites, hoping that this pressure will force the plants to shut down.
But then deregulation came to the energy industry. New York and about a dozen other states are encouraging private companies to provide electricity, hoping that the competition will mean lower prices for consumers. Those states are either forcing utilities to sell their generating plants or are considering doing so. Nuclear plants are not the easiest properties to sell. But while it costs more to generate nuclear power than it does to generate electricity from water, gas or coal, a private company that can buy a reactor cheaply enough can still be competitive.
Indian Point 2 could flourish in a deregulated market, said Neil S. Carns, senior vice president for nuclear operations at Con Ed. He said he could foresee keeping the plant open 20 years beyond 2013, when its current license expires.
But to keep the plant running, Indian Point 2 needs more storage space for spent fuel.
"It's certainly a major point of vulnerability for Con Ed," said Edward A. Smeloff, executive director of the Energy Project at Pace University Law School in White Plains, "if they have no place to take the fuel and they have significant local opposition to siting a dry-storage facility."
Many experts, including Mr. Smeloff, say dry storage can be safer than storage in pools, because fuel can corrode in water and pools can leak. Mr. Smeloff was the head of the Sacramento Municipal Utility District in California when its reactor was shut down, and he supervised the construction of such casks.
Some environmentalists favor storing spent nuclear fuel on reactor sites because shipping the waste creates even more hazards, they say. And many environmentalists are opposed to an agreement Con Ed and other utilities signed with the Goshute Indians to rent storage space on their reservation west of Salt Lake City, calling it environmental racism. In any case, the Utah deal may never come to pass because of opposition from officials there.
In 1982, Con Ed signed a contract with the Energy Department, which promised to begin accepting fuel for burial by 1998 in exchange for payment of a tenth of a cent per kilowatt-hour that Indian Point generated over its lifetime. Con Ed has paid $117.5 million, but the Energy Department has not yet determined whether the site, Yucca Mountain near Las Vegas, is suitable, and now says that it will not be ready until 2010 at the earliest. Con Ed has sued to be relieved of future payments, and a resolution is pending.
Meanwhile, the fuel stays in this village of about 2,000 people on the east bank of the Hudson River. The pool has 1,374 holes for storing the spent nuclear assemblies vertically, and 917 are filled, making the grid look like a giant game of tic-tack-toe that is coming to an end. By 2005, Con Ed will have to move some of the assemblies out or close the plant.
"We have no choice but to bet on every horse in the race," said John M. Sanchez, the project manager for high-level waste at Con Ed.
Not everyone likes all the horses. "We don't want these big concrete things," said Susan Tolchin, a spokeswoman for Andrew J. Spano, the Westchester County Executive. "We want it out of there; that's the bottom line. We don't want the construction of these things to hold this nuclear waste."
It is not clear, though, what leverage the county has. Con Ed would need a permit from the village of Buchanan to build dry-storage casks, and the village has made it clear that its main concern is to keep its jobs and its tax base steady.
Westchester County would like that, too, said Martin L. Rogowski, chairman of the county's Public Utility Service Agency. But Mr. Rogowski, who formerly worked at the Energy Department on nuclear waste problems, expressed some uneasiness about the dry-storage idea. "You never know. How good are these casks?" he asked.
Edward J. Rasmussen, Con Ed's assistant controller, said building enough dry casks to make space in the pool for an additional two-year fueling cycle would cost about $3 million, an increase of about 2 percent in the plant's operating and capital expenses.
In the meantime, the fuel sits in a room certified as safe from earthquakes and hurricanes. The water is a steady 97 degrees, warmed by the radioactive decay and cooled by a whining set of pumps. A white bathtub ring has built up from the boron. Bubbles, created for the most part by air pulled in by the cooling pumps, wobble their way to the surface occasionally. The radiation levels on the walkway surrounding the pool are minuscule, the utility says.
Four times a day, a technician checks the pool for changes, but there are rarely any, said Denis Cornax, a watch engineer. Every few days, a worker checks the water chemistry to insure that there are no chlorides or other rust-inducing chemicals present.
"It's cleaner water than you have in your house," he said.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: DIPLOMACY;
White House Is Bracing For a Chinese Backlash

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
The Clinton Administration, which once hoped that stronger bonds between China and the United States would be a centerpiece of its foreign policy legacy, is now bracing for a deep deterioration in relations that may not improve before President Clinton leaves office.
From the Chinese point of view, NATO's mistaken bombing of its embassy in Belgrade summed up almost everything that China finds offensive about the United States: a raw exercise of hegemonic power by Washington and its allies, ganging up on China and its interests. 
 In American eyes, China's outrage, expressed in diplomatic demarches and in the undiplomatic marches of enraged citizens at the embassy in Beijing, has seemed overblown, even irrational.
As important as this heightened mutual mistrust, a larger casualty of the bombing could well be the Administration's idea of a "strategic partnership' with China, the notion that the two countries have shared interests in the Asia region, a number of former Clinton Administration officials and other China experts said.
Their putative partnership, which already had been called into question by Administration critics in the last six months, may indeed be turning abruptly into a regional rivalry.
Just one week after the bombing, the Administration is cautious in describing its long-term fallout.
"Too early to tell," is the phrase most used by the White House about the potential effects of the bombing on specific Administration interests, like China's membership in the World Trade Organization. On Friday, Mr. Clinton discussed this and other matters with President Jiang Zemin in a telephone call, their first conversation since the bombing.
But a White House official said that the clout of Mr. Jiang and Prime Minister Zhu Rongji -- the two leaders with whom Mr. Clinton had closest contact -- could be undermined by the internal power struggles that some people detect in Chinese politics since the bombing.
These struggles pit more modernizing leaders like Mr. Jiang and Mr. Zhu against more conservative ideologues. Because Mr. Clinton has personalized his dealings with the two leaders, their difficulties would present a major stumbling block to improving the chilled relationship.
The embassy strike came at a time of mounting quarrels between Washington and Beijing over alleged espionage by China in the last 20 years involving nuclear secrets at American laboratories, over the Administration's enthusiasm for a theater missile defense system that could involve Taiwan and over human rights.
In the next several weeks, the Congressional committee headed by Representative Christopher Cox, Republican of California, that investigated illicit technology transfers to China is expected to release its long awaited report, an event likely to worsen the already strained ties with Beijing.
"Like us, the Chinese are beginning to ask whether the strategic partnership is workable," said Robert L. Suettinger, until recently the Central Intelligence Agency's senior analyst for Asia and now a visiting fellow at the Brookings Institution. Though never clearly defined by the Administration, Mr. Suettinger said, the basic premise of the partnership was that China would have a "good relationship with the United States, build an economy and have peace in the region and the world."
Whether the United States and China move toward an "adversarial relationship" now hangs in the balance, Mr. Suettinger said.
In some respects, the China-United States relationship was proving to be like "a bad marriage, which at the core is pretty hollow," said David Shambaugh, a former member of the National Security Council and now a China expert at George Washington University.
"There is no strategic glue holding it together," he said. "There is no common agreement in Asia and I see it as a relationship of strategic competition in Asia and the world."
Among the disagreements in Asia are quarrels over Washington's strengthening of defense ties with Japan and the Administration's recent decision to approve the sale of an early warning radar system to Taiwan, the island that China considers part of its territory. The Chinese Government warned last month that the actual deployment of the radar system -- designed to detect a missile launch by China -- would have a "serious negative impact" on relations with Washington.
The theater missile defense system was originally intended to protect Japan and South Korea against the threat of missiles from North Korea. If extended to Taiwan, as some in the Administration favor, it would be designed to protect Taiwan against missiles from China.
The idea of theater missile defense for Taiwan has been described by the Chinese as another example of the United States playing the hegemonic power that wants to contain China.
American intelligence agencies, for their part, have been warning about Chinese efforts to deploy new and better nuclear missiles, perhaps with stolen American technology.
That the NATO bombing of the embassy occurred in 1999 is viewed by some Chinese as symbolic. At the end of every decade since the Communists took power in China in 1949, major events have occurred that have dictated Beijing's relationship to the rest of the world.
To name the most recent, the United States and China normalized relations in 1979 during the Carter presidency; in 1989 the West turned away from China because of the killing of civilians by the army in Tiananmen Square.
In 1999, China may turn away from the United States, China experts said.
In talks with Chinese officials since the Belgrade bombing, a former American diplomat to China, Chas. W. Freeman Jr., who has been a voice for strengthening ties, said he saw a grim outlook. Unless there is "miraculously deft handling" by the two sides, any movement on issues of importance to Washington will grind to a standstill, he said.
"I think the Chinese Government is paralyzed and can't make any gestures," Mr. Freeman said in a telephone interview from Hong Kong. "That kills human rights, nonproliferation and the World Trade Organization. It hampers cooperation on issues like North Korea." Washington has tried to persuade Beijing to get North Korea to curb the spread of nuclear technology on the Korean peninsula and to persuade Pyongyang to seek a peaceful accommodation with Seoul.
China's most immediate ire may be apparent at the United Nations, an arena that Beijing sees as its most important international platform and which it believes Washington has ignored in favor of other instruments, like NATO.
In the immediate aftermath of the embassy bombing, Administration officials suggested that China would not block efforts to resolve the Kosovo crisis at the United Nations. As anger mounted in Beijing, that confidence ebbed, and Administration officials now say it is quite likely that China may at least frustrate or delay United Nations efforts to end the Balkan war as a way of showing its rage and getting Washington pay a price for its actions against Serbia.

COUNTRY: CHINA (99%); UNITED STATES (99%); SERBIA (92%); ASIA (92%); TAIWAN (79%);

HEADLINE: Chinese Intellectuals in U.S. Say Spying Case Unfairly Casts Doubt on Their Loyalties

BYLINE: By FOX BUTTERFIELD and JOSEPH KAHN 

 BODY:
Many Chinese and Chinese-American scientists and engineers in the United States fear they are being tarnished and their careers threatened by accusations that another scientist, Wen Ho Lee, stole the design of America's most advanced nuclear warhead and gave it to China.
The accusations against Mr. Lee, a computer scientist at Los Alamos National Laboratory, may prove to be true. But Chinese intellectuals in the United States point out that Mr. Lee has not been arrested despite a three-year investigation by the F.B.I., and many are troubled by what they call the circumstantial nature of the accusations, especially the suggestion that Mr. Lee had the opportunity to divulge classified information because he traveled to scientific conferences in China. 
 That puts Chinese scientists and engineers in an awkward position, because many of them, like Mr. Lee, hold significant jobs in government, corporate or university laboratories, have relatives and friends in China, and travel there regularly to maintain contacts and participate in academic conferences.
Until recently, little of this would have provoked suspicion. But news reports of Chinese spying and attempts to buy political influence have changed the political climate, and NATO's bombing of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade and subsequent protests in Beijing have also charged the atmosphere.
"In this climate, many Chinese feel they are being watched all the time, as if they are not full citizens," said Chang-Lin Tien, the former chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley.
They have not forgotten the case of Qian Xuesen, a brilliant immigrant scientist who was accused without proof during the McCarthy era of being a Communist and held under house arrest for five years, said Dr. Tien, the first Chinese-American to head a major research university, and now a professor of mechanical engineering at Berkeley. Mr. Qian, who had helped develop the American rocket program, was finally deported to China. There, he led Beijing's missile program and became an icon in the country's quest to build a modern military.
The changed climate, Dr. Tien said, "makes many people think twice about working for the Department of Defense, the Department of Energy or national labs."
"We can't tolerate spies. But we need to be sensitive and careful. Mistakenly blaming the whole community for one person's action cannot be tolerated."
Xenophobia was the topic this month at a meeting of prominent Chinese-Americans and Energy Secretary Bill Richardson, whose department supervises America's nuclear research laboratories. The meeting, at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel in New York, drew a mixed crowd of Asian-Americans, including natives of the Chinese mainland, people who were born in Taiwan and Hong Kong and even Japanese-Americans.
Raymond Ng, a Chinese-American engineer at the Sandia National Laboratories in Livermore, Calif., told Mr. Richardson that Americans who trace their roots to any part of Asia, from India to Japan, were under suspicion in their workplaces.
"Because of the incident at Los Alamos," Mr. Ng said, "promotions are being held back, we are concerned about discrimination in hiring and a cloud of suspicion appears to hang over all Asian Pacific Americans as a group."
Mr. Richardson told the group that he would not allow racial discrimination at the nuclear laboratories, but he acknowledged an atmosphere of distrust.
"I understand that Asian Pacific Americans are concerned that their loyalty and patriotism are being challenged," he said, adding, "I want to assure you that racial profiling will not be permitted."
To some extent, the suspicions of spying and political influence-buying by Chinese "are a hangover from history," said Stanley Karnow, the Pulitzer Prize-winning author who is writing a book on the Asian experience in America. The Chinese Exclusion Act of 1882, barring Chinese immigration, was the only law in American history that singled out a nationality, Mr. Karnow said. "We've always had this lingering suspicion of sinister Chinese skulking about," he said.
But the accusations of espionage at Los Alamos also raise uncomfortable questions about divided loyalty for some Chinese in the United States.
"Frankly, when I bring it up in class, I can see my Chinese students squirm, especially those from the mainland," said Merle Goldman, a professor of history at Boston University and an expert on Chinese intellectuals.
"Loyalty is a big dilemma for Chinese intellectuals," Professor Goldman said. "They want to do everything to help their country regain its greatness, and part of that involves making China a great economic and military power."
Other experts caution that the overwhelming majority of the 2.5 million Chinese in the United States are patriotic Americans.
"One always has divided loyalties in a way, because you want your native country to thrive, but I don't sense that I have divided loyalties at all, because my loyalties are for the people, the language and the art, things that don't come in conflict with my new home in America," said Betty Bao Lord, the author of the best seller, "Spring Moon," and wife of the former ambassador to China, Winston Lord.
This division of loyalties fits a traditional distinction made by Chinese scholars in past centuries, a difference between loyalty to China, a kind of cultural loyalty, and loyalty to the dynasty, or political loyalty, said Weiming Tu, a professor of Chinese history and philosophy at Harvard University and director of the Harvard-Yenching Institute.
The complex emotions of many Chinese-Americans were on display at a banquet in Los Angeles for China's Prime Minister, Zhu Rongji, during his April visit to the United States. Many of the 1,500 Chinese-Americans there wore Chinese outfits like silk gowns or the slit dress known as a qipao. Most speeches were in Mandarin, with little translation. Musicians played the Chinese national anthem. The two masters of ceremonies referred to Mr. Zhu as "our premier."
Such expressions of support for China do not strike Chinese-Americans as disloyal. Many at the banquet complained about the accusations of spying against Mr. Lee, saying that news reports tended to tar Chinese scientists in sensitive positions with the same brush.
Collin L. Lai, a retired aerospace engineer who was among the guests, said he was furious about news reports on the Lee case.
In some aerospace companies, "the unofficial language is Mandarin," Mr. Lai said, adding, "What are you going to do, throw us all out?"
In fact, many university physics departments are dependent on graduate students from China. Over all, students from mainland China account for 21 percent of foreign graduate students in physics departments, and this year foreign students make up half of all physics graduate students, said Roman Czujko of the American Institute of Physics.
A scientist from mainland China who works for the Xerox Corporation in Syracuse said that the espionage accusations had made him and his wife rethink their view of America.
"When we came here 10 years ago," he said, "we thought about staying here forever. After this incident, you really think that maybe this is not your homeland. If people don't like you here, why stay?"
The scientist said he was particularly outraged at the way some news reports described the Los Alamos accusations as "Chinese espionage," lumping together the Communist Government in Beijing and all Chinese everywhere, whatever their background, with little hard evidence.
Mr. Lee, the computer expert at Los Alamos, was born on Taiwan, where most residents are opposed to the Communist Government of mainland China.
To further complicate the situation, China does spy on the United States, just as the United States spies on China, and some spies for China have been caught and convicted.
In 1997, Peter H. Lee, a naturalized citizen from Taiwan who worked at Los Alamos, pleaded guilty to orally passing classified nuclear weapons information to Chinese scientists during a conference in Beijing, a set of facts much like the current accusations against Wen Ho Lee.
And China painstakingly trains spies for missions in the United States, according to a book to be published this year by Larry Engelman and his wife, Meihong Xu, a former lieutenant in intelligence in the Chinese Army. In the book, "Daughter of China: A True Story of Love and Betrayal," (John Wiley & Sons), Ms. Xu describes how she and other attractive young women were selected to be sent abroad, adopt new identities, get jobs, marry and then years later surface as spies for China.
Another factor that contributes to misunderstanding, Chinese say, is the inability of the American public, politicians and the news media to distinguish among different groups of Chinese in the United States.
The first immigrants from China were poor peasants who came in the 1850's to work in the gold mines or build the transcontinental railroads. Better-educated Chinese came as students in the 1930's, or as refugees from the Communists in the 1940's.
Until President Lyndon B. Johnson changed the immigration law in 1965, the total number of Chinese in the United States remained small, about a quarter of a million, according to the Census Bureau. But since then there has been an explosion of immigration -- graduate students from Taiwan, intellectuals from the mainland and working-class people from southern China, near Hong Kong -- so that the total is now about 2.5 million, the Population Reference Bureau says.
Professor Tien and others are concerned that Washington and the news media have been too quick to conclude that all of these people are subject to pressure from the Communist Government in Beijing, just because they are ethnically Chinese.
In both the campaign finance scandal, involving John Huang and Johnny Chung, and the Wen Ho Lee spy case, Professor Tien said, Americans have made the assumption that these individual Chinese were part of a plot orchestrated by top authorities in Beijing, despite a lack of hard evidence.
But Professor Tien also sees some progress.
"I came to the United States as a poor, penniless student, and I made it to become chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley," he said. "There has been tremendous improvement in civil rights in America. So we should be careful not to draw too sweeping a conclusion from those incidents."

HEADLINE: Station Has a Blueprint, but Still Needs Money

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
Thirty-six years after New York City tore down the original Pennsylvania Station in an act so widely condemned that it spawned a campaign for historic preservation, President Clinton in a visit to Manhattan on Wednesday is to inaugurate the renovation of the old station's surviving sister, the General Post Office on Eighth Avenue, into a new railroad terminal.
Mr. Clinton's visit promises to provide political momentum to a project that has been planned and debated for six years and still lacks the final commitment of Government funds to cover its expected budget of $484 million, say officials involved in the project. 
 Although a White House spokeswoman, Julie Goldberg, said Mr. Clinton's visit was intended simply to "inaugurate the project," Federal officials said it was envisioned as a way to draw public attention to the architectural work that is now proposed, and to encourage Congress to approve the project.
"We have a terrific design and we thought it was time to show the world what is being planned," said Tony Bullock, the chief of staff to Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, who has been the leading proponent of the project in Congress.
Another Federal official who has been at the center of planning for the project, Robert Peck, the Commissioner of the Public Buildings Service, a branch of the General Services Administration, said that discussions in recent weeks had "put us in striking distance" of fully financing the project.
The original Penn Station was widely regarded as one of the city's best early 20th-century examples of neo-classical design before it was demolished to make way for Madison Square Garden, but the railroad station now being planned would be anchored by a distinctly modern addition of glass and steel girders.
Several involved in the project, including its principal architect, David M. Childs of the firm Skidmore, Owings & Merrill, said the design might surprise those who envision something closer to the ornate grandeur of the original Penn Station. But they said the demands of modern technology and huge crowds dictated a different approach.
"Someone who likes true classicism and takes the attitude of 'don't touch anything' is likely to be on the other side of the table from us," Mr. Childs said. But he added that his design would "honor the relationship between the modern and the classic."
Philip K. Howard, the chairman of the Municipal Art Society, an organization that has championed historic preservation in the three decades that followed the demolition of Pennsylvania Station, said he had reviewed the new design and fully supported it.
"Our principal concern has been to make a train station at a scale that would accommodate millions of visitors and tourists, and you can do that with modern design as well as classical design," he said.
To date, Mr. Moynihan has led a campaign that focused largely on reaching an agreement for shared use of the General Post Office, formally known as the James A. Farley Building, by the Postal Service and the proposed rail terminal.
Under agreements mediated in recent months by Mr. Peck, the Postal Service has agreed to vacate roughly a third of its space in the vast structure of 1.4 million square feet by the time construction begins. Mr. Peck said the Postal Service had also agreed to vacate the entire structure at an unspecified point in the future.
But the arrangement of shared space resulted from years of hard-fought negotiations in which some proponents of a new Penn Station had maintained that the postal operations should simply be moved out, and the Postal Service fought tenaciously to stay in what is one of the nation's largest and most historically distinguished postal buildings.
"The Post Office deserves a lot of credit at this point," said Charles A. Gargano, the senior economic adviser to Gov. George E. Pataki and chairman of the Pennsylvania Station Redevelopment Corporation, an agency established in 1996 with commitments of $75 million from the state and $25 million from the city.
From its inception, the project has depended on far greater commitments of Federal funds, particularly because its anticipated costs have risen. The current estimate of $484 million, provided by Mr. Gargano, is far higher than estimates a year ago that it would cost less than $350 million, and officials say the construction taking place elsewhere in New York City is likely to increase the cost more by creating a shortage of workers and material.
So far, commitments from Congress, the Department of Transportation and other Federal agencies have added $250 million to the amount available, but such aid remains contingent on Congressional votes in the future.
One fear, according to people involved in the project, is that members of Congress will reverse themselves and divert money from the project now that Alfonse M. D'Amato is no longer in the Senate after many years as a powerful voice on the Senate Appropriations Committee.
And even if no money is diverted, Mr. Gargano said, the project is still $134 million short of the present cost estimate. In any case, he said, the development agency he heads plans to adhere to a schedule of breaking ground in 2000 and completing the project in 2003.

HEADLINE: In the Wealthy Silicon Valley, a United Way Runs Dry

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
In what may be a leading indicator of how traditional social welfare agencies are struggling even as technology yields new riches, the United Way of Santa Clara County, in Silicon Valley, collapsed this month as donations slipped, a reserve fund once brimming with $11 million went dry, and on May 1 the agency ran out of money.
Donations to the Santa Clara United Way, the 30th largest in the nation, are expected to total $20 million in the current campaign, down 40 percent from the $32.6 million, adjusted for inflation, that the organization raised nine years ago. 
 The social services agencies it supports have faced even bigger cuts in the 1990's than these figures suggest, however, because the proportion of United Way money that donors designate to organizations other than social services agencies has been rising rapidly and now approaches half the total raised, said Michael E. Fox Sr., a San Jose beer distributor who is the United Way chairman in Santa Clara.
While Internet millionaires in Silicon Valley have drawn attention for multimillion-dollar gifts to higher education and major arts organizations, social services charities there say they struggle with flat or shrinking support and are often spurned by high-tech companies who see no link between their business interests and social services.
Congress has slashed financing for social services charities by 25 percent since 1996, according to a study sponsored by the Nathan Cummings Foundation in New York. Donations to social services charities have slipped about 6 percent since 1990, two other studies show.
To help the 100 agencies in Santa Clara County whose financing was abruptly cut by the United Way collapse, Community Foundation Silicon Valley, a charitable endowment, has created a fund.
The first contributor, Steve Kirsch, the founder of Infoseek, put up $1 million on Wednesday and announced that he had asked a Who's Who of Silicon Valley billionaires and wealthy executives to match his gift. As of yesterday, only Ebay, the Internet auction company, had announced that it would match Mr. Kirsch's gift.
Eleanor Jacobs, the president of the United Way until she was fired on May 6, said that in her four years in San Jose, she approached many high-tech companies only to be told that the social services needs of the county were not important.
"The Silicon Valley way of life is one of the best in the country," Mrs. Jacobs said, "but I don't know that there is a grasp on the part of residents that there are people who need basic social services -- shelters for battered wives, mental health services. I dealt with a number of companies whose officials said, 'Our employees make this much money and they do not need these services, so why are you here?' "
Mrs. Jacobs said she also tried to meet with 12 wealthy Silicon Valley residents about supporting United Way, but 8 of them would not even give her an appointment.
Jennifer Tait, executive director of Friends Outside, which depended on United Way for 20 percent of the money it spends on counseling, job referrals and other help to families who have relatives in jail, said she had encountered similar responses. But Mrs. Tait said the fault may lie with the charities themselves.
"Perhaps in this valley," Mrs. Tait said, "we have done a poor job of educating the public" about how social ills spread when there are no services available.
United Way of America officials sought to portray Silicon Valley as an anomaly. Giving to United Way in other high-tech centers is rising. The officials cited the Research Triangle area of North Carolina, with the biggest growth, up threefold since 1984. And King County, Wash., and the high-tech community around Seattle -- which has about the same population as Santa Clara County -- raised $68.5 million in the current campaign, more than three times the amount raised in Santa Clara.
The level of giving in King County "disproves the claim that young people in high-tech industries will not give for social services," said Peter Hero, president of Community Foundation Silicon Valley, which has a $240 million endowment.
King County relies heavily for support on workers at Boeing and Costco and on support drummed up by the chairman of Microsoft, William H. Gates 3d, whose parents were long active in United Way.
Betty Beene, president of United Way of America, which represents 1,300 local United Ways, said the collapse in San Jose "is about a director with a good heart who made overly optimistic projections about pledges and who was trying to deal with a very high level of designations," in which donors directed which charities received their gifts.
After Mrs. Jacobs was hired in 1995, she expanded the Santa Clara United Way staff to 77 from 52 even though donations were flat. Last fall, the board approved her request for a $1 million line of credit without inquiring about the state of the organization's finances, said Mr. Fox, who holds the volunteer position of Santa Clara United Way board chairman.
In February, Mrs. Jacobs laid off 32 staff members, but the board was not aware that she had paid each dismissed employee a month's pay for each year on the payroll, at a total cost of $1 million.
Mr. Fox, who is also on 34 other charity and civic boards, said he had learned last week that $3 million of pledges from businesses were made orally and are now worthless.
Mrs. Jacobs said written letters were never sent to confirm the pledges and no event was held to introduce these businesses to United Way. She said that when the flow of donations fell, she did not call in the member agencies to tell them they would have to take less "because I did not want to anger them and upset them. I guess, with what happened, it would have been better if I did."
Margie Diaz Kintz, an Intel Foundation director, and Joseph Valentine, former president of the San Francisco United Way, will temporarily run the Santa Clara County United Way and try to keep it out of bankruptcy proceedings, United Way officials said.

HEADLINE: CRISIS IN THE BALKANS: CHINA;
Embassy Blast Churns Political Tea Leaves

BYLINE: By SETH FAISON

DATELINE: SHANGHAI, May 15

 BODY:
Why did Zhu Rongji, China's popular Prime Minister, cry on TV?
At the end of a tumultuous week when student-led protests and Government-run media dovetailed in a remarkable show of nationalist frenzy, one of the main questions haunting Politburo-watchers in China is why Mr. Zhu shed tears when he and other leaders appeared at memorial services for three Chinese killed in the accidental bombing by NATO of the Chinese Embassy in Belgrade. 
 Beyond the first reason, that even a politician as hard-boiled as Mr. Zhu was genuinely overcome by emotion for the tragic deaths of three fellow citizens, Chinese analysts and journalists say that politics also helped darken Mr. Zhu's demeanor. The political stakes in China's current outburst of nationalism are high, and the overriding question of the day is: Has Mr. Zhu been hurt?
Mr. Zhu, seen by many ordinary Chinese as the best hope for combating corruption and transforming the moribund state sector of the economy, is suddenly vulnerable to accusations by rivals that he is too soft on the United States, the country Chinese seem both to love and to hate.
Fresh from his trip to Washington in April, when he made broad concessions on trade issues but failed to win China's entry to the World Trade Organization, Mr. Zhu is being accused of humiliating his country by selling out its interests and getting nothing in return, particularly by officials threatened by Mr. Zhu's reforms.
Now that China's extensive political machinery is issuing spirited nationalist edicts and speeches to be studied and recited by local officials in every province of China, Mr. Zhu's reform program appears certain to be slowed. Even if Mr. Zhu's political standing is not seriously diminished by attacks from opponents, he will doubtless have to delay or soften his more aggressive reforms.
For political scorekeepers who scour the official media for clues to the power struggle that inevitably intensifies during a political crisis, even though it remains hidden, the main event this week was state television's news broadcast on Wednesday evening.
It showed little besides a formal mourning routine by six of China's top leaders at ceremonies for the three Chinese who were killed, recorded in minute detail. Yet in China, even a simple event may offer hints whose political implications are debated by viewers for days afterward.
On Wednesday's broadcast, starting with President Jiang Zemin, each leader performed the same solemn triple bow before photographs of the dead, and then moved slowly down a receiving line of relatives, shaking hands and giving condolences.
The broadcast was clearly intended to convey the leadership's sympathy for the victims of the bombing, since leaders are sensitive to accusations, from students and military officers and conservative politicians, that the official response to the bombing has been too weak.
Mr. Jiang, whose nickname among Chinese journalists is the Actor because of his attempts to stage his appearance at news events, looked saddened and solemn as he shook hands with the grieving families.
Next in line was Li Peng, chairman of China's legislature, who is deeply unpopular for presiding over the crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in 1989. Mr. Li appeared to avoid looking at the people with whom he shook hands, achieving less than the desired effect.
Then came Mr. Zhu. He looked each relative in the eye, in silence. His distressed expression said it all: This is unspeakably sad, and I feel your pain. By the time he reached the end of the line, Mr. Zhu was crying and looked genuinely moved. It was a virtuoso performance, several Chinese journalists said.
"Zhu is already the most popular leader among common people," said a magazine editor in Beijing who watched the broadcast. "In a crisis, everyone looks to see how the leadership acts. Zhu did best, in that one moment."
Yet Mr. Zhu's tears also meant something more, the editor said.
"His expression said, 'This is a terrible thing for China,' " the editor explained. "Not just the families, not just China's image, but also the whole economic reform process, which could be affected."
Other close observers of the week's events debated whether Mr. Zhu's tears were a warning to sophisticated viewers, or an appeal for support from fellow Communist Party members, or something else.
"If he were seriously under attack, he would not appear on television at all," said an official at a state-run company who follows politics closely. "I think he was trying to look humble."
The official pointed to another clue, which came on the following day's television broadcast, where China's leaders were shown going to the hospital to visit several Chinese diplomats who were wounded in the bombing of the embassy in Belgrade, and have returned to Beijing.
Rather than show each of the top leaders comforting separate wounded people, as such broadcasts often do, Mr. Jiang and Mr. Li and Mr. Zhu and three other top leaders trooped into each hospital room together. It involved awkward camera work to get them all on screen at the same time, but the effort was made.
"There's only one reason to show them all together, rather than separately," the official said. "The message is that they are united. Whether or not it is true, that is the message."
Almost exactly 10 years ago, China's leading political reformer and Communist Party chief at the time, Zhao Ziyang, made a tearful appearance on national television as he visited hunger-striking student demonstrators in Tiananmen Square just two weeks before the violent crackdown.
It was the last time Mr. Zhao was seen in public. He has been under house arrest ever since.
Mr. Zhu does not seem to be in any imminent danger of dismissal. China's media, by the end of the week, were reporting the activities of Mr. Jiang, Mr. Li and Mr. Zhu in that order, in keeping with their ranking in the Communist Party hierarchy.
Another Chinese journalist pointed out that many people took note when Mr. Zhu said just before going to the United States last month that he actually did not want to go, but that Mr. Jiang had specifically insisted that he do so.
Chinese leaders take few important decisions unilaterally, the journalist said, so Mr. Zhu's statement, though it sounded simple, indicated that it was a collective decision of the leadership that he should go ahead with his trip, implying that a collective responsibility must be borne if things did not go well.
In the 14 months since he was appointed Prime Minister, Mr. Zhu has won loyal admirers and bitter enemies by taking bold steps to kill off unproductive sectors of China's economy.
The sweeping concessions he offered in Washington during his visit there last month were specifically aimed at winning entry to the World Trade Organization, but more generally aimed at forcing open change-resistant parts of China's telecommunications, banking and financial services industries.
Mr. Zhu is also said to be resented by some of his top colleagues, with less talent for public speaking, because he is so appealing, direct and humorous in public.
Yet one of Mr. Zhu's enduring political weaknesses, Chinese analysts say, is that he is so popular among Western businessmen and officials, who appreciate his direct manner. At a time of strong anti-American sentiment, that vulnerability can only become more pronounced.
